Sky"},"video":[],"structured":false}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":1212,"name":"energy","slug":"energy","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":911,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":472,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":204777755,"name":"Politics","slug":"politics","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":17,"taxonomy":"time_section","description":"Political insight from the Beltway and beyond. Covering the White House, elections, primaries, Congress, domestic policy, foreign policy, the military and more","parent":0,"count":11779,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["politics","us"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4677394,"date":"2017-02-24T12:15:02","date_gmt":"2017-02-24T17:15:02","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4677394"},"modified":"2017-02-24T12:25:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-24T17:25:00","slug":"donald-trump-opioid-epidemic-and-rising-drug-costs","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4677394\u002Fdonald-trump-opioid-epidemic-and-rising-drug-costs\u002F","title":{"rendered":"President Trump Vowed to Solve the Opioid Crisis. He Needs to Fix This Problem First"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EDuring a freewheeling \u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Erecent \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4673878\u002Ftrump-drugs-cheaper-than-candy\u002F\"\u003Epress conference\u003C\u002Fa\u003E,\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E President Trump declared that America was &ldquo;drug-infested&rdquo; country. &ldquo;Drugs,&rdquo; Trump said, &ldquo;are becoming cheaper than candy bars.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhat the President failed to mention: the price of one lifesaving medication&mdash;naloxone&mdash;is more expensive than caviar.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"video-container\"\u003E\u003Cvideo id=\"brightcove-player-5325977864001\" data-video-id=\"5325977864001\" data-account=\"293884104\" data-player=\"SJa0Thl7\" data-embed=\"default\" autoplay controls preload=\"auto\" class=\"video-js responsive-video\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fvideo\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThroughout the 2016 presidential campaign, \u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E Trump promised to solve America&rsquo;s opioid crisis, which claimed 33,000 lives in 2015&mdash;the most deaths in a single year in U.S. history, according to \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cdc.gov\u002Fdrugoverdose\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Erecent federal statistics\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E. Trump&#8217;s \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.donaldjtrump.com\u002Fpress-releases\u002Fdonald-j.-trump-addresses-the-drug-epidemic-in-the-united-states\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eplan\u003C\u002Fa\u003E to combat the epidemic included widespread access to naloxone, a drug that can reverse the effects of an opioid overdose. But as the need for the drug has grown, it has become increasingly expensive and hard to get for many addicts and the front line workers who try to help them. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E &#8220;All the politicians, Obama, Trump, everyone says, &#8216;We&#8217;re going to solve it&#8217;,&#8221; says Gordon Merry, director of West Virginia&#8217;s Cabell County EMS, which serves Huntington, a city that saw 26 opioid overdoses over four hours last August. &#8220;I haven&#8217;t seen anything that has changed.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003EMeanwhile, the price of naloxone is soaring. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003EEvzio, a form of naloxone manufactured by Kal&eacute;o that&#8217;s administered through auto-injection, rose from $575 per package in 2014 to a whopping $4,100 in 2016. Another version of the drug, made by Hospira, has risen from \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s2\"\u003Efrom $9.20 for 10 vials in in 2005 to $158.30 in 2014, according to Truven Health Analytics. The price of the naloxone nasal spray Narcan has remained stable&mdash;around $125 for a two-pack&mdash;since it was approved by the FDA in 2015.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E&#8220;The best word for what&#8217;s happening now,&#8221; says Paul Ginsburg, director of the Center for Health Policy at the Brookings Institution, &#8220;is profiteering.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENaloxone price hikes parallel a spike in demand for the drug that&#8217;s fueled by the opioid epidemic, stretching government budgets&mdash;the drug is often administered by first responders&mdash;while creating a robust market for the drug.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003EIn late November, \u003Cspan class=\"s2\"\u003EDr. Leana Wen, Baltimore City&#8217;s Health Commissioner\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E, and 10 other health officials \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fhealth.baltimorecity.gov\u002Fnews\u002Ftestimony\u002F2016-11-29-frontline-health-leaders-urge-presidential-transition-team-invest-public\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s3\"\u003Ewrote a letter to President Trump\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E asking the new administration to prioritize public health, specifically solutions to the opioid epidemic. &ldquo;In the campaign, President Trump talked about the problems of drug addiction,&rdquo; says Wen. &ldquo;We hope that this will not just be rhetoric but resources will be devoted to this issue too.&rdquo; \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003ESo far Wen and her colleagues haven&rsquo;t received a response.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EExperts attribute the rising naloxone prices\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E to a combination of soaring need, drug-industry consolidation and an onerous FDA-approval process, which can stifle competition. Critics contend that price gouging may also be at play. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003EKal&eacute;o CEO Spencer Williamson says Evzio&#8217;s list price of $4,100 &#8220;is not a true net price to anyone&hellip;due to numerous discounts and rebates that are negotiated in the supply chain.&#8221; Most patients with insurance pay nothing out of pocket, says Williamson, while uninsured patients with household incomes of less than $100,000 can also access Evzio free of charge. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003EKal&eacute;o says it also offers product grants to some nonprofits and government agencies that demonstrate a need for the drug. For instance, \u003C\u002Fspan\u003EKal&eacute;o has granted 2,200 kits to the Cabell-Huntington Health Department, where the overdose death rate is nearly 10 times the national average. &#8220;The more naloxone there is, the more lives will be saved,&#8221; says Dr. Michael Kilkenny, physician director of the Cabell-Huntington Health Department. &#8220;I have to admit, if we didn&#8217;t get the grant, we wouldn&#8217;t have the drug. We don&#8217;t have the finances.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EYet even beneficiaries of naloxone grants acknowledge that demand outstrips affordable supply. \u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003EIn Palm Beach County, Fla., for instance, the Fire and Rescue department spent nearly $205,400 on naloxone in 2016, compared with $57,500 in 2015. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003EIn Baltimore, first responders are facing similar constraints. &ldquo;We have to decide who is the most likely to die and make a guess on which patients we distribute naloxone to,&rdquo; says \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s2\"\u003EWen, the health commissioner, adding that the \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003Eprice they pay for naloxone more than doubled over the course of just a few years.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s2\"\u003E &#8220;It doesn&rsquo;t make sense that at a time of great demand this medication is being priced out of our reach.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn Newtown, Ohio, police chief Tom Synan says the opioid epidemic in his community is worsening. The county averages up to 70 overdoses a week. &ldquo;That&rsquo;s our new normal,&rdquo; he says. Synan, who serves on the Hamilton County Heroin Coalition steering committee, says his officers use the naloxone nasal spray Narcan, and the department has not been hit with major cost increases. But the overall trend is disconcerting. &ldquo;These are life and death situations,&#8221; says Synan.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EIf his earlier promises hold true, Trump will eventually\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E train his lens on drug companies&mdash;and drug prices. A White House spokesperson says\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003E the administration is extending grant programs to help get naloxone in the hands of first responders, has encouraged Medicaid programs to include naloxone access for low-income people, and has made sure Veterans Affairs programs offer naloxone for eligible veterans. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EStill, some say more drastic action will be necessary. Ohio has already taken action: in November the state reached an agreement with Adapt Pharma, the manufacturer of Narcan, to freeze the price of the naloxone nasal spray for Ohio law enforcement, first responders, state and local government agencies, and community-based organizations for a year. These entities can buy 48 or more Narcan units for $75 each, a 40% discount from the $125 wholesale price.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;It&#8217;s hard to justify the price increases you see on purely economic grounds,&#8221; says Darius Lakdawalla, an economist and professor of pharmaceutical development and regulatory innovation at the University of Southern California. &#8220;The case is pretty strong for government interference.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EEspecially when lives are at stake. Laurie Fugitt, co-founder of Georgia Overdose Prevention, a volunteer group, hopscotches across the state teaching people how to administer naloxone to themselves or their loved ones. She equates naloxone to a fire extinguisher. You never want anyone to use it. But it should be there just in case.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;A lot of people have no idea that there&#8217;s even an antidote for an opioid overdose,&#8221; says Fugitt. &#8220;Back in the day, a vial of naloxone cost a couple of bucks. Now, everybody is trying to get their piece of the pie.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003EWith reporting by Zeke J. Miller\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["During a freewheeling  recent ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4673878\u002Ftrump-drugs-cheaper-than-candy\u002F"},"content":["press conference"]},",  President Trump declared that America was “drug-infested” country. “Drugs,” Trump said, “are becoming cheaper than candy bars.”"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["What the President failed to mention: the price of one lifesaving medication—naloxone—is more expensive than caviar."]},{"tag":"video","attributes":{"autoplay":"1","controls":"1","videoid":"5325977864001"},"content":[]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Throughout the 2016 presidential campaign,   Trump promised to solve America’s opioid crisis, which claimed 33,000 lives in 2015—the most deaths in a single year in U.S. history, according to ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cdc.gov\u002Fdrugoverdose\u002F"},"content":["recent federal statistics"]},". Trump's ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.donaldjtrump.com\u002Fpress-releases\u002Fdonald-j.-trump-addresses-the-drug-epidemic-in-the-united-states"},"content":["plan"]}," to combat the epidemic included widespread access to naloxone, a drug that can reverse the effects of an opioid overdose. But as the need for the drug has grown, it has become increasingly expensive and hard to get for many addicts and the front line workers who try to help them. "]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[" \"All the politicians, Obama, Trump, everyone says, 'We're going to solve it',\" says Gordon Merry, director of West Virginia's Cabell County EMS, which serves Huntington, a city that saw 26 opioid overdoses over four hours last August. \"I haven't seen anything that has changed.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Meanwhile, the price of naloxone is soaring.  Evzio, a form of naloxone manufactured by Kaléo that's administered through auto-injection, rose from $575 per package in 2014 to a whopping $4,100 in 2016. Another version of the drug, made by Hospira, has risen from  from $9.20 for 10 vials in in 2005 to $158.30 in 2014, according to Truven Health Analytics. The price of the naloxone nasal spray Narcan has remained stable—around $125 for a two-pack—since it was approved by the FDA in 2015."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"The best word for what's happening now,\" says Paul Ginsburg, director of the Center for Health Policy at the Brookings Institution, \"is profiteering.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Naloxone price hikes parallel a spike in demand for the drug that's fueled by the opioid epidemic, stretching government budgets—the drug is often administered by first responders—while creating a robust market for the drug."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In late November,  Dr. Leana Wen, Baltimore City's Health Commissioner , and 10 other health officials ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fhealth.baltimorecity.gov\u002Fnews\u002Ftestimony\u002F2016-11-29-frontline-health-leaders-urge-presidential-transition-team-invest-public"},"content":["wrote a letter to President Trump"]}," asking the new administration to prioritize public health, specifically solutions to the opioid epidemic. “In the campaign, President Trump talked about the problems of drug addiction,” says Wen. “We hope that this will not just be rhetoric but resources will be devoted to this issue too.”  So far Wen and her colleagues haven’t received a response."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["Experts attribute the rising naloxone prices"]}," to a combination of soaring need, drug-industry consolidation and an onerous FDA-approval process, which can stifle competition. Critics contend that price gouging may also be at play. "]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Kaléo CEO Spencer Williamson says Evzio's list price of $4,100 \"is not a true net price to anyone…due to numerous discounts and rebates that are negotiated in the supply chain.\" Most patients with insurance pay nothing out of pocket, says Williamson, while uninsured patients with household incomes of less than $100,000 can also access Evzio free of charge. "]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Kaléo says it also offers product grants to some nonprofits and government agencies that demonstrate a need for the drug. For instance,  Kaléo has granted 2,200 kits to the Cabell-Huntington Health Department, where the overdose death rate is nearly 10 times the national average. \"The more naloxone there is, the more lives will be saved,\" says Dr. Michael Kilkenny, physician director of the Cabell-Huntington Health Department. \"I have to admit, if we didn't get the grant, we wouldn't have the drug. We don't have the finances.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Yet even beneficiaries of naloxone grants acknowledge that demand outstrips affordable supply.  In Palm Beach County, Fla., for instance, the Fire and Rescue department spent nearly $205,400 on naloxone in 2016, compared with $57,500 in 2015. "]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In Baltimore, first responders are facing similar constraints. “We have to decide who is the most likely to die and make a guess on which patients we distribute naloxone to,” says  Wen, the health commissioner, adding that the  price they pay for naloxone more than doubled over the course of just a few years.  \"It doesn’t make sense that at a time of great demand this medication is being priced out of our reach.”"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In Newtown, Ohio, police chief Tom Synan says the opioid epidemic in his community is worsening. The county averages up to 70 overdoses a week. “That’s our new normal,” he says. Synan, who serves on the Hamilton County Heroin Coalition steering committee, says his officers use the naloxone nasal spray Narcan, and the department has not been hit with major cost increases. But the overall trend is disconcerting. “These are life and death situations,\" says Synan."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["If his earlier promises hold true, Trump will eventually"]}," train his lens on drug companies—and drug prices. A White House spokesperson says  the administration is extending grant programs to help get naloxone in the hands of first responders, has encouraged Medicaid programs to include naloxone access for low-income people, and has made sure Veterans Affairs programs offer naloxone for eligible veterans. "]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Still, some say more drastic action will be necessary. Ohio has already taken action: in November the state reached an agreement with Adapt Pharma, the manufacturer of Narcan, to freeze the price of the naloxone nasal spray for Ohio law enforcement, first responders, state and local government agencies, and community-based organizations for a year. These entities can buy 48 or more Narcan units for $75 each, a 40% discount from the $125 wholesale price."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"It's hard to justify the price increases you see on purely economic grounds,\" says Darius Lakdawalla, an economist and professor of pharmaceutical development and regulatory innovation at the University of Southern California. \"The case is pretty strong for government interference.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Especially when lives are at stake. Laurie Fugitt, co-founder of Georgia Overdose Prevention, a volunteer group, hopscotches across the state teaching people how to administer naloxone to themselves or their loved ones. She equates naloxone to a fire extinguisher. You never want anyone to use it. But it should be there just in case."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"A lot of people have no idea that there's even an antidote for an opioid overdose,\" says Fugitt. \"Back in the day, a vial of naloxone cost a couple of bucks. Now, everybody is trying to get their piece of the pie.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["With reporting by Zeke J. Miller"]}]}],"plain":"During a freewheeling recent press conference, President Trump declared that America was &ldquo;drug-infested&rdquo; country. &ldquo;Drugs,&rdquo; Trump said, &ldquo;are becoming cheaper than candy bars.&rdquo; What the President failed to mention: the price of one lifesaving medication&mdash;naloxone&mdash;is more expensive than caviar. Throughout the 2016 presidential campaign, Trump promised to solve America&rsquo;s opioid crisis, which claimed 33,000 lives in 2015&mdash;the most deaths in a single year in U.S. history, according to recent federal statistics. Trump&#8217;s plan to combat the epidemic included widespread access to naloxone, a drug that can reverse the effects of an opioid overdose. But as the need for the drug has grown, it has become increasingly expensive and hard to get for many addicts and the front line workers who try to help them. &#8220;All the politicians, Obama, Trump, everyone says, &#8216;We&#8217;re going to solve it&#8217;,&#8221; says Gordon Merry, director of West Virginia&#8217;s Cabell County EMS, which serves Huntington, a city that saw 26 opioid overdoses over four hours last August. &#8220;I haven&#8217;t seen anything that has changed.&#8221; Meanwhile, the price of naloxone is soaring. Evzio, a form of naloxone manufactured by Kal&eacute;o that&#8217;s administered through auto-injection, rose from $575 per package in 2014 to a whopping $4,100 in 2016. Another version of the drug, made by Hospira, has risen from from $9.20 for 10 vials in in 2005 to $158.30 in 2014, according to Truven Health Analytics. The price of the naloxone nasal spray Narcan has remained stable&mdash;around $125 for a two-pack&mdash;since it was approved by the FDA in 2015. &#8220;The best word for what&#8217;s happening now,&#8221; says Paul Ginsburg, director of the Center for Health Policy at the Brookings Institution, &#8220;is profiteering.&#8221; Naloxone price hikes parallel a spike in demand for the drug that&#8217;s fueled by the opioid epidemic, stretching government budgets&mdash;the drug is often administered by first responders&mdash;while creating a robust market for the drug. In late November, Dr. Leana Wen, Baltimore City&#8217;s Health Commissioner, and 10 other health officials wrote a letter to President Trump asking the new administration to prioritize public health, specifically solutions to the opioid epidemic. &ldquo;In the campaign, President Trump talked about the problems of drug addiction,&rdquo; says Wen. &ldquo;We hope that this will not just be rhetoric but resources will be devoted to this issue too.&rdquo; So far Wen and her colleagues haven&rsquo;t received a response. Experts attribute the rising naloxone prices to a combination of soaring need, drug-industry consolidation and an onerous FDA-approval process, which can stifle competition. Critics contend that price gouging may also be at play. Kal&eacute;o CEO Spencer Williamson says Evzio&#8217;s list price of $4,100 &#8220;is not a true net price to anyone&hellip;due to numerous discounts and rebates that are negotiated in the supply chain.&#8221; Most patients with insurance pay nothing out of pocket, says Williamson, while uninsured patients with household incomes of less than $100,000 can also access Evzio free of charge. Kal&eacute;o says it also offers product grants to some nonprofits and government agencies that demonstrate a need for the drug. For instance, Kal&eacute;o has granted 2,200 kits to the Cabell-Huntington Health Department, where the overdose death rate is nearly 10 times the national average. &#8220;The more naloxone there is, the more lives will be saved,&#8221; says Dr. Michael Kilkenny, physician director of the Cabell-Huntington Health Department. &#8220;I have to admit, if we didn&#8217;t get the grant, we wouldn&#8217;t have the drug. We don&#8217;t have the finances.&#8221; Yet even beneficiaries of naloxone grants acknowledge that demand outstrips affordable supply. In Palm Beach County, Fla., for instance, the Fire and Rescue department spent nearly $205,400 on naloxone in 2016, compared with $57,500 in 2015. In Baltimore, first responders are facing similar constraints. &ldquo;We have to decide who is the most likely to die and make a guess on which patients we distribute naloxone to,&rdquo; says Wen, the health commissioner, adding that the price they pay for naloxone more than doubled over the course of just a few years. &#8220;It doesn&rsquo;t make sense that at a time of great demand this medication is being priced out of our reach.&rdquo; In Newtown, Ohio, police chief Tom Synan says the opioid epidemic in his community is worsening. The county averages up to 70 overdoses a week. &ldquo;That&rsquo;s our new normal,&rdquo; he says. Synan, who serves on the Hamilton County Heroin Coalition steering committee, says his officers use the naloxone nasal spray Narcan, and the department has not been hit with major cost increases. But the overall trend is disconcerting. &ldquo;These are life and death situations,&#8221; says Synan. If his earlier promises hold true, Trump will eventually train his lens on drug companies&mdash;and drug prices. A White House spokesperson says the administration is extending grant programs to help get naloxone in the hands of first responders, has encouraged Medicaid programs to include naloxone access for low-income people, and has made sure Veterans Affairs programs offer naloxone for eligible veterans. Still, some say more drastic action will be necessary. Ohio has already taken action: in November the state reached an agreement with Adapt Pharma, the manufacturer of Narcan, to freeze the price of the naloxone nasal spray for Ohio law enforcement, first responders, state and local government agencies, and community-based organizations for a year. These entities can buy 48 or more Narcan units for $75 each, a 40% discount from the $125 wholesale price. &#8220;It&#8217;s hard to justify the price increases you see on purely economic grounds,&#8221; says Darius Lakdawalla, an economist and professor of pharmaceutical development and regulatory innovation at the University of Southern California. &#8220;The case is pretty strong for government interference.&#8221; Especially when lives are at stake. Laurie Fugitt, co-founder of Georgia Overdose Prevention, a volunteer group, hopscotches across the state teaching people how to administer naloxone to themselves or their loved ones. She equates naloxone to a fire extinguisher. You never want anyone to use it. But it should be there just in case. &#8220;A lot of people have no idea that there&#8217;s even an antidote for an opioid overdose,&#8221; says Fugitt. &#8220;Back in the day, a vial of naloxone cost a couple of bucks. Now, everybody is trying to get their piece of the pie.&#8221; With reporting by Zeke J. Miller"},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EDuring a freewheeling recent press conference, President Trump declared that America was &ldquo;drug-infested&rdquo; country. &ldquo;Drugs,&rdquo; Trump said, &ldquo;are becoming cheaper than candy bars.&rdquo; What the President failed to mention: the price of one lifesaving medication&mdash;naloxone&mdash;is more expensive than caviar. Throughout the 2016 presidential campaign, Trump promised to solve America&rsquo;s opioid crisis, which claimed 33,000 lives&hellip;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":14074318,"featured_media":4682040,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[189091,4381760,430952899,429195055,108735],"time_section":[204777760,204777764,204777755,204777754],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937772],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4677394"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4677394\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4677394\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=4677394"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=4677394"},{"taxonomy":"topic","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftopics?post=4677394"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4677394\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4677394\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4677394\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4677394\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002 under President Trump?","twitter_text":"Donald Trump vowed to solve the opioid crisis, but he needs to fix this major problem first","permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4677394\u002Fdonald-trump-opioid-epidemic-and-rising-drug-costs\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ftime\u002F4677394\u002Fdonald-trump-opioid-epidemic-and-rising-drug-costs\u002F?source=dam","og_title":"President Bob Dold pushes for Lalis Law","caption":"Jody Daitchman holds two versions of Naloxone, also known as Narcan, which combat drug overdoses, in Washington, on May 11, 2016. ","credit":"Al Drago—CQ-Roll\u002FGetty Images","title":"Rep. Bob Dold pushes for Lalis Law"},"video":[],"structured":false}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":429195055,"name":"opioid epidemic","slug":"opioid-epidemic","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":82387,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":5,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":204777754,"name":"U.S.","slug":"us","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":16,"taxonomy":"time_section","description":"The latest news and analysis on crime, religion, education, transportation, weather, immigration, sports, drugs, the law, and other news from around the nation","parent":0,"count":11631,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["business","health","politics","us"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4681072,"date":"2017-02-24T11:41:09","date_gmt":"2017-02-24T16:41:09","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4681072"},"modified":"2017-02-24T12:03:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-24T17:03:00","slug":"transgender-students-bathroom-donald-trump","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4681072\u002Ftransgender-students-bathroom-donald-trump\u002F","title":{"rendered":"What the Trump Administration’s Bathroom Memo Means for Transgender Kids"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EThe \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4681019\u002Fpresident-trump-cpac-watch-live\u002F\"\u003ETrump\u003C\u002Fa\u003E administration&#8217;s letter this week \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4679063\u002Fdonald-trump-transgender-bathroom\u002F?xid=homepage\"\u003Erevoking protections for transgender students\u003C\u002Fa\u003E does not directly change schools&#8217; existing policies &mdash; but transgender students and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4661514\u002Flgbt-asylum-seekers-face-extra-anxiety-under-president-trumps-travel-ban\u002F\"\u003ELGBT\u003C\u002Fa\u003E rights advocates say the action sends a message that the highest political office in the U.S. does not support transgender rights.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe administration&#8217;s letter rescinds guidance that came under former President Obama instructing schools to allow transgender students access to bathrooms and other facilities that aligned with their gender identity. But any enforcement of those guidelines was already on hold even before this week, after 13 states accused the Obama administration of overstepping its bounds and a federal judge in Texas temporarily blocked it late last year.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENow, states are largely left where they started &mdash; guided by state law, if there is one that addresses the rights of transgender students, and otherwise able to make up their own minds about how to treat transgender students in public schools. And that, according to advocates like Sarah Warbelow, legal director at the Human Rights Campaign, is a problem.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;We worry that it encourages states and local governments to behave badly toward transgender people,&#8221; Warbelow said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFourteen states have passed their own non-discrimination laws to protect transgender students, Warbelow said, and political leaders in many of those states publicly opposed the Trump administration&#8217;s decision this week, including in Washington, Connecticut, California, New Mexico, New York and Minnesota.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThere remains a risk of litigation, but advocates worry that the move by Trump&#8217;s Justice Department will embolden states, cities or school districts to require that transgender students use the bathrooms that align with the sex assigned to them at birth, even if enforcement of such policies is difficult. The prospect of singling out transgender students is harmful to children, advocates say, noting that they already face misunderstanding and bullying. In Virginia, the Gloucester County School Board&mdash; which was sued by 17-year-old student Gavin Grimm after he was blocked from using the boys&#8217; restroom two years ago &mdash; \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.chicagotribune.com\u002Fnews\u002Flocal\u002Fbreaking\u002Fct-gavin-grimm-transgender-ruling-trump-20170223-story.html\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Esaid\u003C\u002Fa\u003E it was &#8220;pleased&#8221; by the government withdrawing the guidance. The school board is set to defend its policy before the Supreme Court next month.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELegal advocates say they believe that regardless of the Trump administration&#8217;s guidance, transgender kids are still protected under Title IX, which prohibits sex discrimination in education, and they plan to fight for those protections in states that aren&#8217;t already offering them.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;What the administration did yesterday was just another moment where they are once again attacking a vulnerable community in this country, and this time, it&#8217;s transgender youths,&#8221; said Kris Hayashi, executive director of the Transgender Law Center. &#8220;It&#8217;s just horrendous and shameful that government officials and politicians use their power to target students, target transgender people who are just trying to go to school.&#8221; Transgender activist Caitlyn Jenner \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fpeople.com\u002Fpolitics\u002Fcaitlyn-jenner-donald-trump-transgender-bathroom\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Ecalled the Trump administration&#8217;s move a &#8220;disaster.&#8221; \u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhite House Press Secretary Sean Spicer defended the Trump administration&#8217;s decision this week, saying the Obama-era interpretation of Title IX was flawed.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHolly Montemayor, a transgender student in Minnesota who dropped out of school because of continuous bullying, is worried that the Trump administration&#8217;s letter will make things worse for transgender kids.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;I think it&#8217;s going to enable more bigotry to happen to transgender students,&#8221; Montemayor said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EMontemayor, who is now 18, came out in 2012 at the age of 13. The staff at her middle school said she could not use the girls&#8217; restroom, she said, leading her peers to ask invasive questions and stare at her when she went to the bathroom. Although she was allowed to use the women&#8217;s restroom in high school, Montemayor said she started receiving death threats from other students. The emotional toll caused her grades to suffer; she dropped out in 2016 and is pursuing her G.E.D.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHer father, Ramon Montemayor, said the Obama-era guidance sent a powerful message of inclusion to school administrators who may not have been familiar with the challenges facing transgender kids.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;I didn&#8217;t know anything about this topic when Holly came out,&#8221; he said. &#8220;We became educated and fully supportive. Those guidelines that have been reversed &mdash; they would be very helpful to have them for schools. They would go a long way.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4681019\u002Fpresident-trump-cpac-watch-live\u002F"},"content":["Trump"]}," administration's letter this week ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4679063\u002Fdonald-trump-transgender-bathroom\u002F?xid=homepage"},"content":["revoking protections for transgender students"]}," does not directly change schools' existing policies — but transgender students and ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4661514\u002Flgbt-asylum-seekers-face-extra-anxiety-under-president-trumps-travel-ban\u002F"},"content":["LGBT"]}," rights advocates say the action sends a message that the highest political office in the U.S. does not support transgender rights."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The administration's letter rescinds guidance that came under former President Obama instructing schools to allow transgender students access to bathrooms and other facilities that aligned with their gender identity. But any enforcement of those guidelines was already on hold even before this week, after 13 states accused the Obama administration of overstepping its bounds and a federal judge in Texas temporarily blocked it late last year."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Now, states are largely left where they started — guided by state law, if there is one that addresses the rights of transgender students, and otherwise able to make up their own minds about how to treat transgender students in public schools. And that, according to advocates like Sarah Warbelow, legal director at the Human Rights Campaign, is a problem."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"We worry that it encourages states and local governments to behave badly toward transgender people,\" Warbelow said."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Fourteen states have passed their own non-discrimination laws to protect transgender students, Warbelow said, and political leaders in many of those states publicly opposed the Trump administration's decision this week, including in Washington, Connecticut, California, New Mexico, New York and Minnesota."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["There remains a risk of litigation, but advocates worry that the move by Trump's Justice Department will embolden states, cities or school districts to require that transgender students use the bathrooms that align with the sex assigned to them at birth, even if enforcement of such policies is difficult. The prospect of singling out transgender students is harmful to children, advocates say, noting that they already face misunderstanding and bullying. In Virginia, the Gloucester County School Board— which was sued by 17-year-old student Gavin Grimm after he was blocked from using the boys' restroom two years ago — ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.chicagotribune.com\u002Fnews\u002Flocal\u002Fbreaking\u002Fct-gavin-grimm-transgender-ruling-trump-20170223-story.html"},"content":["said"]}," it was \"pleased\" by the government withdrawing the guidance. The school board is set to defend its policy before the Supreme Court next month."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Legal advocates say they believe that regardless of the Trump administration's guidance, transgender kids are still protected under Title IX, which prohibits sex discrimination in education, and they plan to fight for those protections in states that aren't already offering them."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"What the administration did yesterday was just another moment where they are once again attacking a vulnerable community in this country, and this time, it's transgender youths,\" said Kris Hayashi, executive director of the Transgender Law Center. \"It's just horrendous and shameful that government officials and politicians use their power to target students, target transgender people who are just trying to go to school.\" Transgender activist Caitlyn Jenner ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fpeople.com\u002Fpolitics\u002Fcaitlyn-jenner-donald-trump-transgender-bathroom\u002F"},"content":["called the Trump administration's move a \"disaster.\" "]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer defended the Trump administration's decision this week, saying the Obama-era interpretation of Title IX was flawed."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Holly Montemayor, a transgender student in Minnesota who dropped out of school because of continuous bullying, is worried that the Trump administration's letter will make things worse for transgender kids."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"I think it's going to enable more bigotry to happen to transgender students,\" Montemayor said."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Montemayor, who is now 18, came out in 2012 at the age of 13. The staff at her middle school said she could not use the girls' restroom, she said, leading her peers to ask invasive questions and stare at her when she went to the bathroom. Although she was allowed to use the women's restroom in high school, Montemayor said she started receiving death threats from other students. The emotional toll caused her grades to suffer; she dropped out in 2016 and is pursuing her G.E.D."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Her father, Ramon Montemayor, said the Obama-era guidance sent a powerful message of inclusion to school administrators who may not have been familiar with the challenges facing transgender kids."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"I didn't know anything about this topic when Holly came out,\" he said. \"We became educated and fully supportive. Those guidelines that have been reversed — they would be very helpful to have them for schools. They would go a long way.\""]}],"plain":"The Trump administration&#8217;s letter this week revoking protections for transgender students does not directly change schools&#8217; existing policies &mdash; but transgender students and LGBT rights advocates say the action sends a message that the highest political office in the U.S. does not support transgender rights. The administration&#8217;s letter rescinds guidance that came under former President Obama instructing schools to allow transgender students access to bathrooms and other facilities that aligned with their gender identity. But any enforcement of those guidelines was already on hold even before this week, after 13 states accused the Obama administration of overstepping its bounds and a federal judge in Texas temporarily blocked it late last year. Now, states are largely left where they started &mdash; guided by state law, if there is one that addresses the rights of transgender students, and otherwise able to make up their own minds about how to treat transgender students in public schools. And that, according to advocates like Sarah Warbelow, legal director at the Human Rights Campaign, is a problem. &#8220;We worry that it encourages states and local governments to behave badly toward transgender people,&#8221; Warbelow said. Fourteen states have passed their own non-discrimination laws to protect transgender students, Warbelow said, and political leaders in many of those states publicly opposed the Trump administration&#8217;s decision this week, including in Washington, Connecticut, California, New Mexico, New York and Minnesota. There remains a risk of litigation, but advocates worry that the move by Trump&#8217;s Justice Department will embolden states, cities or school districts to require that transgender students use the bathrooms that align with the sex assigned to them at birth, even if enforcement of such policies is difficult. The prospect of singling out transgender students is harmful to children, advocates say, noting that they already face misunderstanding and bullying. In Virginia, the Gloucester County School Board&mdash; which was sued by 17-year-old student Gavin Grimm after he was blocked from using the boys&#8217; restroom two years ago &mdash; said it was &#8220;pleased&#8221; by the government withdrawing the guidance. The school board is set to defend its policy before the Supreme Court next month. Legal advocates say they believe that regardless of the Trump administration&#8217;s guidance, transgender kids are still protected under Title IX, which prohibits sex discrimination in education, and they plan to fight for those protections in states that aren&#8217;t already offering them. &#8220;What the administration did yesterday was just another moment where they are once again attacking a vulnerable community in this country, and this time, it&#8217;s transgender youths,&#8221; said Kris Hayashi, executive director of the Transgender Law Center. &#8220;It&#8217;s just horrendous and shameful that government officials and politicians use their power to target students, target transgender people who are just trying to go to school.&#8221; Transgender activist Caitlyn Jenner called the Trump administration&#8217;s move a &#8220;disaster.&#8221; White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer defended the Trump administration&#8217;s decision this week, saying the Obama-era interpretation of Title IX was flawed. Holly Montemayor, a transgender student in Minnesota who dropped out of school because of continuous bullying, is worried that the Trump administration&#8217;s letter will make things worse for transgender kids. &#8220;I think it&#8217;s going to enable more bigotry to happen to transgender students,&#8221; Montemayor said. Montemayor, who is now 18, came out in 2012 at the age of 13. The staff at her middle school said she could not use the girls&#8217; restroom, she said, leading her peers to ask invasive questions and stare at her when she went to the bathroom. Although she was allowed to use the women&#8217;s restroom in high school, Montemayor said she started receiving death threats from other students. The emotional toll caused her grades to suffer; she dropped out in 2016 and is pursuing her G.E.D. Her father, Ramon Montemayor, said the Obama-era guidance sent a powerful message of inclusion to school administrators who may not have been familiar with the challenges facing transgender kids. &#8220;I didn&#8217;t know anything about this topic when Holly came out,&#8221; he said. &#8220;We became educated and fully supportive. Those guidelines that have been reversed &mdash; they would be very helpful to have them for schools. They would go a long way.&#8221;"},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;It encourages states and local governments to behave badly toward transgender people&#8221; \u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":107515770,"featured_media":4681274,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[10257,430939235],"time_section":[204777755,204777754],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937772],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681072"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681072\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681072\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=4681072"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=4681072"},{"taxonomy":"topic","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftopics?post=4681072"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681072\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681072\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681072\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681072\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681072\u002Fauthors"}],"fortune:newsletter":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681072\u002Fnewsletter"}],"fortune:more":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681072\u002Fmore"}],"fortune:popular":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681072\u002Fpopular"}],"fortune:listicle":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681072\u002Flisticle"}],"fortune:gallery":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681072\u002Fgallery"}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681072\u002Fprimary_tag"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681072\u002Fprimary_section"}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681072\u002Fprimary_topic"}],"ng:more:brand":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681072\u002Fbrand"}],"ng:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fauthors?post=4681072"}]},"_embedded":{"wp:term":[[{"id":1,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fcategory\u002Funcategorized\u002F","name":"Uncategorized","slug":"uncategorized","taxonomy":"category","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories\u002F1"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fcategory"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?categories=1"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?categories=1"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[{"id":10257,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Ftag\u002Flgbt\u002F","name":"LGBT","slug":"lgbt","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags\u002F10257"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fpost_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?tags=10257"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=10257"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":430939235,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Ftag\u002Fonetime\u002F","name":"onetime","slug":"onetime","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags\u002F430939235"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fpost_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?tags=430939235"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=430939235"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}}],{"code":"rest_no_route","message":"No Leonard Lance said was going over well. Constituents gathered at a town hall in Branchburg, NJ Feb. 22 weren&#8217;t buying the Republican Congressman&#8217;s answers to questions about health care reform, or the environment, or financial regulation. Each time he acknowledged he was skeptical of President Trump&#8217;s ties to Russia, the packed crowd roared back: &#8220;What are you going to do about it?&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELance was elected in 2008, but Ed Marceski said the event was the first time he felt the need to confront his representative. Wearing a T-shirt with the word &#8220;Resist,&#8221; Marceski, who voted for Hillary Clinton, said Trump&#8217;s election had energized him. &#8220;I&#8217;m 61 years old, and this is the first time we&#8217;ve done something like this,&#8221; Marceski said. &#8220;It won&#8217;t be the last.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"video-container\"\u003E\u003Cvideo id=\"brightcove-player-5332620994001\" data-video-id=\"5332620994001\" data-account=\"293884104\" data-player=\"SJa0Thl7\" data-embed=\"default\" autoplay controls preload=\"auto\" class=\"video-js responsive-video\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fvideo\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELance is one of a wave of Republican senators and representatives who have been met by vocal crowds at events held in their district during this week&#8217;s congressional recess, a groundswell that has led some to see a left wing echo of the outrage that propelled the Tea Party. Mobilized by their concern over the GOP&#8217;s promise to repeal the Affordable Care Act, as well as questions about Trump&#8217;s immigration policies and his ties to Russia, protesters have confronted\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fnymag.com\u002Fdaily\u002Fintelligencer\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fhundreds-confront-congressman-chaffetz-at-rowdy-town-hall.html\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E Rep. Jason Chaffetz in Utah,\u003C\u002Fa\u003E Rep. Mark Sanford in South Carolina, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwavy.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002F20\u002Fcongressman-scott-taylor-hosts-town-hall-meeting-in-va-beach\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ERep. Scott Taylor in Virginia\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, Rep. Jim Jordan in \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.cleveland.com\u002Fpolitics\u002Findex.ssf\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fjim_jordan_engages_his_protest.html\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EOhio,\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and Sen. Tom Cotton in Arkansas. Support for the ACA has grown since the threat of repeal, with 48% of Americans saying they favor the law compared to 42% who oppose it, according to a \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fkff.org\u002Fhealth-reform\u002Fpoll-finding\u002Fkaiser-health-tracking-poll-future-directions-for-the-aca-and-medicaid\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EKaiser Health Tracking Poll\u003C\u002Fa\u003E released Feb. 24. The approval level is the highest since Kaiser began the poll in 2010.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn Iowa, Anna Plank drove an hour and a half to confront Senator \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4678389\u002Frepublican-congress-donald-trump-town-hall-protests\u002F\"\u003EJoni Ernst\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. &#8220;People were yelling in the hallway, people were chanting &#8216;do your job,'&#8221; Plank said \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnn.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002F21\u002Fpolitics\u002Fjoni-ernst-iowa-town-hall\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eafter the veterans&#8217; event in Maquoketa\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. &#8220;We don&#8217;t feel heard, we don&#8217;t feel listened to,&#8221; Plank said. &#8220;It doesn&#8217;t feel like this country this was meant to be.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA spokesperson for Ernst says the senator &#8220;believes it&#8217;s critical that she hears from folks across the state directly,&#8221; and said that Ernst holds 99 county tours in her state every year, including three public events last month.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EPlank is an organizer of \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4649891\u002Fprotest-donald-trump\u002F\"\u003EIndivisible Iowa\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, one of hundreds of grassroots organizations that have sprung up around the country in opposition to Trump&#8217;s policies and GOP policy planks like the repeal of the ACA. Indivisible started as an \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.indivisibleguide.com\u002Fresources-2\u002F2017\u002F2\u002F16\u002Freclaim-recess\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eonline how-to guide\u003C\u002Fa\u003E for citizens to effectively pressure their representatives, written by former congressional staffers who witnessed the rise of the Tea Party in 2009. In the months since the election, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.indivisibleguide.com\u002Fgroups-nav.\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EIndivisible has morphed into an organizing engine\u003C\u002Fa\u003E for the Trump opposition, pumping energy and information into local resistance efforts.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhite House officials have \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.washingtonpost.com\u002Fnews\u002Fpost-politics\u002Fwp\u002F2017\u002F02\u002F06\u002Fin-echoes-of-2009-republicans-see-astroturf-in-democratic-protests\u002F?utm_term=.4c8e3066f4dd\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Edescribed \u003C\u002Fa\u003Ethe anti-Trump protests as &#8220;astro-turf,&#8221; coordinated national efforts masquerading as grassroots pushback. Trump dismissed the boisterous town halls as &#8220;so-called angry crowds&#8221; and \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002FrealDonaldTrump\u002Fstatus\u002F834181712783560705\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Esuggested on Twitter\u003C\u002Fa\u003E that they were &#8220;planned by liberal activists.&#8221; White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer called the protesters a &#8220;small, loud group of people&#8221; on \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fabcnews.go.com\u002FPolitics\u002Fgop-town-hall-backlash-hybrid-real-concern-manufactured\u002Fstory?id=45663842\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E Wednesday,\u003C\u002Fa\u003E adding that &#8220;just because they&#8217;re loud doesn&#8217;t mean that there are many.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIt&#8217;s difficult to tell exactly how many people are involved with the protests, but they have been building momentum. Indivisible has more than 5,000 verified groups, and 678 registered events with more than 12,000 RSVPs. The website has been viewed more than 15.5 million times since the election, and the Indivisible Guide has been viewed 2 million times on the site, according to the group&#8217;s organizers. All of the Indivisible organizers interviewed by TIME in four states say they are first-time organizers, new to political activism, and are not being paid.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;I wish I was being paid,&#8221; says Plank, an elementary school teacher currently raising her daughters full time, adding that she was so angry with Trump and Ernst that she didn&#8217;t need a financial incentive. &#8220;They could pay me to \u003Cem\u003Enot\u003C\u002Fem\u003E show up.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn Tennessee, local constituents confronted Republican Rep. Marsha Blackburn during a town hall meeting Tuesday, demanding answers about health care and Trump&#8217;s ties to Russia. &#8220;A lot of our questions were followed by &#8216;I&#8217;ll look into it,'&#8221; says Michelle Bewley, 36, who helped organize the Indivisible group in Blackburn&#8217;s district, a stretch of Middle Tennessee that includes some of Nashville&#8217;s wealthiest suburbs. &#8220;We didn&#8217;t get a lot of clear answers on any of our questions.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBewley is a parent, adjunct professor, volunteer and first-time political organizer. When her Indivisible group first started shortly after the election, they had a handful of members. Now, she says they have more than 400 people involved and organize multiple events a week.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;As an individual, if I&#8217;m just one person voicing my opinion, I&#8217;m not going to get heard,&#8221; she says. &#8220;But if we have 100 people voicing the same concerns, it&#8217;s gonna be heard.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIt&#8217;s too early to know if this outrage will be sustained, let alone if it can\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4675256\u002Fdonald-trump-congress-town-hall-protests\u002F\"\u003E change outcomes in Congress\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. But it is already forcing many Republicans to recalibrate their outreach efforts.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"video-container\"\u003E\u003Cvideo id=\"brightcove-player-5334420223001\" data-video-id=\"5334420223001\" data-account=\"293884104\" data-player=\"SJa0Thl7\" data-embed=\"default\" controls preload=\"auto\" class=\"video-js responsive-video\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fvideo\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOf the 59 Republican members of Congress targeted as vulnerable by the DCCC in 2018 elections, only 19 held any sort of constituent event this week, according to a running tally compiled by the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdocs.google.com\u002Fspreadsheets\u002Fd\u002F1yq1NT9DZ2z3B8ixhid894e77u9rN5XIgOwWtTW72IYA\u002Fhtmlview?sle=true#\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ETownHallProject. \u003C\u002Fa\u003EOf those, 17 were &#8220;empty chair&#8221; town halls, tele-town halls (where constituents can call in their questions) or appearances by staff instead of the elected officials.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESome Republicans who did show up to meet their constituents said the confrontations turned into productive dialogue. In South Carolina, Sanford lingered to talk to constituents after a boisterous town hall meeting on Saturday. &#8220;Nobody drives out of their way to go to a town hall just to score points,&#8221; Sanford said. &#8220;Let&#8217;s get to the bottom of this.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESanford and Senator Rand Paul are \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnn.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002F14\u002Fpolitics\u002Frand-paul-mark-sanford-obamacare\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eco-sponsoring a health care replacement bill \u003C\u002Fa\u003Ethat would allow insurers to sell a wider range of policies (including some with lower premiums but limited benefits), allow citizens to sock away more money in tax-free health-care savings accounts, and allow those with pre-existing conditions to keep their coverage as long as they had continuous coverage. The bill, which was \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnn.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002F14\u002Fpolitics\u002Frand-paul-mark-sanford-obamacare\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eendorsed\u003C\u002Fa\u003E by the House Freedom Caucus earlier this month, turns up the pressure on House Republicans to repeal the ACA. But Sanford said that speaking with some of the attendees caused him to &#8220;look more deeply&#8221; at the way the bill would treat pre-existing conditions.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;There&#8217;s a degree of directness that I haven&#8217;t really seen before,&#8221; he said. &#8220;I&#8217;ve seen pieces of it, but not with such energy.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFor Republican members of Congress who rode the Tea Party wave to Washington, the local resistance movement created a sense of deja vu&#8211;but only to a point. &#8220;The energy looks familiar,&#8221; says Rep. David Brat, who toppled then-House Majority Leader Eric Cantor in the 2014 Virginia Republican primary. But there are differences. &#8220;Over half the energy from the Tea Party was against our own party leadership, and that&#8217;s not what&#8217;s going on here,&#8221; he said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAnti-Trump protesters have also focused some attention on Democratic representatives, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.washingtonpost.com\u002Fvideo\u002Fnational\u002Fprotesters-rally-outside-chuck-schumers-home\u002F2017\u002F02\u002F01\u002Fd0d95e50-e88f-11e6-903d-9b11ed7d8d2a_video.html\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Ewith hundreds gathering in front of Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer&#8217;s\u003C\u002Fa\u003E New York home to challenge him to stand up to Trump.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ECome Feb. 27th, Congress will be back in session and its members shielded by the relative protection of its chambers. Those who rallied at town halls say they&#8217;ll keep working, turning their attention to other forms of organizing. The New Jersey Indivisible group convenes postcard parties to write to local representatives and hosts information sessions on immigration and gerrymandering. The Arkansas Indivisible group makes daily calls to their representatives and organizes local volunteer efforts like a trail cleanup &#8220;to show our neighbors that we&#8217;re not just those people they saw on TV, we&#8217;re actually helping our community,&#8221; says Caitlynn Moses, another first-time organizer. In Iowa, Plank and her fellow Indivisible members have been throwing fake retirement parties for Ernst.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;We&#8217;re out here,&#8221; Plank says. &#8220;You may ignore us, but we&#8217;re not going away.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Nothing Rep. The New Jersey Indivisible group convenes postcard parties to write to local representatives and hosts information sessions on immigration and gerrymandering. The Arkansas Indivisible group makes daily calls to their representatives and organizes local volunteer efforts like a trail cleanup \"to show our neighbors that we're not just those people they saw on TV, we're actually helping our community,\" says Caitlynn Moses, another first-time organizer. In Iowa, Plank and her fellow Indivisible members have been throwing fake retirement parties for Ernst."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"We're out here,\" Plank says. \"You may ignore us, but we're not going away.\""]}],"plain":"Nothing Rep. Leonard Lance said was going over well. Constituents gathered at a town hall in Branchburg, NJ Feb. 22 weren&#8217;t buying the Republican Congressman&#8217;s answers to questions about health care reform, or the environment, or financial regulation. Each time he acknowledged he was skeptical of President Trump&#8217;s ties to Russia, the packed crowd roared back: &#8220;What are you going to do about it?&#8221; Lance was elected in 2008, but Ed Marceski said the event was the first time he felt the need to confront his representative. Wearing a T-shirt with the word &#8220;Resist,&#8221; Marceski, who voted for Hillary Clinton, said Trump&#8217;s election had energized him. &#8220;I&#8217;m 61 years old, and this is the first time we&#8217;ve done something like this,&#8221; Marceski said. &#8220;It won&#8217;t be the last.&#8221; Lance is one of a wave of Republican senators and representatives who have been met by vocal crowds at events held in their district during this week&#8217;s congressional recess, a groundswell that has led some to see a left wing echo of the outrage that propelled the Tea Party. Mobilized by their concern over the GOP&#8217;s promise to repeal the Affordable Care Act, as well as questions about Trump&#8217;s immigration policies and his ties to Russia, protesters have confronted Rep. Jason Chaffetz in Utah, Rep. Mark Sanford in South Carolina, Rep. Scott Taylor in Virginia, Rep. Jim Jordan in Ohio, and Sen. Tom Cotton in Arkansas. Support for the ACA has grown since the threat of repeal, with 48% of Americans saying they favor the law compared to 42% who oppose it, according to a Kaiser Health Tracking Poll released Feb. 24. The approval level is the highest since Kaiser began the poll in 2010. In Iowa, Anna Plank drove an hour and a half to confront Senator Joni Ernst. &#8220;People were yelling in the hallway, people were chanting &#8216;do your job,'&#8221; Plank said after the veterans&#8217; event in Maquoketa. &#8220;We don&#8217;t feel heard, we don&#8217;t feel listened to,&#8221; Plank said. &#8220;It doesn&#8217;t feel like this country this was meant to be.&#8221; A spokesperson for Ernst says the senator &#8220;believes it&#8217;s critical that she hears from folks across the state directly,&#8221; and said that Ernst holds 99 county tours in her state every year, including three public events last month. Plank is an organizer of Indivisible Iowa, one of hundreds of grassroots organizations that have sprung up around the country in opposition to Trump&#8217;s policies and GOP policy planks like the repeal of the ACA. Indivisible started as an online how-to guide for citizens to effectively pressure their representatives, written by former congressional staffers who witnessed the rise of the Tea Party in 2009. In the months since the election, Indivisible has morphed into an organizing engine for the Trump opposition, pumping energy and information into local resistance efforts. White House officials have described the anti-Trump protests as &#8220;astro-turf,&#8221; coordinated national efforts masquerading as grassroots pushback. Trump dismissed the boisterous town halls as &#8220;so-called angry crowds&#8221; and suggested on Twitter that they were &#8220;planned by liberal activists.&#8221; White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer called the protesters a &#8220;small, loud group of people&#8221; on Wednesday, adding that &#8220;just because they&#8217;re loud doesn&#8217;t mean that there are many.&#8221; It&#8217;s difficult to tell exactly how many people are involved with the protests, but they have been building momentum. Indivisible has more than 5,000 verified groups, and 678 registered events with more than 12,000 RSVPs. The website has been viewed more than 15.5 million times since the election, and the Indivisible Guide has been viewed 2 million times on the site, according to the group&#8217;s organizers. All of the Indivisible organizers interviewed by TIME in four states say they are first-time organizers, new to political activism, and are not being paid. &#8220;I wish I was being paid,&#8221; says Plank, an elementary school teacher currently raising her daughters full time, adding that she was so angry with Trump and Ernst that she didn&#8217;t need a financial incentive. &#8220;They could pay me to not show up.&#8221; In Tennessee, local constituents confronted Republican Rep. Marsha Blackburn during a town hall meeting Tuesday, demanding answers about health care and Trump&#8217;s ties to Russia. &#8220;A lot of our questions were followed by &#8216;I&#8217;ll look into it,'&#8221; says Michelle Bewley, 36, who helped organize the Indivisible group in Blackburn&#8217;s district, a stretch of Middle Tennessee that includes some of Nashville&#8217;s wealthiest suburbs. &#8220;We didn&#8217;t get a lot of clear answers on any of our questions.&#8221; Bewley is a parent, adjunct professor, volunteer and first-time political organizer. When her Indivisible group first started shortly after the election, they had a handful of members. Now, she says they have more than 400 people involved and organize multiple events a week. &#8220;As an individual, if I&#8217;m just one person voicing my opinion, I&#8217;m not going to get heard,&#8221; she says. &#8220;But if we have 100 people voicing the same concerns, it&#8217;s gonna be heard.&#8221; It&#8217;s too early to know if this outrage will be sustained, let alone if it can change outcomes in Congress. But it is already forcing many Republicans to recalibrate their outreach efforts. Of the 59 Republican members of Congress targeted as vulnerable by the DCCC in 2018 elections, only 19 held any sort of constituent event this week, according to a running tally compiled by the TownHallProject. Of those, 17 were &#8220;empty chair&#8221; town halls, tele-town halls (where constituents can call in their questions) or appearances by staff instead of the elected officials. Some Republicans who did show up to meet their constituents said the confrontations turned into productive dialogue. In South Carolina, Sanford lingered to talk to constituents after a boisterous town hall meeting on Saturday. &#8220;Nobody drives out of their way to go to a town hall just to score points,&#8221; Sanford said. &#8220;Let&#8217;s get to the bottom of this.&#8221; Sanford and Senator Rand Paul are co-sponsoring a health care replacement bill that would allow insurers to sell a wider range of policies (including some with lower premiums but limited benefits), allow citizens to sock away more money in tax-free health-care savings accounts, and allow those with pre-existing conditions to keep their coverage as long as they had continuous coverage. The bill, which was endorsed by the House Freedom Caucus earlier this month, turns up the pressure on House Republicans to repeal the ACA. But Sanford said that speaking with some of the attendees caused him to &#8220;look more deeply&#8221; at the way the bill would treat pre-existing conditions. &#8220;There&#8217;s a degree of directness that I haven&#8217;t really seen before,&#8221; he said. &#8220;I&#8217;ve seen pieces of it, but not with such energy.&#8221; For Republican members of Congress who rode the Tea Party wave to Washington, the local resistance movement created a sense of deja vu&#8211;but only to a point. &#8220;The energy looks familiar,&#8221; says Rep. David Brat, who toppled then-House Majority Leader Eric Cantor in the 2014 Virginia Republican primary. But there are differences. &#8220;Over half the energy from the Tea Party was against our own party leadership, and that&#8217;s not what&#8217;s going on here,&#8221; he said. Anti-Trump protesters have also focused some attention on Democratic representatives, with hundreds gathering in front of Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer&#8217;s New York home to challenge him to stand up to Trump. Come Feb. 27th, Congress will be back in session and its members shielded by the relative protection of its chambers. Those who rallied at town halls say they&#8217;ll keep working, turning their attention to other forms of organizing. The New Jersey Indivisible group convenes postcard parties to write to local representatives and hosts information sessions on immigration and gerrymandering. The Arkansas Indivisible group makes daily calls to their representatives and organizes local volunteer efforts like a trail cleanup &#8220;to show our neighbors that we&#8217;re not just those people they saw on TV, we&#8217;re actually helping our community,&#8221; says Caitlynn Moses, another first-time organizer. In Iowa, Plank and her fellow Indivisible members have been throwing fake retirement parties for Ernst. &#8220;We&#8217;re out here,&#8221; Plank says. &#8220;You may ignore us, but we&#8217;re not going away.&#8221;"},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003ENothing Rep. Leonard Lance said was going over well. Constituents gathered at a town hall in Branchburg, NJ Feb. 22 weren&#8217;t buying the Republican Congressman&#8217;s answers to questions about health care reform, or the environment, or financial regulation. Each time he acknowledged he was skeptical of President Trump&#8217;s ties to Russia, the packed crowd pi\u002Fv1\u002Ftags"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fpost_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?tags=518843"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=518843"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":15007,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Ftag\u002Frepresentatives\u002F","name":"representatives","slug":"representatives","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags\u002F15007"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fpost_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?tags=15007"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=15007"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}}],{"code":"rest_no_route","message":"No Covering the White House, elections, primaries, Congress, domestic policy, foreign policy, the military and more","parent":0,"count":11779,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["politics","us"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4681179,"date":"2017-02-24T10:42:48","date_gmt":"2017-02-24T15:42:48","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4681179"},"modified":"2017-02-24T18:20:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-24T23:20:00","slug":"supreme-court-service-dog-ehlena-fry","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4681179\u002Fsupreme-court-service-dog-ehlena-fry\u002F","title":{"rendered":"A Girl With Cerebral Palsy Was Denied Her Service Dog at School. The Supreme Court Has Sided With Her."},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EThe family of a Michigan girl with cerebral palsy who was barred from bringing her service dog to school is hailing a \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.aclumich.org\u002Farticle\u002Fscotus-rules-unanimously-behalf-michigan-girl-cerebral-palsy-who-was-prevented-bringing\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ESupreme Court ruling in their favor\u003C\u002Fa\u003E as a victory for all children with disabilities.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.reuters.com\u002Farticle\u002Fus-usa-court-dog-idUSKBN1611Y6\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EEhlena Fry\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, now 13, used to heavily rely on her Goldendoodle named Wonder to balance, open doors and turn off lights &mdash; some of the daily tasks she struggled with because she has a severe form of cerebral palsy which affects her legs, arms and body. But in 2009, when Ehlena was 5, the girl&#8217;s school district said her hypoallergenic and certified service dog was not allowed. While the school district slightly bowed to pressures from the American Civil Liberties Union of Michigan, which advocated on her behalf, the civil rights group said Wonder was still prohibited from being by Ehlena&rsquo;s side for most of the day.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&ldquo;It was devastating as a parent to see a child go through that,&rdquo; Ehlena&#8217;s mother Stacy Fry told TIME on Thursday. &ldquo;At school, where it was really most important for her to be accepted, which was key to her development, they essentially said no. Nobody deserves to be treated this way.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-custom-size alignnone \"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"4681826\"
