ACLU\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EEhlena&rsquo;s family made the decision to homeschool her, choosing not to separate her from Wonder, and then filed a federal complaint against \u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003Ethe Napoleon School District and the Jackson County Intermediate School District. A\u003C\u002Fspan\u003Efter several legal back and forths, the case landed before the Supreme Court. The nation&rsquo;s highest court sided with Ehlena in a \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.supremecourt.gov\u002Fopinions\u002F16pdf\u002F15-497_p8k0.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eruling\u003C\u002Fa\u003E on Wednesday that ultimately streamlines discrimination cases in federal court and allows the Fry family to sue for violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&ldquo;It&rsquo;s our hope that this will set the precedent that&rsquo;s needed to tear down the barriers,&rdquo; Stacy Fry said. &ldquo;We feel that this really is a victory for our family and all the families with children of differing abilities. For us, it really means that we did the right thing. It was not in vain. We had a bigger purpose.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"article-video\"\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"time-embed time-embed__youtube video-wrapper\" data-provider=\"youtube\" data-url=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.youtube.com\u002Fwatch?v=PIfyHn2_lmE\" \u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"embed-youtube\"\u003E\u003Ciframe width=\"500\" height=\"281\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.youtube.com\u002Fembed\u002FPIfyHn2_lmE?feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen\u003E\u003C\u002Fiframe\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003ENeither school district returned requests for comment. Stacy Fry said \u003C\u002Fspan\u003EEhlena no longer needs the help of Wonder, 9, who is retired from his service and spends his days as the girl&rsquo;s companion. The girl&#8217;s mother credits Wonder with teaching her daughter everything she needs to complete tasks on her own.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&ldquo;He&rsquo;s a companion. He&rsquo;s her sidekick. He&rsquo;s that constant reassurance,&rdquo; she said. &ldquo;He&rsquo;s given her the confidence to navigate her environment more independently. Socially and emotionally, he has given her so much confidence to do the things that she wasn&rsquo;t previously able to do. He was that bridge.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&ldquo;He was a great teacher,&rdquo; she added.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The family of a Michigan girl with cerebral palsy who was barred from bringing her service dog to school is hailing a ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.aclumich.org\u002Farticle\u002Fscotus-rules-unanimously-behalf-michigan-girl-cerebral-palsy-who-was-prevented-bringing","target":"_blank"},"content":["Supreme Court ruling in their favor"]}," as a victory for all children with disabilities."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.reuters.com\u002Farticle\u002Fus-usa-court-dog-idUSKBN1611Y6","target":"_blank"},"content":["Ehlena Fry"]},", now 13, used to heavily rely on her Goldendoodle named Wonder to balance, open doors and turn off lights — some of the daily tasks she struggled with because she has a severe form of cerebral palsy which affects her legs, arms and body. But in 2009, when Ehlena was 5, the girl's school district said her hypoallergenic and certified service dog was not allowed. While the school district slightly bowed to pressures from the American Civil Liberties Union of Michigan, which advocated on her behalf, the civil rights group said Wonder was still prohibited from being by Ehlena’s side for most of the day."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["“It was devastating as a parent to see a child go through that,” Ehlena's mother Stacy Fry told TIME on Thursday. “At school, where it was really most important for her to be accepted, which was key to her development, they essentially said no. For us, it really means that we did the right thing. It was not in vain. We had a bigger purpose.”"]},{"tag":"oembed","attributes":{"raw_html":"&lt;div class=&quot;embed-youtube&quot;&gt;&lt;iframe width=&quot;500&quot; height=&quot;281&quot; src=&quot;https:\u002F\u002Fwww.youtube.com\u002Fembed\u002FPIfyHn2_lmE?feature=oembed&quot; frameborder=&quot;0&quot; allowfullscreen&gt;&lt;\u002Fiframe&gt;&lt;\u002Fdiv&gt;","type":"youtube","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.youtube.com\u002Fwatch?v=PIfyHn2_lmE"},"content":[]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Neither school district returned requests for comment. The girl's mother credits Wonder with teaching her daughter everything she needs to complete tasks on her own."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["“He’s a companion. He’s her sidekick. He’s that constant reassurance,” she said. “He’s given her the confidence to navigate her environment more independently. Socially and emotionally, he has given her so much confidence to do the things that she wasn’t previously able to do. He was that bridge.”"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["“He was a great teacher,” she added."]}],"plain":"The family of a Michigan girl with cerebral palsy who was barred from bringing her service dog to school is hailing a Supreme Court ruling in their favor as a victory for all children with disabilities. Ehlena Fry, now 13, used to heavily rely on her Goldendoodle named Wonder to balance, open doors and turn off lights &mdash; some of the daily tasks she struggled with because she has a severe form of cerebral palsy which affects her legs, arms and body. But in 2009, when Ehlena was 5, the girl&#8217;s school district said her hypoallergenic and certified service dog was not allowed. While the school district slightly bowed to pressures from the American Civil Liberties Union of Michigan, which advocated on her behalf, the civil rights group said Wonder was still prohibited from being by Ehlena&rsquo;s side for most of the day. &ldquo;It was devastating as a parent to see a child go through that,&rdquo; Ehlena&#8217;s mother Stacy Fry told TIME on Thursday. &ldquo;At school, where it was really most important for her to be accepted, which was key to her development, they essentially said no. Nobody deserves to be treated this way.&rdquo; Photo courtesy ACLU Ehlena&rsquo;s family made the decision to homeschool her, choosing not to separate her from Wonder, and then filed a federal complaint against the Napoleon School District and the Jackson County Intermediate School District. After several legal back and forths, the case landed before the Supreme Court. The nation&rsquo;s highest court sided with Ehlena in a ruling on Wednesday that ultimately streamlines discrimination cases in federal court and allows the Fry family to sue for violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act. &ldquo;It&rsquo;s our hope that this will set the precedent that&rsquo;s needed to tear down the barriers,&rdquo; Stacy Fry said. &ldquo;We feel that this really is a victory for our family and all the families with children of differing abilities. For us, it really means that we did the right thing. It was not in vain. We had a bigger purpose.&rdquo; Neither school district returned requests for comment. Stacy Fry said Ehlena no longer needs the help of Wonder, 9, who is retired from his service and spends his days as the girl&rsquo;s companion. The girl&#8217;s mother credits Wonder with teaching her daughter everything she needs to complete tasks on her own. &ldquo;He&rsquo;s a companion. He&rsquo;s her sidekick. He&rsquo;s that constant reassurance,&rdquo; she said. &ldquo;He&rsquo;s given her the confidence to navigate her environment more independently. Socially and emotionally, he has given her so much confidence to do the things that she wasn&rsquo;t previously able to do. He was that bridge.&rdquo; &ldquo;He was a great teacher,&rdquo; she added."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E“He’s a companion. He’s her sidekick. He’s that constant reassurance&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":97824220,"featured_media":4681180,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[490,11110,430939235],"time_section":[204777754],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937772],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681179"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681179\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681179\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=4681179"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=4681179"},{"taxonomy":"topic","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftopics?post=4681179"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681179\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681179\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681179\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681179\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681179\u002Fauthors"}],"fo Email Morning Brief writer Melissa Chan at ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"mailto:melissa.chan@time.com","target":"_blank"},"content":["melissa.chan@time.com"]},"."]}]}],"plain":"Good morning. These are today&rsquo;s top stories: President Trump speaks at CPAC today President Donald Trump is slated to deliver remarks today at the Conservative Political Action Conference outside Washington, D.C. Yesterday, white nationalist Richard Spencer made an unwelcome appearance before security guards booted him. Other speakers today include former U.K. Independence Party leader Nigel Farage and National Rifle Association Executive Vice President Wayne LaPierre. Watch Trump&#8217;s speech here. Kansas bar shooting may have been racially motivated A suspected gunman has been charged with murder after police say he opened fire inside a Kansas bar, killing an Indian man and injuring two others. Witnesses say the attack may have been racially motivated. Chemical used to kill Kim Jong Un&rsquo;s half-brother Authorities said Kim Jong Nam, the estranged half-brother of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, was killed by a chemical weapon. The banned and deadly VX nerve agent was detected on the victim&rsquo;s eyes and face. Caitlyn Jenner blasts Trump&rsquo;s transgender rule change Caitlyn Jenner, a prominent transgender activist and a Republican, criticized the Trump Administration&rsquo;s decision to roll back guidelines that allow transgender students in public schools to use the bathroom of their choice. &ldquo;This is a disaster, and you can still fix it,&rdquo; she said in a video posted on Twitter. &ldquo;You made a promise to protect the LGBTQ community. Call me.&rdquo; Also: At least 60 people were killed when a car bomb detonated near Syria&#8217;s Al-Bab, which was recently freed from ISIS. Immigration agents have reportedly removed a woman with a brain tumor from a Texas hospital. Uber said it is &#8220;deeply hurting&#8221; from allegations of sexual harassment in the workplace in messages it sent to users deleting the app. Beyonc&eacute;, who is pregnant with twins, is no longer headlining this year&#8217;s Coachella at the advice of her doctors. The consumption of more fruits and vegetables can prevent millions of deaths each year, a new study suggests. The 89th Academy Awards, hosted by Jimmy Kimmel, take place Sunday. Here&#8217;s everything you need to know before tuning in. The Morning Brief is published Mondays through Fridays. nation","parent":0,"count":11631,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["us"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4681616,"date":"2017-02-24T07:50:36","date_gmt":"2017-02-24T12:50:36","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4681616"},"modified":"2017-02-24T07:50:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-24T12:50:00","slug":"donald-trump-white-house-women-kellyanne-conway","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4681616\u002Fdonald-trump-white-house-women-kellyanne-conway\u002F","title":{"rendered":"Kellyanne Conway Is Overstating How Much Trump Has Done for Women in the White House"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EWASHINGTON (AP) &mdash; President Donald Trump is giving himself too much credit for sending criminal foreigners out of the country and saving money on fighter planes. He&#8217;s getting too much credit from one of the few women with a top White House job for elevating women in the administration.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA look at some statements Thursday by Trump and\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fmotto.time.com\u002F4512953\u002Fmegyn-kelly-kellyanne-conway-misogyny\u002F?iid=sr-link1\"\u003E presidential counselor Kellyanne Conway\u003C\u002Fa\u003E:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETRUMP: &#8220;We&#8217;re getting gang members out, we&#8217;re getting drug lords out, we&#8217;re getting really bad dudes out of this country, at a rate nobody has ever seen before. &#8230; It&#8217;s a military operation because what has been allowed to come into our country, when you see gang violence that you&#8217;ve read about like never before and all of the things, much of that is people who are here illegally. And they&#8217;re rough and they&#8217;re tough, but they&#8217;re not tough like our people. So we&#8217;re getting them out.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv id=\"div-gpt-ad-1470255291270-0\" class=\"ad-placeholder\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETHE FACTS: Trump is broadly embellishing his brief track record on immigration and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4680815\u002Fdonald-trump-deportations-military-operation\u002F?iid=sr-link1\"\u003Ewrongly branding the deportation effort\u003C\u002Fa\u003E a military operation.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe number of people expelled from the country since Trump took office Jan. 20 has not been released. No available data supports his claim that immigrants in the country illegally are being expelled at a rate &#8220;nobody has ever seen before.&#8221; Deportations were brisk when Barack Obama was president.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAltogether in January, 16,643 people were deported, a drop from December (20,395) but a number that is similar to monthly deportations in early 2015 and 2016.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThis month, Homeland Security officials have said 680 people were arrested in a weeklong effort to find and arrest criminal immigrants living in the United States illegally. Three-quarters of those people had been convicted of crimes, Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly said. The remaining 25 percent were not. The government has not provided information about who was arrested in that roundup, so it&#8217;s impossible to determine how many gang members or drug lords were in that group.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThat effort was largely planned before Trump took office and was alternately described by the administration as a routine enforcement effort and a signal of Trump&#8217;s pledge to take a harder line on illegal immigration. During the Obama administration similar operations were carried out that yielded thousands of arrests.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe 680 arrests were not carried out in a military operation. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, responsible for finding and deporting immigrants in the country illegally, is a civilian law enforcement agency.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETrump plans to increase enforcement, but Kelly contradicted him Thursday over the nature of that initiative:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;There will be no use of military forces in immigration,&#8221; Kelly said while visiting Mexico. &#8220;There will be no &mdash; repeat, no &mdash; mass deportations.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E___\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETRUMP, at a White House meeting with manufacturers, again claimed credit for a $700 million savings in the military&#8217;s contract with Lockheed for the F-35 fighter jet. Speaking to the defense contractor&#8217;s CEO Marillyn Hewson, he said: &#8220;Over $700 million. Do you think Hillary would have cost you $700 million? I assume you wanted her to win.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv id=\"div-gpt-ad-1470255291270-1\" class=\"ad-placeholder\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETHE FACTS: Cost savings for the F-35 began before Trump&#8217;s inauguration and predate his complaints about the price tag.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe head of the Air Force program announced significant price reductions Dec. 19 &mdash; after Trump had tweeted about the cost but weeks before Trump met about the issue on Jan. 13 with Hewson.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;There is absolutely no evidence whatsoever of additional F-35 cost savings as a result of President Trump&#8217;s intervention,&#8221; said Richard Aboulafia, an analyst with the aerospace consulting firm Teal Group. He said Trump appears to be taking credit for prior-year budget decisions and for work already done by managers at the Pentagon who took action before the presidential election to reduce costs.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E___\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ECONWAY \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fmotto.time.com\u002F4680131\u002Fkellyanne-conway-feminism-cpac\u002F?iid=sr-link4\"\u003Eat a conference\u003C\u002Fa\u003E of the\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4679969\u002Fwelcome-to-conservatisms-ground-zero\u002F?iid=sr-link3\"\u003E Conservative Political Action Committee\u003C\u002Fa\u003E: &#8220;He has been promoting and elevating women in the Trump Corporation &mdash; in the Trump campaign, in the Trump Cabinet, certainly in the Trump White House. It&#8217;s just a very natural affinity for him.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETHE FACTS: No such elevation of women has taken place, when Trump&#8217;s choices for the Cabinet and top White House aides are compared with those of other presidents in recent decades. Indeed, there&#8217;s been backsliding.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&mdash; Cabinet: Trump has nominated four women for Cabinet or Cabinet-level jobs. That&#8217;s fewer than Democrats Barack Obama (seven) and Bill Clinton (six) had for their first Cabinets, and the same number as Republican George W. Bush chose out of the gate.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAs well, women chosen by Trump are in less senior positions &mdash; both in prominence and in the line of succession to the presidency &mdash; than some of the women nominated by his predecessors. For example, Obama&#8217;s first secretary of state, a top-tier post, was Hillary Clinton. Bush made \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fcontent.time.com\u002Ftime\u002Fspecials\u002Fpackages\u002Farticle\u002F0,28804,1850902_1850905_1850906,00.html?iid=sr-link5\"\u003ECondoleezza Rice\u003C\u002Fa\u003E his secretary of state in his second term. Clinton&#8217;s first Cabinet had a woman as attorney general. Trump&#8217;s top four Cabinet positions &mdash; secretary of state, attorney general, treasury secretary and defense secretary &mdash; are all filled by men.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELooking more broadly, women occupied as much as 35 percent of Obama&#8217;s Cabinet at their maximum numbers, compared with the historic high of 41 percent during Clinton&#8217;s second term, according to the Center for American Women and Politics. Women make up 17 percent of Trump&#8217;s Cabinet choices, the center found. At their height, women comprised 18 percent of Ronald Reagan&#8217;s Cabinet, the same percentage under George H.W. Bush and 30 percent under George W. Bush, the center found.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETrump chose Elaine Chao for Labor, Betsy DeVos for Education and Linda McMahon for the Small Business Administration. As for jobs that are not traditionally part of the Cabinet but considered Cabinet-level, Nikki Haley is ambassador to the United Nations and Trump has not named someone to lead the Council of Economic Advisers.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&mdash; White House: The percentage of women in top White House jobs is shaping up to be lower than during at least five of the last six presidential terms, according to an analysis Monday by USA Today.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe high for women in senior West Wing jobs was 52 percent under Clinton in 2000, the analysis found, while the percentage dipped to 28 percent in 2008, under George W. Bush. For Trump, it&#8217;s 23 percent of known staff.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe White House quarreled with USA Today&#8217;s findings, saying the percentage is actually 31 percent, but refused to back up its figure by giving names or titles for those it considers senior.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAs for White House staff overall, the percentage is &#8220;nearly the same&#8221; as for past administrations, the White House told the paper.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["WASHINGTON (AP) — President Donald Trump is giving himself too much credit for sending criminal foreigners out of the country and saving money on fighter planes. I assume you wanted her to win.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["THE FACTS: Cost savings for the F-35 began before Trump's inauguration and predate his complaints about the price tag."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The head of the Air Force program announced significant price reductions Dec. 19 — after Trump had tweeted about the cost but weeks before Trump met about the issue on Jan. 13 with Hewson."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"There is absolutely no evidence whatsoever of additional F-35 cost savings as a result of President Trump's intervention,\" said Richard Aboulafia, an analyst with the aerospace consulting firm Teal Group. He said Trump appears to be taking credit for prior-year budget decisions and for work already done by managers at the Pentagon who took action before the presidential election to reduce costs."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["___"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["CONWAY ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fmotto.time.com\u002F4680131\u002Fkellyanne-conway-feminism-cpac\u002F?iid=sr-link4"},"content":["at a conference"]}," of the",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4679969\u002Fwelcome-to-conservatisms-ground-zero\u002F?iid=sr-link3"},"content":[" Conservative Political Action Committee"]},": \"He has been promoting and elevating women in the Trump Corporation — in the Trump campaign, in the Trump Cabinet, certainly in the Trump White House. It's just a very natural affinity for him.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["THE FACTS: No such elevation of women has taken place, when Trump's choices for the Cabinet and top White House aides are compared with those of other presidents in recent decades. Indeed, there's been backsliding."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["— Cabinet: Trump has nominated four women for Cabinet or Cabinet-level jobs. Bush chose out of the gate."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["As well, women chosen by Trump are in less senior positions — both in prominence and in the line of succession to the presidency — than some of the women nominated by his predecessors. For example, Obama's first secretary of state, a top-tier post, was Hillary Clinton. Bush made ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fcontent.time.com\u002Ftime\u002Fspecials\u002Fpackages\u002Farticle\u002F0,28804,1850902_1850905_1850906,00.html?iid=sr-link5"},"content":["Condoleezza Rice"]}," his secretary of state in his second term. Clinton's first Cabinet had a woman as attorney general. Trump's top four Cabinet positions — secretary of state, attorney general, treasury secretary and defense secretary — are all filled by men."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Looking more broadly, women occupied as much as 35 percent of Obama's Cabinet at their maximum numbers, compared with the historic high of 41 percent during Clinton's second term, according to the Center for American Women and Politics. Women make up 17 percent of Trump's Cabinet choices, the center found. At their height, women comprised 18 percent of Ronald Reagan's Cabinet, the same percentage under George H.W. Bush and 30 percent under George W. Bush, the center found."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Trump chose Elaine Chao for Labor, Betsy DeVos for Education and Linda McMahon for the Small Business Administration. As for jobs that are not traditionally part of the Cabinet but considered Cabinet-level, Nikki Haley is ambassador to the United Nations and Trump has not named someone to lead the Council of Economic Advisers."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["— White House: The percentage of women in top White House jobs is shaping up to be lower than during at least five of the last six presidential terms, according to an analysis Monday by USA Today."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The high for women in senior West Wing jobs was 52 percent under Clinton in 2000, the analysis found, while the percentage dipped to 28 percent in 2008, under George W. Bush. For Trump, it's 23 percent of known staff."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The White House quarreled with USA Today's findings, saying the percentage is actually 31 percent, but refused to back up its figure by giving names or titles for those it considers senior."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["As for White House staff overall, the percentage is \"nearly the same\" as for past administrations, the White House told the paper."]}],"plain":"WASHINGTON (AP) &mdash; President Donald Trump is giving himself too much credit for sending criminal foreigners out of the country and saving money on fighter planes. He&#8217;s getting too much credit from one of the few women with a top White House job for elevating women in the administration. A look at some statements Thursday by Trump and presidential counselor Kellyanne Conway: TRUMP: &#8220;We&#8217;re getting gang members out, we&#8217;re getting drug lords out, we&#8217;re getting really bad dudes out of this country, at a rate nobody has ever seen before. &#8230; It&#8217;s a military operation because what has been allowed to come into our country, when you see gang violence that you&#8217;ve read about like never before and all of the things, much of that is people who are here illegally. And they&#8217;re rough and they&#8217;re tough, but they&#8217;re not tough like our people. So we&#8217;re getting them out.&#8221; THE FACTS: Trump is broadly embellishing his brief track record on immigration and wrongly branding the deportation effort a military operation. The number of people expelled from the country since Trump took office Jan. 20 has not been released. No available data supports his claim that immigrants in the country illegally are being expelled at a rate &#8220;nobody has ever seen before.&#8221; Deportations were brisk when Barack Obama was president. Altogether in January, 16,643 people were deported, a drop from December (20,395) but a number that is similar to monthly deportations in early 2015 and 2016. This month, Homeland Security officials have said 680 people were arrested in a weeklong effort to find and arrest criminal immigrants living in the United States illegally. Three-quarters of those people had been convicted of crimes, Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly said. The remaining 25 percent were not. The government has not provided information about who was arrested in that roundup, so it&#8217;s impossible to determine how many gang members or drug lords were in that group. That effort was largely planned before Trump took office and was alternately described by the administration as a routine enforcement effort and a signal of Trump&#8217;s pledge to take a harder line on illegal immigration. During the Obama administration similar operations were carried out that yielded thousands of arrests. The 680 arrests were not carried out in a military operation. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, responsible for finding and deporting immigrants in the country illegally, is a civilian law enforcement agency. Trump plans to increase enforcement, but Kelly contradicted him Thursday over the nature of that initiative: &#8220;There will be no use of military forces in immigration,&#8221; Kelly said while visiting Mexico. &#8220;There will be no &mdash; repeat, no &mdash; mass deportations.&#8221; ___ TRUMP, at a White House meeting with manufacturers, again claimed credit for a $700 million savings in the military&#8217;s contract with Lockheed for the F-35 fighter jet. Speaking to the defense contractor&#8217;s CEO Marillyn Hewson, he said: &#8220;Over $700 million. Do you think Hillary would have cost you $700 million? I assume you wanted her to win.&#8221; THE FACTS: Cost savings for the F-35 began before Trump&#8217;s inauguration and predate his complaints about the price tag. The head of the Air Force program announced significant price reductions Dec. 19 &mdash; after Trump had tweeted about the cost but weeks before Trump met about the issue on Jan. 13 with Hewson. &#8220;There is absolutely no evidence whatsoever of additional F-35 cost savings as a result of President Trump&#8217;s intervention,&#8221; said Richard Aboulafia, an analyst with the aerospace consulting firm Teal Group. He said Trump appears to be taking credit for prior-year budget decisions and for work already done by managers at the Pentagon who took action before the presidential election to reduce costs. ___ CONWAY at a conference of the Conservative Political Action Committee: &#8220;He has been promoting and elevating women in the Trump Corporation &mdash; in the Trump campaign, in the Trump Cabinet, certainly in the Trump White House. It&#8217;s just a very natural affinity for him.&#8221; THE FACTS: No such elevation of women has taken place, when Trump&#8217;s choices for the Cabinet and top White House aides are compared with those of other presidents in recent decades. Indeed, there&#8217;s been backsliding. &mdash; Cabinet: Trump has nominated four women for Cabinet or Cabinet-level jobs. That&#8217;s fewer than Democrats Barack Obama (seven) and Bill Clinton (six) had for their first Cabinets, and the same number as Republican George W. Bush chose out of the gate. As well, women chosen by Trump are in less senior positions &mdash; both in prominence and in the line of succession to the presidency &mdash; than some of the women nominated by his predecessors. For example, Obama&#8217;s first secretary of state, a top-tier post, was Hillary Clinton. Bush made Condoleezza Rice his secretary of state in his second term. Clinton&#8217;s first Cabinet had a woman as attorney general. Trump&#8217;s top four Cabinet positions &mdash; secretary of state, attorney general, treasury secretary and defense secretary &mdash; are all filled by men. Looking more broadly, women occupied as much as 35 percent of Obama&#8217;s Cabinet at their maximum numbers, compared with the historic high of 41 percent during Clinton&#8217;s second term, according to the Center for American Women and Politics. Women make up 17 percent of Trump&#8217;s Cabinet choices, the center found. At their height, women comprised 18 percent of Ronald Reagan&#8217;s Cabinet, the same percentage under George H.W. Bush and 30 percent under George W. Bush, the center found. Trump chose Elaine Chao for Labor, Betsy DeVos for Education and Linda McMahon for the Small Business Administration. As for jobs that are not traditionally part of the Cabinet but considered Cabinet-level, Nikki Haley is ambassador to the United Nations and Trump has not named someone to lead the Council of Economic Advisers. &mdash; White House: The percentage of women in top White House jobs is shaping up to be lower than during at least five of the last six presidential terms, according to an analysis Monday by USA Today. The high for women in senior West Wing jobs was 52 percent under Clinton in 2000, the analysis found, while the percentage dipped to 28 percent in 2008, under George W. Bush. For Trump, it&#8217;s 23 percent of known staff. The White House quarreled with USA Today&#8217;s findings, saying the percentage is actually 31 percent, but refused to back up its figure by giving names or titles for those it considers senior. As for White House staff overall, the percentage is &#8220;nearly the same&#8221; as for past administrations, the White House told the paper."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003ENo major elevation of women has taken place in the White House Kuchibhotla  and Madasani are reportedly not from the Middle East."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Police said it was too early to determine whether the shooting was a hate crime, but said local authorities were investigating the incident with the FBI, AP ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.kansascity.com\u002Fnews\u002Fnation-world\u002Farticle134444319.html"},"content":["reports"]},"."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["[",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.kansascity.com\u002Fnews\u002Flocal\u002Fcrime\u002Farticle134396049.html"},"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Kansas Star"]}]},"]"]}],"plain":"A gunman opened fire in a busy Kansas bar on Wednesday, killing one Indian man and injuring two others in what witnesses say may have been a racially motivated attack. The Kansas Star reports that the suspect, identified by police as Adam Purinton, has been charged with first-degree murder and attempted murder after being apprehended Thursday morning in Missouri. Srinivas Kuchibhotla, 32, died in hospital following the shooting in Austins Bar and Grill in Olathe. Alok Madasani, 32, and Ian Grillot, 24, were both injured but are reportedly in a stable condition. Kuchibhotla and Madasani were both engineers who worked at the nearby GPS-maker Garmin and had studied in India, the Associated Press reports. In an interview with the Star, Grillot described how he jumped up to pursue the shooter after he thought the gunman was out of bullets. &ldquo;I wasn&rsquo;t really thinking when I did that,&rdquo; Grillot said. &ldquo;It was just, it wasn&rsquo;t right, and I didn&rsquo;t want the gentleman to potentially go after somebody else.&rdquo; According to the Star, at least one witness recalled hearing the shooter yell, &ldquo;Get out of my country!&rdquo; before opening fire. The Star reports that the suspect allegedly told a bartender in Missouri that he needed a place to hide because he had shot two Middle Eastern men. The suspect reportedly said he believed that he had killed them both. Kuchibhotla and Madasani are reportedly not from the Middle East. Police said it was too early to determine whether the shooting was a hate crime, but said local authorities were investigating the incident with the FBI, AP reports. [Kansas Star]"},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EA witness says the shooter yelled &#8220;get out of my country&#8221; before opening Pew researchers spent about a month before Trump&#8217;s inauguration asking Latinos how they felt about their place in America, in addition to what they expected under a Trump presidency. Forty-one percent said they were worried about their situation, while 54% said they were confident about their future. Unauthorized Latinos and those who were legal residents without citizenship were even more concerned, with 47% of Latinos worried that a family member or a close friend could be deported. A growing number of Latinos consider their situation in the U.S. to be worse than it was a year ago. &ldquo;The share today that says the group&rsquo;s situation has worsened is about double the share that said the same in 2013,&rdquo; Pew reports. The survey was conducted before President Trump ramped up enforcement of national immigration laws on Tuesday, expanding his administration&rsquo;s priorities to allow for the arrest and deportation of nearly all unauthorized immigrants regardless of circumstance. It was also before Trump&#8217;s proposed immigration ban, which has been temporarily blocked. Despite the growing fear of deportation, immigration was a lower priority for Latinos: Nearly three quarters of survey respondents said that improving the country&rsquo;s education system was their top priority, followed by defending the country against terrorism, strengthening the economy and reducing healthcare costs. Immigration came in last of the five priorities Pew surveyed for, which is consistent with previous Pew surveys. President Trump&#8217;s new immigration ban is reportedly nearing completion, according to CNN."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EBut not necessarily because of the proposed immigration ban\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":107326812,"featured_media":4681066,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[386794,189091,4363,281731,430939235],"time_section":[204777755,204777754],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937769],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4680955"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4680955\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4680955\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=4680955"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=4680955"},{"taxonomy":"topic","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftopics?post=4680955"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4680955\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4680955\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4680955\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4680955\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4680955\u002Fau The camp gained increased attention starting in August after its population had grown and authorities made their first arrests. At its height, the camp included thousands of people, but the numbers had dwindled during the winter and as the fight over the pipeline moved into the courts.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe Army Corps of Engineers said it needed to clear the camp ahead of spring flooding, and had ordered everyone to leave by 2 p.m. Wednesday. The agency said it was concerned about protesters&#8217; safety and about the environmental effects of tents, cars, garbage and other items in the camp being washed into nearby rivers.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EMost protesters left peacefully Wednesday, when authorities closed the camp, but some stayed overnight in defiance of the government order.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAs police in full riot gear worked to arrest the stragglers Thursday, cleanup crews began razing buildings on the square-mile piece of property at the confluence of the Cannonball and Missouri rivers.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAuthorities chose to enter the camp &#8220;cautiously and tactfully&#8221; to ensure the safety of officers and protesters, according to Highway Patrol Lt. Tom Iverson. The arrests were a last resort, he said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;We did not want this. Unfortunately, there were some bad actors that forced us into this position,&#8221; he said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOnly one person resisted arrest; otherwise there were no major incidents, and there were no injuries, Morton County Sheriff Kyle Kirchmeier said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAfterward, officers showed visible relief, smiling, shaking hands and patting one another on the back.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EGuardsmen and officers entered the camp from two directions shortly before midday, alongside numerous law enforcement and military vehicles and with a helicopter and airplane overhead. As they checked and cleared buildings, they marked them with a fluorescent orange &#8220;X.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThey declared the camp cleared shortly after 2 p.m., though Morton County Sheriff Kyle Kirchmeier said 15 protesters crossed the frozen Cannonball River on foot to the south bank. That land also is Corps-managed but is on the Standing Rock Reservation, where North Dakota authorities don&#8217;t have jurisdiction. They planned to station officers on the north shore to keep anyone from re-entering the camp.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBefore authorities moved in, Gov. Doug Burgum had said those remaining at the camp still had a chance to leave without facing charges. The state sent a bus to the site on Thursday to transport anyone to Bismarck, where officials were doling out basic necessities, along with hotel and bus vouchers.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENo one took advantage of the offer Thursday, and only nine people used the center Tuesday and Wednesday. The center was closed Thursday due to the lack of use, state Emergency Services spokeswoman Cecily Fong said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EEnergy Transfer Partners began work on the last big section of the oil pipeline this month after the Army gave it permission to lay pipe under a reservoir on the Missouri River. When complete, the pipeline will carry oil through the Dakotas and Iowa to a shipping point in Illinois.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["(CANNON BALL, N.D.) — Authorities on Thursday cleared a protest camp where opponents of the Dakota Access oil pipeline had gathered for the better part of a year, searching tents and huts and arresting three dozen holdouts who had defied a government order to leave."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["It took 3 ½ hours for about 220 officers and 18 National Guardsmen to methodically search the protesters' temporary homes and arrest people, including a man who climbed atop a building and stayed there for more than an hour before surrendering."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Native Americans who oppose the $3.8 billion pipeline established the Oceti Sakowin camp last April on federal land near the Standing Rock Indian Reservation to draw attention to their concerns that the project will hurt the environment and sacred sites — claims Dallas-based pipeline developer Energy Transfer Partners disputes. The camp gained increased attention starting in August after its population had grown and authorities made their first arrests. At its height, the camp included thousands of people, but the numbers had dwindled during the winter and as the fight over the pipeline moved into the courts."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The Army Corps of Engineers said it needed to clear the camp ahead of spring flooding, and had ordered everyone to leave by 2 p.m. Wednesday. The agency said it was concerned about protesters' safety and about the environmental effects of tents, cars, garbage and other items in the camp being washed into nearby rivers."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Most protesters left peacefully Wednesday, when authorities closed the camp, but some stayed overnight in defiance of the government order."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["As police in full riot gear worked to arrest the stragglers Thursday, cleanup crews began razing buildings on the square-mile piece of property at the confluence of the Cannonball and Missouri rivers."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Authorities chose to enter the camp \"cautiously and tactfully\" to ensure the safety of officers and protesters, according to Highway Patrol Lt. Tom Iverson. The arrests were a last resort, he said."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"We did not want this. Unfortunately, there were some bad actors that forced us into this position,\" he said."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Only one person resisted arrest; otherwise there were no major incidents, and there were no injuries, Morton County Sheriff Kyle Kirchmeier said."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Afterward, officers showed visible relief, smiling, shaking hands and patting one another on the back."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Guardsmen and officers entered the camp from two directions shortly before midday, alongside numerous law enforcement and military vehicles and with a helicopter and airplane overhead. As they checked and cleared buildings, they marked them with a fluorescent orange \"X.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["They declared the camp cleared shortly after 2 p.m., though Morton County Sheriff Kyle Kirchmeier said 15 protesters crossed the frozen Cannonball River on foot to the south bank. That land also is Corps-managed but is on the Standing Rock Reservation, where North Dakota authorities don't have jurisdiction. They planned to station officers on the north shore to keep anyone from re-entering the camp."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Before authorities moved in, Gov. Doug Burgum had said those remaining at the camp still had a chance to leave without facing charges. The state sent a bus to the site on Thursday to transport anyone to Bismarck, where officials were doling out basic necessities, along with hotel and bus vouchers."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["No one took advantage of the offer Thursday, and only nine people used the center Tuesday and Wednesday. The center was closed Thursday due to the lack of use, state Emergency Services spokeswoman Cecily Fong said."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Energy Transfer Partners began work on the last big section of the oil pipeline this month after the Army gave it permission to lay pipe under a reservoir on the Missouri River. When complete, the pipeline will carry oil through the Dakotas and Iowa to a shipping point in Illinois."]}],"plain":"(CANNON BALL, N.D.) &mdash; Authorities on Thursday cleared a protest camp where opponents of the Dakota Access oil pipeline had gathered for the better part of a year, searching tents and huts and arresting three dozen holdouts who had defied a government order to leave. It took 3 &frac12; hours for about 220 officers and 18 National Guardsmen to methodically search the protesters&#8217; temporary homes and arrest people, including a man who climbed atop a building and stayed there for more than an hour before surrendering. Native Americans who oppose the $3.8 billion pipeline established the Oceti Sakowin camp last April on federal land near the Standing Rock Indian Reservation to draw attention to their concerns that the project will hurt the environment and sacred sites &mdash; claims Dallas-based pipeline developer Energy Transfer Partners disputes. The camp gained increased attention starting in August after its population had grown and authorities made their first arrests. At its height, the camp included thousands of people, but the numbers had dwindled during the winter and as the fight over the pipeline moved into the courts. The Army Corps of Engineers said it needed to clear the camp ahead of spring flooding, and had ordered everyone to leave by 2 p.m. Wednesday. The agency said it was concerned about protesters&#8217; safety and about the environmental effects of tents, cars, garbage and other items in the camp being washed into nearby rivers. Most protesters left peacefully Wednesday, when authorities closed the camp, but some stayed overnight in defiance of the government order. As police in full riot gear worked to arrest the stragglers Thursday, cleanup crews began razing buildings on the square-mile piece of property at the confluence of the Cannonball and Missouri rivers. Authorities chose to enter the camp &#8220;cautiously and tactfully&#8221; to ensure the safety of officers and protesters, according to Highway Patrol Lt. Tom Iverson. The arrests were a last resort, he said. &#8220;We did not want this. Unfortunately, there were some bad actors that forced us into this position,&#8221; he said. Only one person resisted arrest; otherwise there were no major incidents, and there were no injuries, Morton County Sheriff Kyle Kirchmeier said. Afterward, officers showed visible relief, smiling, shaking hands and patting one another on the back. Guardsmen and officers entered the camp from two directions shortly before midday, alongside numerous law enforcement and military vehicles and with a helicopter and airplane overhead. As they checked and cleared buildings, they marked them with a fluorescent orange &#8220;X.&#8221; They declared the camp cleared shortly after 2 p.m., though Morton County Sheriff Kyle Kirchmeier said 15 protesters crossed the frozen Cannonball River on foot to the south bank. That land also is Corps-managed but is on the Standing Rock Reservation, where North Dakota authorities don&#8217;t have jurisdiction. They planned to station officers on the north shore to keep anyone from re-entering the camp. Before authorities moved in, Gov. Doug Burgum had said those remaining at the camp still had a chance to leave without facing charges. The state sent a bus to the site on Thursday to transport anyone to Bismarck, where officials were doling out basic necessities, along with hotel and bus vouchers. No one took advantage of the offer Thursday, and only nine people used the center Tuesday and Wednesday. The center was closed Thursday due to the lack of use, state Emergency Services spokeswoman Cecily Fong said. Energy Transfer Partners began work on the last big section of the oil pipeline this month after the Army gave it permission to lay pipe under a reservoir on the Missouri River. When complete, the pipeline will carry oil through the Dakotas and Iowa to a shipping point in Illinois."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E220 officers and 18 National Guardsmen searched temporary homes for holdouts\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":99245892,"featured_media":4681350,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[430941506,15103,430942904,430939235],"time_section":[204777754],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937772],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681344"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681344\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681344\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=4681344"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=4681344"},{"taxonomy":"topic","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftopics?post=4681344"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681344\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681344\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681344\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681344\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681344\u002Fauthors" It’s So Hard to Investigate the Recent Wave of Anti-Semitic Threats"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003ENearly 200 children and adults were at the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.stpauljcc.org\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ESt. Paul Jewish Community Center \u003C\u002Fa\u003Ein Minnesota &mdash; which offers swim lessons, community lectures and preschool classes &mdash; when the phone rang with a bomb threat on Monday morning. Students quickly evacuated to a nearby fire station, police officers swept the building and the center re-opened after no bombs were found. Days later, no one has been arrested.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003E&#8220;There&rsquo;s very little evidence on which to move forward,&#8221; said \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003ESteve Linders, a spokesman for the St. Paul Police Department. He\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003E said it&#8217;s not yet clear what phone number or device was used to make the threat.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe case illustrates the challenges faced by law enforcement officials and hate crime experts working to combat a wave of recent anti-Semitic incidents across the country.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E&#8220;Statistically, most of them are hoaxes. Realistically, you have to handle every one as if it&rsquo;s the real deal,&#8221; said James Mulvaney, an adjunct professor at John Jay College of Criminal Justice who previously worked with the New York Police Department&#8217;s hate crimes task force.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;The duty of a terrorist is to terrorize, and you can terrorize a community without actually causing damage but by just causing unrest,&#8221; Mulvaney said. &#8220;Any threats against these places is an act of terror because it scares the heck out of people &mdash; and it scares the heck out of people who have a history of being victimized.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"video-container\"\u003E\u003Cvideo id=\"brightcove-player-5331174059001\" data-video-id=\"5331174059001\" data-account=\"293884104\" data-player=\"SJa0Thl7\" data-embed=\"default\" autoplay controls preload=\"auto\" class=\"video-js responsive-video\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fvideo\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003EThere have been nearly 70 bomb threats at 53 Jewish Community Centers (JCCs) in the U.S. and Canada so far this year, according to the JCC Association of North America. Although it&#8217;s \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fbigstory.ap.org\u002Farticle\u002F0f03d4c012094f5aa3e56ceb3ac1bf15\u002Fevidence-rising-anti-semitism-data-mostly-elusive\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Edifficult to quantify\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, civil rights experts see those threats as part of a spike in \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4569129\u002Fracist-anti-semitic-incidents-donald-trump\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eracist and anti-Semitic incidents\u003C\u002Fa\u003E since the presidential election.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe Southern Poverty Law Center counted 1,094 bias-related incidents in the month following the election. But the center, which has long \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4671800\u002Fhate-groups-on-the-rise\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Etracked hate groups\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, has no way of comparing that figure to previous months because it only began tracking hate incidents after the election, when it was flooded with an &#8220;alarming&#8221; number of reports about racist and anti-Semitic incidents.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe Anti-Defamation League does not release its annual audit of hate incidents until all reports can be vetted, but the organization said it has been receiving more reports than usual this year.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EMore than 150 members of Congress on Wednesday \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fstephaniemurphy.house.gov\u002Fnews\u002Fdocumentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=41\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Esent a letter\u003C\u002Fa\u003E to the Department of Homeland Security, the Department of Justice and the FBI, urging authorities to &#8220;swiftly&#8221; investigate recent threats and prosecute the perpetrators. The FBI has said it is investigating &#8220;\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003Epossible civil rights violations in connection with threats to Jewish Community Centers across the country&#8221; and declined to comment further.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E&#8220;The reason they&rsquo;re so difficult is, indeed, because this is not 1980 where someone can just do a quick look and find where the call emanated from,&#8221; said Oren Segal, director \u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003Eof the ADL&#8217;s Center on Extremism\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E, noting that the internet and other forms of technology have made it easier for perpetrators to remain hidden.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EHe said the ADL, whose headquarters were targeted with a bomb threat on Wednesday, is working with the FBI to investigate the source.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E&#8220;They&rsquo;re extremely difficult to investigate, again, because they are perpetrated from a distance. The offender tends to remain anonymous, and hate crimes are difficult to identify in the first place,&#8221; said Jack Levin, a hate crimes expert and co-director of the \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.northeastern.edu\u002Fbrudnickcenter\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EBrudnick Center on Violence and Conflict \u003C\u002Fa\u003Eat Northeastern University.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E&#8220;Even if they never find the perpetrator, there are solutions that go beyond law enforcement,&#8221; Levin said, noting that the community and political leaders can offer support to those affected. He believes hate crime laws are also important because they can be a deterrent.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E&#8220;It&rsquo;s kind of like asking the impossible: How do you stop racism? If I knew the answer to the question &mdash; if anyone knew the answer to that question &mdash; the world would be a much better place,&#8221; said Ryan Lenz, editor of the Southern Poverty Law Center&#8217;s Hatewatch blog.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003ELenz said President Donald Trump&#8217;s \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4676837\u002Fdonald-trump-anti-semitism-threats\u002F?iid=sr-link1\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Edenunciation of anti-Semitism\u003C\u002Fa\u003E this week &mdash; and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4679604\u002Fmike-pence-condemns-cemetery-vandalism\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EVice President Mike Pence&#8217;s\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Evisit to a \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4679048\u002Fjewish-cemetery-vandalism-muslims-fundraiser\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Evandalized Jewish cemetery\u003C\u002Fa\u003E in St. Louis &mdash;\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E were important steps. But he thinks the threats deserve more attention.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E&#8220;I think it&rsquo;s important to recognize that something changed in this country after the election,&#8221; Lenz said. &#8220;This without a doubt is a new development.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003EMelissa Chan contributed reporting\u003C\u002Fem\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Nearly 200 children and adults were at the ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.stpauljcc.org\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["St. Paul Jewish Community Center "]},"in Minnesota — which offers swim lessons, community lectures and preschool classes — when the phone rang with a bomb threat on Monday morning. Students quickly evacuated to a nearby fire station, police officers swept the building and the center re-opened after no bombs were found. Days later, no one has been arrested."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"There’s very little evidence on which to move forward,\" said  Steve Linders, a spokesman for the St. Paul Police Department. The FBI has said it is investigating \" possible civil rights violations in connection with threats to Jewish Community Centers across the country\" and declined to comment further."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"The reason they’re so difficult is, indeed, because this is not 1980 where someone can just do a quick look and find where the call emanated from,\" said Oren Segal, director  of the ADL's Center on Extremism , noting that the internet and other forms of technology have made it easier for perpetrators to remain hidden."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["He said the ADL, whose headquarters were targeted with a bomb threat on Wednesday, is working with the FBI to investigate the source."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"They’re extremely difficult to investigate, again, because they are perpetrated from a distance. The offender tends to remain anonymous, and hate crimes are difficult to identify in the first place,\" said Jack Levin, a hate crimes expert and co-director of the ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.northeastern.edu\u002Fbrudnickcenter\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Brudnick Center on Violence and Conflict "]},"at Northeastern University."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"Even if they never find the perpetrator, there are solutions that go beyond law enforcement,\" Levin said, noting that the community and political leaders can offer support to those affected. He believes hate crime laws are also important because they can be a deterrent."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"It’s kind of like asking the impossible: How do you stop racism? If I knew the answer to the question — if anyone knew the answer to that question — the world would be a much better place,\" said Ryan Lenz, editor of the Southern Poverty Law Center's Hatewatch blog."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Lenz said President Donald Trump's ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4676837\u002Fdonald-trump-anti-semitism-threats\u002F?iid=sr-link1","target":"_blank"},"content":["denunciation of anti-Semitism"]}," this week — and ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4679604\u002Fmike-pence-condemns-cemetery-vandalism\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Vice President Mike Pence's"]},"  visit to a ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4679048\u002Fjewish-cemetery-vandalism-muslims-fundraiser\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["vandalized Jewish cemetery"]}," in St. Louis —  were important steps. But he thinks the threats deserve more attention."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"I think it’s important to recognize that something changed in this country after the election,\" Lenz said. \"This without a doubt is a new development.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Melissa Chan contributed reporting"]},"."]}],"plain":"Nearly 200 children and adults were at the St. Paul Jewish Community Center in Minnesota &mdash; which offers swim lessons, community lectures and preschool classes &mdash; when the phone rang with a bomb threat on Monday morning. Students quickly evacuated to a nearby fire station, police officers swept the building and the center re-opened after no bombs were found. Days later, no one has been arrested. &#8220;There&rsquo;s very little evidence on which to move forward,&#8221; said Steve Linders, a spokesman for the St. Paul Police Department. He said it&#8217;s not yet clear what phone number or device was used to make the threat. The case illustrates the challenges faced by law enforcement officials and hate crime experts working to combat a wave of recent anti-Semitic incidents across the country. &#8220;Statistically, most of them are hoaxes. Realistically, you have to handle every one as if it&rsquo;s the real deal,&#8221; said James Mulvaney, an adjunct professor at John Jay College of Criminal Justice who previously worked with the New York Police Department&#8217;s hate crimes task force. &#8220;The duty of a terrorist is to terrorize, and you can terrorize a community without actually causing damage but by just causing unrest,&#8221; Mulvaney said. &#8220;Any threats against these places is an act of terror because it scares the heck out of people &mdash; and it scares the heck out of people who have a history of being victimized.&#8221; There have been nearly 70 bomb threats at 53 Jewish Community Centers (JCCs) in the U.S. and Canada so far this year, according to the JCC Association of North America. Although it&#8217;s difficult to quantify, civil rights experts see those threats as part of a spike in racist and anti-Semitic incidents since the presidential election. The Southern Poverty Law Center counted 1,094 bias-related incidents in the month following the election. But the center, which has long tracked hate groups, has no way of comparing that figure to previous months because it only began tracking hate incidents after the election, when it was flooded with an &#8220;alarming&#8221; number of reports about racist and anti-Semitic incidents. The Anti-Defamation League does not release its annual audit of hate incidents until all reports can be vetted, but the organization said it has been receiving more reports than usual this year. More than 150 members of Congress on Wednesday sent a letter to the Department of Homeland Security, the Department of Justice and the FBI, urging authorities to &#8220;swiftly&#8221; investigate recent threats and prosecute the perpetrators. The FBI has said it is investigating &#8220;possible civil rights violations in connection with threats to Jewish Community Centers across the country&#8221; and declined to comment further. &#8220;The reason they&rsquo;re so difficult is, indeed, because this is not 1980 where someone can just do a quick look and find where the call emanated from,&#8221; said Oren Segal, director of the ADL&#8217;s Center on Extremism, noting that the internet and other forms of technology have made it easier for perpetrators to remain hidden. He said the ADL, whose headquarters were targeted with a bomb threat on Wednesday, is working with the FBI to investigate the source. &#8220;They&rsquo;re extremely difficult to investigate, again, because they are perpetrated from a distance. The offender tends to remain anonymous, and hate crimes are difficult to identify in the first place,&#8221; said Jack Levin, a hate crimes expert and co-director of the Brudnick Center on Violence and Conflict at Northeastern University. &#8220;Even if they never find the perpetrator, there are solutions that go beyond law enforcement,&#8221; Levin said, noting that the community and political leaders can offer support to those affected. He believes hate crime laws are also important because they can be a deterrent. &#8220;It&rsquo;s kind of like asking the impossible: How do you stop racism? If I knew the answer to the question &mdash; if anyone knew the answer to that question &mdash; the world would be a much better place,&#8221; said Ryan Lenz, editor of the Southern Poverty Law Center&#8217;s Hatewatch blog. Lenz said President Donald Trump&#8217;s denunciation of anti-Semitism this week &mdash; and Vice President Mike Pence&#8217;s visit to a vandalized Jewish cemetery in St. Louis &mdash; were important steps. But he thinks the threats deserve more attention. &#8220;I think it&rsquo;s important to recognize that something changed in this country after the election,&#8221; Lenz said. &#8220;This without a doubt is a new development.&#8221; Melissa Chan contributed reporting."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EJewish Community Centers across the country have faced bomb
