","credit":"Robert Cohen—St. Louis Post-Dispatch\u002FAP","title":"Cemetery Vandalized-Missouri"},"video":[],"structured":false}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":57280,"name":"anti-semitism","slug":"anti-semitism","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":5620,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":27,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":204777754,"name":"U.S.","slug":"us","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":16,"taxonomy":"time_section","description":"The latest news and analysis on crime, religion, education, transportation, weather, immigration, sports, drugs, the law, and other news from around the nation","parent":0,"count":11631,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["us"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4680821,"date":"2017-02-23T13:43:28","date_gmt":"2017-02-23T18:43:28","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4680821"},"modified":"2017-02-23T13:39:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-23T18:39:00","slug":"california-evacuees-return-home","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4680821\u002Fcalifornia-evacuees-return-home\u002F","title":{"rendered":"Thousands of California Evacuees Return Home After Major Floods"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E(SAN JOSE, Calif.) &mdash; Thousands of people evacuated from a flood in San Jose, California, returned home Thursday amid warnings to be careful about hygiene and handling food that may have come into contact with flood water.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;The water is not safe,&#8221; Mayor Sam Liccardo said. &#8220;There is contamination in this water and the contamination runs the gamut.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOfficials also hoped to rescue more than two dozen horses from ranches if the water recedes enough.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAbout two-thirds of the 14,000 residents evacuated two days ago were being allowed to return home while 3,800 people remain under a mandatory evacuation order issued when a creek overflowed following heavy rains and sent waist-high water into neighborhoods.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThose who went home were sorting through waterlogged furniture, toys and clothing after the creek water carrying engine fuel and sewage swamped their homes.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EVictor Chen, his two children, and his wife returned home after being evacuated Tuesday night.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;It&#8217;s really tough to see. A home is all we worked for, and our family is all here,&#8221; Chen, 42, told the San Francisco Chronicle. &#8220;And we had to leave it behind when the water was rising.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELiccardo acknowledged that the city failed to properly notify residents to evacuate early Wednesday, Some people said they got their first notice by seeing firefighters in boats in the neighborhood.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;We are assessing what happened in that failure,&#8221; he said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFlood warnings were in place until Saturday because waterways were overtaxed.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe city began alerting residents of the flood situation on Tuesday via social and mainstream media and sending emergency alerts to those who had signed up for it, city spokesman David Vossbrink said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhen water levels changed dramatically overnight, they sent police and firefighters door-to-door during the dramatic overnight evacuation.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESeveral residents faulted the city for failing to provide proper warnings.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;The city dropped the ball on making sure that people were notified of the potential impact of this flood,&#8221; said resident Jean-Marie White, whose house and backyard were flooded. &#8220;Nobody had any clue.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAssistant San Jose City Manager Dave Sykes said officials first became aware of the rising water late Tuesday when firefighters began evacuating about 400 people from a low-lying residential area.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ECity officials did not believe the waters would spread to other neighborhoods and did not expand the evacuation orders.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["(SAN JOSE, Calif.) — Thousands of people evacuated from a flood in San Jose, California, returned home Thursday amid warnings to be careful about hygiene and handling food that may have come into contact with flood water."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"The water is not safe,\" Mayor Sam Liccardo said. \"There is contamination in this water and the contamination runs the gamut.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Officials also hoped to rescue more than two dozen horses from ranches if the water recedes enough."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["About two-thirds of the 14,000 residents evacuated two days ago were being allowed to return home while 3,800 people remain under a mandatory evacuation order issued when a creek overflowed following heavy rains and sent waist-high water into neighborhoods."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Those who went home were sorting through waterlogged furniture, toys and clothing after the creek water carrying engine fuel and sewage swamped their homes."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Victor Chen, his two children, and his wife returned home after being evacuated Tuesday night."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"It's really tough to see. A home is all we worked for, and our family is all here,\" Chen, 42, told the San Francisco Chronicle. \"And we had to leave it behind when the water was rising.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Liccardo acknowledged that the city failed to properly notify residents to evacuate early Wednesday, Some people said they got their first notice by seeing firefighters in boats in the neighborhood."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"We are assessing what happened in that failure,\" he said."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Flood warnings were in place until Saturday because waterways were overtaxed."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The city began alerting residents of the flood situation on Tuesday via social and mainstream media and sending emergency alerts to those who had signed up for it, city spokesman David Vossbrink said."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["When water levels changed dramatically overnight, they sent police and firefighters door-to-door during the dramatic overnight evacuation."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Several residents faulted the city for failing to provide proper warnings."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"The city dropped the ball on making sure that people were notified of the potential impact of this flood,\" said resident Jean-Marie White, whose house and backyard were flooded. \"Nobody had any clue.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Assistant San Jose City Manager Dave Sykes said officials first became aware of the rising water late Tuesday when firefighters began evacuating about 400 people from a low-lying residential area."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["City officials did not believe the waters would spread to other neighborhoods and did not expand the evacuation orders."]}],"plain":"(SAN JOSE, Calif.) &mdash; Thousands of people evacuated from a flood in San Jose, California, returned home Thursday amid warnings to be careful about hygiene and handling food that may have come into contact with flood water. &#8220;The water is not safe,&#8221; Mayor Sam Liccardo said. &#8220;There is contamination in this water and the contamination runs the gamut.&#8221; Officials also hoped to rescue more than two dozen horses from ranches if the water recedes enough. About two-thirds of the 14,000 residents evacuated two days ago were being allowed to return home while 3,800 people remain under a mandatory evacuation order issued when a creek overflowed following heavy rains and sent waist-high water into neighborhoods. Those who went home were sorting through waterlogged furniture, toys and clothing after the creek water carrying engine fuel and sewage swamped their homes. Victor Chen, his two children, and his wife returned home after being evacuated Tuesday night. &#8220;It&#8217;s really tough to see. A home is all we worked for, and our family is all here,&#8221; Chen, 42, told the San Francisco Chronicle. &#8220;And we had to leave it behind when the water was rising.&#8221; Liccardo acknowledged that the city failed to properly notify residents to evacuate early Wednesday, Some people said they got their first notice by seeing firefighters in boats in the neighborhood. &#8220;We are assessing what happened in that failure,&#8221; he said. Flood warnings were in place until Saturday because waterways were overtaxed. The city began alerting residents of the flood situation on Tuesday via social and mainstream media and sending emergency alerts to those who had signed up for it, city spokesman David Vossbrink said. When water levels changed dramatically overnight, they sent police and firefighters door-to-door during the dramatic overnight evacuation. Several residents faulted the city for failing to provide proper warnings. &#8220;The city dropped the ball on making sure that people were notified of the potential impact of this flood,&#8221; said resident Jean-Marie White, whose house and backyard were flooded. &#8220;Nobody had any clue.&#8221; Assistant San Jose City Manager Dave Sykes said officials first became aware of the rising water late Tuesday when firefighters began evacuating about 400 people from a low-lying residential area. City officials did not believe the waters would spread to other neighborhoods and did not expand the evacuation orders."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EResidents were warned about potential A Border Patrol agent, meantime, testified that Sarah told him she had come to the United States for work."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Although Sara was detained in 2015, her case has ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4674729\u002Fimmigrations-church-sensitive-policy-concerns\u002F"},"content":["gotten renewed attention"]}," because of ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4676959\u002Fdonald-trump-deportation-rules-undocumented\u002F"},"content":["recent executive orders"]}," from the Trump Administration aimed at increasing deportations."]}],"plain":"Law enforcement officials moved a 26-year-old woman from a Texas hospital where she was being treated for a brain tumor back to a detention facility against her will, according to her legal representative. The undocumented El Salvadoran woman, who is being identified only as Sara to protect her privacy, began complaining of headaches while in a detention facility in early February, according to The Daily Beast, which first reported the story. On Feb. 10, she collapsed, and she was later taken to a hospital, where she was diagnosed with a brain tumor. Melissa Zuniga, a paralegal who is working on the case, said in an email that Sara told her on Wednesday night that she had been taken back to a detention facility with her hands and ankles in restraints. &#8220;She was brought in a wheelchair and is not being given treatment even though her nose continues to bleed and she has told them her head is exploding,&#8221; Zuniga said in an email. According to The Daily Beast, Sara admitted to crossing the border illegally in November of 2015 but claimed she had done so because she feared an aunt in El Salvador would kill her. A Border Patrol agent, meantime, testified that Sarah told him she had come to the United States for work. Although Sara was detained in 2015, her case has gotten renewed attention because of recent executive orders from the Trump Administration aimed at increasing deportations."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003ELaw enforcement officials moved a 26-year-old woman from a Texas hospital where she was being treated for a brain tumor back to a detention facility against her will, according to her legal representative. Lewis, who was charged with a misdemeanor count of culpable negligence, faces up to 60 days in jail."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Steve Knowlton, one of Mary Knowlton’s two sons, told TIME in August that he was struggling with his anger toward the officer who shot his mother, because she taught him not to “harbor hate.”"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["“I know the police officer didn’t intentionally do it, but it just feels like our souls got ripped out of our chest,” he said at the time. “It just turned everything upside down.”"]}],"plain":"A Florida police chief has been charged with negligence and one of his officers was charged with manslaughter six months after a 73-year-old woman was accidentally shot dead during a civilian police academy course. Punta Gorda Police Chief Tom Lewis and police officer Lee Coel, who fatally fired at Mary Knowlton, both face charges in the August 2016 shooting, prosecutors said Wednesday. Knowlton, a longtime librarian, was participating in a role-playing exercise at the Punta Gorda, Fla. police station when Coel &#8220;mistakenly&#8221; shot her, authorities said at the time. The exercise was meant to teach students when to shoot and when not to shoot during lethal force situations. Coel, 28, could receive up to 30 years in prison for the felony manslaughter charge, according to the Naples Daily News. His lawyer, Jerry Berry, said Coel didn&rsquo;t know the gun had live ammunition in it, WINK News reported. Lewis, who was charged with a misdemeanor count of culpable negligence, faces up to 60 days in jail. Steve Knowlton, one of Mary Knowlton&rsquo;s two sons, told TIME in August that he was struggling with his anger toward the officer who shot his mother, because she taught him not to &ldquo;harbor hate.&rdquo; &ldquo;I know the police officer didn&rsquo;t intentionally do it, but it just feels like our souls got ripped out of our chest,&rdquo; he said at the time. &ldquo;It just turned everything upside down.&rdquo;"},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EThe woman was mistakenly shot dead last year during a civilian police Email Morning Brief writer Melissa Chan at ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"mailto:melissa.chan@time.com","target":"_blank"},"content":["melissa.chan@time.com"]},"."]}]}],"plain":"Good morning. These are today&rsquo;s top stories: Conservative Political Action Conference begins This year&rsquo;s Conservative Political Action Conference kicks off today in Maryland. The event, which ends Saturday, will feature remarks from leaders of the conservative movement and the Trump administration, including Vice President Mike Pence, White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus and Senior Counselor Steve Bannon. President Trump rescinds bathroom rules for transgender students President Donald Trump&rsquo;s Administration has retracted guidelines created under President Barack Obama that said schools across the country had to allow transgender students to use public bathrooms that aligned with their identified gender. The Obama directive &ldquo;did not contain sufficient legal analysis,&rdquo; Attorney General Jeff Sessions said in a statement as one of the reasons for the change. North Korea says it didn&rsquo;t kill Kim Jong Un&#8217;s half-brother North Korea claims it had nothing to do with the mysterious death of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un&rsquo;s estranged half-brother Kim Jong Nam. Nam was killed in Malaysia last week. NASA finds habitable Earth-like planets NASA has discovered, for the first time ever, seven Earth-size planets outside our solar system that could be suitable for life. The exoplanets orbit a single star relatively close to Earth. &#8220;I think that we&#8217;ve made a crucial step towards finding if there is life out there,&#8221; University of Cambridge astronomer Amaury Triaud, one of the researchers, told reporters after the space agency made its announcement. Katy Perry appears to mock Trump at BRIT Awards Pop star Katy Perry performed her latest single Chained to the Rhythm at yesterday&rsquo;s BRIT Awards, considered the British version of the Grammys. Social media users were quick to compare two dancing skeleton props she used onstage to Trump and U.K. Prime Minister Theresa May. Also: A former USA Gymnastics doctor has been charged with sexual assault. Hundreds of people protested in Anaheim, Calif. after a purported police gunfire video went viral. Muslim-Americans helped raise more than $113,000 to help a vandalized Jewish cemetery repair hundreds of gravesites. Cats don&rsquo;t increase your risk for developing mental health problems, a new study has found. McDonald&#8217;s will sell $1 sodas of any size starting in April. The Morning Brief is published Mondays through Fridays. Email Morning Brief writer Melissa Chan at melissa.chan@time.com."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EHere&#8217;s what&#8217;s going on in the news ney_article?categories=1"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[{"id":430939235,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Ftag\u002Fonetime\u002F","name":"onetime","slug":"onetime","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags\u002F430939235"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fpost_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?tags=430939235"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=430939235"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":430951269,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Ftag\u002Fthe-morning-brief\u002F","name":"the morning nation","parent":0,"count":11631,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["us"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4679987,"date":"2017-02-23T08:20:28","date_gmt":"2017-02-23T13:20:28","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4679987"},"modified":"2017-02-23T11:08:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-23T16:08:00","slug":"donald-trump-immigrants-deportation","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4679987\u002Fdonald-trump-immigrants-deportation\u002F","title":{"rendered":"Immigrants Are Changing Their Routines to Avoid Deportation Under President Trump"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EIn Orange County, California, dozens of immigrant parents have signed legal documents authorizing friends and relatives to pick up their children from school and access their bank accounts to pay their bills in the event they are arrested by immigration agents.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn Philadelphia, immigrants are carrying around wallet-size &#8220;Know Your Rights&#8221; guides in Spanish and English that explain what to do if they&#8217;re rounded up.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAnd in New York, 23-year-old Zuleima Dominguez and other members of her Mexican family are careful about answering the door and start making worried phone calls when someone doesn&#8217;t come home on time.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAround the country, President Donald Trump&#8217;s efforts to crack down on the estimated 11 million immigrants living illegally in the U.S. have spread fear and anxiety and led many people to brace for arrest and to change up their daily routines in hopes of not getting caught.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn El Paso, Texas, Carmen Ramos and her friends have developed a network to keep each other updated via text messages on where immigration checkpoints have been set up.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EShe said she also is making certain everything she does is in order at all times. She checks her taillights before leaving the house to make sure they are working. She won&#8217;t speed and keeps a close eye on her surroundings.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;We are surprised that even a ticket can get us back to Mexico,&#8221; said the 41-year-old Ramos, who with her husband and three children left Ciudad Juarez because of drug violence and death threats in 2008 and entered the U.S. on tourist visas that have since expired. &#8220;We wouldn&#8217;t have anywhere to return.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAn undocumented Guatemalan migrant mother and her son have called an Austin, Texas, church home for more than a year. Hilda Ramirez says they were fleeing the danger of their country and were caught by immigration authorities as they illegally crossed the border at Texas in 2014. After they were released from a holding facility, a pastor allowed them to live on church grounds.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe unease among immigrants has been building but intensified in recent weeks with ever-clearer signs that the Trump administration would jettison the Obama-era policy of focusing mostly on deporting those who had committed serious crimes.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe administration announced Tuesday that any immigrant in the country illegally who is charged with or convicted of any offense, or even suspected of a crime, will now be an enforcement priority. That could include people arrested for shoplifting or other minor offenses, or those who simply crossed the border illegally.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESome husbands and wives fear spouses who lack legal papers could be taken away. And many worry that parents will be separated from their U.S.-born children.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDozens of immigrants have been turning up at an advocacy group&#8217;s offices in Philadelphia, asking questions like, &#8220;Who will take care of my children if I am deported?&#8221; They also are coached on how to develop a &#8220;deportation plan&#8221; that includes the name and number of an attorney and other emergency contacts in case of arrest.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAn organization in Austin, Texas, that runs a deportation hotline said it normally would receive one or two calls every few days. After recent immigration raids, the phone rang off the hook.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;We got over 1,000 phone calls in three days about the raids,&#8221; said Cristina Parker, immigration programs director for Grassroots Leadership. &#8220;And certainly a lot of those were people who wanted information about the raids saying, &#8216;I&#8217;m scared, I&#8217;m worried, what can I do?&#8217;&#8230; A lot of them were people who were impacted by the raids who saw a friend or family be taken.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EImmigrants in the Chicago area have said they are scared to drive, and some are even wary of taking public transit. When Chicago police and federal authorities conducted regular safety checks on a train line earlier this month, many assumed it was an immigration checkpoint.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWord spread so quickly that Chicago police issued a statement assuring immigrants, &#8220;You are welcome here.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn Arizona, immigrant Abril Gallardo said the policies have prompted new conversations with her parents and siblings. Her father, who&#8217;s in the country illegally, made sure all the taillights work in the van he drives to his construction job in the Phoenix area. They look through the window if anyone knocks.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHer brother is getting married this weekend, and immigrant friends were reluctant to drive to the bridal shower.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;We have a regular life, but with this new executive order, anyone, just for the fact that you&#8217;re here, you can become a priority,&#8221; said Gallardo, 26, who is in the U.S. with permission under the Obama administration policy for people who entered illegally as children.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn the Bronx, Dominguez, a college student protected from deportation under the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, is looking into what she needs to do to raise her American-born brother and sister, ages 6 and 11, if their parents are deported.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhen Dominguez goes out, she tells the others where she is going, with whom, and when she will be home, and expects the same from her parents and siblings. If someone is late getting home, she said, &#8220;we start calling.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In Orange County, California, dozens of immigrant parents have signed legal documents authorizing friends and relatives to pick up their children from school and access their bank accounts to pay their bills in the event they are arrested by immigration agents."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In Philadelphia, immigrants are carrying around wallet-size \"Know Your Rights\" guides in Spanish and English that explain what to do if they're rounded up."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["And in New York, 23-year-old Zuleima Dominguez and other members of her Mexican family are careful about answering the door and start making worried phone calls when someone doesn't come home on time."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Around the country, President Donald Trump's efforts to crack down on the estimated 11 million immigrants living illegally in the U.S. have spread fear and anxiety and led many people to brace for arrest and to change up their daily routines in hopes of not getting caught."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In El Paso, Texas, Carmen Ramos and her friends have developed a network to keep each other updated via text messages on where immigration checkpoints have been set up."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["She said she also is making certain everything she does is in order at all times. She checks her taillights before leaving the house to make sure they are working. She won't speed and keeps a close eye on her surroundings."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"We are surprised that even a ticket can get us back to Mexico,\" said the 41-year-old Ramos, who with her husband and three children left Ciudad Juarez because of drug violence and death threats in 2008 and entered the U.S. on tourist visas that have since expired. \"We wouldn't have anywhere to return.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["An undocumented Guatemalan migrant mother and her son have called an Austin, Texas, church home for more than a year. Hilda Ramirez says they were fleeing the danger of their country and were caught by immigration authorities as they illegally crossed the border at Texas in 2014. After they were released from a holding facility, a pastor allowed them to live on church grounds."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The unease among immigrants has been building but intensified in recent weeks with ever-clearer signs that the Trump administration would jettison the Obama-era policy of focusing mostly on deporting those who had committed serious crimes."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The administration announced Tuesday that any immigrant in the country illegally who is charged with or convicted of any offense, or even suspected of a crime, will now be an enforcement priority. That could include people arrested for shoplifting or other minor offenses, or those who simply crossed the border illegally."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Some husbands and wives fear spouses who lack legal papers could be taken away. And many worry that parents will be separated from their U.S.-born children."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Dozens of immigrants have been turning up at an advocacy group's offices in Philadelphia, asking questions like, \"Who will take care of my children if I am deported?\" They also are coached on how to develop a \"deportation plan\" that includes the name and number of an attorney and other emergency contacts in case of arrest."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["An organization in Austin, Texas, that runs a deportation hotline said it normally would receive one or two calls every few days. After recent immigration raids, the phone rang off the hook."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"We got over 1,000 phone calls in three days about the raids,\" said Cristina Parker, immigration programs director for Grassroots Leadership. \"And certainly a lot of those were people who wanted information about the raids saying, 'I'm scared, I'm worried, what can I do?'... A lot of them were people who were impacted by the raids who saw a friend or family be taken.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Immigrants in the Chicago area have said they are scared to drive, and some are even wary of taking public transit. When Chicago police and federal authorities conducted regular safety checks on a train line earlier this month, many assumed it was an immigration checkpoint."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Word spread so quickly that Chicago police issued a statement assuring immigrants, \"You are welcome here.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In Arizona, immigrant Abril Gallardo said the policies have prompted new conversations with her parents and siblings. Her father, who's in the country illegally, made sure all the taillights work in the van he drives to his construction job in the Phoenix area. They look through the window if anyone knocks."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Her brother is getting married this weekend, and immigrant friends were reluctant to drive to the bridal shower."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"We have a regular life, but with this new executive order, anyone, just for the fact that you're here, you can become a priority,\" said Gallardo, 26, who is in the U.S. with permission under the Obama administration policy for people who entered illegally as children."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In the Bronx, Dominguez, a college student protected from deportation under the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, is looking into what she needs to do to raise her American-born brother and sister, ages 6 and 11, if their parents are deported."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["When Dominguez goes out, she tells the others where she is going, with whom, and when she will be home, and expects the same from her parents and siblings. If someone is late getting home, she said, \"we start calling.\""]}],"plain":"In Orange County, California, dozens of immigrant parents have signed legal documents authorizing friends and relatives to pick up their children from school and access their bank accounts to pay their bills in the event they are arrested by immigration agents. In Philadelphia, immigrants are carrying around wallet-size &#8220;Know Your Rights&#8221; guides in Spanish and English that explain what to do if they&#8217;re rounded up. And in New York, 23-year-old Zuleima Dominguez and other members of her Mexican family are careful about answering the door and start making worried phone calls when someone doesn&#8217;t come home on time. Around the country, President Donald Trump&#8217;s efforts to crack down on the estimated 11 million immigrants living illegally in the U.S. have spread fear and anxiety and led many people to brace for arrest and to change up their daily routines in hopes of not getting caught. In El Paso, Texas, Carmen Ramos and her friends have developed a network to keep each other updated via text messages on where immigration checkpoints have been set up. She said she also is making certain everything she does is in order at all times. She checks her taillights before leaving the house to make sure they are working. She won&#8217;t speed and keeps a close eye on her surroundings. &#8220;We are surprised that even a ticket can get us back to Mexico,&#8221; said the 41-year-old Ramos, who with her husband and three children left Ciudad Juarez because of drug violence and death threats in 2008 and entered the U.S. on tourist visas that have since expired. &#8220;We wouldn&#8217;t have anywhere to return.&#8221; An undocumented Guatemalan migrant mother and her son have called an Austin, Texas, church home for more than a year. Hilda Ramirez says they were fleeing the danger of their country and were caught by immigration authorities as they illegally crossed the border at Texas in 2014. After they were released from a holding facility, a pastor allowed them to live on church grounds. The unease among immigrants has been building but intensified in recent weeks with ever-clearer signs that the Trump administration would jettison the Obama-era policy of focusing mostly on deporting those who had committed serious crimes. The administration announced Tuesday that any immigrant in the country illegally who is charged with or convicted of any offense, or even suspected of a crime, will now be an enforcement priority. That could include people arrested for shoplifting or other minor offenses, or those who simply crossed the border illegally. Some husbands and wives fear spouses who lack legal papers could be taken away. And many worry that parents will be separated from their U.S.-born children. Dozens of immigrants have been turning up at an advocacy group&#8217;s offices in Philadelphia, asking questions like, &#8220;Who will take care of my children if I am deported?&#8221; They also are coached on how to develop a &#8220;deportation plan&#8221; that includes the name and number of an attorney and other emergency contacts in case of arrest. An organization in Austin, Texas, that runs a deportation hotline said it normally would receive one or two calls every few days. After recent immigration raids, the phone rang off the hook. &#8220;We got over 1,000 phone calls in three days about the raids,&#8221; said Cristina Parker, immigration programs director for Grassroots Leadership. &#8220;And certainly a lot of those were people who wanted information about the raids saying, &#8216;I&#8217;m scared, I&#8217;m worried, what can I do?&#8217;&#8230; A lot of them were people who were impacted by the raids who saw a friend or family be taken.&#8221; Immigrants in the Chicago area have said they are scared to drive, and some are even wary of taking public transit. When Chicago police and federal authorities conducted regular safety checks on a train line earlier this month, many assumed it was an immigration checkpoint. Word spread so quickly that Chicago police issued a statement assuring immigrants, &#8220;You are welcome here.&#8221; In Arizona, immigrant Abril Gallardo said the policies have prompted new conversations with her parents and siblings. Her father, who&#8217;s in the country illegally, made sure all the taillights work in the van he drives to his construction job in the Phoenix area. They look through the window if anyone knocks. Her brother is getting married this weekend, and immigrant friends were reluctant to drive to the bridal shower. &#8220;We have a regular life, but with this new executive order, anyone, just for the fact that you&#8217;re here, you can become a priority,&#8221; said Gallardo, 26, who is in the U.S. with permission under the Obama administration policy for people who entered illegally as children. In the Bronx, Dominguez, a college student protected from deportation under the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, is looking into what she needs to do to raise her American-born brother and sister, ages 6 and 11, if their parents are deported. When Dominguez goes out, she tells the others where she is going, with whom, and when she will be home, and expects the same from her parents and siblings. If someone is late getting home, she said, &#8220;we start calling.&#8221;"},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EMany are afraid to drive or answer the The L.A. Times says that no one was injured during the incident, but many found the behavior depicted unacceptable and flooded the Anaheim police department with complaints, prompting an investigation into the officer&#8217;s alleged actions. At least two protesters were detained after police ordered the crowd to disperse, the Times reports. About 300 people had joined the march, which ended in a brief confrontation between police and demonstrators. Most marched peacefully, some chanting &#8220;Hands up, don&#8217;t shoot!&#8221; and &#8220;Whose streets? Our streets!&#8221; A few threw rocks and cursed at police. The Times quoted LAPD spokesman Capt. Andy Neiman as saying that the officer reportedly shown in the video had been pulled from duty for 72 hours. Such suspensions are standard practice after a gun has been fired. Anaheim Police Chief Raul Quezada is expected to brief the press Thursday afternoon with regard to the investigation. [L.A. ","credit":"Joshua Sudock—AP","title":"Police Gunshot Video"},"video":[],"structured":false}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":46227,"name":"Law Enforcement","slug":"law-enforcement","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":2577,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":83,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":204777754,"name":"U.S.","slug":"us","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":16,"taxonomy":"time_section","description":"The latest news and analysis on crime, religion, education, transportation, weather, immigration, sports, drugs, the law, and other news from around the nation","parent":0,"count":11631,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["us"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4679883,"date":"2017-02-23T04:28:01","date_gmt":"2017-02-23T09:28:01","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4679883"},"modified":"2017-02-23T04:28:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-23T09:28:00","slug":"immigration-donald-trump-deportations","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4679883\u002Fimmigration-donald-trump-deportations\u002F","title":{"rendered":"Undocumented Immigrants Across the U.S. Are Bracing for Trump's Deportation Crackdown"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EIn Orange County, Calif., dozens of immigrant parents have signed legal documents authorizing friends and relatives to pick up their children from school and access their bank accounts to pay their bills in the event they are arrested by immigration agents.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn Philadelphia, immigrants are carrying around wallet-size &#8220;Know Your Rights&#8221; guides in Spanish and English that explain what to do if they&#8217;re rounded up.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAnd in New York, 23-year-old Zuleima Dominguez and other members of her Mexican family are careful about answering the door and start making worried phone calls when someone doesn&#8217;t come home on time.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ERead More:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003E \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4672992\u002Ftrumps-immigration-crackdown-seems-designed-to-spread-fear\u002F\"\u003ETrump&#8217;s Immigration Crackdown Seems Designed to Spread Fear\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAround the country, President Donald Trump&#8217;s efforts to crack down on the estimated 11 million immigrants living illegally in the U.S. have spread fear and anxiety and led many people to brace for arrest and to change up their daily routines in hopes of not getting caught.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn El Paso, Texas, Carmen Ramos and her friends have developed a network to keep each other updated via text messages on where immigration checkpoints have been set up.She said she also is making certain everything she does is in order at all times. She checks her taillights before leaving the house to make sure they are working. She won&#8217;t speed and keeps a close eye on her surroundings.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;We are surprised that even a ticket can get us back to Mexico,&#8221; said the 41-year-old Ramos, who with her husband and three children left Ciudad Juarez because of drug violence and death threats in 2008 and entered the U.S. on tourist visas that have since expired. &#8220;We wouldn&#8217;t have anywhere to return.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ERead More:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4674729\u002Fimmigrations-church-sensitive-policy-concerns\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003EImmigration Agents Arrested Men Outside a Church. But Officials Say It Was Just a Coincidence\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe unease among immigrants has been building for months but intensified in recent weeks with ever-clearer signs that the Trump administration would jettison the Obama-era policy of focusing mostly on deporting those who had committed serious crimes.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe administration announced Tuesday that any immigrant in the country illegally who is charged with or convicted of any offense, or even suspected of a crime, will now be an enforcement priority. That could include people arrested for shoplifting or other minor offenses, or those who simply crossed the border illegally.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESome husbands and wives fear spouses who lack legal papers could be taken away. And many worry that parents will be separated from their U.S.-born children.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-custom-size aligncenter \"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"4679929\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4679883\u002Fimmigration-donald-trump-deportations\u002Fimmigration-enforcement-fears\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fimmigration-enforceme_wong.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"5244,3474\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{\"aperture\":\"2.2\",\"credit\":\"Gregory Bull\",\"camera\":\"Canon EOS-1D X Mark II\",\"caption\":\"Mr. Lane, who did not give his first name, stands over a pile of documents on the dining room table as one of his children pass, right, in their home Wednesday, Feb. 22, 2017, in San Diego. The Lane family has been on edge since President Donald Trump took office. The mother, a Mexican who is in the country illegally, now carries her birth and marriage certificates and other documents wherever she goes. Around the country, Trump's efforts to crack down on the estimated 11 million immigrants living illegally in the U.S. have spread fear and anxiety and led many people to brace for arrest and to change up their daily routines in hopes of not getting caught. (AP Photo\\\u002FGregory Bull)\",\"created_timestamp\":\"1487820619\",\"copyright\":\"AP\",\"focal_length\":\"24\",\"iso\":\"4000\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0.0025\",\"title\":\"Immigration Enforcement Fears\",\"orientation\":\"1\"}\" data-image-title=\"Immigration Enforcement Fears\" data-image-description=\"\u003Cp\u003EMr. Lane, who did not give his first name, stands over a pile of documents on the dining room table as one of his children pass, right, in their home Wednesday, Feb. 22, 2017, in San Diego. \u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fimmigration-enforceme_wong.jpg?quality=85&w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fimmigration-enforceme_wong.jpg?quality=85&w=600\" class=\" wp-image-4679929\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fimmigration-enforceme_wong.jpg?w=300&quality=85&w=569\" alt=\"Immigration Enforcement Fears\" width=\"569\" height=\"377\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\" style=\"max-width:569px\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\" \u003EGregory Bull&mdash;AP \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"caption\" \u003EMr. Lane, who did not give his first name, stands over a pile of documents on the dining room table as one of his children pass, in their home Feb. 22, 2017, in San Diego. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDozens of immigrants have been turning up at an advocacy group&#8217;s offices in Philadelphia, asking questions like, &#8220;Who will take care of my children if I am deported?&#8221; They also are coached on how to develop a &#8220;deportation plan&#8221; that includes the name and number of an attorney and other emergency contacts in case of arrest.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAn organization in Austin, Texas, that runs a deportation hotline said it normally would receive one or two calls every few days. After recent immigration raids, the phone rang off the hook.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;We got over 1,000 phone calls in three days about the raids,&#8221; said Cristina Parker, immigration programs director for Grassroots Leadership. &#8220;And certainly a lot of those were people who wanted information about the raids saying, &#8216;I&#8217;m scared, I&#8217;m worried, what can I do?&#8217;&#8230; A lot of them were people who were impacted by the raids who saw a friend or family be taken.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EImmigrants in the Chicago area have said they are scared to drive, and some are even wary of taking public transit. When Chicago police and federal authorities conducted regular safety checks on a train line earlier this month, many assumed it was an immigration checkpoint.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ERead More:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4674504\u002Fcanada-asylum-border\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003EPeople Who Fear Deportation Under President Trump Are Fleeing to Canada for Asylum\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWord spread so quickly that Chicago police issued a statement assuring immigrants, &#8220;You are welcome here.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn Arizona, immigrant Abril Gallardo said the policies have prompted new conversations with her parents and siblings. Her father, who&#8217;s in the country illegally, made sure all the taillights work in the van he drives to his construction job in the Phoenix area. They look through the window if anyone knocks.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHer brother is getting married this weekend, and immigrant friends were reluctant to drive to the bridal shower.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;We have a regular life, but with this new executive order, anyone, just for the fact that you&#8217;re here, you can become a priority,&#8221; said Gallardo, 26, who is in the U.S. with permission under the Obama administration policy for people who entered illegally as children.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn the Bronx, Dominguez, a college student protected from deportation under the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, is looking into what she needs to do to raise her American-born brother and sister, ages 6 and 11, if their parents are deported.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&gt;\u003Cstrong\u003ERead More: \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4674590\u002Fdonald-trump-immigration-national-guard\u002F\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003EWhite House Pushes Back Against Report of Plan to Use National Guard for Deportations\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhen Dominguez goes out, she tells the others where she is going, with whom, and when she will be home, and expects the same from her parents and siblings. If someone is late getting home, she said, &#8220;we start calling.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAssociated Press Writers Sophia Tareen in Chicago; Adriana Gomez Licon in Miami; Astrid Galvan in El Paso, Texas; and Errin Haines Whack in Philadelphia contributed to this report.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In Orange County, Calif., dozens of immigrant parents have signed legal documents authorizing friends and relatives to pick up their children from school and access their bank accounts to pay their bills in the event they are arrested by immigration agents."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In Philadelphia, immigrants are carrying around wallet-size \"Know Your Rights\" guides in Spanish and English that explain what to do if they're rounded up."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["And in New York, 23-year-old Zuleima Dominguez and other members of her Mexican family are careful about answering the door and start making worried phone calls when someone doesn't come home on time."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["Read More:"]},{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[" ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4672992\u002Ftrumps-immigration-crackdown-seems-designed-to-spread-fear\u002F"},"content":["Trump's Immigration Crackdown Seems Designed to Spread Fear"]}]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Around the country, President Donald Trump's efforts to crack down on the estimated 11 million immigrants living illegally in the U.S. have spread fear and anxiety and led many people to brace for arrest and to change up their daily routines in hopes of not getting caught."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In El Paso, Texas, Carmen Ramos and her friends have developed a network to keep each other updated via text messages on where immigration checkpoints have been set up.She said she also is making certain everything she does is in order at all times. In Philadelphia, immigrants are carrying around wallet-size &#8220;Know Your Rights&#8221; guides in Spanish and English that explain what to do if they&#8217;re rounded up. And in New York, 23-year-old Zuleima Dominguez and other members of her Mexican family are careful about answering the door and start making worried phone calls when someone doesn&#8217;t come home on time. Read More: Trump&#8217;s Immigration Crackdown Seems Designed to Spread Fear Around the country, President Donald Trump&#8217;s efforts to crack down on the estimated 11 million immigrants living illegally in the U.S. have spread fear and anxiety and led many people to brace for arrest and to change up their daily routines in hopes of not getting caught. In El Paso, Texas, Carmen Ramos and her friends have developed a network to keep each other updated via text messages on where immigration checkpoints have been set up.She said she also is making certain everything she does is in order at all times. She checks her taillights before leaving the house to make sure they are working. She won&#8217;t speed and keeps a close eye on her surroundings. &#8220;We are surprised that even a ticket can get us back to Mexico,&#8221; said the 41-year-old Ramos, who with her husband and three children left Ciudad Juarez because of drug violence and death threats in 2008 and entered the U.S. on tourist visas that have since expired. &#8220;We wouldn&#8217;t have anywhere to return.&#8221; Read More: Immigration Agents Arrested Men Outside a Church. But Officials Say It Was Just a Coincidence The unease among immigrants has been building for months but intensified in recent weeks with ever-clearer signs that the Trump administration would jettison the Obama-era policy of focusing mostly on deporting those who had committed serious crimes. The administration announced Tuesday that any immigrant in the country illegally who is charged with or convicted of any offense, or even suspected of a crime, will now be an enforcement priority. That could include people arrested for shoplifting or other minor offenses, or those who simply crossed the border illegally. Some husbands and wives fear spouses who lack legal papers could be taken away. And many worry that parents will be separated from their U.S.-born children."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EUnease has been building for months but intensified in recent weeks with ever-clearer signs that the Trump administration would act swiftly on deportations\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":71203109,"featured_media":4679947,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[4363,430939235,7053],"time_section":[204777755,204777754],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937769],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4679883"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4679883\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4679883\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=4679883"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=4679883"},{"taxonomy":"topic","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftopics?post=4679883"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4679883\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4679883\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4679883\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4679883\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4679883\u002Fauthors"}],"fortune:newsletter":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4679883\u002Fnewsletter"}],"fortune:more":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4679883\u002Fmore"}],"fortune:popular":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4679883\u002Fpopular"}],"fortune:listicle":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4679883\u002Flisticle"}],"fortune:gallery":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4679883\u002Fgallery"}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4679883\u002Fprimary_tag"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4679883\u002Fprimary_section"}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4679883\u002Fprimary_topic"}],"ng:more:brand":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4679883\u002Fbrand"}],"ng:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fauthors?post=4679883"}]},"_embedded":{"wp:term":[[{"id":1,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fcategory\u002Funcategorized\u002F","name":"Uncategorized","slug":"uncategorized","taxonomy":"category","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories\u002F1"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fcategory"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?categories=1"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\ House","slug":"white-house","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags\u002F7053"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fpost_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?tags=7053"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=7053"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}}],{"code":"rest_no_route","message":"No route was found matching the URL and request method","data":{"status":404}}],"wp:meta":[{"bitly_url":"http:\u002F\u002Fti.me\u002F2mnzT5G","negative_coverage":false,"mt_seo_title":"U.S. Immigrants Bracing for Trump's Deportation Crackdown","mt_seo_description":"Around the U.S., the administration's efforts to crack down on the about 11 million of undocumented immigrants have spread fear and anxiety.","mt_seo_keywords":"undocumented, illegal, immigrants, donald trump, president trump, ice agency, deportation, daca, dreamers, immigration and customs enforcement, john kelly, aliens,","mt_seo_google_news_meta":"undocumented, illegal, immigrants, donald trump, president trump, ice agency, deportation, daca, dreamers, immigration and customs enforcement, john kelly, aliens,","short_title":"Immigrants Bracing for Trump's Deportation Crackdown","home_deck":"Around the U.S., the administration's efforts to crack down on the about 11 million of undocumented immigrants have spread fear and anxiety. Unease has intensified in recent weeks with signs that the Trump administration would act swiftly on deportations","og_title":"U.S. Immigrants Bracing for Trump's Deportation Crackdown","og_description":"Fears intensified in recent weeks with signs that enforcement would be swift","twitter_text":"Immigrants across the U.S. are bracing for Trump's deportation crackdown","permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4679883\u002Fimmigration-donald-trump-deportations\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ftime\u002F4679883\u002Fimmigration-donald-trump-deportations\u002F?source=dam"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"landscape","type":"image","visible":false,"image":{"id":4679947,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fgettyimages-643845386.jpg?quality=85","alt":"Immigrants Are Sworn In As American Citizens During A Naturalization Ceremony In Chicago's City Hall","caption":"Immigrants participate in a naturalization ceremony on February 22, 2017 in Chicago, Illinois. ","credit":"Scott Olson—Getty Images","title":"Immigrants Are Sworn In As American Citizens During A Naturalization Ceremony In Chicago's City Hall"},"video":[],"structured":false}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":4363,"name":"Immigration","slug":"immigration","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":1374,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":543,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":204777755,"name":"Politics","slug":"politics","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":17,"taxonomy":"time_section","description":"Political insight from the Beltway and beyond. Covering the White House, elections, primaries, Congress, domestic policy, foreign policy, the military and more","parent":0,"count":11779,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["politics","us"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}}]],"fortune:popular":[[{"id":4672988,"date":"2017-02-16T07:12:29","date_gmt":"2017-02-16T12:12:29","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4672988"},"modified":"2017-02-22T10:52:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-22T15:52:00","slug":"the-sleep-cure-fountain-of-youth","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4672988\u002Fthe-sleep-cure-fountain-of-youth\u002F","title":{"rendered":"The Sleep Cure: The Fountain of Youth May Be Closer Than You Ever Thought"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EMark Zielinski knew he was onto something when his mice stopped sleeping. Normally, the animals woke and slept on a 12-hour cycle. When the lights were on in the lab, the mice were active. When it went dark on a timer, down they went. But Zielinski, who teaches psychiatry at Harvard Medical School, had recently tweaked their schedule to keep the mice up past their bedtime.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EZielinski and his colleagues would rustle the bedding in the mice&#8217;s cages to keep them from dozing off when they started to display the telltale signs of sleepiness&#8211;drooping lids, sluggish walk, EEG readings showing their brain activity was waning. But Zielinski noticed that when the mice were left alone to slumber at will after the disruption, they didn&#8217;t, or perhaps couldn&#8217;t, fall asleep.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"video-container\"\u003E\u003Cvideo id=\"brightcove-player-5026612549001\" data-video-id=\"5026612549001\" data-account=\"293884104\" data-player=\"SJa0Thl7\" data-embed=\"default\" autoplay controls preload=\"auto\" class=\"video-js responsive-video\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fvideo\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThat the sleep-deprived rodents slept less than they normally would didn&#8217;t really surprise Zielinski. The mice had a genetic mutation that he suspected was linked to sleep problems. More striking were the electrical brain readings showing that even when they did sleep, they weren&#8217;t getting the deep, restorative kind of rest that doctors say matters most&#8211;not just to rodents but also to humans.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn the right conditions, researchers believe, the brain produces a signal that essentially tells the body&#8217;s major systems&#8211;the heart, the lungs, the digestive system, the nervous system, even the muscles&#8211;that it&#8217;s time to call it quits for the day. Zielinski&#8217;s research has found that, just as with the mice with the mutation, it&#8217;s likely that in some people with chronic sleep problems, that critical signal isn&#8217;t firing.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EUnderstanding what&#8217;s behind some forms of insomnia, an aim of Zielinski&#8217;s research, is a major step in learning how to fix it. That&#8217;s a big deal in sleep research, because evidence linking quality rest to good health and longevity has never been more convincing.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EScientists are learning that shortchanging sleep can compromise nearly every major body system, from the brain to the heart to the immune system, making our inability&#8211;or unwillingness&#8211;to sleep enough one of the unhealthiest things we can do.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EStudies of people whose sleep sessions are irregular or short show they are at higher risk of developing diseases that can lead to early death, including heart disease, diabetes, high blood pressure and obesity. Poor sleep may have detrimental effects on the brain as well, increasing the risk of dementia, including Alzheimer&#8217;s disease, as well as mood disorders like depression, posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and anxiety. And like smoking, a terrible diet and not exercising enough, poor sleep is now linked to an overall increased risk of premature death.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;I used to suggest that sleep is the third pillar of good health, along with diet and exercise,&#8221; says Matthew Walker, a professor of neuroscience and psychology at the University of California, Berkeley. &#8220;But I don&#8217;t agree with that anymore. Sleep is the single most effective thing you can do to reset your brain and body for health.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDespite the mounting evidence of its benefits, Americans are sleeping about two hours less each night than they did a century ago. Blame the technology-fueled 24\u002F7 workplace, social media or the relentless news cycle, but about one-third of U.S. adults sleep less than the recommended seven hours daily, and 40% report feeling drowsy during the day, according to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The problem begins early: only 15% to 30% of U.S. teens get the 8&frac12; hours a night recommended for adolescents.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhile life expectancy has been inching upward over the past century thanks to advances in medicine and technology, those gains could start to sag under the weight of our collective sleeplessness. Many people still dismiss sleep as something they can occasionally (or even regularly) skimp on, but the biological facts are clear: it is neither safe nor wise to take sleep lightly.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;To me, sleep is like the canary in the coal mine,&#8221; says David Schnyer, a professor of psychology and neuroscience at the University of Texas, Austin. &#8220;Changes in sleep can create systemwide changes in the organism, and all of the stages of sleep affect the entire body and brain.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThat&#8217;s why sleep deprivation is so strongly linked to disease and premature death. One recent study even showed that sleep deprivation in mice can cause death faster than starvation can. And yet doctors&#8211;those who talk to their patients about sleep in the first place, anyway&#8211;report that many people still aren&#8217;t convinced that their nightly rest is a critical piece of the long-life puzzle. Health obsessives who would never touch a cigarette and pride themselves on avoiding junk food may also boast about how much they get done, and how little they sleep at night.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;Because we&#8217;re asleep, we don&#8217;t see the benefits of it,&#8221; says Robert Stickgold, a well-known sleep researcher and an associate professor of psychiatry at Harvard Medical School. &#8220;That&#8217;s the disaster and tragedy of our current world.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIt&#8217;s been that way for a long time. Benjamin Franklin famously quipped that &#8220;there will be sleeping enough in the grave,&#8221; and today, sleep is still misperceived as one of the most duty-driven and unproductive parts of the day&#8211;the habit that gets in the way of life as opposed to the one most likely to extend it.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EPerhaps that&#8217;s because until very recently, scientists couldn&#8217;t even agree on the evolutionary reason why animals need to sleep in the first place. But now they know that what happens during sleep, particularly in the brain, is critical to human well-being&#8211;not to mention a long life. That&#8217;s why they also know that the cost of ignoring the latest science on sleep can be dear.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESpending a good third of the day oblivious to the world around you and, by extension, incapable of protecting yourself doesn&#8217;t seem like a smart way for a species to stay alive. And yet every animal does it, leading scientists to accept that sleep must be nonnegotiable for some reason&#8211;and that we must need a certain amount of it to survive.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFollowing a rigorous, milestone study in 2002 of more than 1 million healthy men and women by the American Cancer Society, experts suggested that the magic amount of sleep for longevity was seven hours a night. People who slept that amount were most likely to still be alive at the end of the study&#8217;s six years, compared with people who got either six hours or less, or eight hours or more, of sleep each night. To this day, that&#8217;s typically the amount that doctors and public-health groups recommend for the average adult, though older people can probably get away with a little less sleep than that, and younger people need more.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAnother even longer study, which followed more than 21,000 twins in Finland, found that people who were regularly sleeping less than seven hours daily were 21% to 26% more likely to die of any cause during the study&#8217;s 22-year period than those who slept more than eight hours.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESo clearly sleep has some real biological benefit. Could it just be that the brain and body need downtime to recuperate after the activity of the day? That was the most popular explanation for decades, until an inquisitive neuroscientist at the University of Rochester decided to look for the answer inside the brain itself. When she did, Dr. Maiken Nedergaard uncovered what many scientists now agree is sleep&#8217;s primary evolutionary function: to clean out the brain, quite literally, of accumulating debris.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn 2014, Nedergaard first revealed that while the body appears to rest during sleep, a whole lot is happening inside the brain. Neurons pulse with electrical signals that wash over the brain in a rhythmic flow. The brain runs checks on itself to ensure that the balance of hormones, enzymes and proteins isn&#8217;t too far off-kilter. All the while, brain cells contract, opening up the spaces between them so that fluid can wash out the toxic detritus that can cause all kinds of problems if it builds up.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;It&#8217;s like a dishwasher that keeps flushing through to wash the dirt away,&#8221; Nedergaard says.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWithout that nightly wash cycle, dangerous toxins can damage healthy cells and interfere with their ability to communicate with one another. In the short term, that can impede memory formation and the ability to coherently compose our thoughts and regulate our emotions. Over time, the consequences can be more dire. Lack of sleep can lead to faster aging of brain cells, contributing to diseases like Alzheimer&#8217;s, which is now the cause of death for 1 in 3 seniors.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENedergaard&#8217;s research, which was done in mice, prompted a crucial rethinking of not only the benefits of sleep but also its biological function. It turns out the brain and body are extremely active when we sleep&#8211;we&#8217;re just not aware of most of what occurs while we do it.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;Sleep is not just a passive state but a fairly active state on the molecular level,&#8221; says Dr. Allan Pack, director of the Center for Sleep and Circadian Neurobiology at the University of Pennsylvania. &#8220;During the day, the brain is using energy resources to fire neurons. At night, a switch turns on so the sleeping brain can take advantage of the metabolic downtime to do some cleaning up.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe idea that sleep is a time of important biological activity, rather than a period when the body checks out, is transforming how doctors think about another important factor in longevity: mental health.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EScientists have long known that sleep is important for memory. But it turns out that during sleep, especially the cycles of deep dream sleep, the brain doesn&#8217;t just revisit the events of a day in a more organized way. It also works on processing the emotions attached to these recollections. When a memory is filed away during sleep, it&#8217;s also stripped of some of the powerful feelings&#8211;like fear, grief, anger or joy&#8211;that might have clouded the experiences in the heat of the moment.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIt wouldn&#8217;t be healthy, or efficient, to remember every event or experience in its full factual and emotional context. But separating the emotional aspects of a memory&#8211;the anger over an argument with your spouse, the frustration at the guy who cut you off in traffic, the dejection you felt after getting a curt email reply from your boss&#8211;from its objective parts allows you to recall the experience without reliving it. &#8220;We sleep to remember and we sleep to forget,&#8221; says Walker, the UC Berkeley sleep scientist, of this coping mechanism. &#8220;I call it overnight therapy.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThis type of processing takes time. It likely happens only during deep, quality sleep, and only over consistent nights of such sleep. That may explain why people who cut their sleep short or experience interrupted sleep may not fully disentangle the emotional baggage from their memories.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn those cases the memory, in its emotionally taxing entirety, continues to resurface every time the brain tries to sleep, in a vain effort to be properly processed. The brain tries to store the memory in a neutral way, but without deep sleep, there just isn&#8217;t enough time for that triage.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWalker believes these aborted efforts may drive conditions like PTSD, which is well understood to be common among combat veterans but which may be more common among the general population than therapists and researchers previously thought.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;The more nights you sleep, the more soothing the influence of sleep on that memory,&#8221; he says. &#8220;Sleep continues to work on those emotional memories and flatten them out after about a week. Now there&#8217;s great evidence that PTSD is a disorder in which that process fails.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWalker saw this effect firsthand when he showed a group of people a frightening video. He kept some of the people awake after the viewing and allowed the rest to sleep normally. Those who were not allowed to sleep properly were more likely to remember the negative aspects of the video than those who got enough sleep.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThere&#8217;s also strong support for the idea that insufficient sleep may be a trigger for, and not just a symptom of, a number of mental illnesses, including depression, bipolar disorder and even schizophrenia. Depriving people with bipolar disorder of sleep, for example, can launch a manic episode, while some people with depression report worsening symptoms when they aren&#8217;t sleeping well.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFully understanding the role sleep plays in mental illness is a rich area of future research. Already many doctors think consistent, high-quality sleep can have a direct bearing on the health of those with mental illness. &#8220;Anyone who suffers from moderate or significant mental-health concerns needs to be aware that sleep may be one of the most important things they can do,&#8221; says Walker.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EStress, scientists also know, is one of the more potent accelerators of aging, and a body that&#8217;s not sleeping enough looks similar to one that&#8217;s stressed out&#8211;it&#8217;s highly reactive to perceived threats, even when those threats don&#8217;t pose any real risk. Biologically speaking, there&#8217;s virtually no difference in the way a body reacts to a startling noise in the middle of the night, a rabid raccoon or a stressful work deadline: in all cases, fight-or-flight mode is triggered, blood pressure spikes, breathing gets shallow, and the heart starts to race. That&#8217;s what happens to a body on no sleep too.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThose stress reactions can be useful, of course: they help you respond more readily to an actual physical threat. But that&#8217;s not usually what&#8217;s going on. And staying in an alert mode can trigger a number of unhealthy conditions, the most damaging of which is inflammation.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EInflammation is the body&#8217;s natural defense system against injury or invading microbes like bacteria and viruses. It&#8217;s why your toe turns red and throbs when you stub it or when it&#8217;s infected: white blood cells rush to the area in order to protect it for the short time it&#8217;s needed to help you get better. But inflammation can also become chronic, and that&#8217;s when the real trouble starts.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EChronic inflammation, doctors now know, is a leading driver of many diseases, including some cancers, cognitive decline, heart disease, Type 2 diabetes&#8211;even chronic pain. And one of the main drivers of chronic inflammation is, of course, not sleeping enough.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EGetting a decent night&#8217;s sleep, then, is good advice for all of us. Americans spent an estimated $41 billion on sleeping pills and other sleep aids in 2015; no matter how much we may boast about our stamina, we know intuitively that we need sleep, even if we don&#8217;t always know why.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBut scientists do. That&#8217;s why experts are insisting, with increasing frequency and noise, that sleep be a priority&#8211;as important or more than what you eat and how much you exercise. We wouldn&#8217;t dream of skipping meals on a regular basis, so why skimp on sleep?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThere&#8217;s still much about sleep that mystifies scientists&#8211;particularly about what goes wrong for so many of us, night after night. But as they chip away at the underlying causes of sleeplessness, they get ever closer to a cure. Harvard&#8217;s Zielinski, for one, is hopeful that they will eventually find a way to help more people sleep better every night.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhen he gave his sleepless mice a drug to fix the mutation that was interfering with their sleep in the first place, they began to slumber anew.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cbr\u003E\u003Cem\u003EThis appears in the February 27, 2017 issue of TIME.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Mark Zielinski knew he was onto something when his mice stopped sleeping. Normally, the animals woke and slept on a 12-hour cycle. When the lights were on in the lab, the mice were active. When it went dark on a timer, down they went. But Zielinski, who teaches psychiatry at Harvard Medical School, had recently tweaked their schedule to keep the mice up past their bedtime."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Zielinski and his colleagues would rustle the bedding in the mice's cages to keep them from dozing off when they started to display the telltale signs of sleepiness--drooping lids, sluggish walk, EEG readings showing their brain activity was waning. But Zielinski noticed that when the mice were left alone to slumber at will after the disruption, they didn't, or perhaps couldn't, fall asleep."]},{"tag":"video","attributes":{"autoplay":"1","controls":"1","videoid":"5026612549001"},"content":[]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["That the sleep-deprived rodents slept less than they normally would didn't really surprise Zielinski. The mice had a genetic mutation that he suspected was linked to sleep problems. More striking were the electrical brain readings showing that even when they did sleep, they weren't getting the deep, restorative kind of rest that doctors say matters most--not just to rodents but also to humans."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In the right conditions, researchers believe, the brain produces a signal that essentially tells the body's major systems--the heart, the lungs, the digestive system, the nervous system, even the muscles--that it's time to call it quits for the day.
