Zielinski's research has found that, just as with the mice with the mutation, it's likely that in some people with chronic sleep problems, that critical signal isn't firing."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Understanding what's behind some forms of insomnia, an aim of Zielinski's research, is a major step in learning how to fix it. That's a big deal in sleep research, because evidence linking quality rest to good health and longevity has never been more convincing."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Scientists are learning that shortchanging sleep can compromise nearly every major body system, from the brain to the heart to the immune system, making our inability--or unwillingness--to sleep enough one of the unhealthiest things we can do."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Studies of people whose sleep sessions are irregular or short show they are at higher risk of developing diseases that can lead to early death, including heart disease, diabetes, high blood pressure and obesity. Poor sleep may have detrimental effects on the brain as well, increasing the risk of dementia, including Alzheimer's disease, as well as mood disorders like depression, posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and anxiety. And like smoking, a terrible diet and not exercising enough, poor sleep is now linked to an overall increased risk of premature death."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"I used to suggest that sleep is the third pillar of good health, along with diet and exercise,\" says Matthew Walker, a professor of neuroscience and psychology at the University of California, Berkeley. \"But I don't agree with that anymore. Sleep is the single most effective thing you can do to reset your brain and body for health.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Despite the mounting evidence of its benefits, Americans are sleeping about two hours less each night than they did a century ago. Blame the technology-fueled 24\u002F7 workplace, social media or the relentless news cycle, but about one-third of U.S. adults sleep less than the recommended seven hours daily, and 40% report feeling drowsy during the day, according to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The problem begins early: only 15% to 30% of U.S. teens get the 8½ hours a night recommended for adolescents."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["While life expectancy has been inching upward over the past century thanks to advances in medicine and technology, those gains could start to sag under the weight of our collective sleeplessness. Many people still dismiss sleep as something they can occasionally (or even regularly) skimp on, but the biological facts are clear: it is neither safe nor wise to take sleep lightly."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"To me, sleep is like the canary in the coal mine,\" says David Schnyer, a professor of psychology and neuroscience at the University of Texas, Austin. \"Changes in sleep can create systemwide changes in the organism, and all of the stages of sleep affect the entire body and brain.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["That's why sleep deprivation is so strongly linked to disease and premature death. One recent study even showed that sleep deprivation in mice can cause death faster than starvation can. And yet doctors--those who talk to their patients about sleep in the first place, anyway--report that many people still aren't convinced that their nightly rest is a critical piece of the long-life puzzle. Health obsessives who would never touch a cigarette and pride themselves on avoiding junk food may also boast about how much they get done, and how little they sleep at night."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"Because we're asleep, we don't see the benefits of it,\" says Robert Stickgold, a well-known sleep researcher and an associate professor of psychiatry at Harvard Medical School. \"That's the disaster and tragedy of our current world.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["It's been that way for a long time. Benjamin Franklin famously quipped that \"there will be sleeping enough in the grave,\" and today, sleep is still misperceived as one of the most duty-driven and unproductive parts of the day--the habit that gets in the way of life as opposed to the one most likely to extend it."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Perhaps that's because until very recently, scientists couldn't even agree on the evolutionary reason why animals need to sleep in the first place. But now they know that what happens during sleep, particularly in the brain, is critical to human well-being--not to mention a long life. That's why they also know that the cost of ignoring the latest science on sleep can be dear."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Spending a good third of the day oblivious to the world around you and, by extension, incapable of protecting yourself doesn't seem like a smart way for a species to stay alive. And yet every animal does it, leading scientists to accept that sleep must be nonnegotiable for some reason--and that we must need a certain amount of it to survive."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Following a rigorous, milestone study in 2002 of more than 1 million healthy men and women by the American Cancer Society, experts suggested that the magic amount of sleep for longevity was seven hours a night. People who slept that amount were most likely to still be alive at the end of the study's six years, compared with people who got either six hours or less, or eight hours or more, of sleep each night. To this day, that's typically the amount that doctors and public-health groups recommend for the average adult, though older people can probably get away with a little less sleep than that, and younger people need more."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Another even longer study, which followed more than 21,000 twins in Finland, found that people who were regularly sleeping less than seven hours daily were 21% to 26% more likely to die of any cause during the study's 22-year period than those who slept more than eight hours."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["So clearly sleep has some real biological benefit. Could it just be that the brain and body need downtime to recuperate after the activity of the day? That was the most popular explanation for decades, until an inquisitive neuroscientist at the University of Rochester decided to look for the answer inside the brain itself. When she did, Dr. Maiken Nedergaard uncovered what many scientists now agree is sleep's primary evolutionary function: to clean out the brain, quite literally, of accumulating debris."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In 2014, Nedergaard first revealed that while the body appears to rest during sleep, a whole lot is happening inside the brain. Neurons pulse with electrical signals that wash over the brain in a rhythmic flow. The brain runs checks on itself to ensure that the balance of hormones, enzymes and proteins isn't too far off-kilter. All the while, brain cells contract, opening up the spaces between them so that fluid can wash out the toxic detritus that can cause all kinds of problems if it builds up."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"It's like a dishwasher that keeps flushing through to wash the dirt away,\" Nedergaard says."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Without that nightly wash cycle, dangerous toxins can damage healthy cells and interfere with their ability to communicate with one another. In the short term, that can impede memory formation and the ability to coherently compose our thoughts and regulate our emotions. Over time, the consequences can be more dire. Lack of sleep can lead to faster aging of brain cells, contributing to diseases like Alzheimer's, which is now the cause of death for 1 in 3 seniors."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Nedergaard's research, which was done in mice, prompted a crucial rethinking of not only the benefits of sleep but also its biological function. It turns out the brain and body are extremely active when we sleep--we're just not aware of most of what occurs while we do it."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"Sleep is not just a passive state but a fairly active state on the molecular level,\" says Dr. Allan Pack, director of the Center for Sleep and Circadian Neurobiology at the University of Pennsylvania. \"During the day, the brain is using energy resources to fire neurons. At night, a switch turns on so the sleeping brain can take advantage of the metabolic downtime to do some cleaning up.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The idea that sleep is a time of important biological activity, rather than a period when the body checks out, is transforming how doctors think about another important factor in longevity: mental health."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Scientists have long known that sleep is important for memory. But it turns out that during sleep, especially the cycles of deep dream sleep, the brain doesn't just revisit the events of a day in a more organized way. It also works on processing the emotions attached to these recollections. When a memory is filed away during sleep, it's also stripped of some of the powerful feelings--like fear, grief, anger or joy--that might have clouded the experiences in the heat of the moment."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["It wouldn't be healthy, or efficient, to remember every event or experience in its full factual and emotional context. But separating the emotional aspects of a memory--the anger over an argument with your spouse, the frustration at the guy who cut you off in traffic, the dejection you felt after getting a curt email reply from your boss--from its objective parts allows you to recall the experience without reliving it. \"We sleep to remember and we sleep to forget,\" says Walker, the UC Berkeley sleep scientist, of this coping mechanism. \"I call it overnight therapy.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["This type of processing takes time. It likely happens only during deep, quality sleep, and only over consistent nights of such sleep. That may explain why people who cut their sleep short or experience interrupted sleep may not fully disentangle the emotional baggage from their memories."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In those cases the memory, in its emotionally taxing entirety, continues to resurface every time the brain tries to sleep, in a vain effort to be properly processed. The brain tries to store the memory in a neutral way, but without deep sleep, there just isn't enough time for that triage."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Walker believes these aborted efforts may drive conditions like PTSD, which is well understood to be common among combat veterans but which may be more common among the general population than therapists and researchers previously thought."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"The more nights you sleep, the more soothing the influence of sleep on that memory,\" he says. \"Sleep continues to work on those emotional memories and flatten them out after about a week. Now there's great evidence that PTSD is a disorder in which that process fails.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Walker saw this effect firsthand when he showed a group of people a frightening video. He kept some of the people awake after the viewing and allowed the rest to sleep normally. Those who were not allowed to sleep properly were more likely to remember the negative aspects of the video than those who got enough sleep."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["There's also strong support for the idea that insufficient sleep may be a trigger for, and not just a symptom of, a number of mental illnesses, including depression, bipolar disorder and even schizophrenia. Depriving people with bipolar disorder of sleep, for example, can launch a manic episode, while some people with depression report worsening symptoms when they aren't sleeping well."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Fully understanding the role sleep plays in mental illness is a rich area of future research. Already many doctors think consistent, high-quality sleep can have a direct bearing on the health of those with mental illness. \"Anyone who suffers from moderate or significant mental-health concerns needs to be aware that sleep may be one of the most important things they can do,\" says Walker."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Stress, scientists also know, is one of the more potent accelerators of aging, and a body that's not sleeping enough looks similar to one that's stressed out--it's highly reactive to perceived threats, even when those threats don't pose any real risk. Biologically speaking, there's virtually no difference in the way a body reacts to a startling noise in the middle of the night, a rabid raccoon or a stressful work deadline: in all cases, fight-or-flight mode is triggered, blood pressure spikes, breathing gets shallow, and the heart starts to race. That's what happens to a body on no sleep too."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Those stress reactions can be useful, of course: they help you respond more readily to an actual physical threat. But that's not usually what's going on. And staying in an alert mode can trigger a number of unhealthy conditions, the most damaging of which is inflammation."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Inflammation is the body's natural defense system against injury or invading microbes like bacteria and viruses. It's why your toe turns red and throbs when you stub it or when it's infected: white blood cells rush to the area in order to protect it for the short time it's needed to help you get better. But inflammation can also become chronic, and that's when the real trouble starts."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Chronic inflammation, doctors now know, is a leading driver of many diseases, including some cancers, cognitive decline, heart disease, Type 2 diabetes--even chronic pain. And one of the main drivers of chronic inflammation is, of course, not sleeping enough."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Getting a decent night's sleep, then, is good advice for all of us. Americans spent an estimated $41 billion on sleeping pills and other sleep aids in 2015; no matter how much we may boast about our stamina, we know intuitively that we need sleep, even if we don't always know why."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["But scientists do. That's why experts are insisting, with increasing frequency and noise, that sleep be a priority--as important or more than what you eat and how much you exercise. We wouldn't dream of skipping meals on a regular basis, so why skimp on sleep?"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["There's still much about sleep that mystifies scientists--particularly about what goes wrong for so many of us, night after night. But as they chip away at the underlying causes of sleeplessness, they get ever closer to a cure. Harvard's Zielinski, for one, is hopeful that they will eventually find a way to help more people sleep better every night."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["When he gave his sleepless mice a drug to fix the mutation that was interfering with their sleep in the first place, they began to slumber anew."]}],"plain":"Mark Zielinski knew he was onto something when his mice stopped sleeping. Normally, the animals woke and slept on a 12-hour cycle. When the lights were on in the lab, the mice were active. When it went dark on a timer, down they went. But Zielinski, who teaches psychiatry at Harvard Medical School, had recently tweaked their schedule to keep the mice up past their bedtime. Zielinski and his colleagues would rustle the bedding in the mice&#8217;s cages to keep them from dozing off when they started to display the telltale signs of sleepiness&#8211;drooping lids, sluggish walk, EEG readings showing their brain activity was waning. But Zielinski noticed that when the mice were left alone to slumber at will after the disruption, they didn&#8217;t, or perhaps couldn&#8217;t, fall asleep. That the sleep-deprived rodents slept less than they normally would didn&#8217;t really surprise Zielinski. The mice had a genetic mutation that he suspected was linked to sleep problems. More striking were the electrical brain readings showing that even when they did sleep, they weren&#8217;t getting the deep, restorative kind of rest that doctors say matters most&#8211;not just to rodents but also to humans. In the right conditions, researchers believe, the brain produces a signal that essentially tells the body&#8217;s major systems&#8211;the heart, the lungs, the digestive system, the nervous system, even the muscles&#8211;that it&#8217;s time to call it quits for the day. Zielinski&#8217;s research has found that, just as with the mice with the mutation, it&#8217;s likely that in some people with chronic sleep problems, that critical signal isn&#8217;t firing. Understanding what&#8217;s behind some forms of insomnia, an aim of Zielinski&#8217;s research, is a major step in learning how to fix it. That&#8217;s a big deal in sleep research, because evidence linking quality rest to good health and longevity has never been more convincing. Scientists are learning that shortchanging sleep can compromise nearly every major body system, from the brain to the heart to the immune system, making our inability&#8211;or unwillingness&#8211;to sleep enough one of the unhealthiest things we can do. Studies of people whose sleep sessions are irregular or short show they are at higher risk of developing diseases that can lead to early death, including heart disease, diabetes, high blood pressure and obesity. Poor sleep may have detrimental effects on the brain as well, increasing the risk of dementia, including Alzheimer&#8217;s disease, as well as mood disorders like depression, posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and anxiety. And like smoking, a terrible diet and not exercising enough, poor sleep is now linked to an overall increased risk of premature death. &#8220;I used to suggest that sleep is the third pillar of good health, along with diet and exercise,&#8221; says Matthew Walker, a professor of neuroscience and psychology at the University of California, Berkeley. &#8220;But I don&#8217;t agree with that anymore. Sleep is the single most effective thing you can do to reset your brain and body for health.&#8221; Despite the mounting evidence of its benefits, Americans are sleeping about two hours less each night than they did a century ago. Blame the technology-fueled 24\u002F7 workplace, social media or the relentless news cycle, but about one-third of U.S. adults sleep less than the recommended seven hours daily, and 40% report feeling drowsy during the day, according to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The problem begins early: only 15% to 30% of U.S. teens get the 8&frac12; hours a night recommended for adolescents. While life expectancy has been inching upward over the past century thanks to advances in medicine and technology, those gains could start to sag under the weight of our collective sleeplessness. Many people still dismiss sleep as something they can occasionally (or even regularly) skimp on, but the biological facts are clear: it is neither safe nor wise to take sleep lightly. &#8220;To me, sleep is like the canary in the coal mine,&#8221; says David Schnyer, a professor of psychology and neuroscience at the University of Texas, Austin. &#8220;Changes in sleep can create systemwide changes in the organism, and all of the stages of sleep affect the entire body and brain.&#8221; That&#8217;s why sleep deprivation is so strongly linked to disease and premature death. One recent study even showed that sleep deprivation in mice can cause death faster than starvation can. And yet doctors&#8211;those who talk to their patients about sleep in the first place, anyway&#8211;report that many people still aren&#8217;t convinced that their nightly rest is a critical piece of the long-life puzzle. Health obsessives who would never touch a cigarette and pride themselves on avoiding junk food may also boast about how much they get done, and how little they sleep at night. &#8220;Because we&#8217;re asleep, we don&#8217;t see the benefits of it,&#8221; says Robert Stickgold, a well-known sleep researcher and an associate professor of psychiatry at Harvard Medical School. &#8220;That&#8217;s the disaster and tragedy of our current world.&#8221; It&#8217;s been that way for a long time. Benjamin Franklin famously quipped that &#8220;there will be sleeping enough in the grave,&#8221; and today, sleep is still misperceived as one of the most duty-driven and unproductive parts of the day&#8211;the habit that gets in the way of life as opposed to the one most likely to extend it. Perhaps that&#8217;s because until very recently, scientists couldn&#8217;t even agree on the evolutionary reason why animals need to sleep in the first place. But now they know that what happens during sleep, particularly in the brain, is critical to human well-being&#8211;not to mention a long life. That&#8217;s why they also know that the cost of ignoring the latest science on sleep can be dear. Spending a good third of the day oblivious to the world around you and, by extension, incapable of protecting yourself doesn&#8217;t seem like a smart way for a species to stay alive. And yet every animal does it, leading scientists to accept that sleep must be nonnegotiable for some reason&#8211;and that we must need a certain amount of it to survive. Following a rigorous, milestone study in 2002 of more than 1 million healthy men and women by the American Cancer Society, experts suggested that the magic amount of sleep for longevity was seven hours a night. People who slept that amount were most likely to still be alive at the end of the study&#8217;s six years, compared with people who got either six hours or less, or eight hours or more, of sleep each night. To this day, that&#8217;s typically the amount that doctors and public-health groups recommend for the average adult, though older people can probably get away with a little less sleep than that, and younger people need more. Another even longer study, which followed more than 21,000 twins in Finland, found that people who were regularly sleeping less than seven hours daily were 21% to 26% more likely to die of any cause during the study&#8217;s 22-year period than those who slept more than eight hours. So clearly sleep has some real biological benefit. Could it just be that the brain and body need downtime to recuperate after the activity of the day? That was the most popular explanation for decades, until an inquisitive neuroscientist at the University of Rochester decided to look for the answer inside the brain itself. When she did, Dr. Maiken Nedergaard uncovered what many scientists now agree is sleep&#8217;s primary evolutionary function: to clean out the brain, quite literally, of accumulating debris. In 2014, Nedergaard first revealed that while the body appears to rest during sleep, a whole lot is happening inside the brain. Neurons pulse with electrical signals that wash over the brain in a rhythmic flow. The brain runs checks on itself to ensure that the balance of hormones, enzymes and proteins isn&#8217;t too far off-kilter. All the while, brain cells contract, opening up the spaces between them so that fluid can wash out the toxic detritus that can cause all kinds of problems if it builds up. &#8220;It&#8217;s like a dishwasher that keeps flushing through to wash the dirt away,&#8221; Nedergaard says. Without that nightly wash cycle, dangerous toxins can damage healthy cells and interfere with their ability to communicate with one another. In the short term, that can impede memory formation and the ability to coherently compose our thoughts and regulate our emotions. Over time, the consequences can be more dire. Lack of sleep can lead to faster aging of brain cells, contributing to diseases like Alzheimer&#8217;s, which is now the cause of death for 1 in 3 seniors. Nedergaard&#8217;s research, which was done in mice, prompted a crucial rethinking of not only the benefits of sleep but also its biological function. It turns out the brain and body are extremely active when we sleep&#8211;we&#8217;re just not aware of most of what occurs while we do it. &#8220;Sleep is not just a passive state but a fairly active state on the molecular level,&#8221; says Dr. Allan Pack, director of the Center for Sleep and Circadian Neurobiology at the University of Pennsylvania. &#8220;During the day, the brain is using energy resources to fire neurons. At night, a switch turns on so the sleeping brain can take advantage of the metabolic downtime to do some cleaning up.&#8221; The idea that sleep is a time of important biological activity, rather than a period when the body checks out, is transforming how doctors think about another important factor in longevity: mental health. Scientists have long known that sleep is important for memory. But it turns out that during sleep, especially the cycles of deep dream sleep, the brain doesn&#8217;t just revisit the events of a day in a more organized way. It also works on processing the emotions attached to these recollections. When a memory is filed away during sleep, it&#8217;s also stripped of some of the powerful feelings&#8211;like fear, grief, anger or joy&#8211;that might have clouded the experiences in the heat of the moment. It wouldn&#8217;t be healthy, or efficient, to remember every event or experience in its full factual and emotional context. But separating the emotional aspects of a memory&#8211;the anger over an argument with your spouse, the frustration at the guy who cut you off in traffic, the dejection you felt after getting a curt email reply from your boss&#8211;from its objective parts allows you to recall the experience without reliving it. &#8220;We sleep to remember and we sleep to forget,&#8221; says Walker, the UC Berkeley sleep scientist, of this coping mechanism. &#8220;I call it overnight therapy.&#8221; This type of processing takes time. It likely happens only during deep, quality sleep, and only over consistent nights of such sleep. That may explain why people who cut their sleep short or experience interrupted sleep may not fully disentangle the emotional baggage from their memories. In those cases the memory, in its emotionally taxing entirety, continues to resurface every time the brain tries to sleep, in a vain effort to be properly processed. The brain tries to store the memory in a neutral way, but without deep sleep, there just isn&#8217;t enough time for that triage. Walker believes these aborted efforts may drive conditions like PTSD, which is well understood to be common among combat veterans but which may be more common among the general population than therapists and researchers previously thought. &#8220;The more nights you sleep, the more soothing the influence of sleep on that memory,&#8221; he says. &#8220;Sleep continues to work on those emotional memories and flatten them out after about a week. Now there&#8217;s great evidence that PTSD is a disorder in which that process fails.&#8221; Walker saw this effect firsthand when he showed a group of people a frightening video. He kept some of the people awake after the viewing and allowed the rest to sleep normally. Those who were not allowed to sleep properly were more likely to remember the negative aspects of the video than those who got enough sleep. There&#8217;s also strong support for the idea that insufficient sleep may be a trigger for, and not just a symptom of, a number of mental illnesses, including depression, bipolar disorder and even schizophrenia. Depriving people with bipolar disorder of sleep, for example, can launch a manic episode, while some people with depression report worsening symptoms when they aren&#8217;t sleeping well. Fully understanding the role sleep plays in mental illness is a rich area of future research. Already many doctors think consistent, high-quality sleep can have a direct bearing on the health of those with mental illness. &#8220;Anyone who suffers from moderate or significant mental-health concerns needs to be aware that sleep may be one of the most important things they can do,&#8221; says Walker. Stress, scientists also know, is one of the more potent accelerators of aging, and a body that&#8217;s not sleeping enough looks similar to one that&#8217;s stressed out&#8211;it&#8217;s highly reactive to perceived threats, even when those threats don&#8217;t pose any real risk. Biologically speaking, there&#8217;s virtually no difference in the way a body reacts to a startling noise in the middle of the night, a rabid raccoon or a stressful work deadline: in all cases, fight-or-flight mode is triggered, blood pressure spikes, breathing gets shallow, and the heart starts to race. That&#8217;s what happens to a body on no sleep too. Those stress reactions can be useful, of course: they help you respond more readily to an actual physical threat. But that&#8217;s not usually what&#8217;s going on. And staying in an alert mode can trigger a number of unhealthy conditions, the most damaging of which is inflammation. Inflammation is the body&#8217;s natural defense system against injury or invading microbes like bacteria and viruses. It&#8217;s why your toe turns red and throbs when you stub it or when it&#8217;s infected: white blood cells rush to the area in order to protect it for the short time it&#8217;s needed to help you get better. But inflammation can also become chronic, and that&#8217;s when the real trouble starts. Chronic inflammation, doctors now know, is a leading driver of many diseases, including some cancers, cognitive decline, heart disease, Type 2 diabetes&#8211;even chronic pain. And one of the main drivers of chronic inflammation is, of course, not sleeping enough. Getting a decent night&#8217;s sleep, then, is good advice for all of us. Americans spent an estimated $41 billion on sleeping pills and other sleep aids in 2015; no matter how much we may boast about our stamina, we know intuitively that we need sleep, even if we don&#8217;t always know why. But scientists do. That&#8217;s why experts are insisting, with increasing frequency and noise, that sleep be a priority&#8211;as important or more than what you eat and how much you exercise. We wouldn&#8217;t dream of skipping meals on a regular basis, so why skimp on sleep? There&#8217;s still much about sleep that mystifies scientists&#8211;particularly about what goes wrong for so many of us, night after night. But as they chip away at the underlying causes of sleeplessness, they get ever closer to a cure. Harvard&#8217;s Zielinski, for one, is hopeful that they will eventually find a way to help more people sleep better every night. When he gave his sleepless mice a drug to fix the mutation that was interfering with their sleep in the first place, they began to slumber anew. This appears in the February 27, 2017 issue of TIME."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EThe fountain of youth may be closer than you ever thought\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":108299499,"featured_media":4672712,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[430952382,2224],"time_section":[204777764],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937789],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4672988\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4672988\u002Fprimary_tag"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4672988\u002Fprimary_section"}]},"_embedded":{"fortune:featured":[{"size":"landscape","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":4672712,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Flongevity-sleep-cure-erik-madigan-heck.jpg?quality=85","alt":"longevity-sleep-cure-erik-madigan-heck","caption":"","credit":"Erik Madigan Heck for TIME","title":"longevity-sleep-cure-erik-madigan-heck"},"video":[],"structured":false}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":430952382,"name":"Longevity 2017","slug":"longevity-2017","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":100849,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":11,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":204777764,"name":"Health","slug":"health","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":21,"taxonomy":"time_section","description":"The latest health news, trends, and commentary from TIME, covering medicine, mental health, diet, fitness, sex, aging, disease, healthcare, policy and more","parent":0,"count":5891,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["health"]}]}},{"id":4682990,"date":"2017-02-25T16:47:43","date_gmt":"2017-02-25T21:47:43","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4682990"},"modified":"2017-02-25T16:22:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-25T21:22:00","slug":"muhammad-ali-son-detained-airport","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4682990\u002Fmuhammad-ali-son-detained-airport\u002F","title":{"rendered":"Muhammad Ali's Son Detained at Airport and Was Asked 'Are you Muslim?'"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EMuhammad Ali&#8217;s son, who bears the boxing great&#8217;s name, was detained by immigration officials at a Florida airport and questioned about his ancestry and religion in what amounted to profiling, a family friend said Saturday.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EReturning from a Black History Month event in Jamaica, Muhammad Ali Jr. and his mother, Khalilah Camacho Ali, were pulled aside and separated from each other while going through the immigration checkpoint on Feb. 7 at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport, said Chris Mancini, a family friend and attorney.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ECamacho Ali was released a short time later after showing a photo of herself with her ex-husband, the former heavyweight boxing champion, Mancini said. But Ali Jr. was not carrying a photo of his world-famous father &mdash; a recipient of the Presidential Medal of Freedom.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAli Jr., 44, who confirmed his Muslim faith, was detained about two hours, despite telling officials that he&#8217;s Ali&#8217;s son and a native-born U.S. citizen, Mancini said. It was the first time Ali Jr. and his mother have ever been asked if they&#8217;re Muslim when re-entering the United States, he said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;From the way they were treated, from what was said to them, they can come up with no other rational explanation except they fell into a profiling program run by customs, which is designed to obtain information from anyone who says they&#8217;re a Muslim,&#8221; Mancini said in a phone interview. &#8220;It&#8217;s quite clear that what triggered his detention was his Arabic name and his religion.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EReached for comment Friday, a U.S. Customs and Border Protection spokesman said in an email: &#8220;Due to the restrictions of the Privacy Act, the U.S. Customs and Border Protection cannot discuss individual travelers; however, all international travelers arriving in the U.S. are subject to CBP inspection,&#8221; according to The Courier-Journal&#8217;s report about the detention.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAn airport spokesman referred questions on Saturday to customs and border protection officials.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDuring his detention, Ali Jr. was asked repeatedly about his lineage and his name, &#8220;as if that was a pre-programmed question that was part of a profile,&#8221; Mancini said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAli Jr. and his mother have been frequent global travelers. The family connects their treatment to President Donald Trump&#8217;s efforts to restrict immigration after calling during his campaign for a ban on Muslims entering the U.S.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;This has never happened to them before,&#8221; Mancini said. &#8220;They&#8217;re asked specifically about their Arabic names. Where they got their names from and whether they&#8217;re Muslims. It doesn&#8217;t take much to connect those dots to what Trump is doing.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ECamacho Ali and Ali Jr. live in Florida. They have not traveled abroad since, and are considering filing a federal lawsuit, he said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAli, the three-time heavyweight champion and humanitarian, died last June at age 74 after a long battle with Parkinson&#8217;s disease. People lined the streets of Louisville, Kentucky, to say goodbye to the city&#8217;s most celebrated son before a star-studded memorial service watched worldwide.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Muhammad Ali's son, who bears the boxing great's name, was detained by immigration officials at a Florida airport and questioned about his ancestry and religion in what amounted to profiling, a family friend said Saturday."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Returning from a Black History Month event in Jamaica, Muhammad Ali Jr. and his mother, Khalilah Camacho Ali, were pulled aside and separated from each other while going through the immigration checkpoint on Feb. 7 at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport, said Chris Mancini, a family friend and attorney."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Camacho Ali was released a short time later after showing a photo of herself with her ex-husband, the former heavyweight boxing champion, Mancini said. But Ali Jr. was not carrying a photo of his world-famous father — a recipient of the Presidential Medal of Freedom."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Ali Jr., 44, who confirmed his Muslim faith, was detained about two hours, despite telling officials that he's Ali's son and a native-born U.S. citizen, Mancini said. It was the first time Ali Jr. and his mother have ever been asked if they're Muslim when re-entering the United States, he said."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"From the way they were treated, from what was said to them, they can come up with no other rational explanation except they fell into a profiling program run by customs, which is designed to obtain information from anyone who says they're a Muslim,\" Mancini said in a phone interview. \"It's quite clear that what triggered his detention was his Arabic name and his religion.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Reached for comment Friday, a U.S. Customs and Border Protection spokesman said in an email: \"Due to the restrictions of the Privacy Act, the U.S. Customs and Border Protection cannot discuss individual travelers; however, all international travelers arriving in the U.S. are subject to CBP inspection,\" according to The Courier-Journal's report about the detention."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["An airport spokesman referred questions on Saturday to customs and border protection officials."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["During his detention, Ali Jr. was asked repeatedly about his lineage and his name, \"as if that was a pre-programmed question that was part of a profile,\" Mancini said."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Ali Jr. and his mother have been frequent global travelers. The family connects their treatment to President Donald Trump's efforts to restrict immigration after calling during his campaign for a ban on Muslims entering the U.S."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"This has never happened to them before,\" Mancini said. \"They're asked specifically about their Arabic names. Where they got their names from and whether they're Muslims. It doesn't take much to connect those dots to what Trump is doing.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Camacho Ali and Ali Jr. live in Florida. They have not traveled abroad since, and are considering filing a federal lawsuit, he said."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Ali, the three-time heavyweight champion and humanitarian, died last June at age 74 after a long battle with Parkinson's disease. People lined the streets of Louisville, Kentucky, to say goodbye to the city's most celebrated son before a star-studded memorial service watched worldwide."]}],"plain":"Muhammad Ali&#8217;s son, who bears the boxing great&#8217;s name, was detained by immigration officials at a Florida airport and questioned about his ancestry and religion in what amounted to profiling, a family friend said Saturday. Returning from a Black History Month event in Jamaica, Muhammad Ali Jr. and his mother, Khalilah Camacho Ali, were pulled aside and separated from each other while going through the immigration checkpoint on Feb. 7 at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport, said Chris Mancini, a family friend and attorney. Camacho Ali was released a short time later after showing a photo of herself with her ex-husband, the former heavyweight boxing champion, Mancini said. But Ali Jr. was not carrying a photo of his world-famous father &mdash; a recipient of the Presidential Medal of Freedom. Ali Jr., 44, who confirmed his Muslim faith, was detained about two hours, despite telling officials that he&#8217;s Ali&#8217;s son and a native-born U.S. citizen, Mancini said. It was the first time Ali Jr. and his mother have ever been asked if they&#8217;re Muslim when re-entering the United States, he said. &#8220;From the way they were treated, from what was said to them, they can come up with no other rational explanation except they fell into a profiling program run by customs, which is designed to obtain information from anyone who says they&#8217;re a Muslim,&#8221; Mancini said in a phone interview. &#8220;It&#8217;s quite clear that what triggered his detention was his Arabic name and his religion.&#8221; Reached for comment Friday, a U.S. Customs and Border Protection spokesman said in an email: &#8220;Due to the restrictions of the Privacy Act, the U.S. Customs and Border Protection cannot discuss individual travelers; however, all international travelers arriving in the U.S. are subject to CBP inspection,&#8221; according to The Courier-Journal&#8217;s report about the detention. An airport spokesman referred questions on Saturday to customs and border protection officials. During his detention, Ali Jr. was asked repeatedly about his lineage and his name, &#8220;as if that was a pre-programmed question that was part of a profile,&#8221; Mancini said. Ali Jr. and his mother have been frequent global travelers. The family connects their treatment to President Donald Trump&#8217;s efforts to restrict immigration after calling during his campaign for a ban on Muslims entering the U.S. &#8220;This has never happened to them before,&#8221; Mancini said. &#8220;They&#8217;re asked specifically about their Arabic names. Where they got their names from and whether they&#8217;re Muslims. It doesn&#8217;t take much to connect those dots to what Trump is doing.&#8221; Camacho Ali and Ali Jr. live in Florida. They have not traveled abroad since, and are considering filing a federal lawsuit, he said. Ali, the three-time heavyweight champion and humanitarian, died last June at age 74 after a long battle with Parkinson&#8217;s disease. People lined the streets of Louisville, Kentucky, to say goodbye to the city&#8217;s most celebrated son before a star-studded memorial service watched worldwide."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;It&#8217;s quite clear that what triggered his detention was his Arabic name and his religion,&#8221; a family friend and lawyer said\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":108310934,"featured_media":4682999,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[1657],"time_section":[204777754],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937772],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682990\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682990\u002Fprimary_tag"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682990\u002Fprimary_section"}]},"_embedded":{"fortune:featured":[{"size":"landscape","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":4682999,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmuhammad_ali_jr.jpg?quality=85","alt":"The late Muhammad Ali, with Muhammad Ali Jr., then 2 1\u002F2 years old, at Miami Beach, April 15, 1975. The boxing legend's son was detained and questioned by immigration officials at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport after returning to the U.S. from a trip to Jamaica.","caption":"The late Muhammad Ali, with Muhammad Ali Jr., then 2 1\u002F2 years old, at Miami Beach, April 15, 1975. The boxing legend's son was detained and questioned by immigration officials at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport after returning to the U.S. from a trip to Jamaica. ","credit":"AP","title":"The late Muhammad Ali, with Muhammad Ali Jr., then 2 1\u002F2 years old, at Miami Beach, April 15, 1975. The boxing legend's son was detained and questioned by immigration officials at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport after returning to the U.S. from a trip to Jamaica."},"video":[],"structured":false}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":1657,"name":"Florida","slug":"florida","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":2557,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":384,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":204777754,"name":"U.S.","slug":"us","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":16,"taxonomy":"time_section","description":"The latest news and analysis on crime, religion, education, transportation, weather, immigration, sports, drugs, the law, and other news from around the nation","parent":0,"count":11631,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["us"]}]}},{"id":4675860,"date":"2017-02-18T14:13:48","date_gmt":"2017-02-18T19:13:48","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4675860"},"modified":"2017-02-21T08:20:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-21T13:20:00","slug":"donald-trump-fake-news-attacks","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4675860\u002Fdonald-trump-fake-news-attacks\u002F","title":{"rendered":"Don't Dismiss President Trump's Attacks on the Media as Mere Stupidity"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003EBret Stephens delivered the Daniel Pearl Memorial Lecture this week at the University of California, Los Angeles. Read the full text of his remarks below:\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EI&rsquo;m profoundly honored to have this opportunity to celebrate the legacy of Danny Pearl, my colleague at \u003Cem\u003EThe Wall Street Journal.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EMy topic this evening is intellectual integrity in the age of \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4672974\u002Fdonald-trump-white-house-chaos\u002F\"\u003EDonald Trump\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. I suspect this is a theme that would have resonated with Danny.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EWhen you work at \u003Cem\u003EThe Wall Street Journal\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, the coins of the realm are truth and trust &mdash; the latter flowing exclusively from the former. When you read a story in the \u003Cem\u003EJournal\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, you do so with the assurance that immense reportorial and editorial effort has been expended to ensure that what you read is factual.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003ENot \u003Ci\u003Eprobably\u003C\u002Fi\u003E factual. Not \u003Ci\u003Epartially\u003C\u002Fi\u003E factual. Not \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4642689\u002Fkellyanne-conway-sean-spicer-donald-trump-alternative-facts\u002F\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003Ealternatively\u003C\u002Fi\u003E factual\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. I mean fundamentally, comprehensively and exclusively factual. And therefore trustworthy.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EThis is how we operate. This is how Danny operated. This is how he died, losing his life in an effort to nail down a story.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EIn the 15 years since Danny&rsquo;s death, the list of murdered journalists has grown long.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EPaul Klebnikov and Anna Politkovskaya in Russia.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EZahra Kazemi and Sattar Behesti in Iran.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EJim Foley and Steve Sotloff in Syria.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EFive journalists in Turkey. Twenty-six in Mexico. More than 100 in Iraq.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EWhen we honor Danny, we honor them, too.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EWe do more than that.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-portrait_small_2x aligncenter \"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"4676387\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4675860\u002Fdonald-trump-fake-news-attacks\u002Fthis-is-an-undated-file-photo-of-wall-street-journ\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fdaniel-pearl.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"2560,2783\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"0\",\"credit\":\"AFP\",\"camera\":\"\",\"caption\":\"JANUARY28:  This is an undated file photo of Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl who disappeared in the Pakistani port city of Karachi 23 January 2002 after telling his wife he was going to interview an Islamic group leader. US Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) agents arrived in Pakistan 28 January 2002 to join the search for Pearl, who they believed to have been kidnapped, police sources said. AFP PHOTO  (Photo credit should read AFP\\\u002FAFP\\\u002FGetty Images)\",\"created_timestamp\":\"1012204800\",\"copyright\":\"AFP\\\u002FGetty Images\",\"focal_length\":\"0\",\"iso\":\"0\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0\",\"title\":\"This is an undated file photo of Wall Street Journ\",\"orientation\":\"1\"}' data-image-title=\"This is an undated file photo of Wall Street Journ\" data-image-description=\"pWall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl disappeared in the Pakistani port city of Karachi  on Jan 23, 2002 after telling his wife he was going to interview an Islamic group leader. \u002Fp\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fdaniel-pearl.jpg?quality=85&w=276\" data-large-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fdaniel-pearl.jpg?quality=85&w=552\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fdaniel-pearl.jpg?w=560&#038;quality=85&#038;h=609\" alt=\"This is an undated file photo of Wall Street Journ\" height=\"609\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\" \u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\" \u003EAFP\u002FGetty Images\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"caption\" \u003EWall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl disappeared in the Pakistani port city of Karachi on Jan 23, 2002 after telling his wife he was going to interview an Islamic group leader. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EWe honor the central idea of journalism &mdash; the conviction, as my old boss Peter Kann once said, &ldquo;that facts are facts; that they are ascertainable through honest, open-minded and diligent reporting; that truth is attainable by laying fact upon fact, much like the construction of a cathedral; and that truth is not merely in the eye of the beholder.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EAnd we honor the responsibility to separate truth from falsehood, which is never more important than when powerful people insist that falsehoods are truths, or that there is no such thing as truth to begin with.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003ESo that&rsquo;s the business we&rsquo;re in: the business of journalism. Or, as the 45th president of the United States likes to call us, the \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4673707\u002Fdonald-trump-press-conference-news-media\u002F\"\u003E&ldquo;disgusting and corrupt media.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Cdiv class=\"video-container\"\u003E\u003Cvideo id=\"brightcove-player-5325845908001\" data-video-id=\"5325845908001\" data-account=\"293884104\" data-player=\"SJa0Thl7\" data-embed=\"default\" autoplay controls preload=\"auto\" class=\"video-js responsive-video\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fvideo\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003ESome of you may have noticed that we&rsquo;re living through a period in which the executive branch of government is engaged in a systematic effort to create a climate of opinion against the news business.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EThe President routinely describes reporting he dislikes as FAKE NEWS. The Administration calls the press &ldquo;the opposition party,&rdquo; ridicules news organizations it doesn&rsquo;t like as business failures, and calls for journalists to be fired. Mr. Trump has called for rewriting libel laws in order to more easily sue the press.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EThis isn&rsquo;t unprecedented in U.S. history, though you might have to go back to the Administration of John Adams to see something quite like it. And so far the rhetorical salvos haven&rsquo;t been matched by legal or regulatory action. Maybe they never will be.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EBut the question of what Mr. Trump might yet do by political methods against the media matters a great deal less than what he is attempting to do by ideological and philosophical methods.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EIdeologically, the president is trying to depose so-called mainstream media in favor of the media he likes &mdash; Breitbart News and the rest. Another way of making this point is to say that he&rsquo;s trying to substitute news for propaganda, information for boosterism.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EHis objection to, say, the New York\u003Cem\u003E Times\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, isn&rsquo;t that there&rsquo;s a liberal bias in the paper that gets in the way of its objectivity, which I think would be a fair criticism. His objection is to objectivity itself. He&rsquo;s perfectly happy for the media to be disgusting and corrupt &mdash; so long as it&rsquo;s on his side.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EBut again, that&rsquo;s not all the president is doing.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EConsider this recent exchange he had with Bill O&rsquo;Reilly. O&rsquo;Reilly asks:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\" style=\"padding-left:30px;\"\u003EIs there any validity to the criticism of you that you say things that you can&rsquo;t back up factually, and as the President you say there are three million illegal aliens who voted and you don&rsquo;t have the data to back that up, some people are going to say that it&rsquo;s irresponsible for the President to say that.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003ETo which the president replies:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\" style=\"padding-left:30px;\"\u003EMany people have come out and said I&rsquo;m right.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003ENow many people also say Jim Morrison faked his own death. Many people say Barack Obama was born in Kenya. &ldquo;Many people say&rdquo; is what&rsquo;s known as an \u003Ci\u003Eargumentum ad populum\u003C\u002Fi\u003E. If we were a nation of logicians, we would dismiss the argument as dumb.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EWe are not a nation of logicians.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EI think it&rsquo;s important not to dismiss the president&rsquo;s reply simply as dumb. We ought to assume that it&rsquo;s darkly brilliant &mdash; if not in intention then certainly in effect. The president is responding to a \u003Ci\u003Eclaim of fact\u003C\u002Fi\u003E not by denying the \u003Ci\u003Efact\u003C\u002Fi\u003E, but by denying the claim that facts are supposed to have on an argument.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EHe isn&rsquo;t telling O&rsquo;Reilly that he&rsquo;s got his facts wrong. He&rsquo;s saying that, as far as he is concerned, facts, as most people understand the term, don&rsquo;t matter: That they are indistinguishable from, and interchangeable with, opinion; and that statements of fact needn&rsquo;t have any purchase against a man who is either sufficiently powerful to ignore them or sufficiently shameless to deny them &mdash; or, in his case, both.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EIf some of you in this room are students of political philosophy, you know where this argument originates. This is a version of Thrasymachus&rsquo;s argument in Plato&rsquo;s Republic that justice is the advantage of the stronger and that injustice &ldquo;if it is on a large enough scale, is stronger, freer, and more masterly than justice.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003ESubstitute the words &ldquo;truth&rdquo; and &ldquo;falsehood&rdquo; for &ldquo;justice&rdquo; and &ldquo;injustice,&rdquo; and there you have the Trumpian view of the world. If I had to sum it up in a single sentence, it would be this: \u003Ci\u003ETruth is what you can get away with\u003C\u002Fi\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EIf you can sell condos by claiming your building is 90% occupied when it&rsquo;s only 20% occupied, well, then&mdash;it&rsquo;s 90% occupied. If you can convince a sufficient number of people that you really did win the popular vote, or that your inauguration crowds were the biggest&mdash;well then, what do the statistical data and aerial photographs matter?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003ENow, we could have some interesting conversations about why this is happening&mdash;and why it seems to be happening all of a sudden.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EToday we have &ldquo;dis-intermediating&rdquo; technologies such as Twitter, which have cut out the media as the middleman between politicians and the public. Today, just 17% of adults aged 18-24 read a newspaper daily, down from 42% at the turn of the century. Today there are fewer than 33,000 full-time newsroom employees, a drop from 55,000 just 20 years ago.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EWhen Trump attacks the news media, he&rsquo;s kicking a wounded animal.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EBut the most interesting conversation is not about why Donald Trump lies. Many public figures lie, and he&rsquo;s only a severe example of a common type.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EThe interesting conversation concerns how we come to accept those lies.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003ENearly 25 years ago, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the great scholar and Democratic Senator from New York, coined the phrase, &ldquo;defining deviancy down.&rdquo; His topic at the time was crime, and how American society had come to accept ever-increasing rates of violent crime as normal.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003E&ldquo;We have been re-defining deviancy so as to exempt much conduct previously stigmatized, and also quietly raising the &lsquo;normal&rsquo; level in categories where behavior is now abnormal by any earlier standard,&rdquo; Moynihan wrote.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EYou can point to all sorts of ways in which this redefinition of deviancy has also been the story of our politics over the past 30 years, a story with a fully bipartisan set of villains.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EI personally think we crossed a rubicon in the Clinton years, when three things happened: we decided that some types of presidential lies didn&rsquo;t matter; we concluded that &ldquo;character&rdquo; was an over-rated consideration when it came to judging a president; and we allowed the lines between political culture and celebrity culture to become hopelessly blurred.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EBut whatever else one might say about President Clinton, what we have now is the crack-cocaine version of that.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EIf a public figure tells a whopping lie once in his life, it&rsquo;ll haunt him into his grave. If he lies morning, noon and night, it will become almost impossible to remember any one particular lie. \u003Ci\u003EOutrage will fall victim to its own ubiquity\u003C\u002Fi\u003E. It&rsquo;s the same truth contained in Stalin&rsquo;s famous remark that the death of one man is a tragedy but the death of a million is a statistic.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EOne of the most interesting phenomena during the presidential campaign was waiting for Trump to say that one thing that would surely break the back of his candidacy.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EWould it be his slander against Mexican immigrants? Or his slur about John McCain&rsquo;s record as a POW? Or his lie about New Jersey Muslims celebrating 9\u002F11? Or his attacks on Megyn Kelly, on a disabled New York Times reporter, on a Mexican-American judge? Would it be him tweeting quotations from Benito Mussolini, or his sly overtures to David Duke and the alt-right? Would it be his unwavering praise of Vladimir Putin? Would it be his refusal to release his tax returns, or the sham that seems to been perpetrated on the saps who signed up for his Trump U courses? Would it be the tape of him with Billy Bush?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003ENone of this made the slightest difference. On the contrary, it helped him. Some people became desensitized by the never-ending assaults on what was once quaintly known as &ldquo;human decency.&rdquo; Others seemed to positively admire the comments as refreshing examples of personal authenticity and political incorrectness.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EShameless rhetoric will always find a receptive audience with shameless people. Donald Trump&rsquo;s was the greatest political strip-tease act in U.S. political history: the dirtier he got, the more skin he showed, the more his core supporters liked it.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EAbraham Lincoln, in his first inaugural address, called on Americans to summon &ldquo;the better angels of our nature.&rdquo; Donald Trump&rsquo;s candidacy, and so far his presidency, has been Lincoln&rsquo;s exhortation in reverse.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EHere&rsquo;s a simple truth about a politics of dishonesty, insult and scandal: It&rsquo;s entertaining. Politics as we&rsquo;ve had it for most of my life has, with just a few exceptions, been distant and dull.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003ENow it&rsquo;s all we can talk about. If you like Trump, his presence in the White House is a daily extravaganza of sticking it to pompous elites and querulous reporters. If you hate Trump, you wake up every day with some fresh outrage to turn over in your head and text your friends about.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EWhichever way, it&rsquo;s exhilarating. Haven&rsquo;t all of us noticed that everything feels speeded up, more vivid, more intense and consequential? One of the benefits of an alternative-facts administration is that fiction can take you anywhere.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EEarlier today, at his press conference, the president claimed his administration is running like a &ldquo;fine-tuned machine.&rdquo; In actual fact, he just lost his Labor Secretary nominee, his National Security Adviser was forced out in disgrace, and the Intelligence Community is refusing to fully brief the president for fear he might compromise sources and methods.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EBut who cares? Since when in Washington has there been a presidential press conference like that? Since when has the denial of reality been taken to such a bald-faced extreme?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EAt some point, it becomes increasingly easy for people to mistake the reality of the performance for reality itself. If Trump can get through a press conference like that without showing a hint of embarrassment, remorse or misgiving&mdash;well, then, that becomes a new basis on which the president can now be judged.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003ETo tell a lie is wrong. But to tell a lie with brass takes skill. Ultimately, Trump&rsquo;s press conference will be judged not on some kind of Olympic point system, but on whether he &ldquo;won&rdquo;&mdash;which is to say, whether he brazened his way through it. And the answer to that is almost certainly yes.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003ESo far, I&rsquo;ve offered you three ideas about how it is that we have come to accept the president&rsquo;s behavior.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EThe first is that we normalize it, simply by becoming inured to constant repetition of the same bad behavior.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EThe second is that at some level it excites and entertains us. By putting aside our usual moral filters&mdash;the ones that tell us that truth matters, that upright conduct matters, that things ought to be done in a certain way&mdash;we have been given tickets to a spectacle, in which all you want to do is watch.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EAnd the third is that we adopt new metrics of judgment, in which politics becomes more about perceptions than performance&mdash;of how a given action \u003Ci\u003Eis perceived as being perceived\u003C\u002Fi\u003E. If a reporter for the New York Times says that Trump&rsquo;s press conference probably plays well in Peoria, then that increases the chances that it will play well in Peoria.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003ELet me add a fourth point here: our tendency to rationalize.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EOne of the more fascinating aspects of last year&rsquo;s presidential campaign was the rise of a class of pundits I call the &ldquo;TrumpXplainers.&rdquo; For instance, Trump would give a speech or offer an answer in a debate that amounted to little more than a word jumble.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EBut rather than quote Trump, or point out that what he had said was grammatically and logically nonsensical, the TrumpXplainers would tell us what he had allegedly \u003Ci\u003Emeant\u003C\u002Fi\u003E to say. They became our political semioticians, ascribing pattern and meaning to the rune-stones of Trump&rsquo;s mind.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EIf Trump said he&rsquo;d get Mexico to pay for his wall, you could count on someone to provide a complex tariff scheme to make good on the promise. If Trump said that we should not have gone into Iraq but that, once there, we should have &ldquo;taken the oil,&rdquo; we&rsquo;d have a similarly high-flown explanation as to how we could engineer this theft.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EA year ago, when he was trying to explain his idea of a foreign policy to the New York Times&rsquo;s David Sanger, the reporter asked him whether it didn&rsquo;t amount to a kind of &ldquo;America First policy&rdquo;&mdash;a reference to the isolationist and anti-Semitic America First Committee that tried to prevent U.S. entry into World War II. Trump clearly had never heard of the group, but he liked the phrase and made it his own. And that&rsquo;s how we got the return of America First.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EMore recently, I came across this headline in the conservative Washington Times: &ldquo;How Trump&rsquo;s &lsquo;disarray&rsquo; may be merely a strategy,&rdquo; by Wesley Pruden, the paper&rsquo;s former editor-in-chief. In his view, the president&rsquo;s first disastrous month in office is, in fact, evidence of a refreshing openness to dissent, reminiscent of Washington and Lincoln&rsquo;s cabinet of rivals. Sure.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EOverall, the process is one in which explanation becomes rationalization, which in turn becomes justification. Trump says X. What he really means is Y. And while you might not like it, he&rsquo;s giving voice to the angers and anxieties of Z. Who, by the way, you&rsquo;re not allowed to question or criticize, because anxiety and anger are their own justifications these days.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EWatching this process unfold has been particularly painful for me as a conservative columnist. I find myself in the awkward position of having recently become popular among some of my liberal peers&mdash;precisely because I \u003Ci\u003Ehaven&rsquo;t\u003C\u002Fi\u003E changed my opinions about anything.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EBy contrast, I&rsquo;ve become suddenly unpopular among some of my former fans on the right&mdash;again, because I&rsquo;ve stuck to my views. It is almost amusing to be accused of suffering from something called &ldquo;Trump Derangement Syndrome&rdquo; simply because I feel an obligation to raise my voice against, say, the president suggesting a moral equivalency between the U.S. and Vladimir Putin&rsquo;s Russia.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EThe most painful aspect of this has been to watch people I previously considered thoughtful and principled conservatives give themselves over to a species of illiberal politics from which I once thought they were immune.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EIn his 1953 masterpiece, &ldquo;The Captive Mind,&rdquo; the Polish poet and dissident Czeslaw Milosz analyzed the psychological and intellectual pathways through which some of his former colleagues in Poland&rsquo;s post-war Communist regime allowed themselves to be converted into ardent Stalinists. In none of the cases that Milosz analyzed was coercion the main reason for the conversion.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EThey \u003Ci\u003Ewanted\u003C\u002Fi\u003E to believe. They were willing to \u003Ci\u003Eadapt\u003C\u002Fi\u003E. They thought they could do more good from the inside. They convinced themselves that their former principles didn&rsquo;t fit with the march of history, or that to hold fast to one&rsquo;s beliefs was a sign of priggishness and pig-headedness. They felt that to reject the new order of things was to relegate themselves to irrelevance and oblivion. They mocked their former friends who refused to join the new order as morally vain reactionaries. They convinced themselves that, brutal and capricious as Stalinism might be, it couldn&rsquo;t possibly be worse than the exploitative capitalism of the West.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EI fear we are witnessing a similar process unfold among many conservative intellectuals on the right. It has been stunning to watch a movement that once believed in the benefits of free trade and free enterprise merrily give itself over to a champion of protectionism whose economic instincts recall the corporatism of 1930s Italy or 1950s Argentina. It is no less stunning to watch people who once mocked Obama for being too soft on Russia suddenly discover the virtues of Trump&rsquo;s &ldquo;pragmatism&rdquo; on the subject.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EAnd it is nothing short of amazing to watch the party of onetime moral majoritarians, who spent a decade fulminating about Bill Clinton&rsquo;s sexual habits, suddenly find complete comfort with the idea that character and temperament are irrelevant qualifications for high office.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EThe mental pathways by which the new Trumpian conservatives have made their peace with their new political master aren&rsquo;t so different from Milosz&rsquo;s former colleagues.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EThere&rsquo;s the same desperate desire for political influence; the same belief that Trump represents a historical force to which they ought to belong; the same willingness to bend or discard principles they once considered sacred; the same fear of seeming out-of-touch with the mood of the public; the same tendency to look the other way at comments or actions that they cannot possibly justify; the same belief that you do more good by joining than by opposing; the same Manichean belief that, if Hillary Clinton had been elected, the United States would have all-but ended as a country.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EThis is supposed to be the road of pragmatism, of turning lemons into lemonade. I would counter that it&rsquo;s the road of ignominy, of hitching a ride with a drunk driver.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003ESo, then, to the subject that brings me here today: Maintaining intellectual integrity in the age of Trump.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EWhen Judea wrote me last summer to ask if I&rsquo;d be this year&rsquo;s speaker, I got my copy of Danny&rsquo;s collected writings, &ldquo;At Home in the World,&rdquo; and began to read him all over again. It brought back to me the fact that, the reason we honor Danny&rsquo;s memory isn&rsquo;t that he&rsquo;s a martyred journalist. It&rsquo;s that he was a great journalist.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003ELet me show you what I mean. Here&rsquo;s something Danny wrote in February 2001, almost exactly a year before his death, from the site of an earthquake disaster in the Indian town of Anjar.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\" style=\"padding-left:30px;\"\u003EWhat is India&rsquo;s earthquake zone really like? It smells. It reeks. You can&rsquo;t imagine the odor of several hundred bodies decaying for five days as search teams pick away at slabs of crumbled buildings in this town. Even if you&rsquo;ve never smelled it before, the brain knows what it is, and orders you to get away. After a day, the nose gets stuffed up in self-defense. But the brain has registered the scent, and picks it up in innocent places: lip balm, sweet candy, stale breath, an airplane seat.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EWhat stands out for me in this passage is that it shows that Danny was a writer who observed with all his senses. He saw. He listened. He smelled. He bore down. He reflected. He understood that what the reader had to know about Anjar wasn&rsquo;t a collection of statistics; it was the visceral reality of a massive human tragedy. And he was able to express all this in language that was compact, unadorned, compelling and deeply true.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EGeorge Orwell wrote, &ldquo;To see what is in front of one&rsquo;s nose needs a constant struggle.&rdquo; Danny saw what was in front of his nose.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EWe each have our obligations to see what&rsquo;s in front of one&rsquo;s nose, whether we&rsquo;re reporters, columnists, or anything else. This is the essence of intellectual integrity.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003ENot to look around, or beyond, or away from the facts, but to look straight at them, to recognize and call them for what they are, nothing more or less. To see things as they are before we re-interpret them into what we&rsquo;d like them to be. To believe in an epistemology that can distinguish between truth and falsity, facts and opinions, evidence and wishes. To defend habits of mind and institutions of society, above all a free press, which preserve that epistemology. To hold fast to a set of intellectual standards and moral convictions that won&rsquo;t waver amid changes of political fashion or tides of unfavorable opinion. To speak the truth irrespective of what it means for our popularity or influence.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EThe legacy of Danny Pearl is that he died for this. We are being asked to do much less. We have no excuse not to do it.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EThank you.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Bret Stephens delivered the Daniel Pearl Memorial Lecture this week at the University of California, Los Angeles. I suspect this is a theme that would have resonated with Danny."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["When you work at ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["The Wall Street Journal"]},", the coins of the realm are truth and trust — the latter flowing exclusively from the former. When you read a story in the ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Journal"]},", you do so with the assurance that immense reportorial and editorial effort has been expended to ensure that what you read is factual."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Not ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["probably"]}," factual. I mean fundamentally, comprehensively and exclusively factual. And therefore trustworthy."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["This is how we operate. This is how Danny operated. This is how he died, losing his life in an effort to nail down a story."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In the 15 years since Danny’s death, the list of murdered journalists has grown long."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Paul Klebnikov and Anna Politkovskaya in Russia."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Zahra Kazemi and Sattar Behesti in Iran."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Jim Foley and Steve Sotloff in Syria."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Five journalists in Turkey.
