"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"figcredit","attributes":[],"content":["AFP\u002FGetty Images"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["We honor the central idea of journalism — the conviction, as my old boss Peter Kann once said, “that facts are facts; that they are ascertainable through honest, open-minded and diligent reporting; that truth is attainable by laying fact upon fact, much like the construction of a cathedral; and that truth is not merely in the eye of the beholder.”"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["And we honor the responsibility to separate truth from falsehood, which is never more important than when powerful people insist that falsehoods are truths, or that there is no such thing as truth to begin with."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["So that’s the business we’re in: the business of journalism. Or, as the 45th president of the United States likes to call us, the ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4673707\u002Fdonald-trump-press-conference-news-media\u002F"},"content":["“disgusting and corrupt media.”"]}]},{"tag":"video","attributes":{"autoplay":"1","controls":"1","videoid":"5325845908001"},"content":[]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Some of you may have noticed that we’re living through a period in which the executive branch of government is engaged in a systematic effort to create a climate of opinion against the news business."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The President routinely describes reporting he dislikes as FAKE NEWS. The Administration calls the press “the opposition party,” ridicules news organizations it doesn’t like as business failures, and calls for journalists to be fired. Mr. Trump has called for rewriting libel laws in order to more easily sue the press."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["This isn’t unprecedented in U.S. history, though you might have to go back to the Administration of John Adams to see something quite like it. And so far the rhetorical salvos haven’t been matched by legal or regulatory action. Maybe they never will be."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["But the question of what Mr. Trump might yet do by political methods against the media matters a great deal less than what he is attempting to do by ideological and philosophical methods."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Ideologically, the president is trying to depose so-called mainstream media in favor of the media he likes — Breitbart News and the rest. Another way of making this point is to say that he’s trying to substitute news for propaganda, information for boosterism."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["His objection to, say, the New York",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[" Times"]},", isn’t that there’s a liberal bias in the paper that gets in the way of its objectivity, which I think would be a fair criticism. His objection is to objectivity itself. He’s perfectly happy for the media to be disgusting and corrupt — so long as it’s on his side."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["But again, that’s not all the president is doing."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Consider this recent exchange he had with Bill O’Reilly. O’Reilly asks:"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":{"style":"padding-left:30px;"},"content":["Is there any validity to the criticism of you that you say things that you can’t back up factually, and as the President you say there are three million illegal aliens who voted and you don’t have the data to back that up, some people are going to say that it’s irresponsible for the President to say that."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["To which the president replies:"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":{"style":"padding-left:30px;"},"content":["Many people have come out and said I’m right."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Now many people also say Jim Morrison faked his own death. Many people say Barack Obama was born in Kenya. “Many people say” is what’s known as an ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["argumentum ad populum"]},". If we were a nation of logicians, we would dismiss the argument as dumb."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["We are not a nation of logicians."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["I think it’s important not to dismiss the president’s reply simply as dumb. We ought to assume that it’s darkly brilliant — if not in intention then certainly in effect. The president is responding to a ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["claim of fact"]}," not by denying the ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["fact"]},", but by denying the claim that facts are supposed to have on an argument."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["He isn’t telling O’Reilly that he’s got his facts wrong. He’s saying that, as far as he is concerned, facts, as most people understand the term, don’t matter: That they are indistinguishable from, and interchangeable with, opinion; and that statements of fact needn’t have any purchase against a man who is either sufficiently powerful to ignore them or sufficiently shameless to deny them — or, in his case, both."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["If some of you in this room are students of political philosophy, you know where this argument originates. This is a version of Thrasymachus’s argument in Plato’s Republic that justice is the advantage of the stronger and that injustice “if it is on a large enough scale, is stronger, freer, and more masterly than justice.”"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Substitute the words “truth” and “falsehood” for “justice” and “injustice,” and there you have the Trumpian view of the world. If I had to sum it up in a single sentence, it would be this: ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Truth is what you can get away with"]},"."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["If you can sell condos by claiming your building is 90% occupied when it’s only 20% occupied, well, then—it’s 90% occupied. If you can convince a sufficient number of people that you really did win the popular vote, or that your inauguration crowds were the biggest—well then, what do the statistical data and aerial photographs matter?"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Now, we could have some interesting conversations about why this is happening—and why it seems to be happening all of a sudden."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Today we have “dis-intermediating” technologies such as Twitter, which have cut out the media as the middleman between politicians and the public. Today, just 17% of adults aged 18-24 read a newspaper daily, down from 42% at the turn of the century. Today there are fewer than 33,000 full-time newsroom employees, a drop from 55,000 just 20 years ago."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["When Trump attacks the news media, he’s kicking a wounded animal."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["But the most interesting conversation is not about why Donald Trump lies. Many public figures lie, and he’s only a severe example of a common type."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The interesting conversation concerns how we come to accept those lies."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Nearly 25 years ago, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the great scholar and Democratic Senator from New York, coined the phrase, “defining deviancy down.” His topic at the time was crime, and how American society had come to accept ever-increasing rates of violent crime as normal."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["“We have been re-defining deviancy so as to exempt much conduct previously stigmatized, and also quietly raising the ‘normal’ level in categories where behavior is now abnormal by any earlier standard,” Moynihan wrote."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["You can point to all sorts of ways in which this redefinition of deviancy has also been the story of our politics over the past 30 years, a story with a fully bipartisan set of villains."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["I personally think we crossed a rubicon in the Clinton years, when three things happened: we decided that some types of presidential lies didn’t matter; we concluded that “character” was an over-rated consideration when it came to judging a president; and we allowed the lines between political culture and celebrity culture to become hopelessly blurred."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["But whatever else one might say about President Clinton, what we have now is the crack-cocaine version of that."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["If a public figure tells a whopping lie once in his life, it’ll haunt him into his grave. Donald Trump’s was the greatest political strip-tease act in U.S. political history: the dirtier he got, the more skin he showed, the more his core supporters liked it."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Abraham Lincoln, in his first inaugural address, called on Americans to summon “the better angels of our nature.” Donald Trump’s candidacy, and so far his presidency, has been Lincoln’s exhortation in reverse."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Here’s a simple truth about a politics of dishonesty, insult and scandal: It’s entertaining. Politics as we’ve had it for most of my life has, with just a few exceptions, been distant and dull."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Now it’s all we can talk about. One of the benefits of an alternative-facts administration is that fiction can take you anywhere."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Earlier today, at his press conference, the president claimed his administration is running like a “fine-tuned machine.” In actual fact, he just lost his Labor Secretary nominee, his National Security Adviser was forced out in disgrace, and the Intelligence Community is refusing to fully brief the president for fear he might compromise sources and methods."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["But who cares? Since when in Washington has there been a presidential press conference like that? Since when has the denial of reality been taken to such a bald-faced extreme?"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["At some point, it becomes increasingly easy for people to mistake the reality of the performance for reality itself. If Trump can get through a press conference like that without showing a hint of embarrassment, remorse or misgiving—well, then, that becomes a new basis on which the president can now be judged."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["To tell a lie is wrong. But to tell a lie with brass takes skill. Ultimately, Trump’s press conference will be judged not on some kind of Olympic point system, but on whether he “won”—which is to say, whether he brazened his way through it. And the answer to that is almost certainly yes."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["So far, I’ve offered you three ideas about how it is that we have come to accept the president’s behavior."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The first is that we normalize it, simply by becoming inured to constant repetition of the same bad behavior."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The second is that at some level it excites and entertains us. By putting aside our usual moral filters—the ones that tell us that truth matters, that upright conduct matters, that things ought to be done in a certain way—we have been given tickets to a spectacle, in which all you want to do is watch."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["And the third is that we adopt new metrics of judgment, in which politics becomes more about perceptions than performance—of how a given action ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["is perceived as being perceived"]},". If a reporter for the New York Times says that Trump’s press conference probably plays well in Peoria, then that increases the chances that it will play well in Peoria."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Let me add a fourth point here: our tendency to rationalize."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["One of the more fascinating aspects of last year’s presidential campaign was the rise of a class of pundits I call the “TrumpXplainers.” For instance, Trump would give a speech or offer an answer in a debate that amounted to little more than a word jumble."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["But rather than quote Trump, or point out that what he had said was grammatically and logically nonsensical, the TrumpXplainers would tell us what he had allegedly ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["meant"]}," to say. They became our political semioticians, ascribing pattern and meaning to the rune-stones of Trump’s mind."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["If Trump said he’d get Mexico to pay for his wall, you could count on someone to provide a complex tariff scheme to make good on the promise. If Trump said that we should not have gone into Iraq but that, once there, we should have “taken the oil,” we’d have a similarly high-flown explanation as to how we could engineer this theft."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["A year ago, when he was trying to explain his idea of a foreign policy to the New York Times’s David Sanger, the reporter asked him whether it didn’t amount to a kind of “America First policy”—a reference to the isolationist and anti-Semitic America First Committee that tried to prevent U.S. entry into World War II. Trump clearly had never heard of the group, but he liked the phrase and made it his own. And that’s how we got the return of America First."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["More recently, I came across this headline in the conservative Washington Times: “How Trump’s ‘disarray’ may be merely a strategy,” by Wesley Pruden, the paper’s former editor-in-chief. In his view, the president’s first disastrous month in office is, in fact, evidence of a refreshing openness to dissent, reminiscent of Washington and Lincoln’s cabinet of rivals. Sure."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Overall, the process is one in which explanation becomes rationalization, which in turn becomes justification. Trump says X. What he really means is Y. And while you might not like it, he’s giving voice to the angers and anxieties of Z. Who, by the way, you’re not allowed to question or criticize, because anxiety and anger are their own justifications these days."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Watching this process unfold has been particularly painful for me as a conservative columnist. I find myself in the awkward position of having recently become popular among some of my liberal peers—precisely because I ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["haven’t"]}," changed my opinions about anything."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["By contrast, I’ve become suddenly unpopular among some of my former fans on the right—again, because I’ve stuck to my views. It is almost amusing to be accused of suffering from something called “Trump Derangement Syndrome” simply because I feel an obligation to raise my voice against, say, the president suggesting a moral equivalency between the U.S. and Vladimir Putin’s Russia."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The most painful aspect of this has been to watch people I previously considered thoughtful and principled conservatives give themselves over to a species of illiberal politics from which I once thought they were immune."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In his 1953 masterpiece, “The Captive Mind,” the Polish poet and dissident Czeslaw Milosz analyzed the psychological and intellectual pathways through which some of his former colleagues in Poland’s post-war Communist regime allowed themselves to be converted into ardent Stalinists. In none of the cases that Milosz analyzed was coercion the main reason for the conversion."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["They ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["wanted"]}," to believe. They were willing to ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["adapt"]},". They thought they could do more good from the inside. They convinced themselves that their former principles didn’t fit with the march of history, or that to hold fast to one’s beliefs was a sign of priggishness and pig-headedness. They felt that to reject the new order of things was to relegate themselves to irrelevance and oblivion. They mocked their former friends who refused to join the new order as morally vain reactionaries. They convinced themselves that, brutal and capricious as Stalinism might be, it couldn’t possibly be worse than the exploitative capitalism of the West."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["I fear we are witnessing a similar process unfold among many conservative intellectuals on the right. It has been stunning to watch a movement that once believed in the benefits of free trade and free enterprise merrily give itself over to a champion of protectionism whose economic instincts recall the corporatism of 1930s Italy or 1950s Argentina. It is no less stunning to watch people who once mocked Obama for being too soft on Russia suddenly discover the virtues of Trump’s “pragmatism” on the subject."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["And it is nothing short of amazing to watch the party of onetime moral majoritarians, who spent a decade fulminating about Bill Clinton’s sexual habits, suddenly find complete comfort with the idea that character and temperament are irrelevant qualifications for high office."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The mental pathways by which the new Trumpian conservatives have made their peace with their new political master aren’t so different from Milosz’s former colleagues."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["There’s the same desperate desire for political influence; the same belief that Trump represents a historical force to which they ought to belong; the same willingness to bend or discard principles they once considered sacred; the same fear of seeming out-of-touch with the mood of the public; the same tendency to look the other way at comments or actions that they cannot possibly justify; the same belief that you do more good by joining than by opposing; the same Manichean belief that, if Hillary Clinton had been elected, the United States would have all-but ended as a country."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["This is supposed to be the road of pragmatism, of turning lemons into lemonade. I would counter that it’s the road of ignominy, of hitching a ride with a drunk driver."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["So, then, to the subject that brings me here today: Maintaining intellectual integrity in the age of Trump."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["When Judea wrote me last summer to ask if I’d be this year’s speaker, I got my copy of Danny’s collected writings, “At Home in the World,” and began to read him all over again. It brought back to me the fact that, the reason we honor Danny’s memory isn’t that he’s a martyred journalist. It’s that he was a great journalist."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Let me show you what I mean. Here’s something Danny wrote in February 2001, almost exactly a year before his death, from the site of an earthquake disaster in the Indian town of Anjar."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":{"style":"padding-left:30px;"},"content":["What is India’s earthquake zone really like? It smells. It reeks. You can’t imagine the odor of several hundred bodies decaying for five days as search teams pick away at slabs of crumbled buildings in this town. Even if you’ve never smelled it before, the brain knows what it is, and orders you to get away. After a day, the nose gets stuffed up in self-defense. But the brain has registered the scent, and picks it up in innocent places: lip balm, sweet candy, stale breath, an airplane seat."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["What stands out for me in this passage is that it shows that Danny was a writer who observed with all his senses. He saw. He listened. He smelled. He bore down. He reflected. He understood that what the reader had to know about Anjar wasn’t a collection of statistics; it was the visceral reality of a massive human tragedy. And he was able to express all this in language that was compact, unadorned, compelling and deeply true."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["George Orwell wrote, “To see what is in front of one’s nose needs a constant struggle.” Danny saw what was in front of his nose."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["We each have our obligations to see what’s in front of one’s nose, whether we’re reporters, columnists, or anything else. This is the essence of intellectual integrity."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Not to look around, or beyond, or away from the facts, but to look straight at them, to recognize and call them for what they are, nothing more or less. To see things as they are before we re-interpret them into what we’d like them to be. To believe in an epistemology that can distinguish between truth and falsity, facts and opinions, evidence and wishes. To defend habits of mind and institutions of society, above all a free press, which preserve that epistemology. To hold fast to a set of intellectual standards and moral convictions that won’t waver amid changes of political fashion or tides of unfavorable opinion. To speak the truth irrespective of what it means for our popularity or influence."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The legacy of Danny Pearl is that he died for this. We are being asked to do much less. We have no excuse not to do it."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Thank you."]}],"plain":"Bret Stephens delivered the Daniel Pearl Memorial Lecture this week at the University of California, Los Angeles. Read the full text of his remarks below: I&rsquo;m profoundly honored to have this opportunity to celebrate the legacy of Danny Pearl, my colleague at The Wall Street Journal. My topic this evening is intellectual integrity in the age of Donald Trump. I suspect this is a theme that would have resonated with Danny. When you work at The Wall Street Journal, the coins of the realm are truth and trust &mdash; the latter flowing exclusively from the former. When you read a story in the Journal, you do so with the assurance that immense reportorial and editorial effort has been expended to ensure that what you read is factual. Not probably factual. Not partially factual. Not alternatively factual. I mean fundamentally, comprehensively and exclusively factual. And therefore trustworthy. This is how we operate. This is how Danny operated. This is how he died, losing his life in an effort to nail down a story. In the 15 years since Danny&rsquo;s death, the list of murdered journalists has grown long. Paul Klebnikov and Anna Politkovskaya in Russia. Zahra Kazemi and Sattar Behesti in Iran. Jim Foley and Steve Sotloff in Syria. Five journalists in Turkey. Twenty-six in Mexico. More than 100 in Iraq. When we honor Danny, we honor them, too. We do more than that. AFP\u002FGetty ImagesWall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl disappeared in the Pakistani port city of Karachi on Jan 23, 2002 after telling his wife he was going to interview an Islamic group leader. We honor the central idea of journalism &mdash; the conviction, as my old boss Peter Kann once said, &ldquo;that facts are facts; that they are ascertainable through honest, open-minded and diligent reporting; that truth is attainable by laying fact upon fact, much like the construction of a cathedral; and that truth is not merely in the eye of the beholder.&rdquo; And we honor the responsibility to separate truth from falsehood, which is never more important than when powerful people insist that falsehoods are truths, or that there is no such thing as truth to begin with. So that&rsquo;s the business we&rsquo;re in: the business of journalism. Or, as the 45th president of the United States likes to call us, the &ldquo;disgusting and corrupt media.&rdquo; Some of you may have noticed that we&rsquo;re living through a period in which the executive branch of government is engaged in a systematic effort to create a climate of opinion against the news business. The President routinely describes reporting he dislikes as FAKE NEWS. The Administration calls the press &ldquo;the opposition party,&rdquo; ridicules news organizations it doesn&rsquo;t like as business failures, and calls for journalists to be fired. Mr. Trump has called for rewriting libel laws in order to more easily sue the press. This isn&rsquo;t unprecedented in U.S. history, though you might have to go back to the Administration of John Adams to see something quite like it. And so far the rhetorical salvos haven&rsquo;t been matched by legal or regulatory action. Maybe they never will be. But the question of what Mr. Trump might yet do by political methods against the media matters a great deal less than what he is attempting to do by ideological and philosophical methods. Ideologically, the president is trying to depose so-called mainstream media in favor of the media he likes &mdash; Breitbart News and the rest. Another way of making this point is to say that he&rsquo;s trying to substitute news for propaganda, information for boosterism. His objection to, say, the New York Times, isn&rsquo;t that there&rsquo;s a liberal bias in the paper that gets in the way of its objectivity, which I think would be a fair criticism. His objection is to objectivity itself. He&rsquo;s perfectly happy for the media to be disgusting and corrupt &mdash; so long as it&rsquo;s on his side. But again, that&rsquo;s not all the president is doing. Consider this recent exchange he had with Bill O&rsquo;Reilly. O&rsquo;Reilly asks: Is there any validity to the criticism of you that you say things that you can&rsquo;t back up factually, and as the President you say there are three million illegal aliens who voted and you don&rsquo;t have the data to back that up, some people are going to say that it&rsquo;s irresponsible for the President to say that. To which the president replies: Many people have come out and said I&rsquo;m right. Now many people also say Jim Morrison faked his own death. Many people say Barack Obama was born in Kenya. &ldquo;Many people say&rdquo; is what&rsquo;s known as an argumentum ad populum. If we were a nation of logicians, we would dismiss the argument as dumb. We are not a nation of logicians. I think it&rsquo;s important not to dismiss the president&rsquo;s reply simply as dumb. We ought to assume that it&rsquo;s darkly brilliant &mdash; if not in intention then certainly in effect. The president is responding to a claim of fact not by denying the fact, but by denying the claim that facts are supposed to have on an argument. He isn&rsquo;t telling O&rsquo;Reilly that he&rsquo;s got his facts wrong. He&rsquo;s saying that, as far as he is concerned, facts, as most people understand the term, don&rsquo;t matter: That they are indistinguishable from, and interchangeable with, opinion; and that statements of fact needn&rsquo;t have any purchase against a man who is either sufficiently powerful to ignore them or sufficiently shameless to deny them &mdash; or, in his case, both. If some of you in this room are students of political philosophy, you know where this argument originates. This is a version of Thrasymachus&rsquo;s argument in Plato&rsquo;s Republic that justice is the advantage of the stronger and that injustice &ldquo;if it is on a large enough scale, is stronger, freer, and more masterly than justice.&rdquo; Substitute the words &ldquo;truth&rdquo; and &ldquo;falsehood&rdquo; for &ldquo;justice&rdquo; and &ldquo;injustice,&rdquo; and there you have the Trumpian view of the world. If I had to sum it up in a single sentence, it would be this: Truth is what you can get away with. If you can sell condos by claiming your building is 90% occupied when it&rsquo;s only 20% occupied, well, then&mdash;it&rsquo;s 90% occupied. If you can convince a sufficient number of people that you really did win the popular vote, or that your inauguration crowds were the biggest&mdash;well then, what do the statistical data and aerial photographs matter? Now, we could have some interesting conversations about why this is happening&mdash;and why it seems to be happening all of a sudden. Today we have &ldquo;dis-intermediating&rdquo; technologies such as Twitter, which have cut out the media as the middleman between politicians and the public. Today, just 17% of adults aged 18-24 read a newspaper daily, down from 42% at the turn of the century. Today there are fewer than 33,000 full-time newsroom employees, a drop from 55,000 just 20 years ago. When Trump attacks the news media, he&rsquo;s kicking a wounded animal. But the most interesting conversation is not about why Donald Trump lies. Many public figures lie, and he&rsquo;s only a severe example of a common type. The interesting conversation concerns how we come to accept those lies. Nearly 25 years ago, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the great scholar and Democratic Senator from New York, coined the phrase, &ldquo;defining deviancy down.&rdquo; His topic at the time was crime, and how American society had come to accept ever-increasing rates of violent crime as normal. &ldquo;We have been re-defining deviancy so as to exempt much conduct previously stigmatized, and also quietly raising the &lsquo;normal&rsquo; level in categories where behavior is now abnormal by any earlier standard,&rdquo; Moynihan wrote. You can point to all sorts of ways in which this redefinition of deviancy has also been the story of our politics over the past 30 years, a story with a fully bipartisan set of villains. I personally think we crossed a rubicon in the Clinton years, when three things happened: we decided that some types of presidential lies didn&rsquo;t matter; we concluded that &ldquo;character&rdquo; was an over-rated consideration when it came to judging a president; and we allowed the lines between political culture and celebrity culture to become hopelessly blurred. But whatever else one might say about President Clinton, what we have now is the crack-cocaine version of that. If a public figure tells a whopping lie once in his life, it&rsquo;ll haunt him into his grave. If he lies morning, noon and night, it will become almost impossible to remember any one particular lie. Outrage will fall victim to its own ubiquity. It&rsquo;s the same truth contained in Stalin&rsquo;s famous remark that the death of one man is a tragedy but the death of a million is a statistic. One of the most interesting phenomena during the presidential campaign was waiting for Trump to say that one thing that would surely break the back of his candidacy. Would it be his slander against Mexican immigrants? Or his slur about John McCain&rsquo;s record as a POW? Or his lie about New Jersey Muslims celebrating 9\u002F11? Or his attacks on Megyn Kelly, on a disabled New York Times reporter, on a Mexican-American judge? Would it be him tweeting quotations from Benito Mussolini, or his sly overtures to David Duke and the alt-right? Would it be his unwavering praise of Vladimir Putin? Would it be his refusal to release his tax returns, or the sham that seems to been perpetrated on the saps who signed up for his Trump U courses? Would it be the tape of him with Billy Bush? None of this made the slightest difference. On the contrary, it helped him. Some people became desensitized by the never-ending assaults on what was once quaintly known as &ldquo;human decency.&rdquo; Others seemed to positively admire the comments as refreshing examples of personal authenticity and political incorrectness. Shameless rhetoric will always find a receptive audience with shameless people. Donald Trump&rsquo;s was the greatest political strip-tease act in U.S. political history: the dirtier he got, the more skin he showed, the more his core supporters liked it. Abraham Lincoln, in his first inaugural address, called on Americans to summon &ldquo;the better angels of our nature.&rdquo; Donald Trump&rsquo;s candidacy, and so far his presidency, has been Lincoln&rsquo;s exhortation in reverse. Here&rsquo;s a simple truth about a politics of dishonesty, insult and scandal: It&rsquo;s entertaining. Politics as we&rsquo;ve had it for most of my life has, with just a few exceptions, been distant and dull. Now it&rsquo;s all we can talk about. If you like Trump, his presence in the White House is a daily extravaganza of sticking it to pompous elites and querulous reporters. If you hate Trump, you wake up every day with some fresh outrage to turn over in your head and text your friends about. Whichever way, it&rsquo;s exhilarating. Haven&rsquo;t all of us noticed that everything feels speeded up, more vivid, more intense and consequential? One of the benefits of an alternative-facts administration is that fiction can take you anywhere. Earlier today, at his press conference, the president claimed his administration is running like a &ldquo;fine-tuned machine.&rdquo; In actual fact, he just lost his Labor Secretary nominee, his National Security Adviser was forced out in disgrace, and the Intelligence Community is refusing to fully brief the president for fear he might compromise sources and methods. But who cares? Since when in Washington has there been a presidential press conference like that? Since when has the denial of reality been taken to such a bald-faced extreme? At some point, it becomes increasingly easy for people to mistake the reality of the performance for reality itself. If Trump can get through a press conference like that without showing a hint of embarrassment, remorse or misgiving&mdash;well, then, that becomes a new basis on which the president can now be judged. To tell a lie is wrong. But to tell a lie with brass takes skill. Ultimately, Trump&rsquo;s press conference will be judged not on some kind of Olympic point system, but on whether he &ldquo;won&rdquo;&mdash;which is to say, whether he brazened his way through it. And the answer to that is almost certainly yes. So far, I&rsquo;ve offered you three ideas about how it is that we have come to accept the president&rsquo;s behavior. The first is that we normalize it, simply by becoming inured to constant repetition of the same bad behavior. The second is that at some level it excites and entertains us. By putting aside our usual moral filters&mdash;the ones that tell us that truth matters, that upright conduct matters, that things ought to be done in a certain way&mdash;we have been given tickets to a spectacle, in which all you want to do is watch. And the third is that we adopt new metrics of judgment, in which politics becomes more about perceptions than performance&mdash;of how a given action is perceived as being perceived. If a reporter for the New York Times says that Trump&rsquo;s press conference probably plays well in Peoria, then that increases the chances that it will play well in Peoria. Let me add a fourth point here: our tendency to rationalize. One of the more fascinating aspects of last year&rsquo;s presidential campaign was the rise of a class of pundits I call the &ldquo;TrumpXplainers.&rdquo; For instance, Trump would give a speech or offer an answer in a debate that amounted to little more than a word jumble. But rather than quote Trump, or point out that what he had said was grammatically and logically nonsensical, the TrumpXplainers would tell us what he had allegedly meant to say. They became our political semioticians, ascribing pattern and meaning to the rune-stones of Trump&rsquo;s mind. If Trump said he&rsquo;d get Mexico to pay for his wall, you could count on someone to provide a complex tariff scheme to make good on the promise. If Trump said that we should not have gone into Iraq but that, once there, we should have &ldquo;taken the oil,&rdquo; we&rsquo;d have a similarly high-flown explanation as to how we could engineer this theft. A year ago, when he was trying to explain his idea of a foreign policy to the New York Times&rsquo;s David Sanger, the reporter asked him whether it didn&rsquo;t amount to a kind of &ldquo;America First policy&rdquo;&mdash;a reference to the isolationist and anti-Semitic America First Committee that tried to prevent U.S. entry into World War II. Trump clearly had never heard of the group, but he liked the phrase and made it his own. And that&rsquo;s how we got the return of America First. More recently, I came across this headline in the conservative Washington Times: &ldquo;How Trump&rsquo;s &lsquo;disarray&rsquo; may be merely a strategy,&rdquo; by Wesley Pruden, the paper&rsquo;s former editor-in-chief. In his view, the president&rsquo;s first disastrous month in office is, in fact, evidence of a refreshing openness to dissent, reminiscent of Washington and Lincoln&rsquo;s cabinet of rivals. Sure. Overall, the process is one in which explanation becomes rationalization, which in turn becomes justification. Trump says X. What he really means is Y. And while you might not like it, he&rsquo;s giving voice to the angers and anxieties of Z. Who, by the way, you&rsquo;re not allowed to question or criticize, because anxiety and anger are their own justifications these days. Watching this process unfold has been particularly painful for me as a conservative columnist. I find myself in the awkward position of having recently become popular among some of my liberal peers&mdash;precisely because I haven&rsquo;t changed my opinions about anything. By contrast, I&rsquo;ve become suddenly unpopular among some of my former fans on the right&mdash;again, because I&rsquo;ve stuck to my views. It is almost amusing to be accused of suffering from something called &ldquo;Trump Derangement Syndrome&rdquo; simply because I feel an obligation to raise my voice against, say, the president suggesting a moral equivalency between the U.S. and Vladimir Putin&rsquo;s Russia. The most painful aspect of this has been to watch people I previously considered thoughtful and principled conservatives give themselves over to a species of illiberal politics from which I once thought they were immune. In his 1953 masterpiece, &ldquo;The Captive Mind,&rdquo; the Polish poet and dissident Czeslaw Milosz analyzed the psychological and intellectual pathways through which some of his former colleagues in Poland&rsquo;s post-war Communist regime allowed themselves to be converted into ardent Stalinists. In none of the cases that Milosz analyzed was coercion the main reason for the conversion. They wanted to believe. They were willing to adapt. They thought they could do more good from the inside. They convinced themselves that their former principles didn&rsquo;t fit with the march of history, or that to hold fast to one&rsquo;s beliefs was a sign of priggishness and pig-headedness. They felt that to reject the new order of things was to relegate themselves to irrelevance and oblivion. They mocked their former friends who refused to join the new order as morally vain reactionaries. They convinced themselves that, brutal and capricious as Stalinism might be, it couldn&rsquo;t possibly be worse than the exploitative capitalism of the West. I fear we are witnessing a similar process unfold among many conservative intellectuals on the right. It has been stunning to watch a movement that once believed in the benefits of free trade and free enterprise merrily give itself over to a champion of protectionism whose economic instincts recall the corporatism of 1930s Italy or 1950s Argentina. It is no less stunning to watch people who once mocked Obama for being too soft on Russia suddenly discover the virtues of Trump&rsquo;s &ldquo;pragmatism&rdquo; on the subject. And it is nothing short of amazing to watch the party of onetime moral majoritarians, who spent a decade fulminating about Bill Clinton&rsquo;s sexual habits, suddenly find complete comfort with the idea that character and temperament are irrelevant qualifications for high office. The mental pathways by which the new Trumpian conservatives have made their peace with their new political master aren&rsquo;t so different from Milosz&rsquo;s former colleagues. There&rsquo;s the same desperate desire for political influence; the same belief that Trump represents a historical force to which they ought to belong; the same willingness to bend or discard principles they once considered sacred; the same fear of seeming out-of-touch with the mood of the public; the same tendency to look the other way at comments or actions that they cannot possibly justify; the same belief that you do more good by joining than by opposing; the same Manichean belief that, if Hillary Clinton had been elected, the United States would have all-but ended as a country. This is supposed to be the road of pragmatism, of turning lemons into lemonade. I would counter that it&rsquo;s the road of ignominy, of hitching a ride with a drunk driver. So, then, to the subject that brings me here today: Maintaining intellectual integrity in the age of Trump. When Judea wrote me last summer to ask if I&rsquo;d be this year&rsquo;s speaker, I got my copy of Danny&rsquo;s collected writings, &ldquo;At Home in the World,&rdquo; and began to read him all over again. It brought back to me the fact that, the reason we honor Danny&rsquo;s memory isn&rsquo;t that he&rsquo;s a martyred journalist. It&rsquo;s that he was a great journalist. Let me show you what I mean. Here&rsquo;s something Danny wrote in February 2001, almost exactly a year before his death, from the site of an earthquake disaster in the Indian town of Anjar. What is India&rsquo;s earthquake zone really like? It smells. It reeks. You can&rsquo;t imagine the odor of several hundred bodies decaying for five days as search teams pick away at slabs of crumbled buildings in this town. Even if you&rsquo;ve never smelled it before, the brain knows what it is, and orders you to get away. After a day, the nose gets stuffed up in self-defense. But the brain has registered the scent, and picks it up in innocent places: lip balm, sweet candy, stale breath, an airplane seat. What stands out for me in this passage is that it shows that Danny was a writer who observed with all his senses. He saw. He listened. He smelled. He bore down. He reflected. He understood that what the reader had to know about Anjar wasn&rsquo;t a collection of statistics; it was the visceral reality of a massive human tragedy. And he was able to express all this in language that was compact, unadorned, compelling and deeply true. George Orwell wrote, &ldquo;To see what is in front of one&rsquo;s nose needs a constant struggle.&rdquo; Danny saw what was in front of his nose. We each have our obligations to see what&rsquo;s in front of one&rsquo;s nose, whether we&rsquo;re reporters, columnists, or anything else. This is the essence of intellectual integrity. Not to look around, or beyond, or away from the facts, but to look straight at them, to recognize and call them for what they are, nothing more or less. To see things as they are before we re-interpret them into what we&rsquo;d like them to be. To believe in an epistemology that can distinguish between truth and falsity, facts and opinions, evidence and wishes. To defend habits of mind and institutions of society, above all a free press, which preserve that epistemology. To hold fast to a set of intellectual standards and moral convictions that won&rsquo;t waver amid changes of political fashion or tides of unfavorable opinion. To speak the truth irrespective of what it means for our popularity or influence. The legacy of Danny Pearl is that he died for this. We are being asked to do much less. We have no excuse not to do it. Thank you."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EWe should assume they are darkly brilliant\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":53721627,"featured_media":4675870,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[292,430939235],"time_section":[272184451,204777755],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937781],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":true,"_links":{"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4675860\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4675860\u002Fprimary_tag"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4675860\u002Fprimary_section"}]},"_embedded":{"fortune:featured":[{"size":"landscape","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":4675870,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Ftrump8.jpg?quality=85","alt":"President Trump Holds Joint Press Conference With Japanese PM Shinzo Abe","caption":"President Trump stands during a joint press conference with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe at the White House on Feb. 10, 2017 in Washington, DC. We welcome outside contributions. Opinions expressed do not necessarily reflect the views of TIME editors.","parent":0,"count":5725,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["ideas","politics"]}]}},{"id":4682189,"date":"2017-02-24T15:18:11","date_gmt":"2017-02-24T20:18:11","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4682189"},"modified":"2017-02-24T15:39:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-24T20:39:00","slug":"ren-hang-chinese-photographer-dies","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4682189\u002Fren-hang-chinese-photographer-dies\u002F","title":{"rendered":"Controversial Chinese Photographer Ren Hang Dies at 29"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EChinese photographer and poet, Ren Hang, has died at the age of 29. His searing images, a carnival of milky limbs and botanical beauty, were celebrated and censored in equal measure.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHang was arrested several times for his explicit photographs and experienced censorship throughout his career in his home country of China. His pictures were a celebration of brazen exposure told through a language of graphic lines and block coloring. His subjects, always nude, were friends and more recently fans. A self-taught photographer, Hang once said he shoots with &#8220;no plans.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-portrait_small_2x aligncenter \"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"4682588\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4682189\u002Fren-hang-chinese-photographer-dies\u002F0f59f9733c0d2a3cfd6a99400ea84917\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002F0f59f9733c0d2a3cfd6a99400ea84917.jpeg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"670,452\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"0\",\"credit\":\"\",\"camera\":\"\",\"caption\":\"\",\"created_timestamp\":\"0\",\"copyright\":\"\",\"focal_length\":\"0\",\"iso\":\"0\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0\",\"title\":\"\",\"orientation\":\"0\"}' data-image-title=\"0f59f9733c0d2a3cfd6a99400ea84917\" data-image-description=\"pUntitled, 2015. \u002Fp\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002F0f59f9733c0d2a3cfd6a99400ea84917.jpeg?quality=85&w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002F0f59f9733c0d2a3cfd6a99400ea84917.jpeg?quality=85&w=600\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002F0f59f9733c0d2a3cfd6a99400ea84917.jpeg?w=560&#038;quality=85&#038;h=378\" alt=\"Ren Hang\" height=\"378\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\" \u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\" \u003ERen Hang\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"caption\" \u003EUntitled, 2015\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"image-wrapper no-caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAlexander &Ouml;berg, of \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.tryffelgrisen.com\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EGalleri Tryffelgrisen\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, a longtime collaborator of Hang, told TIME: &ldquo;We are shocked and incredibly sad about Ren&#8217;s death. He was such a lovely person. We still cannot believe it is true. We can only speculate about what led him to end his life at the young age of 29.&rdquo; &Ouml;berg added that Hang was a &ldquo;lovely person and an incredibly creative artist who had so much more to share with the world.&rdquo; Tryffelgrisen had collaborated with Hang for several years and exhibited him before he became widely known. &Ouml;berg added that he always knew Hang as a &ldquo;kind, humble and somewhat shy person.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-portrait_small_2x aligncenter \"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"4682107\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4682189\u002Fren-hang-chinese-photographer-dies\u002Fren-hang-03\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fren-hang-03.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"670,452\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"0\",\"credit\":\"\",\"camera\":\"\",\"caption\":\"\",\"created_timestamp\":\"0\",\"copyright\":\"\",\"focal_length\":\"0\",\"iso\":\"0\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0\",\"title\":\"\",\"orientation\":\"0\"}' data-image-title=\"ren-hang-03\" data-image-description=\"pUntitled, 2013\u002Fp\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fren-hang-03.jpg?quality=85&w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fren-hang-03.jpg?quality=85&w=600\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fren-hang-03.jpg?w=560&#038;quality=85&#038;h=378\" alt=\"Ren Hang\" height=\"378\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\" \u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\" \u003ERen Hang\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"caption\" \u003EUntitled, 2013\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHang was born in Jilin, China, in 1987 and began taking pictures in 2008. He was drawn to photography while studying marketing; his college work didn&rsquo;t interest him but he realized taking pictures did. Hang once said he simply &ldquo;shot what he saw,&rdquo; which began with his roommate&#8217;s naked body. Nudity continued to be a source of inspiration for Hang, whose visionary, artfully-constructed scenes bled the surreal with the provocative.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHis work, though celebrated across the world, was a subject of controversy in his homeland. Outdoor nudity and pornographic images have been banned in the People&rsquo;s Republic of China since 1949 and Hang was arrested several times, though he was unsure\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.pacificdissent.com\u002Fblog\u002F2015\u002F10\u002F19\u002Fjenna-homan-interviews-photographer-ren-hang-for-pacific-dissent-magazine\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E &#8220;what the legal reason was.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fa\u003E Despite this, Hang has always maintained that his work was not &ldquo;taboo&rdquo; or seeking to &ldquo;push boundaries,&rdquo; adding: &ldquo;I just do what I do.&rdquo; Hang was championed by Ai Weiwei, who he also collaborated with, and was held up as a leading light of Chinese contemporary photography.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-portrait_small_2x aligncenter \"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"4682110\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4682189\u002Fren-hang-chinese-photographer-dies\u002Fren-hang-06\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fren-hang-06.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"670,452\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"0\",\"credit\":\"\",\"camera\":\"\",\"caption\":\"\",\"created_timestamp\":\"0\",\"copyright\":\"\",\"focal_length\":\"0\",\"iso\":\"0\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0\",\"title\":\"\",\"orientation\":\"0\"}' data-image-title=\"ren-hang-06\" data-image-description=\"pUntitled, 2011\u002Fp\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fren-hang-06.jpg?quality=85&w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fren-hang-06.jpg?quality=85&w=600\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fren-hang-06.jpg?w=560&#038;quality=85&#038;h=378\" alt=\"Ren Hang\" height=\"378\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\" \u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\" \u003ERen Hang\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"caption\" \u003EUntitled, 2011\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"image-wrapper no-caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHang suffered from cyclical depression, something he documented through his poetry, under the title \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.renhang.org\u002FMy-Depression\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EMy Depression\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. He published seven photo books included Ren Hang, Nude, Republic and Son And Bitch before Taschen&#8217;s recent retrospective, edited by Dian Hanson. Hang has been exhibited around the world and received the Outset\u002F Unseen Exhibition Fund in 2016. Hang was living in Beijing at the time of his death.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ERen Hang&#8217;s\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E work can be viewed \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.renhang.org\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Ehere\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EKim Bubello\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E, who edited this photo essay, is a freelance photo editor at TIME.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003EAlexandra Genova \u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Ci\u003Eis a writer and contributor for TIME LightBox. Follow her on \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002FAlexandraaa_cg\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ETwitter\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.instagram.com\u002Falexandraaaa_cg\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EInstagram\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"column small-12 medium-10 medium-offset-1 large-offset-2 end _10M0Ygc4\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003EFollow \u003Cstrong\u003ETIME LightBox\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E on \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.facebook.com\u002Ftimelightbox\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EFacebook\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Ftimepictures\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ETwitter\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Finstagram.com\u002Ftimelightbox\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EInstagram\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Chinese photographer and poet, Ren Hang, has died at the age of 29. Hang has been exhibited around the world and received the Outset\u002F Unseen Exhibition Fund in 2016. Hang was living in Beijing at the time of his death."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["Ren Hang's"]}," work can be viewed ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.renhang.org\u002F"},"content":["here"]},"."]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["Kim Bubello"]},", who edited this photo essay, is a freelance photo editor at TIME."]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Alexandra Genova "]}]},{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["is a writer and contributor for TIME LightBox. Follow her on ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002FAlexandraaa_cg","target":"_blank"},"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["Twitter"]}]}," and ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.instagram.com\u002Falexandraaaa_cg\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["Instagram"]}]}]}]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Follow ",{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["TIME LightBox"]}," on ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.facebook.com\u002Ftimelightbox","target":"_blank"},"content":["Facebook"]},", ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Ftimepictures","target":"_blank"},"content":["Twitter"]}," and ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Finstagram.com\u002Ftimelightbox\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Instagram"]}]}]}],"plain":"Chinese photographer and poet, Ren Hang, has died at the age of 29. His searing images, a carnival of milky limbs and botanical beauty, were celebrated and censored in equal measure. Hang was arrested several times for his explicit photographs and experienced censorship throughout his career in his home country of China. His pictures were a celebration of brazen exposure told through a language of graphic lines and block coloring. His subjects, always nude, were friends and more recently fans. A self-taught photographer, Hang once said he shoots with &#8220;no plans.&#8221; Ren HangUntitled, 2015 Alexander &Ouml;berg, of Galleri Tryffelgrisen, a longtime collaborator of Hang, told TIME: &ldquo;We are shocked and incredibly sad about Ren&#8217;s death. He was such a lovely person. We still cannot believe it is true. We can only speculate about what led him to end his life at the young age of 29.&rdquo; &Ouml;berg added that Hang was a &ldquo;lovely person and an incredibly creative artist who had so much more to share with the world.&rdquo; Tryffelgrisen had collaborated with Hang for several years and exhibited him before he became widely known. &Ouml;berg added that he always knew Hang as a &ldquo;kind, humble and somewhat shy person.&rdquo; Ren HangUntitled, 2013 &nbsp; Hang was born in Jilin, China, in 1987 and began taking pictures in 2008. He was drawn to photography while studying marketing; his college work didn&rsquo;t interest him but he realized taking pictures did. Hang once said he simply &ldquo;shot what he saw,&rdquo; which began with his roommate&#8217;s naked body. Nudity continued to be a source of inspiration for Hang, whose visionary, artfully-constructed scenes bled the surreal with the provocative. His work, though celebrated across the world, was a subject of controversy in his homeland. Outdoor nudity and pornographic images have been banned in the People&rsquo;s Republic of China since 1949 and Hang was arrested several times, though he was unsure &#8220;what the legal reason was.&#8221; Despite this, Hang has always maintained that his work was not &ldquo;taboo&rdquo; or seeking to &ldquo;push boundaries,&rdquo; adding: &ldquo;I just do what I do.&rdquo; Hang was championed by Ai Weiwei, who he also collaborated with, and was held up as a leading light of Chinese contemporary photography. Ren HangUntitled, 2011 Hang suffered from cyclical depression, something he documented through his poetry, under the title My Depression. He published seven photo books included Ren Hang, Nude, Republic and Son And Bitch before Taschen&#8217;s recent retrospective, edited by Dian Hanson. Hang has been exhibited around the world and received the Outset\u002F Unseen Exhibition Fund in 2016. Hang was living in Beijing at the time of his death. Ren Hang&#8217;s work can be viewed here. Kim Bubello, who edited this photo essay, is a freelance photo editor at TIME. Alexandra Genova is a writer and contributor for TIME LightBox. Follow her on Twitter and Instagram Follow TIME LightBox on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram"},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EHis images were celebrated and censored in equal President Hollande Hits Back at President Trump's Paris Comments"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EFrench President Francois Hollande took issue with Donald Trump&#8217;s \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4682023\u002Fcpac-donald-trump-speech-transcript\u002F\"\u003EFriday comments about Paris\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, in which the American President claimed he had a friend who felt &#8220;Paris is no longer Paris&#8221; in the wake of recent terrorist attacks.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHollande called for Trump to support U.S. allies.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;There is terrorism and we must fight it together,&#8221; Hollande said on Saturday during a visit at the Paris Agric fair, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.reuters.com\u002Farticle\u002Fus-france-usa-paris-idUSKBN1640CD\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eaccording to Reuters\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. &#8220;I think that it is never good to show the smallest defiance toward an allied country. I wouldn&#8217;t do it with the United States and I&#8217;m urging the U.S. president not to do it with France.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;I won&#8217;t make comparisons but here, people don&#8217;t have access to guns,&#8221; the French president added. &#8220;Here, you don&#8217;t have people with guns opening fire on the crowd simply for the satisfaction of causing drama and tragedy.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETrump&#8217;s initial remarks came during a \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4681802\u002Fdonald-trump-cpac-speech-media\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Espeech at the Conservative Political Action Conference\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. The president criticized Europe's handling of ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4314129\u002Fparis-attacks-journalism-in-europe\u002F"},"content":["recent Islamist terrorist attacks"]},", saying his friend \"Jim\" no longer wants to take his family to the French capital."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Paris mayor ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002FAnne_Hidalgo\u002Fstatus\u002F835175467271475200?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw"},"content":["Anne Hidalgo"]}," and French Foreign Minister ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Fjeanmarcayrault\u002Fstatus\u002F835194591670333440?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw"},"content":["Jean-Marc Ayrault"]}," additionally responded to Trump's comments via Twitter on Friday."]}],"plain":"French President Francois Hollande took issue with Donald Trump&#8217;s Friday comments about Paris, in which the American President claimed he had a friend who felt &#8220;Paris is no longer Paris&#8221; in the wake of recent terrorist attacks. Hollande called for Trump to support U.S. allies. &#8220;There is terrorism and we must fight it together,&#8221; Hollande said on Saturday during a visit at the Paris Agric fair, according to Reuters. &#8220;I think that it is never good to show the smallest defiance toward an allied country. I wouldn&#8217;t do it with the United States and I&#8217;m urging the U.S. president not to do it with France. &#8220;I won&#8217;t make comparisons but here, people don&#8217;t have access to guns,&#8221; the French president added. &#8220;Here, you don&#8217;t have people with guns opening fire on the crowd simply for the satisfaction of causing drama and tragedy.&#8221; Trump&#8217;s initial remarks came during a speech at the Conservative Political Action Conference. The president criticized Europe&#8217;s handling of recent Islamist terrorist attacks, saying his friend &#8220;Jim&#8221; no longer wants to take his family to the French capital. Paris mayor Anne Hidalgo and French Foreign Minister Jean-Marc Ayrault additionally responded to Trump&#8217;s comments via Twitter on Friday."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;There is terrorism and we must fight it together&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":116676460,"featured_media":4588869,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[4328,430939235],"time_section":[204777755],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937769],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682918\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682918\u002Fprimary_tag"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682918\u002Fprimary_section"}]},"_embedded":{"fortune:featured":[{"size":"landscape","type":"video","visible":true,"image":{"id":4588869,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002Ffrancois-hollande-reelection-reasons.jpg?quality=85","alt":"French President Francois Hollande receives the Head of Andorra Principality Government, Antoni Marti Petit and President of Parliament of the Principality of Andorra, Vicenc Mateu Zamora for a meeting and a statement to the media at the Elysee Palace on October 25, 2016 in Paris, France.","caption":"French President Francois Hollande receives the Head of Andorra Principality Government, Antoni Marti Petit and President of Parliament of the Principality of Andorra, Vicenc Mateu Zamora for a meeting and a statement to the media at the Elysee Palace on October 25, 2016 in Paris, France. Covering the White House, elections, primaries, Congress, domestic policy, foreign policy, the military and more","parent":0,"count":11779,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["politics"]}]}}]],"ng:more:brand":[[{"id":4683002,"date":"2017-02-25T18:23:17","date_gmt":"2017-02-25T23:23:17","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4683002"},"modified":"2017-02-25T18:23:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-25T23:23:00","slug":"president-trump-skip-white-house-correspondents-dinner","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4683002\u002Fpresident-trump-skip-white-house-correspondents-dinner\u002F","title":{"rendered":"President Trump Announces He'll Skip White House Correspondents' Dinner"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4681555\u002Ftrump-us-nuclear-arsenal\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EPresident Donald Trump\u003C\u002Fa\u003E announced in a tweet Saturday that he will skip this year&#8217;s \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fmoney\u002F4312847\u002Fwhite-house-correspondents-dinner-scholarship-fundraiser\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EWhite House Correspondents&#8217; Dinner\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;I will not be attending the White House Correspondents&#8217; Association Dinner this year,&#8221; the president tweeted. &#8220;Please wish everyone well and have a great evening!&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETrump&#8217;s tweet ends months of will-he, won&#8217;t-he speculation about his attendance at the annual Washington gathering, which has hosted every sitting president since Calvin Coolidge at least once \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwhca.net\u002Fhistory.htm\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Esince its 1921 founding\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. Trump&#8217;s decision not to attend the dinner comes after his repeated criticisms of the press as &#8220;fake news&#8221; and accusing some outlets of being &#8220;enemies of the people.&#8221; Several news outlets publicly stated they were rethinking their attendance at the dinner amid Trump&#8217;s unprecedented attack on the news media.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn early February, association president Jeff Mason informed members that the dinner would take place whether or not Trump attends. &#8220;The White House Correspondents&#8217; Association looks forward to having its annual dinner on April 29,&#8221; Mason said Saturday. &#8220;The WHCA takes note of President Donald Trump&#8217;s announcement on Twitter that he does not plan to attend the dinner, which has been and will continue to be a celebration of the First Amendment and the important role played by an independent news media in a healthy republic. We look forward to shining a spotlight at the dinner on some of the best political journalism of the past year and recognizing the promising students who represent the next generation of our profession.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETrump attended the dinner in 2011, in which he was famously lampooned both by then-President Barack Obama and the evening&#8217;s entertainer, comedian Seth Meyers, for his false public assertions that Obama was not born in the United States. This year&#8217;s dinner, which also funds a \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwhca.net\u002Fscholarships.htm\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Escholarship program\u003C\u002Fa\u003E run by the association, is scheduled for April 29.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4681555\u002Ftrump-us-nuclear-arsenal\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["President Donald Trump"]}," announced in a tweet Saturday that he will skip this year's ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fmoney\u002F4312847\u002Fwhite-house-correspondents-dinner-scholarship-fundraiser\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["White House Correspondents' Dinner"]},"."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"I will not be attending the White House Correspondents' Association Dinner this year,\" the president tweeted. \"Please wish everyone well and have a great evening!\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Trump's tweet ends months of will-he, won't-he speculation about his attendance at the annual Washington gathering, which has hosted every sitting president since Calvin Coolidge at least once ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwhca.net\u002Fhistory.htm"},"content":["since its 1921 founding"]},". Trump's decision not to attend the dinner comes after his repeated criticisms of the press as \"fake news\" and accusing some outlets of being \"enemies of the people.\" Several news outlets publicly stated they were rethinking their attendance at the dinner amid Trump's unprecedented attack on the news media."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In early February, association president Jeff Mason informed members that the dinner would take place whether or not Trump attends. \"The White House Correspondents' Association looks forward to having its annual dinner on April 29,\" Mason said Saturday. \"The WHCA takes note of President Donald Trump's announcement on Twitter that he does not plan to attend the dinner, which has been and will continue to be a celebration of the First Amendment and the important role played by an independent news media in a healthy republic. We look forward to shining a spotlight at the dinner on some of the best political journalism of the past year and recognizing the promising students who represent the next generation of our profession.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Trump attended the dinner in 2011, in which he was famously lampooned both by then-President Barack Obama and the evening's entertainer, comedian Seth Meyers, for his false public assertions that Obama was not born in the United States. This year's dinner, which also funds a ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwhca.net\u002Fscholarships.htm"},"content":["scholarship program"]}," run by the association, is scheduled for April 29."]}],"plain":"President Donald Trump announced in a tweet Saturday that he will skip this year&#8217;s White House Correspondents&#8217; Dinner. &#8220;I will not be attending the White House Correspondents&#8217; Association Dinner this year,&#8221; the president tweeted. &#8220;Please wish everyone well and have a great evening!&#8221; Trump&#8217;s tweet ends months of will-he, won&#8217;t-he speculation about his attendance at the annual Washington gathering, which has hosted every sitting president since Calvin Coolidge at least once since its 1921 founding. Trump&#8217;s decision not to attend the dinner comes after his repeated criticisms of the press as &#8220;fake news&#8221; and accusing some outlets of being &#8220;enemies of the people.&#8221; Several news outlets publicly stated they were rethinking their attendance at the dinner amid Trump&#8217;s unprecedented attack on the news media. In early February, association president Jeff Mason informed members that the dinner would take place whether or not Trump attends. &#8220;The White House Correspondents&#8217; Association looks forward to having its annual dinner on April 29,&#8221; Mason said Saturday. &#8220;The WHCA takes note of President Donald Trump&#8217;s announcement on Twitter that he does not plan to attend the dinner, which has been and will continue to be a celebration of the First Amendment and the important role played by an independent news media in a healthy republic. We look forward to shining a spotlight at the dinner on some of the best political journalism of the past year and recognizing the promising students who represent the next generation of our profession.&#8221; Trump attended the dinner in 2011, in which he was famously lampooned both by then-President Barack Obama and the evening&#8217;s entertainer, comedian Seth Meyers, for his false public assertions that Obama was not born in the United States. This year&#8217;s dinner, which also funds a scholarship program run by the association, is scheduled for April 29. &nbsp;"},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003ETrump&#8217;s tweet ends months of y_article?categories=1"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[{"id":430939235,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Ftag\u002Fonetime\u002F","name":"onetime","slug":"onetime","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags\u002F430939235"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fpost_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?tags=430939235"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=430939235"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":7053,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Ftag\u002Fwhite-house\u002F","name":"White
