Advisors"},"video":[],"structured":false}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":7053,"name":"White House","slug":"white-house","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":702,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":1906,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":204777755,"name":"Politics","slug":"politics","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":17,"taxonomy":"time_section","description":"Political insight from the Beltway and beyond. Covering the White House, elections, primaries, Congress, domestic policy, foreign policy, the military and more","parent":0,"count":11779,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["politics"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4682090,"date":"2017-02-25T18:16:28","date_gmt":"2017-02-25T23:16:28","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4682090"},"modified":"2017-02-25T18:16:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-25T23:16:00","slug":"frank-luntz-america-relationship","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4682090\u002Ffrank-luntz-america-relationship\u002F","title":{"rendered":"Frank Luntz: Americans Trust Their Own States But Not Washington"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003EIf there is one thing \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4655132\u002Fdemocrat-leaders-president-trump-protest-supreme-court-pick\u002F\"\u003EDemocrats\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4681631\u002Faffordable-care-act-obamacare-popularity-poll\u002F\"\u003EIndependents\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4682023\u002Fcpac-donald-trump-speech-transcript\u002F\"\u003ERepublicans\u003C\u002Fa\u003E agree on &mdash; and there is, in fact, only one thing &mdash; it&rsquo;s that it&rsquo;s time for a new relationship between the citizenry and their government. That philosophy is borne from resentment and a sense of betrayal, but it binds us together at a time when everything else in our collective lives are tearing us apart.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESkepticism and cynicism abounds from Atlantic to Pacific, from farm to factory, within urban centers and across suburban sprawl. Americans of all affiliations carry frustration, anger, and Mutually Assured Distrust (&ldquo;MAD&rdquo;) wherever they go, whenever they talk politics. Distrust is as omnipresent as the \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fmotto.time.com\u002F4636760\u002Fchelsea-handler-blames-kardashians-donald-trump\u002F\"\u003EKardashians\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. Americans are MAD as hell, but what matters more is that they&rsquo;re not going to take it anymore.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EEveryone still wants Change, but almost no one believes in Hope anymore. If we are to restore that enduring confidence that America&rsquo;s best days are still ahead, we&rsquo;ll need to find our strength somewhere far outside of Washington, because faith and trust in our federal government, bedrock to our democracy, is sorely lacking.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe American people are asking for &ndash; in fact, demanding &ndash; a &ldquo;New Relationship&rdquo; with their government at all levels. Our nationwide public opinion research at the National Governors Association last month offers a clear path forward. But this path does not lead to Washington D.C., but from it, to the 50 State Capitols.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDespite the difficult but consequential election, Americans are still not optimistic that a broken Washington will be fixed any time soon. My focus groups for \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fcbs-203\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ECBS\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and Fox News are just as toxic today as they were six months ago. President Trump leads a deeply divided nation, and an abiding dislike for Congress and the Washington bureaucracy is among the few things that unites us. Americans are looking elsewhere for \u003Cem\u003E&ldquo;real results and real solutions, for real people.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fem\u003E They are looking for their states, and especially their governors, to stand and deliver.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe data is clear and conclusive. For example, we asked \u003Cem\u003E&ldquo;Overall, which level of government do you believe is doing a better job of serving its citizens and delivering results?&rdquo; \u003C\u002Fem\u003EFully 71% of voters chose &ldquo;State Governments,&rdquo; while just 29% chose &ldquo;The Federal Government.&rdquo; On this, America has achieved rare bipartisan agreement. By party, the spread is 82% state government to 18% federal government among Republicans (+64), 54% to 46% among Democrats (+8), and 77% to 23% among Independents (+54). And with Trump upsetting the Left every day, it&rsquo;s likely that even more Democrats will choose the state government option in the months to follow.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWe then asked Americans to consider government programs like healthcare, Medicaid, education and rebuilding our roads and infrastructure. \u003Cem\u003E&ldquo;What is the best balance of control in terms of setting the rules and regulations and administering the programs?&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fem\u003E Just under one-third (31%) want the federal government to be in control, while more than two-thirds of the country either want genuine federal-state power sharing (35%) or the states to hold the power advantage (35%). Republicans are overwhelmingly in the state government camp, but Independents and Democrats aren&rsquo;t far behind.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIt&rsquo;s not just about the issues. It&rsquo;s also about the people. Nearly half of Americans (45%) regard \u003Cem\u003E&ldquo;America&rsquo;s governors and state governments&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fem\u003E favorably, while only 30% have a negative impression. By comparison, just 29% of the country has a favorable impression of Congress, while a majority (51%) hold a negative view. The federal government does even worse: 27% favorable, 56% unfavorable. I&rsquo;d provide the partisan results, but they&rsquo;re consistent across parties: \u003Cem\u003Eeveryone\u003C\u002Fem\u003E has a net favorable opinion of governors, and \u003Cem\u003Eeveryone\u003C\u002Fem\u003E dislikes Congress and the federal government &ndash; regardless of who&rsquo;s in charge.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EVoters of all stripes simply trust their governors far more than they trust their leaders in Washington. The number one reason among Democrats and Republicans alike: \u003Cem\u003E&ldquo;State leaders are more responsive because they are closer to their constituents.&rdquo; \u003C\u002Fem\u003E In a time when trust is scarce and with Americans demanding real progress right now, state governments and governors represent the best hope to win back to confidence of the voters and get the job done.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThis isn&rsquo;t an academic exercise or an ideological appeal for &ldquo;federalism.&rdquo; (Note to reader: Federalism is about taking power away from Washington. Many Americans think exactly the opposite.) It&rsquo;s not about smaller or more limited government. Almost no one I interview cares about the size of government as much as the efficiency, effectiveness and accountability of government. Americans want to empower states and governors to take a more active role in that governance because they&rsquo;ve given up on Washington &ndash; Trump or no Trump.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESupport for greater state control isn&rsquo;t about politics or partisanship. It&rsquo;s about performance. In recent years, many states have made meaningful and measurable progress, while Washington stoked gridlock with meaningless and maddening false promises. Americans simply have greater favorability towards their governor (net +16% positive) and America&rsquo;s governors and state governments (net +15%) and a more negative reaction towards the &ldquo;federal government&rdquo; (net -29%) and &ldquo;Congress&rdquo; (net -22%). Similarly, an overwhelming majority of voters (71%) believe their state is doing a better job of \u003Cem\u003E&ldquo;serving its citizens and delivering results,&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fem\u003E more than twice as many as the 29% who chose the federal government. And here&rsquo;s the encouraging part: Democrats, Republicans and Independents all agree.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOn most policy issues and personal attributes, voters trust states and governors more than they trust Congress and the federal government. The NGA survey identified ten specific areas where Americans trust state governments more than the federal government. Of all of the issues and attributes, none are more important than \u003Cem\u003E&ldquo;has the most dedicated public servants who are in it for the right reasons.&rdquo; \u003C\u002Fem\u003E Here, state governments hold an overwhelming 30 percent lead.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe American people want their elected officials to fight \u003Cem\u003Efor them\u003C\u002Fem\u003E rather than fight each other. They want cooperation, not confrontation. Message to Capitol Hill: even ordinary Republicans who have felt left out of national politics for the past eight years prefer compromise over uncompromising, unyielding principle by a margin of 58% to 42%.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAmericans are demanding a new relationship with their government that prioritizes local leadership and local solutions rather than an inflexible one-size-fits all national approach to the myriad challenges facing the country.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA relationship that limits mandates and decision-making by unelected bureaucrats in Washington and prioritizes state and local engagement and input.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA relationship where their state and local leaders not just listen but truly &ldquo;hear&rdquo; their constituents, because they often know them and actually understand them.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA relationship that puts to an end the frustratingly failed practice of career politicians fighting so hard for votes on Election Day, only to return to Washington and dismiss the voices of those who cast them. Whether Democratic or Republican, old or young, Rust Belt or Sun Belt, Americans want to be represented by \u003Cem\u003Elocal \u003C\u002Fem\u003Eleaders who say what they mean, mean what they say, and are willing to supplant the status quo in favor of a better future.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThere&rsquo;s a clear message here, if the politicians are willing to hear it. The \u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003ENew Relationship\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E is not about shifting dollars or responsibilities between or across congressional committees or federal agencies. It&rsquo;s about the complete restructure of government from the bottom up and the top down. It&rsquo;s about giving states the responsibilities most of us believe they deserve. Americans are looking to the governors to be their voice. They want to be heard, yes. But more importantly, they want their Governors to lead.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThere are notable exceptions, but for the most part, the American people believe their governors are succeeding. They aren&rsquo;t holding their breath about Washington.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cu\u003EAREAS WHERE STATE GOVERNMENT IS MORE TRUSTED THAN THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8212; &ldquo;Has the most dedicated public servants who are in it for the right reasons:&rdquo; (States +30%)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8212; &ldquo;Educating students and helping them achieve:&rdquo; (States +28%)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8212; &ldquo;Offering quality workforce and job training programs:&rdquo; (States +21%)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8212; &ldquo;Spending my tax dollars efficiently and effectively:&rdquo; (States +16%)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8212; &ldquo;Has the most positive impact on my quality of life:&rdquo; (States +14%)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8212; &ldquo;Listening to, representing and being accountable to us, the voters:&rdquo; (States +14%)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8212; &ldquo;Delivering welfare programs for those who need it, while curbing waste and abuse:&rdquo; (States +10%)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8212; &ldquo;Improving our roads, highways, transit and infrastructure.&rdquo; (States +9%)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8212; &ldquo;Protecting the rights of workers, employees and small business owners:&rdquo; (States +5%)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8212; &ldquo;Creating new solutions that are more innovative and more focused on the future. (States +4%)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"u","attributes":[],"content":[]},"If there is one thing ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4655132\u002Fdemocrat-leaders-president-trump-protest-supreme-court-pick\u002F"},"content":["Democrats"]},", ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4681631\u002Faffordable-care-act-obamacare-popularity-poll\u002F"},"content":["Independents"]}," and ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4682023\u002Fcpac-donald-trump-speech-transcript\u002F"},"content":["Republicans"]}," agree on — and there is, in fact, only one thing — it’s that it’s time for a new relationship between the citizenry and their government. Almost no one I interview cares about the size of government as much as the efficiency, effectiveness and accountability of government. Americans want to empower states and governors to take a more active role in that governance because they’ve given up on Washington – Trump or no Trump."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Support for greater state control isn’t about politics or partisanship. And here’s the encouraging part: Democrats, Republicans and Independents all agree."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["On most policy issues and personal attributes, voters trust states and governors more than they trust Congress and the federal government. The NGA survey identified ten specific areas where Americans trust state governments more than the federal government. Of all of the issues and attributes, none are more important than ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["“has the most dedicated public servants who are in it for the right reasons.” "]}," Here, state governments hold an overwhelming 30 percent lead."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The American people want their elected officials to fight ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["for them"]}," rather than fight each other. They want cooperation, not confrontation. Message to Capitol Hill: even ordinary Republicans who have felt left out of national politics for the past eight years prefer compromise over uncompromising, unyielding principle by a margin of 58% to 42%."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Americans are demanding a new relationship with their government that prioritizes local leadership and local solutions rather than an inflexible one-size-fits all national approach to the myriad challenges facing the country."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["A relationship that limits mandates and decision-making by unelected bureaucrats in Washington and prioritizes state and local engagement and input."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["A relationship where their state and local leaders not just listen but truly “hear” their constituents, because they often know them and actually understand them."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["A relationship that puts to an end the frustratingly failed practice of career politicians fighting so hard for votes on Election Day, only to return to Washington and dismiss the voices of those who cast them. Whether Democratic or Republican, old or young, Rust Belt or Sun Belt, Americans want to be represented by ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["local "]},"leaders who say what they mean, mean what they say, and are willing to supplant the status quo in favor of a better future."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["There’s a clear message here, if the politicians are willing to hear it. The ",{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["New Relationship"]}]}," is not about shifting dollars or responsibilities between or across congressional committees or federal agencies. It’s about the complete restructure of government from the bottom up and the top down. It’s about giving states the responsibilities most of us believe they deserve. Americans are looking to the governors to be their voice. They want to be heard, yes. But more importantly, they want their Governors to lead."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["There are notable exceptions, but for the most part, the American people believe their governors are succeeding. They aren’t holding their breath about Washington."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"u","attributes":[],"content":["AREAS WHERE STATE GOVERNMENT IS MORE TRUSTED THAN THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT"]}]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["-- “Has the most dedicated public servants who are in it for the right reasons:” (States +30%)"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["-- “Educating students and helping them achieve:” (States +28%)"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["-- “Offering quality workforce and job training programs:” (States +21%)"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["-- “Spending my tax dollars efficiently and effectively:” (States +16%)"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["-- “Has the most positive impact on my quality of life:” (States +14%)"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["-- “Listening to, representing and being accountable to us, the voters:” (States +14%)"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["-- “Delivering welfare programs for those who need it, while curbing waste and abuse:” (States +10%)"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["-- “Improving our roads, highways, transit and infrastructure.” (States +9%)"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["-- “Protecting the rights of workers, employees and small business owners:” (States +5%)"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["-- “Creating new solutions that are more innovative and more focused on the future. (States +4%)"]}],"plain":"If there is one thing Democrats, Independents and Republicans agree on &mdash; and there is, in fact, only one thing &mdash; it&rsquo;s that it&rsquo;s time for a new relationship between the citizenry and their government. That philosophy is borne from resentment and a sense of betrayal, but it binds us together at a time when everything else in our collective lives are tearing us apart. Skepticism and cynicism abounds from Atlantic to Pacific, from farm to factory, within urban centers and across suburban sprawl. Americans of all affiliations carry frustration, anger, and Mutually Assured Distrust (&ldquo;MAD&rdquo;) wherever they go, whenever they talk politics. Distrust is as omnipresent as the Kardashians. Americans are MAD as hell, but what matters more is that they&rsquo;re not going to take it anymore. Everyone still wants Change, but almost no one believes in Hope anymore. If we are to restore that enduring confidence that America&rsquo;s best days are still ahead, we&rsquo;ll need to find our strength somewhere far outside of Washington, because faith and trust in our federal government, bedrock to our democracy, is sorely lacking. The American people are asking for &ndash; in fact, demanding &ndash; a &ldquo;New Relationship&rdquo; with their government at all levels. Our nationwide public opinion research at the National Governors Association last month offers a clear path forward. But this path does not lead to Washington D.C., but from it, to the 50 State Capitols. Despite the difficult but consequential election, Americans are still not optimistic that a broken Washington will be fixed any time soon. My focus groups for CBS and Fox News are just as toxic today as they were six months ago. President Trump leads a deeply divided nation, and an abiding dislike for Congress and the Washington bureaucracy is among the few things that unites us. Americans are looking elsewhere for &ldquo;real results and real solutions, for real people.&rdquo; They are looking for their states, and especially their governors, to stand and deliver. The data is clear and conclusive. For example, we asked &ldquo;Overall, which level of government do you believe is doing a better job of serving its citizens and delivering results?&rdquo; Fully 71% of voters chose &ldquo;State Governments,&rdquo; while just 29% chose &ldquo;The Federal Government.&rdquo; On this, America has achieved rare bipartisan agreement. By party, the spread is 82% state government to 18% federal government among Republicans (+64), 54% to 46% among Democrats (+8), and 77% to 23% among Independents (+54). And with Trump upsetting the Left every day, it&rsquo;s likely that even more Democrats will choose the state government option in the months to follow. We then asked Americans to consider government programs like healthcare, Medicaid, education and rebuilding our roads and infrastructure. &ldquo;What is the best balance of control in terms of setting the rules and regulations and administering the programs?&rdquo; Just under one-third (31%) want the federal government to be in control, while more than two-thirds of the country either want genuine federal-state power sharing (35%) or the states to hold the power advantage (35%). Republicans are overwhelmingly in the state government camp, but Independents and Democrats aren&rsquo;t far behind. It&rsquo;s not just about the issues. It&rsquo;s also about the people. Nearly half of Americans (45%) regard &ldquo;America&rsquo;s governors and state governments&rdquo; favorably, while only 30% have a negative impression. By comparison, just 29% of the country has a favorable impression of Congress, while a majority (51%) hold a negative view. The federal government does even worse: 27% favorable, 56% unfavorable. I&rsquo;d provide the partisan results, but they&rsquo;re consistent across parties: everyone has a net favorable opinion of governors, and everyone dislikes Congress and the federal government &ndash; regardless of who&rsquo;s in charge. Voters of all stripes simply trust their governors far more than they trust their leaders in Washington. The number one reason among Democrats and Republicans alike: &ldquo;State leaders are more responsive because they are closer to their constituents.&rdquo; In a time when trust is scarce and with Americans demanding real progress right now, state governments and governors represent the best hope to win back to confidence of the voters and get the job done. This isn&rsquo;t an academic exercise or an ideological appeal for &ldquo;federalism.&rdquo; (Note to reader: Federalism is about taking power away from Washington. Many Americans think exactly the opposite.) It&rsquo;s not about smaller or more limited government. Almost no one I interview cares about the size of government as much as the efficiency, effectiveness and accountability of government. Americans want to empower states and governors to take a more active role in that governance because they&rsquo;ve given up on Washington &ndash; Trump or no Trump. Support for greater state control isn&rsquo;t about politics or partisanship. It&rsquo;s about performance. In recent years, many states have made meaningful and measurable progress, while Washington stoked gridlock with meaningless and maddening false promises. Americans simply have greater favorability towards their governor (net +16% positive) and America&rsquo;s governors and state governments (net +15%) and a more negative reaction towards the &ldquo;federal government&rdquo; (net -29%) and &ldquo;Congress&rdquo; (net -22%). Similarly, an overwhelming majority of voters (71%) believe their state is doing a better job of &ldquo;serving its citizens and delivering results,&rdquo; more than twice as many as the 29% who chose the federal government. And here&rsquo;s the encouraging part: Democrats, Republicans and Independents all agree. On most policy issues and personal attributes, voters trust states and governors more than they trust Congress and the federal government. The NGA survey identified ten specific areas where Americans trust state governments more than the federal government. Of all of the issues and attributes, none are more important than &ldquo;has the most dedicated public servants who are in it for the right reasons.&rdquo; Here, state governments hold an overwhelming 30 percent lead. The American people want their elected officials to fight for them rather than fight each other. They want cooperation, not confrontation. Message to Capitol Hill: even ordinary Republicans who have felt left out of national politics for the past eight years prefer compromise over uncompromising, unyielding principle by a margin of 58% to 42%. Americans are demanding a new relationship with their government that prioritizes local leadership and local solutions rather than an inflexible one-size-fits all national approach to the myriad challenges facing the country. A relationship that limits mandates and decision-making by unelected bureaucrats in Washington and prioritizes state and local engagement and input. A relationship where their state and local leaders not just listen but truly &ldquo;hear&rdquo; their constituents, because they often know them and actually understand them. A relationship that puts to an end the frustratingly failed practice of career politicians fighting so hard for votes on Election Day, only to return to Washington and dismiss the voices of those who cast them. Whether Democratic or Republican, old or young, Rust Belt or Sun Belt, Americans want to be represented by local leaders who say what they mean, mean what they say, and are willing to supplant the status quo in favor of a better future. There&rsquo;s a clear message here, if the politicians are willing to hear it. The New Relationship is not about shifting dollars or responsibilities between or across congressional committees or federal agencies. It&rsquo;s about the complete restructure of government from the bottom up and the top down. It&rsquo;s about giving states the responsibilities most of us believe they deserve. Americans are looking to the governors to be their voice. They want to be heard, yes. But more importantly, they want their Governors to lead. There are notable exceptions, but for the most part, the American people believe their governors are succeeding. They aren&rsquo;t holding their breath about Washington. AREAS WHERE STATE GOVERNMENT IS MORE TRUSTED THAN THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT &#8212; &ldquo;Has the most dedicated public servants who are in it for the right reasons:&rdquo; (States +30%) &#8212; &ldquo;Educating students and helping them achieve:&rdquo; (States +28%) &#8212; &ldquo;Offering quality workforce and job training programs:&rdquo; (States +21%) &#8212; &ldquo;Spending my tax dollars efficiently and effectively:&rdquo; (States +16%) &#8212; &ldquo;Has the most positive impact on my quality of life:&rdquo; (States +14%) &#8212; &ldquo;Listening to, representing and being accountable to us, the voters:&rdquo; (States +14%) &#8212; &ldquo;Delivering welfare programs for those who need it, while curbing waste and abuse:&rdquo; (States +10%) &#8212; &ldquo;Improving our roads, highways, transit and infrastructure.&rdquo; (States +9%) &#8212; &ldquo;Protecting the rights of workers, employees and small business owners:&rdquo; (States +5%) &#8212; &ldquo;Creating new solutions that are more innovative and more focused on the future. (States +4%)"},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;The American people are asking for – in fact, demanding – a &#8216;New Relationship&#8217; with their government at all levels&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":90772803,"featured_media":4683010,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[2311,430939235,398,620,430953096],"time_section":[272184451],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937781],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682090"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682090\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682090\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=4682090"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=4682090"},{"taxonomy":"topic","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftopics?post=4682090"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682090\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682090\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682090\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682090\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682090\u002Fauthors"}],"fortune:newsletter":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682090\u002Fnewsletter"}],"fortune:more":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682090\u002Fmore"}],"fortune:popular":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682090\u002Fpopular"}],"fortune:listicle":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682090\u002Flisticle"}],"fortune:gallery":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682090\u002Fgallery"}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682090\u002Fprimary_tag"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682090\u002Fprimary_section"}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682090\u002Fprimary_topic"}],"ng:more:brand":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682090\u002Fbrand"}],"ng:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fauthors?post=4682090"}]},"_embedded":{"wp:term":[[{"id":1,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fcategory\u002Funcategorized\u002F","name":"Uncategorized","slug":"uncategorized","taxonomy":"category","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories\u002F1"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fcategory"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?categories=1"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002 route was found matching the URL and request method","data":{"status":404}}],"wp:meta":[{"bitly_url":"http:\u002F\u002Fti.me\u002F2lNNINF","negative_coverage":false,"mt_seo_title":"Frank Luntz: Washington","permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4682090\u002Ffrank-luntz-america-relationship\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ftime\u002F4682090\u002Ffrank-luntz-america-relationship\u002F?source=dam"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"landscape","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":4683010,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Famerican-flag.jpg?quality=85","alt":"US-POLITICS-TRUMP-PROTEST","caption":"A Images","title":"US-POLITICS-TRUMP-PROTEST"},"video":[],"structured":false}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":430953096,"name":"The People","slug":"the-people","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":101563,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":1,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":272184451,"name":"Ideas","slug":"ideas","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":31139,"taxonomy":"time_section","description":"TIME Ideas hosts the world's leading voices, providing commentary on events in news, society, and culture. We welcome outside contributions. Opinions expressed do not necessarily reflect the views of TIME editors.","parent":0,"count":5725,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["ideas"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4682994,"date":"2017-02-25T17:16:41","date_gmt":"2017-02-25T22:16:41","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4682994"},"modified":"2017-02-25T17:05:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-25T22:05:00","slug":"diplomat-daniel-fried-retirement-speech","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4682994\u002Fdiplomat-daniel-fried-retirement-speech\u002F","title":{"rendered":"Read U.S. Diplomat Daniel Fried's Retirement Speech Warning Against Isolationism"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EThank you, colleagues and friends.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAnd thank you to my daughters Hannah and Sophie for putting up with all that my job has required over many years. And I am so happy that my son-in-law Brian Hanley, a good guy, has joined our family.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETo Olga, there is much to say, but now I will say only that I relied on your professional guidance for many years, and your analytic judgment helped me make some crucial calls early on. You know what you did, and for that, and much else, my thanks.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAnd to our 15-month old granddaughter Ava, in her terms, &ldquo;Hi!&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EMy 40 years in the Foreign Service &ndash; and the careers of many of my friends &ndash; became associated with the fall of the Soviet Empire and the putting in order of what came after: the building of a Europe whole, free and at peace. It is hard to recall today how improbable victory in the Cold War appeared. For two generations, up through the mid-1980s, many thought we were losing the Cold War. Even in early 1989, few believed that Poland&rsquo;s Solidarity movement could win, that the Iron Curtain would come down, that the Baltic states could be free, that the second of the 20\u003Csup\u003Eth\u003C\u002Fsup\u003E Century&rsquo;s great evils &ndash; Communism &ndash; could be vanquished without war. But it happened, and the West&rsquo;s great institutions &ndash; NATO and the EU &ndash; grew to embrace 100 million liberated Europeans. It was my honor to have done what I could to help. I learned never to underestimate the possibility of change, that values have power, and that time and patience can pay off, especially if you&rsquo;re serious about your objectives. Nothing can be taken for granted, and this great achievement is now under assault by Russia, but what we did in my time is no less honorable. It is for the present generation to defend and, when the time comes again, extend freedom in Europe.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAmerica put its back into this rebirth of freedom in the West, not because we sought to &ldquo;impose&rdquo; ourselves on unwilling nations, but because captive nations sought our aid, and we saw that our interests would advance along with our values. This was no new insight, but merely the expression in my time of what I will call America&rsquo;s Grand Strategy.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFrom our emergence as a world power at the end of the 19\u003Csup\u003Eth\u003C\u002Fsup\u003E Century, the U.S. opposed spheres of influence and the closed European empires of the time. Instead, we favored an open world, ordered by rules, in which the values of our Republic and our business interests could simultaneously succeed. In our abundant self-confidence, we assumed that our Yankee ingenuity would prevail in a fair playing field and that our values would naturally follow. We would fashion the world in our own, democratic, image and get rich in the process: a vision breathtaking in its ambition. Yet our positive-sum world view, exceptional among the great powers, allowed room for others to prosper alongside the United States. In fact, the genius of the American system is that our success depended on the prosperity and security of other nations. We would lead in concert with the other great democracies of the world. George Kennan didn&rsquo;t think much of what he termed America&rsquo;s moralistic-legalistic tradition. But this foreign policy exceptionalism was the heart of our Grand Strategy through two World Wars, the Cold War and the post-1989 era, and it was crowned with success. Our mistakes, blunders, flaws, and shortcomings notwithstanding, the world America made after1945 and 1989 has enjoyed the longest period of general peace in the West since Roman times, and decades of prosperity.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThis track record suggests that an open, rules-based world, with a united West at its core, is an asset and great achievement, and a foundation for more. Yet, some argue that this is actually a liability, that values are a luxury, that in a Hobbesian or Darwinian world we should simply take our share, the largest possible. Consider the consequences of such arguments. By abandoning our American Grand Strategy, we would diminish to being just another zero-sum great power. Spheres of influence &ndash; admired by those who don&rsquo;t have to suffer the consequences &#8212; would mean our acquiescence when great powers &ndash; starting with Russia and China &ndash; dominated their neighbors through force and fear, while creating closed economic empires. Were we to recognize this, we would abandon our American sense of the potential for progress in the world; we would abandon our generations-old support for human rights, turning our backs on those who still turn to American in hope. And of course we would have to accept permanent commercial disadvantage. America would essentially retreat from whole areas of East Asia, Central Asia, and Eastern Europe. More retreat would follow as other emerging great powers carved out their own spheres, small and large.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESome so-called realists might accept such a world as making the best of a harsh world, but it is not realistic to expect that it would be peaceful or stable. Rather the reverse: a sphere of influence system would lead to cycles of rebellion and repression and, if the past 1000 years is any guide, lead to war between the great powers, because no power would be satisfied with its sphere. They never are. In 1940, Germany offered Britain a sphere of influence deal: German recognition of the British Empire in exchange for London&rsquo;s recognition of Germany dominance of continental Europe. Churchill didn&rsquo;t take the deal then; we should not take similar deals now.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAmerica&rsquo;s Grand Strategy did not come from nowhere: it followed from our deeper conception of ourselves and our American identity. Who are we Americans? What is our nation?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWe are not an ethno-state, with identity rooted in shared blood. The option of a White Man&rsquo;s Republic ended at Appomattox. On the contrary, we are &ldquo;\u003Cem\u003Ea new nation, conceived in liberty and dedicated to the proposition that all men are created equal.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E&rdquo; We say this more often than we consider its significance. Our nation is based on an idea that, when embraced, makes us Americans. We fought a Civil War over whether that sentence &ndash; that all men are created equal &ndash; was meant literally.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDon&rsquo;t take my word for it. Consider Abraham Lincoln&rsquo;s speech given just after July 4, 1858. Lincoln observes that in celebrating the 4\u003Csup\u003Eth\u003C\u002Fsup\u003E of July, descendants of the generation of 1776 feel proud, as they should. But he goes on:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003E&ldquo;We have besides these men&mdash;descended by blood from our ancestors &ndash; among us perhaps half our people who are not descendants at all of these men, they are men who have come from Europe&hellip;and settled here, finding themselves our equals in all things. If they look back through this history to trace their connection with those days by blood, they find they have none, they cannot carry themselves back into that glorious epoch and make themselves feel that they are part of us, but when they look through that old Declaration of Independence they find that those old men say that &lsquo;We hold these truths to be self-evident, that all men are created equal,&rsquo; and then they feel that that moral sentiment taught in that day evidences their relation to those men, that it is the father of all moral principle in them, and that they have a right to claim it as though they were blood of the blood, and flesh of the flesh of the men who wrote that Declaration, and so they are.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAnd so we are, all Americans. We opened our country to the stranger, from all lands on Earth, with the door to American identity the principle of that old Declaration, &ldquo;All men are created equal.&rdquo; We feel that sense of American identity to this very day. And that rough sense of equality and opportunity, embedded in us, informed the way that we brought our American power to the world, America&rsquo;s Grand Strategy. We have, imperfectly, and despite detours and retreat along the way, sought to realize a better world for ourselves and for others, for we understood that our prosperity and our values at home depend on that prosperity and those values being secure as far as possible in a sometimes dark world. And we have done well.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EMy time in the Foreign Service is ending. I am grateful for the opportunity it has given me to witness history and, sometimes, to try to bend history&rsquo;s arc.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFor those of you remaining in government service, I say this: serve your nation and this Administration as you serve all Administrations: with loyalty, dedication and courage. Help Secretary TIllerson. He deserves it. And he needs it. And help the President as well, putting your backs in it.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAnd as you serve, you will, as I did, always remember your oath to the Constitution, and to that principle behind the Constitution: our nation is dedicated to the proposition that all men are created equal.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHave faith in our nation, in our Constitution and in that proposition. Have faith in yourselves, thus inspired, and in each other.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAnd therefore, as Lincoln said, \u003Cem\u003E&ldquo;LET US HAVE FAITH THAT RIGHT MAKES MIGHT, AND IN THAT FAITH, LET US, TO THE END, DARE TO DO OUR DUTY AS WE UNDERSTAND IT.&rdquo; \u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Thank you, colleagues and friends."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["And thank you to my daughters Hannah and Sophie for putting up with all that my job has required over many years. And I am so happy that my son-in-law Brian Hanley, a good guy, has joined our family."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["To Olga, there is much to say, but now I will say only that I relied on your professional guidance for many years, and your analytic judgment helped me make some crucial calls early on. You know what you did, and for that, and much else, my thanks."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["And to our 15-month old granddaughter Ava, in her terms, “Hi!”"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["My 40 years in the Foreign Service – and the careers of many of my friends – became associated with the fall of the Soviet Empire and the putting in order of what came after: the building of a Europe whole, free and at peace. It is hard to recall today how improbable victory in the Cold War appeared. For two generations, up through the mid-1980s, many thought we were losing the Cold War. Even in early 1989, few believed that Poland’s Solidarity movement could win, that the Iron Curtain would come down, that the Baltic states could be free, that the second of the 20",{"tag":"sup","attributes":[],"content":["th"]}," Century’s great evils – Communism – could be vanquished without war. But it happened, and the West’s great institutions – NATO and the EU – grew to embrace 100 million liberated Europeans. It was my honor to have done what I could to help. I learned never to underestimate the possibility of change, that values have power, and that time and patience can pay off, especially if you’re serious about your objectives. Nothing can be taken for granted, and this great achievement is now under assault by Russia, but what we did in my time is no less honorable. It is for the present generation to defend and, when the time comes again, extend freedom in Europe."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["America put its back into this rebirth of freedom in the West, not because we sought to “impose” ourselves on unwilling nations, but because captive nations sought our aid, and we saw that our interests would advance along with our values. This was no new insight, but merely the expression in my time of what I will call America’s Grand Strategy."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["From our emergence as a world power at the end of the 19",{"tag":"sup","attributes":[],"content":["th"]}," Century, the U.S. opposed spheres of influence and the closed European empires of the time. Instead, we favored an open world, ordered by rules, in which the values of our Republic and our business interests could simultaneously succeed. In our abundant self-confidence, we assumed that our Yankee ingenuity would prevail in a fair playing field and that our values would naturally follow. We would fashion the world in our own, democratic, image and get rich in the process: a vision breathtaking in its ambition. Yet our positive-sum world view, exceptional among the great powers, allowed room for others to prosper alongside the United States. In fact, the genius of the American system is that our success depended on the prosperity and security of other nations. We would lead in concert with the other great democracies of the world. George Kennan didn’t think much of what he termed America’s moralistic-legalistic tradition. But this foreign policy exceptionalism was the heart of our Grand Strategy through two World Wars, the Cold War and the post-1989 era, and it was crowned with success. Our mistakes, blunders, flaws, and shortcomings notwithstanding, the world America made after1945 and 1989 has enjoyed the longest period of general peace in the West since Roman times, and decades of prosperity."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["This track record suggests that an open, rules-based world, with a united West at its core, is an asset and great achievement, and a foundation for more. Yet, some argue that this is actually a liability, that values are a luxury, that in a Hobbesian or Darwinian world we should simply take our share, the largest possible. Consider the consequences of such arguments. By abandoning our American Grand Strategy, we would diminish to being just another zero-sum great power. Spheres of influence – admired by those who don’t have to suffer the consequences -- would mean our acquiescence when great powers – starting with Russia and China – dominated their neighbors through force and fear, while creating closed economic empires. Were we to recognize this, we would abandon our American sense of the potential for progress in the world; we would abandon our generations-old support for human rights, turning our backs on those who still turn to American in hope. And of course we would have to accept permanent commercial disadvantage. America would essentially retreat from whole areas of East Asia, Central Asia, and Eastern Europe. More retreat would follow as other emerging great powers carved out their own spheres, small and large."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Some so-called realists might accept such a world as making the best of a harsh world, but it is not realistic to expect that it would be peaceful or stable. Rather the reverse: a sphere of influence system would lead to cycles of rebellion and repression and, if the past 1000 years is any guide, lead to war between the great powers, because no power would be satisfied with its sphere. They never are. In 1940, Germany offered Britain a sphere of influence deal: German recognition of the British Empire in exchange for London’s recognition of Germany dominance of continental Europe. Churchill didn’t take the deal then; we should not take similar deals now."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["America’s Grand Strategy did not come from nowhere: it followed from our deeper conception of ourselves and our American identity. Who are we Americans? What is our nation?"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["We are not an ethno-state, with identity rooted in shared blood. The option of a White Man’s Republic ended at Appomattox. On the contrary, we are “",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["a new nation, conceived in liberty and dedicated to the proposition that all men are created equal."]},"” We say this more often than we consider its significance. Our nation is based on an idea that, when embraced, makes us Americans. We fought a Civil War over whether that sentence – that all men are created equal – was meant literally."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Don’t take my word for it. Consider Abraham Lincoln’s speech given just after July 4, 1858. Lincoln observes that in celebrating the 4",{"tag":"sup","attributes":[],"content":["th"]}," of July, descendants of the generation of 1776 feel proud, as they should. But he goes on:"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["“We have besides these men—descended by blood from our ancestors – among us perhaps half our people who are not descendants at all of these men, they are men who have come from Europe…and settled here, finding themselves our equals in all things. If they look back through this history to trace their connection with those days by blood, they find they have none, they cannot carry themselves back into that glorious epoch and make themselves feel that they are part of us, but when they look through that old Declaration of Independence they find that those old men say that ‘We hold these truths to be self-evident, that all men are created equal,’ and then they feel that that moral sentiment taught in that day evidences their relation to those men, that it is the father of all moral principle in them, and that they have a right to claim it as though they were blood of the blood, and flesh of the flesh of the men who wrote that Declaration, and so they are.”"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["And so we are, all Americans. We opened our country to the stranger, from all lands on Earth, with the door to American identity the principle of that old Declaration, “All men are created equal.” We feel that sense of American identity to this very day. And that rough sense of equality and opportunity, embedded in us, informed the way that we brought our American power to the world, America’s Grand Strategy. We have, imperfectly, and despite detours and retreat along the way, sought to realize a better world for ourselves and for others, for we understood that our prosperity and our values at home depend on that prosperity and those values being secure as far as possible in a sometimes dark world. And we have done well."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["My time in the Foreign Service is ending. I am grateful for the opportunity it has given me to witness history and, sometimes, to try to bend history’s arc."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["For those of you remaining in government service, I say this: serve your nation and this Administration as you serve all Administrations: with loyalty, dedication and courage. Help Secretary TIllerson. He deserves it. And he needs it. And help the President as well, putting your backs in it."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["And as you serve, you will, as I did, always remember your oath to the Constitution, and to that principle behind the Constitution: our nation is dedicated to the proposition that all men are created equal."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Have faith in our nation, in our Constitution and in that proposition. Have faith in yourselves, thus inspired, and in each other."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["And therefore, as Lincoln said, ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["“LET US HAVE FAITH THAT RIGHT MAKES MIGHT, AND IN THAT FAITH, LET US, TO THE END, DARE TO DO OUR DUTY AS WE UNDERSTAND IT.” "]}]}],"plain":"Thank you, colleagues and friends. And thank you to my daughters Hannah and Sophie for putting up with all that my job has required over many years. And I am so happy that my son-in-law Brian Hanley, a good guy, has joined our family. To Olga, there is much to say, but now I will say only that I relied on your professional guidance for many years, and your analytic judgment helped me make some crucial calls early on. You know what you did, and for that, and much else, my thanks. And to our 15-month old granddaughter Ava, in her terms, &ldquo;Hi!&rdquo; My 40 years in the Foreign Service &ndash; and the careers of many of my friends &ndash; became associated with the fall of the Soviet Empire and the putting in order of what came after: the building of a Europe whole, free and at peace. It is hard to recall today how improbable victory in the Cold War appeared. For two generations, up through the mid-1980s, many thought we were losing the Cold War. Even in early 1989, few believed that Poland&rsquo;s Solidarity movement could win, that the Iron Curtain would come down, that the Baltic states could be free, that the second of the 20th Century&rsquo;s great evils &ndash; Communism &ndash; could be vanquished without war. But it happened, and the West&rsquo;s great institutions &ndash; NATO and the EU &ndash; grew to embrace 100 million liberated Europeans. It was my honor to have done what I could to help. I learned never to underestimate the possibility of change, that values have power, and that time and patience can pay off, especially if you&rsquo;re serious about your objectives. Nothing can be taken for granted, and this great achievement is now under assault by Russia, but what we did in my time is no less honorable. It is for the present generation to defend and, when the time comes again, extend freedom in Europe. America put its back into this rebirth of freedom in the West, not because we sought to &ldquo;impose&rdquo; ourselves on unwilling nations, but because captive nations sought our aid, and we saw that our interests would advance along with our values. This was no new insight, but merely the expression in my time of what I will call America&rsquo;s Grand Strategy. From our emergence as a world power at the end of the 19th Century, the U.S. opposed spheres of influence and the closed European empires of the time. Instead, we favored an open world, ordered by rules, in which the values of our Republic and our business interests could simultaneously succeed. In our abundant self-confidence, we assumed that our Yankee ingenuity would prevail in a fair playing field and that our values would naturally follow. We would fashion the world in our own, democratic, image and get rich in the process: a vision breathtaking in its ambition. Yet our positive-sum world view, exceptional among the great powers, allowed room for others to prosper alongside the United States. In fact, the genius of the American system is that our success depended on the prosperity and security of other nations. We would lead in concert with the other great democracies of the world. George Kennan didn&rsquo;t think much of what he termed America&rsquo;s moralistic-legalistic tradition. But this foreign policy exceptionalism was the heart of our Grand Strategy through two World Wars, the Cold War and the post-1989 era, and it was crowned with success. Our mistakes, blunders, flaws, and shortcomings notwithstanding, the world America made after1945 and 1989 has enjoyed the longest period of general peace in the West since Roman times, and decades of prosperity. This track record suggests that an open, rules-based world, with a united West at its core, is an asset and great achievement, and a foundation for more. Yet, some argue that this is actually a liability, that values are a luxury, that in a Hobbesian or Darwinian world we should simply take our share, the largest possible. Consider the consequences of such arguments. By abandoning our American Grand Strategy, we would diminish to being just another zero-sum great power. Spheres of influence &ndash; admired by those who don&rsquo;t have to suffer the consequences &#8212; would mean our acquiescence when great powers &ndash; starting with Russia and China &ndash; dominated their neighbors through force and fear, while creating closed economic empires. Were we to recognize this, we would abandon our American sense of the potential for progress in the world; we would abandon our generations-old support for human rights, turning our backs on those who still turn to American in hope. And of course we would have to accept permanent commercial disadvantage. America would essentially retreat from whole areas of East Asia, Central Asia, and Eastern Europe. More retreat would follow as other emerging great powers carved out their own spheres, small and large. Some so-called realists might accept such a world as making the best of a harsh world, but it is not realistic to expect that it would be peaceful or stable. Rather the reverse: a sphere of influence system would lead to cycles of rebellion and repression and, if the past 1000 years is any guide, lead to war between the great powers, because no power would be satisfied with its sphere. They never are. In 1940, Germany offered Britain a sphere of influence deal: German recognition of the British Empire in exchange for London&rsquo;s recognition of Germany dominance of continental Europe. Churchill didn&rsquo;t take the deal then; we should not take similar deals now. America&rsquo;s Grand Strategy did not come from nowhere: it followed from our deeper conception of ourselves and our American identity. Who are we Americans? What is our nation? We are not an ethno-state, with identity rooted in shared blood. The option of a White Man&rsquo;s Republic ended at Appomattox. On the contrary, we are &ldquo;a new nation, conceived in liberty and dedicated to the proposition that all men are created equal.&rdquo; We say this more often than we consider its significance. Our nation is based on an idea that, when embraced, makes us Americans. We fought a Civil War over whether that sentence &ndash; that all men are created equal &ndash; was meant literally. Don&rsquo;t take my word for it. Consider Abraham Lincoln&rsquo;s speech given just after July 4, 1858. Lincoln observes that in celebrating the 4th of July, descendants of the generation of 1776 feel proud, as they should. But he goes on: &ldquo;We have besides these men&mdash;descended by blood from our ancestors &ndash; among us perhaps half our people who are not descendants at all of these men, they are men who have come from Europe&hellip;and settled here, finding themselves our equals in all things. If they look back through this history to trace their connection with those days by blood, they find they have none, they cannot carry themselves back into that glorious epoch and make themselves feel that they are part of us, but when they look through that old Declaration of Independence they find that those old men say that &lsquo;We hold these truths to be self-evident, that all men are created equal,&rsquo; and then they feel that that moral sentiment taught in that day evidences their relation to those men, that it is the father of all moral principle in them, and that they have a right to claim it as though they were blood of the blood, and flesh of the flesh of the men who wrote that Declaration, and so they are.&rdquo; And so we are, all Americans. We opened our country to the stranger, from all lands on Earth, with the door to American identity the principle of that old Declaration, &ldquo;All men are created equal.&rdquo; We feel that sense of American identity to this very day. And that rough sense of equality and opportunity, embedded in us, informed the way that we brought our American power to the world, America&rsquo;s Grand Strategy. We have, imperfectly, and despite detours and retreat along the way, sought to realize a better world for ourselves and for others, for we understood that our prosperity and our values at home depend on that prosperity and those values being secure as far as possible in a sometimes dark world. And we have done well. My time in the Foreign Service is ending. I am grateful for the opportunity it has given me to witness history and, sometimes, to try to bend history&rsquo;s arc. For those of you remaining in government service, I say this: serve your nation and this Administration as you serve all Administrations: with loyalty, dedication and courage. Help Secretary TIllerson. He deserves it. And he needs it. And help the President as well, putting your backs in it. And as you serve, you will, as I did, always remember your oath to the Constitution, and to that principle behind the Constitution: our nation is dedicated to the proposition that all men are created equal. Have faith in our nation, in our Constitution and in that proposition. Have faith in yourselves, thus inspired, and in each other. And therefore, as Lincoln said, &ldquo;LET US HAVE FAITH THAT RIGHT MAKES MIGHT, AND IN THAT FAITH, LET US, TO THE END, DARE TO DO OUR DUTY AS WE UNDERSTAND IT.&rdquo;"},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E&#8216;We are not an ethno-state, with identity rooted in shared blood&#8217;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":108310934,"featured_media":4683001,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[430939235,398],"time_section":[272184451],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937781],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682994"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682994\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682994\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=4682994"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=4682994"},{"taxonomy":"topic","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftopics?post=4682994"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682994\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682994\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682994\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682994\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682994\u002Fauthors"}],"fortune:newsl ney_article?categories=1"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[{"id":430939235,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Ftag\u002Fonetime\u002F","name":"onetime","slug":"onetime","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags\u002F430939235"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fpost_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?tags=430939235"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=430939235"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":398,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Ftag\u002Fpolitics\u002F","name":"politics","slug":"politics","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags\u002F398"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fpost_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?tags=398"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=398"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}}],{"code":"rest_no_route","message":"No Ideas hosts the world's leading voices, providing commentary on events in news, society, and culture. We welcome outside contributions. Opinions expressed do not necessarily reflect the views of TIME editors.","parent":0,"count":5725,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["ideas"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4682990,"date":"2017-02-25T16:47:43","date_gmt":"2017-02-25T21:47:43","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4682990"},"modified":"2017-02-25T16:22:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-25T21:22:00","slug":"muhammad-ali-son-detained-airport","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4682990\u002Fmuhammad-ali-son-detained-airport\u002F","title":{"rendered":"Muhammad Ali's Son Detained at Airport and Was Asked 'Are you Muslim?'"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EMuhammad Ali&#8217;s son, who bears the boxing great&#8217;s name, was detained by immigration officials at a Florida airport and questioned about his ancestry and religion in what amounted to profiling, a family friend said Saturday.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EReturning from a Black History Month event in Jamaica, Muhammad Ali Jr. and his mother, Khalilah Camacho Ali, were pulled aside and separated from each other while going through the immigration checkpoint on Feb. 7 at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport, said Chris Mancini, a family friend and attorney.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ECamacho Ali was released a short time later after showing a photo of herself with her ex-husband, the former heavyweight boxing champion, Mancini said. But Ali Jr. was not carrying a photo of his world-famous father &mdash; a recipient of the Presidential Medal of Freedom.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAli Jr., 44, who confirmed his Muslim faith, was detained about two hours, despite telling officials that he&#8217;s Ali&#8217;s son and a native-born U.S. citizen, Mancini said. It was the first time Ali Jr. and his mother have ever been asked if they&#8217;re Muslim when re-entering the United States, he said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;From the way they were treated, from what was said to them, they can come up with no other rational explanation except they fell into a profiling program run by customs, which is designed to obtain information from anyone who says they&#8217;re a Muslim,&#8221; Mancini said in a phone interview. &#8220;It&#8217;s quite clear that what triggered his detention was his Arabic name and his religion.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EReached for comment Friday, a U.S. Customs and Border Protection spokesman said in an email: &#8220;Due to the restrictions of the Privacy Act, the U.S. Customs and Border Protection cannot discuss individual travelers; however, all international travelers arriving in the U.S. are subject to CBP inspection,&#8221; according to The Courier-Journal&#8217;s report about the detention.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAn airport spokesman referred questions on Saturday to customs and border protection officials.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDuring his detention, Ali Jr. was asked repeatedly about his lineage and his name, &#8220;as if that was a pre-programmed question that was part of a profile,&#8221; Mancini said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAli Jr. and his mother have been frequent global travelers. The family connects their treatment to President Donald Trump&#8217;s efforts to restrict immigration after calling during his campaign for a ban on Muslims entering the U.S.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;This has never happened to them before,&#8221; Mancini said. &#8220;They&#8217;re asked specifically about their Arabic names. Where they got their names from and whether they&#8217;re Muslims. It doesn&#8217;t take much to connect those dots to what Trump is doing.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ECamacho Ali and Ali Jr. live in Florida. They have not traveled abroad since, and are considering filing a federal lawsuit, he said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAli, the three-time heavyweight champion and humanitarian, died last June at age 74 after a long battle with Parkinson&#8217;s disease. People lined the streets of Louisville, Kentucky, to say goodbye to the city&#8217;s most celebrated son before a star-studded memorial service watched worldwide.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Muhammad Ali's son, who bears the boxing great's name, was detained by immigration officials at a Florida airport and questioned about his ancestry and religion in what amounted to profiling, a family friend said Saturday."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Returning from a Black History Month event in Jamaica, Muhammad Ali Jr. and his mother, Khalilah Camacho Ali, were pulled aside and separated from each other while going through the immigration checkpoint on Feb. 7 at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport, said Chris Mancini, a family friend and attorney."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Camacho Ali was released a short time later after showing a photo of herself with her ex-husband, the former heavyweight boxing champion, Mancini said. But Ali Jr. was not carrying a photo of his world-famous father — a recipient of the Presidential Medal of Freedom."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Ali Jr., 44, who confirmed his Muslim faith, was detained about two hours, despite telling officials that he's Ali's son and a native-born U.S. citizen, Mancini said. It was the first time Ali Jr. and his mother have ever been asked if they're Muslim when re-entering the United States, he said."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"From the way they were treated, from what was said to them, they can come up with no other rational explanation except they fell into a profiling program run by customs, which is designed to obtain information from anyone who says they're a Muslim,\" Mancini said in a phone interview. \"It's quite clear that what triggered his detention was his Arabic name and his religion.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Reached for comment Friday, a U.S. Customs and Border Protection spokesman said in an email: \"Due to the restrictions of the Privacy Act, the U.S. Customs and Border Protection cannot discuss individual travelers; however, all international travelers arriving in the U.S. are subject to CBP inspection,\" according to The Courier-Journal's report about the detention."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["An airport spokesman referred questions on Saturday to customs and border protection officials."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["During his detention, Ali Jr. was asked repeatedly about his lineage and his name, \"as if that was a pre-programmed question that was part of a profile,\" Mancini said."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Ali Jr. and his mother have been frequent global travelers. The family connects their treatment to President Donald Trump's efforts to restrict immigration after calling during his campaign for a ban on Muslims entering the U.S."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"This has never happened to them before,\" Mancini said. \"They're asked specifically about their Arabic names. Where they got their names from and whether they're Muslims. It doesn't take much to connect those dots to what Trump is doing.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Camacho Ali and Ali Jr. live in Florida. They have not traveled abroad since, and are considering filing a federal lawsuit, he said."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Ali, the three-time heavyweight champion and humanitarian, died last June at age 74 after a long battle with Parkinson's disease. People lined the streets of Louisville, Kentucky, to say goodbye to the city's most celebrated son before a star-studded memorial service watched worldwide."]}],"plain":"Muhammad Ali&#8217;s son, who bears the boxing great&#8217;s name, was detained by immigration officials at a Florida airport and questioned about his ancestry and religion in what amounted to profiling, a family friend said Saturday. Returning from a Black History Month event in Jamaica, Muhammad Ali Jr. and his mother, Khalilah Camacho Ali, were pulled aside and separated from each other while going through the immigration checkpoint on Feb. 7 at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport, said Chris Mancini, a family friend and attorney. Camacho Ali was released a short time later after showing a photo of herself with her ex-husband, the former heavyweight boxing champion, Mancini said. But Ali Jr. was not carrying a photo of his world-famous father &mdash; a recipient of the Presidential Medal of Freedom. Ali Jr., 44, who confirmed his Muslim faith, was detained about two hours, despite telling officials that he&#8217;s Ali&#8217;s son and a native-born U.S. citizen, Mancini said. It was the first time Ali Jr. and his mother have ever been asked if they&#8217;re Muslim when re-entering the United States, he said. &#8220;From the way they were treated, from what was said to them, they can come up with no other rational explanation except they fell into a profiling program run by customs, which is designed to obtain information from anyone who says they&#8217;re a Muslim,&#8221; Mancini said in a phone interview. &#8220;It&#8217;s quite clear that what triggered his detention was his Arabic name and his religion.&#8221; Reached for comment Friday, a U.S. Customs and Border Protection spokesman said in an email: &#8220;Due to the restrictions of the Privacy Act, the U.S. Customs and Border Protection cannot discuss individual travelers; however, all international travelers arriving in the U.S. are subject to CBP inspection,&#8221; according to The Courier-Journal&#8217;s report about the detention. An airport spokesman referred questions on Saturday to customs and border protection officials. During his detention, Ali Jr. was asked repeatedly about his lineage and his name, &#8220;as if that was a pre-programmed question that was part of a profile,&#8221; Mancini said. Ali Jr. and his mother have been frequent global travelers. The family connects their treatment to President Donald Trump&#8217;s efforts to restrict immigration after calling during his campaign for a ban on Muslims entering the U.S. &#8220;This has never happened to them before,&#8221; Mancini said. &#8220;They&#8217;re asked specifically about their Arabic names. Where they got their names from and whether they&#8217;re Muslims. It doesn&#8217;t take much to connect those dots to what Trump is doing.&#8221; Camacho Ali and Ali Jr. live in Florida. They have not traveled abroad since, and are considering filing a federal lawsuit, he said. Ali, the three-time heavyweight champion and humanitarian, died last June at age 74 after a long battle with Parkinson&#8217;s disease. People lined the streets of Louisville, Kentucky, to say goodbye to the city&#8217;s most celebrated son before a star-studded memorial service watched worldwide."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;It&#8217;s quite clear that what triggered his detention was his Arabic name and his religion,&#8221; a family friend and lawyer But his plans have been upended after U.S. officials reported finding &#8220;derogatory information&#8221; regarding Khateeb.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDerogatory information is a broad category that can include anything from terror connections to passport irregularities. Asked for comment, a spokeswoman for the Department of Homeland Security, Gillian Christensen, said, &#8220;A valid travel document is required for travel to the United States.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;The White Helmets,&#8221; a 40-minute \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fnetflix-379\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ENetflix\u003C\u002Fa\u003E documentary, has been nominated for Best Documentary Short. Many of the group&#8217;s members have been killed by Syrian President Bashar Assad&#8217;s air forces. The group also was nominated for last year&#8217;s Nobel Peace Prize.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;The White Helmets&#8221; includes emblematic scenes of the deadly 6-year-old conflict: people digging through destroyed homes looking for survivors, at constant risk of &#8220;double tap&#8221; attacks that target first responders after they&#8217;ve arrived at the scene of a strike.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EKhateeb had been issued a visa to attend the ceremony with Hollywood&#8217;s biggest stars.
