There was no explanation in the correspondence for why Turkey detained Khateeb.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["(WASHINGTON) — U.S. immigration authorities are barring entry to a 21-year-old Syrian cinematographer who worked on a harrowing film about his nation's civil war, \"The White Helmets,\" that has been nominated for an Academy Award."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["According to internal Trump administration correspondence seen by The Associated Press, the Department of Homeland Security has decided at the last minute to block Khaled Khateeb from traveling to Los Angeles for the Oscars."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Khateeb was scheduled to arrive Saturday in Los Angeles on a Turkish Airlines flight departing from Istanbul. But his plans have been upended after U.S. officials reported finding \"derogatory information\" regarding Khateeb."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Derogatory information is a broad category that can include anything from terror connections to passport irregularities. Khateeb is one of three people credited for cinematography; Franklin Dow is the film's director of photography."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The film focuses on the rescue workers who risk their lives to save Syrians affected by civil war. Many of the group's members have been killed by Syrian President Bashar Assad's air forces. The group also was nominated for last year's Nobel Peace Prize."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"The White Helmets\" includes emblematic scenes of the deadly 6-year-old conflict: people digging through destroyed homes looking for survivors, at constant risk of \"double tap\" attacks that target first responders after they've arrived at the scene of a strike."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Khateeb had been issued a visa to attend the ceremony with Hollywood's biggest stars. But Turkish authorities detained him this week, according to the internal U.S. government correspondence, and he suddenly needed a passport waiver from the United States to enter the country."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The correspondence indicated he would not receive such a waiver. There was no explanation in the correspondence for why Turkey detained Khateeb."]}],"plain":"(WASHINGTON) &mdash; U.S. immigration authorities are barring entry to a 21-year-old Syrian cinematographer who worked on a harrowing film about his nation&#8217;s civil war, &#8220;The White Helmets,&#8221; that has been nominated for an Academy Award. According to internal Trump administration correspondence seen by The Associated Press, the Department of Homeland Security has decided at the last minute to block Khaled Khateeb from traveling to Los Angeles for the Oscars. Khateeb was scheduled to arrive Saturday in Los Angeles on a Turkish Airlines flight departing from Istanbul. But his plans have been upended after U.S. officials reported finding &#8220;derogatory information&#8221; regarding Khateeb. Derogatory information is a broad category that can include anything from terror connections to passport irregularities. Asked for comment, a spokeswoman for the Department of Homeland Security, Gillian Christensen, said, &#8220;A valid travel document is required for travel to the United States.&#8221; &#8220;The White Helmets,&#8221; a 40-minute Netflix documentary, has been nominated for Best Documentary Short. If the film wins the Oscar, the award would go to director Orlando von Einsiedel and producer Joanna Natasegara. Khateeb is one of three people credited for cinematography; Franklin Dow is the film&#8217;s director of photography. The film focuses on the rescue workers who risk their lives to save Syrians affected by civil war. Many of the group&#8217;s members have been killed by Syrian President Bashar Assad&#8217;s air forces. The group also was nominated for last year&#8217;s Nobel Peace Prize. &#8220;The White Helmets&#8221; includes emblematic scenes of the deadly 6-year-old conflict: people digging through destroyed homes looking for survivors, at constant risk of &#8220;double tap&#8221; attacks that target first responders after they&#8217;ve arrived at the scene of a strike. Khateeb had been issued a visa to attend the ceremony with Hollywood&#8217;s biggest stars. But Turkish authorities detained him this week, according to the internal U.S. government correspondence, and he suddenly needed a passport waiver from the United States to enter the country. The correspondence indicated he would not receive such a waiver. There was no explanation in the correspondence for why Turkey detained Khateeb."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EKhaled Khateeb was blocked from traveling to Los Angeles for the Oscars\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":108310934,"featured_media":4682962,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[58298,430939235],"time_section":[1098],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937767],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682957"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682957\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682957\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=4682957"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=4682957"},{"taxonomy":"topic","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftopics?post=4682957"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682957\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682957\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682957\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682957\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682957\u002Fauthors"}],"fortune:newsletter":[{ Keith Ellison on the second round of voting by Democratic National Committee members gathered in Atlanta.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA nod to his margin of 35 votes out of 435 cast, to say nothing of the lingering friction between old-guard Democratic brokers and outspoken liberal upstarts, Perez tapped Ellison to serve as deputy chair.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;We are all in this together,&#8221; Perez said, calling on Democrats to fight &#8220;the worst president in the history of the United States.&#8221; He added, &#8220;I am confident when we lead with our values and we lead with our actions, we succeed.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EPerez had led on the first ballot among six candidates, but fell just short of the required majority.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EEarlier Saturday, Perez told DNC members the party was facing a &#8220;crisis of confidence&#8221; and a &#8220;crisis of relevance.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;We need a chair who cannot only take the fight to Donald Trump but make sure that we talk about our positive message of inclusion and opportunity and talk to that big tent of the Democratic Party,&#8221; Perez said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"video-container\"\u003E\u003Cvideo id=\"brightcove-player-5337704372001\" data-video-id=\"5337704372001\" data-account=\"293884104\" data-player=\"SJa0Thl7\" data-embed=\"default\" controls preload=\"auto\" class=\"video-js responsive-video\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fvideo\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBoth top candidates had promised aggressive rebuilding efforts for state and local Democratic parties.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe chair campaign was uncharted territory as Democrats face a power deficit not seen in nine decades. Republicans control the White House, Congress and about two-thirds of U.S. statehouses. The GOP is one Senate confirmation fight away from a conservative majority on the Supreme Court.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWith Democrats in agreement in their opposition to Trump, the race turned on who was able to convince enough DNC members to believe his promises of rebuilding party infrastructure that withered under President Barack Obama despite his personal electoral success.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EEllison told voting members he had signatures from 750,000 rank-and-file Democrats who support his chairmanship bid. He promised to &#8220;convert them from demonstration energy to electoral energy.&#8221; He pledged to prioritize small donations to finance the party, while working to &#8220;organize this whole country.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EPerez said he would &#8220;rebuild strong parties&#8221; and &#8220;organize, organize, organize&#8221; so Democratic nominees could win &#8220;from the school to the Senate in all the states.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EPerez got into the race at Obama&#8217;s urging, but he pushed back on the notion that represented the same &#8220;establishment&#8221; label that dogged Hillary Clinton&#8217;s presidential campaign. Ellison had endorsements from Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, who challenged Clinton for the Democratic nomination, and also from Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFor their parts, Ellison and Perez had praised each other and promised unity regardless of the outcome.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe winner succeeds outgoing Chairwoman Donna Brazile, who led the party as interim chief in the fallout from disclosure that internal party communications were stolen by hackers and leaked during the 2016 presidential campaign.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EU.S. intelligence officials have blamed Russian agents and said Moscow&#8217;s intention was to help Trump win.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBrazile said Saturday the party has worked with cybersecurity experts to address vulnerabilities. She chided Trump for his mockery of DNC cybersecurity and his doubts that Russians are at fault.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;No, Donald Trump, you can&#8217;t go to \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fstaples-132\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EStaples\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and buy anti-Russian hacking software,&#8221; she said, urging Congress to investigate whether Russians hacked the Republican National Committee.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENo RNC emails were leaked during the 2016 campaign. Republican officials insist their party communications were not breached.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBrazile suggests that proves Russians wanted to help Trump.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["(ATLANTA) — Democrats elected former Labor Secretary Tom Perez as their new national chairman on Saturday over a liberal Minnesota congressman after a divisive campaign that reflected the depths of the party's electoral failures as well as the energy from resistance to President Donald Trump."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Perez, the first Latino to hold the post, edged Rep. Republicans control the White House, Congress and about two-thirds of U.S. statehouses. The GOP is one Senate confirmation fight away from a conservative majority on the Supreme Court."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["With Democrats in agreement in their opposition to Trump, the race turned on who was able to convince enough DNC members to believe his promises of rebuilding party infrastructure that withered under President Barack Obama despite his personal electoral success."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Ellison told voting members he had signatures from 750,000 rank-and-file Democrats who support his chairmanship bid. He promised to \"convert them from demonstration energy to electoral energy.\" He pledged to prioritize small donations to finance the party, while working to \"organize this whole country.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Perez said he would \"rebuild strong parties\" and \"organize, organize, organize\" so Democratic nominees could win \"from the school to the Senate in all the states.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Perez got into the race at Obama's urging, but he pushed back on the notion that represented the same \"establishment\" label that dogged Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign. Ellison had endorsements from Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, who challenged Clinton for the Democratic nomination, and also from Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["For their parts, Ellison and Perez had praised each other and promised unity regardless of the outcome."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The winner succeeds outgoing Chairwoman Donna Brazile, who led the party as interim chief in the fallout from disclosure that internal party communications were stolen by hackers and leaked during the 2016 presidential campaign."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["U.S. intelligence officials have blamed Russian agents and said Moscow's intention was to help Trump win."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Brazile said Saturday the party has worked with cybersecurity experts to address vulnerabilities. She chided Trump for his mockery of DNC cybersecurity and his doubts that Russians are at fault."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"No, Donald Trump, you can't go to ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fstaples-132\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Staples"]}," and buy anti-Russian hacking software,\" she said, urging Congress to investigate whether Russians hacked the Republican National Committee."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["No RNC emails were leaked during the 2016 campaign. Republican officials insist their party communications were not breached."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Brazile suggests that proves Russians wanted to help Trump."]}],"plain":"(ATLANTA) &mdash; Democrats elected former Labor Secretary Tom Perez as their new national chairman on Saturday over a liberal Minnesota congressman after a divisive campaign that reflected the depths of the party&#8217;s electoral failures as well as the energy from resistance to President Donald Trump. Perez, the first Latino to hold the post, edged Rep. Keith Ellison on the second round of voting by Democratic National Committee members gathered in Atlanta. A nod to his margin of 35 votes out of 435 cast, to say nothing of the lingering friction between old-guard Democratic brokers and outspoken liberal upstarts, Perez tapped Ellison to serve as deputy chair. &#8220;We are all in this together,&#8221; Perez said, calling on Democrats to fight &#8220;the worst president in the history of the United States.&#8221; He added, &#8220;I am confident when we lead with our values and we lead with our actions, we succeed.&#8221; Perez had led on the first ballot among six candidates, but fell just short of the required majority. Earlier Saturday, Perez told DNC members the party was facing a &#8220;crisis of confidence&#8221; and a &#8220;crisis of relevance.&#8221; &#8220;We need a chair who cannot only take the fight to Donald Trump but make sure that we talk about our positive message of inclusion and opportunity and talk to that big tent of the Democratic Party,&#8221; Perez said. Both top candidates had promised aggressive rebuilding efforts for state and local Democratic parties. The chair campaign was uncharted territory as Democrats face a power deficit not seen in nine decades. Republicans control the White House, Congress and about two-thirds of U.S. statehouses. The GOP is one Senate confirmation fight away from a conservative majority on the Supreme Court. With Democrats in agreement in their opposition to Trump, the race turned on who was able to convince enough DNC members to believe his promises of rebuilding party infrastructure that withered under President Barack Obama despite his personal electoral success. Ellison told voting members he had signatures from 750,000 rank-and-file Democrats who support his chairmanship bid. He promised to &#8220;convert them from demonstration energy to electoral energy.&#8221; He pledged to prioritize small donations to finance the party, while working to &#8220;organize this whole country.&#8221; Perez said he would &#8220;rebuild strong parties&#8221; and &#8220;organize, organize, organize&#8221; so Democratic nominees could win &#8220;from the school to the Senate in all the states.&#8221; Perez got into the race at Obama&#8217;s urging, but he pushed back on the notion that represented the same &#8220;establishment&#8221; label that dogged Hillary Clinton&#8217;s presidential campaign. Ellison had endorsements from Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, who challenged Clinton for the Democratic nomination, and also from Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer. For their parts, Ellison and Perez had praised each other and promised unity regardless of the outcome. The winner succeeds outgoing Chairwoman Donna Brazile, who led the party as interim chief in the fallout from disclosure that internal party communications were stolen by hackers and leaked during the 2016 presidential campaign. U.S. intelligence officials have blamed Russian agents and said Moscow&#8217;s intention was to help Trump win. Brazile said Saturday the party has worked with cybersecurity experts to address vulnerabilities. She chided Trump for his mockery of DNC cybersecurity and his doubts that Russians are at fault. &#8220;No, Donald Trump, you can&#8217;t go to Staples and buy anti-Russian hacking software,&#8221; she said, urging Congress to investigate whether Russians hacked the Republican National Committee. No RNC emails were leaked during the 2016 campaign. Republican officials insist their party communications were not breached. Brazile suggests that proves Russians wanted to help Trump."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EPerez is the first Latino to hold the going to have to work harder and harder not to let hate win,&#8221; according to the Hollywood Reporter. &#8220;Love Trumps hate, courage Trumps fear and always rights Trump&#8217;s wrongs,&#8221; the Swedish journalist Anders Rydell documents the regime&#8217;s pillaging, and follows new efforts to return the volumes to their rightful owners in his nonfiction work The Book Thieves, out this month in the U.S. Books of course weren&#8217;t the only items Nazis stole. Hitler&#8217;s regime looted art, tchotchkes, furniture, anything of value &mdash; and the stories behind their pillaging have served as source material for a number of nonfiction books, blending the intrigue of mystery with the gravity of restoring justice. Here are 6 fascinating books about the things Nazis stole."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EFrom \u003Cem\u003EThe Book Thieves\u003C\u002Fem\u003E to \u003Cem\u003EThe Lady in I wouldn&#8217;t do it with the United States and I&#8217;m urging the U.S. president not to do it with France.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;I won&#8217;t make comparisons but here, people don&#8217;t have access to guns,&#8221; the French president added. &#8220;Here, you don&#8217;t have people with guns opening fire on the crowd simply for the satisfaction of causing drama and tragedy.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETrump&#8217;s initial remarks came during a \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4681802\u002Fdonald-trump-cpac-speech-media\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Espeech at the Conservative Political Action Conference\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. The president criticized Europe's handling of ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4314129\u002Fparis-attacks-journalism-in-europe\u002F"},"content":["recent Islamist terrorist attacks"]},", saying his friend \"Jim\" no longer wants to take his family to the French capital."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Paris mayor ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002FAnne_Hidalgo\u002Fstatus\u002F835175467271475200?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw"},"content":["Anne Hidalgo"]}," and French Foreign Minister ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Fjeanmarcayrault\u002Fstatus\u002F835194591670333440?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw"},"content":["Jean-Marc Ayrault"]}," additionally responded to Trump's comments via Twitter on Friday."]}],"plain":"French President Francois Hollande took issue with Donald Trump&#8217;s Friday comments about Paris, in which the American President claimed he had a friend who felt &#8220;Paris is no longer Paris&#8221; in the wake of recent terrorist attacks. Hollande called for Trump to support U.S. allies. &#8220;There is terrorism and we must fight it together,&#8221; Hollande said on Saturday during a visit at the Paris Agric fair, according to Reuters. &#8220;I think that it is never good to show the smallest defiance toward an allied country. I wouldn&#8217;t do it with the United States and I&#8217;m urging the U.S. president not to do it with France. &#8220;I won&#8217;t make comparisons but here, people don&#8217;t have access to guns,&#8221; the French president added. &#8220;Here, you don&#8217;t have people with guns opening fire on the crowd simply for the satisfaction of causing drama and tragedy.&#8221; Trump&#8217;s initial remarks came during a speech at the Conservative Political Action Conference. The president criticized Europe&#8217;s handling of recent Islamist terrorist attacks, saying his friend &#8220;Jim&#8221; no longer wants to take his family to the French capital. Paris mayor Anne Hidalgo and French Foreign Minister Jean-Marc Ayrault additionally responded to Trump&#8217;s comments via Twitter on Friday."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;There is terrorism and we must fight it In a statement on their Telegram channel, the group said five attackers stormed the two different security offices. The group said bombs were also detonated at checkpoints outside the buildings just as rescuers were arriving, leading to more casualties.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe governor of Homs Province, Talal Barzani, told The Associated Press there were three blasts in total, killing more than 32 people. He said the attackers were wearing suicide belts, which they detonated in the security offices. The two agencies are two kilometers (1.2 miles) apart.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESyrian State News Agency SANA said Maj. Gen Hassan Daeboul, head of the local Military Intelligence branch, was killed by one of the suicide bombers.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAccording to state TV and state-affiliated al-Ikhbariya TV, Brigadier Ibrahim Darwish, head of the State Security Branch, was also critically wounded in the attacks.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAccording to Ikhbariya, at least six assailants attacked the two security compounds in Homs&#8217; al-Ghouta and al-Mahata neighborhoods, clashing with security officers before at least two of them detonated explosive vests, killing 32 people. It was not clear if there are any civilians among the casualties.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe Britain-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights monitoring group said at least 42 security officers were killed in the attacks on the offices of the State Security and the Military Intelligence services.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe differing casualty estimates could not be immediately reconciled. Such discrepancies are not uncommon in the immediate aftermath of violence in Syria.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHoms is Syria&#8217;s third-largest city and largely in the control of the government.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe attacks are among the most spectacular perpetrated against security agencies in the six-year old conflict &mdash; a coordinated operation against two heavily secured government buildings using a combination of armed assault and suicide bombing. In early days of the conflict, bombings targeting state security institutions were frequent, usually against military intelligence branches in Damascus and other cities. One of the most dramatic attacks came in July 2012, when insurgents detonated explosives inside a high-level crisis meeting in Damascus, killing four top regime officials, including the brother-in-law of President Bashar Assad and the then-defense minister.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe Syrian security forces run a vast intelligence network that enjoys great powers and operates independently of the military and with little judicial oversight. Rights groups and Syria monitors hold the various branches responsible for some of the more shadowy crimes committed during the conflict, including mass arrests, torture, extrajudicial killings and firing on protesters.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn a February report, the human rights watchdog Amnesty International reported that between 5,000 and 13,000 people were killed in mass hangings in the military&#8217;s Saydnaya prison in Damascus between 2011 and 2015. It said the detainees were sent to the prison from around the country by the state&#8217;s four main security branches, including the Military Intelligence.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E___\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAssociated Press writers Albert Aji in Damascus, Syria and Sarah El Deeb in Beirut contributed to this report.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["(BEIRUT) — Twin attacks on two Syrian security offices in the central city of Homs Saturday killed at least 32 people, including a senior security official who heads the feared Military Intelligence services, state media and officials reported."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["An al-Qaida-linked insurgent coalition known as the Levant Liberation Committee claimed responsibility for the attacks, which also left another high-ranking officer seriously wounded. In a statement on their Telegram channel, the group said five attackers stormed the two different security offices. The group said bombs were also detonated at checkpoints outside the buildings just as rescuers were arriving, leading to more casualties."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The governor of Homs Province, Talal Barzani, told The Associated Press there were three blasts in total, killing more than 32 people. He said the attackers were wearing suicide belts, which they detonated in the security offices. The two agencies are two kilometers (1.2 miles) apart."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Syrian State News Agency SANA said Maj. Gen Hassan Daeboul, head of the local Military Intelligence branch, was killed by one of the suicide bombers."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["According to state TV and state-affiliated al-Ikhbariya TV, Brigadier Ibrahim Darwish, head of the State Security Branch, was also critically wounded in the attacks."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["According to Ikhbariya, at least six assailants attacked the two security compounds in Homs' al-Ghouta and al-Mahata neighborhoods, clashing with security officers before at least two of them detonated explosive vests, killing 32 people. It was not clear if there are any civilians among the casualties."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The Britain-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights monitoring group said at least 42 security officers were killed in the attacks on the offices of the State Security and the Military Intelligence services."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The differing casualty estimates could not be immediately reconciled. Such discrepancies are not uncommon in the immediate aftermath of violence in Syria."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Homs is Syria's third-largest city and largely in the control of the government."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The attacks are among the most spectacular perpetrated against security agencies in the six-year old conflict — a coordinated operation against two heavily secured government buildings using a combination of armed assault and suicide bombing. In early days of the conflict, bombings targeting state security institutions were frequent, usually against military intelligence branches in Damascus and other cities. One of the most dramatic attacks came in July 2012, when insurgents detonated explosives inside a high-level crisis meeting in Damascus, killing four top regime officials, including the brother-in-law of President Bashar Assad and the then-defense minister."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The Syrian security forces run a vast intelligence network that enjoys great powers and operates independently of the military and with little judicial oversight. Rights groups and Syria monitors hold the various branches responsible for some of the more shadowy crimes committed during the conflict, including mass arrests, torture, extrajudicial killings and firing on protesters."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In a February report, the human rights watchdog Amnesty International reported that between 5,000 and 13,000 people were killed in mass hangings in the military's Saydnaya prison in Damascus between 2011 and 2015. It said the detainees were sent to the prison from around the country by the state's four main security branches, including the Military Intelligence."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["___"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Associated Press writers Albert Aji in Damascus, Syria and Sarah El Deeb in Beirut contributed to this report."]}],"plain":"(BEIRUT) &mdash; Twin attacks on two Syrian security offices in the central city of Homs Saturday killed at least 32 people, including a senior security official who heads the feared Military Intelligence services, state media and officials reported. An al-Qaida-linked insurgent coalition known as the Levant Liberation Committee claimed responsibility for the attacks, which also left another high-ranking officer seriously wounded. In a statement on their Telegram channel, the group said five attackers stormed the two different security offices. The group said bombs were also detonated at checkpoints outside the buildings just as rescuers were arriving, leading to more casualties. The governor of Homs Province, Talal Barzani, told The Associated Press there were three blasts in total, killing more than 32 people. He said the attackers were wearing suicide belts, which they detonated in the security offices. The two agencies are two kilometers (1.2 miles) apart. Syrian State News Agency SANA said Maj. Gen Hassan Daeboul, head of the local Military Intelligence branch, was killed by one of the suicide bombers. According to state TV and state-affiliated al-Ikhbariya TV, Brigadier Ibrahim Darwish, head of the State Security Branch, was also critically wounded in the attacks. According to Ikhbariya, at least six assailants attacked the two security compounds in Homs&#8217; al-Ghouta and al-Mahata neighborhoods, clashing with security officers before at least two of them detonated explosive vests, killing 32 people. It was not clear if there are any civilians among the casualties. The Britain-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights monitoring group said at least 42 security officers were killed in the attacks on the offices of the State Security and the Military Intelligence services. The differing casualty estimates could not be immediately reconciled. Such discrepancies are not uncommon in the immediate aftermath of violence in Syria. Homs is Syria&#8217;s third-largest city and largely in the control of the government. The attacks are among the most spectacular perpetrated against security agencies in the six-year old conflict &mdash; a coordinated operation against two heavily secured government buildings using a combination of armed assault and suicide bombing. In early days of the conflict, bombings targeting state security institutions were frequent, usually against military intelligence branches in Damascus and other cities. One of the most dramatic attacks came in July 2012, when insurgents detonated explosives inside a high-level crisis meeting in Damascus, killing four top regime officials, including the brother-in-law of President Bashar Assad and the then-defense minister. The Syrian security forces run a vast intelligence network that enjoys great powers and operates independently of the military and with little judicial oversight. Rights groups and Syria monitors hold the various branches responsible for some of the more shadowy crimes committed during the conflict, including mass arrests, torture, extrajudicial killings and firing on protesters. In a February report, the human rights watchdog Amnesty International reported that between 5,000 and 13,000 people were killed in mass hangings in the military&#8217;s Saydnaya prison in Damascus between 2011 and 2015. It said the detainees were sent to the prison from around the country by the state&#8217;s four main security branches, including the Military Intelligence. ___ Associated Press writers Albert Aji in Damascus, Syria and Sarah El Deeb in Beirut contributed to this report."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EAn al-Qaida-linked insurgent coalition known as the Levant Liberation Committee claimed responsibility for the attacks\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":108310934,"featured_media":4682920,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[430939235,18052],"time_section":[204777757],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937774],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682919"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682919\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682919\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=4682919"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=4682919"},{"taxonomy":"topic","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftopics?post=4682919"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682919\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682919\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682919\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682919\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682919\u002Fauthors"}],"fortune:newslett _article?categories=1"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[{"id":430939235,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Ftag\u002Fonetime\u002F","name":"onetime","slug":"onetime","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags\u002F430939235"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fpost_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?tags=430939235"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=430939235"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":18052,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Ftag\u002Fsyria\u002F","name":"Syria","slug":"syria","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags\u002F18052"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fpost_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?tags=18052"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=18052"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}}],{"code":"rest_no_route","message":"No ","credit":"Hassan Ammar—AP","title":"A Syrian man carries a carpet through a devastated part of the town of Palmyra as families load their belongings onto buses in the central Homs province in Syria, April 14, 2016."},"video":[],"structured":false}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":18052,"name":"Syria","slug":"syria","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":721,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":935,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":204777757,"name":"World","slug":"world","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":18,"taxonomy":"time_section","description":"The latest news and analysis from TIME's correspondents on world politics, diplomacy, conflict, culture, humanitarian disasters, religion and much more","parent":0,"count":13738,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["world"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4682886,"date":"2017-02-25T05:37:20","date_gmt":"2017-02-25T10:37:20","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4682886"},"modified":"2017-02-25T05:37:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-25T10:37:00","slug":"leila-de-lima-manila-philippines-duterte","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4682886\u002Fleila-de-lima-manila-philippines-duterte\u002F","title":{"rendered":"Exclusive: Inside the Cell of Leila de Lima, Duterte's 'First Political Prisoner'"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EThe headquarters of the Philippine National Police, known as Camp Crame, sits like a fortress in the middle of Quezon City, the busiest and most populous of the 16 municipalities comprising Metro Manila. Tall walls along its two-mile perimeter separate it from the clamor and chaos of the cell phone shops and passing trucks outside; so quiet is it inside the detention center deep within the complex that its prisoners can, if nothing else, get a good night&#8217;s sleep.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESenator \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4603123\u002Fleila-de-lima-philippines-opposition-duterte-drug-war\u002F\"\u003ELeila de Lima\u003C\u002Fa\u003E is indeed well-rested. &#8220;I prepared myself for this psychologically,&rdquo; she says on Saturday morning, sitting in the small concrete courtyard outside her cell. Just over 24 hours have passed since she \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4681484\u002Fleila-de-lima-arrested-rodrigo-duterte-philippines\u002F\"\u003Ewas arrested\u003C\u002Fa\u003E outside the Philippine Senate on three charges of drug trafficking &mdash; charges that she dismisses as attempt to silence her vocal crusade against President Rodrigo Duterte&#8217;s \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fphilippines-rodrigo-duterte-drug-war-local-photographers\u002F\"\u003Ewar on drugs\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. Since taking office last June, 57-year-old de Lima, who previously served as the Philippines Secretary of Justice, has been the brash President&#8217;s most prominent opponent, attempting to use her position of power to fight the campaign of extrajudicial killings that has \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4436655\u002Frodrigo-duterte-philippines-drug-newspaper\u002F\"\u003Eclaimed the lives of thousands\u003C\u002Fa\u003E of alleged drug users and pushers.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENow, she says, she is his first political prisoner.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;It&#8217;s an attempt to intimidate his critics &mdash; to bring about a chilling effect,&#8221; she says. She wears a yellow T-shirt, jeans, and sandals; her expression is uncharacteristically stony. She is one of 26 individuals being held at Camp Crame&#8217;s custodial center &mdash; some of whom she investigated during her tenure as Secretary of Justice, an irony she appreciates &mdash; and the only woman. She is ineligible for bail.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ERead More:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Cem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fphilippines-rodrigo-duterte-drug-war-local-photographers\u002F\"\u003E12 Photographers in the Philippines Reveal the Drug War Images That Moved Them Most\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDe Lima was anticipating this. She launched her campaign against Duterte within two weeks of taking office, when she introduced a Senate resolution calling for an investigation into the emerging spate of extrajudicial killings that had been Duterte&rsquo;s foremost campaign promise. (The death toll today stands at more than 7,000, according to a running tab by \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.rappler.com\u002Fnewsbreak\u002Fiq\u002F145814-numbers-statistics-philippines-war-drugs\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ERappler\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, a Philippine news website.)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe 71-year-old President had made his political name as the foul-mouthed mayor of the southern city of Davao, where he had spearheaded an unorthodox anti-crime campaign that left an untold number dead. (A 2010 U.N. special report, which landed on de Lima&rsquo;s desk when she was Secretary of Justice, described Duterte as an &ldquo;authoritarian populist&rdquo; who &#8220;insisted that he controls the army and the police.&rdquo;)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDuterte swiftly fought back. In August, he publicly claimed that while she was Secretary of Justice, de Lima had willfully turned a blind eye to the rampant drug trade at Metro Manila&rsquo;s New Bilibid Prison in exchange for kickbacks, which went toward her senatorial campaign. Duterte also alleged that her accomplice in this scheme was her longtime bodyguard and driver, Ronnie Dayan, who was also her lover; the President said that he had seen a sex tape of the two of them that made him &ldquo;lose his appetite.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"video-container\"\u003E\u003Cvideo id=\"brightcove-player-5237577082001\" data-video-id=\"5237577082001\" data-account=\"293884104\" data-player=\"SJa0Thl7\" data-embed=\"default\" autoplay controls preload=\"auto\" class=\"video-js responsive-video\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fvideo\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&ldquo;De Lima is not only screwing her driver; she is also screwing the nation,&rdquo; Duterte said in public remarks in September.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn a conversation with TIME in December, de Lima admitted to a romantic relationship with Dayan, but firmly denied allegations of legal wrongdoing. She was formally charged in October; plans to arrest her began to \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4670074\u002Fleila-de-lima-war-on-drugs-philippines-rodrigo-duterte\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Egalvanize\u003C\u002Fa\u003E last week. A local court formally issued a warrant for her arrest on Thursday afternoon.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&ldquo;She knew that if she kept criticizing the Duterte administration, she would eventually go to jail,&rdquo; Donnah Camitan, de Lima&#8217;s lawyer, told TIME on Saturday. &#8220;She was prepared for this, and she did not want to stop speaking out, because the killings were not stopping.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ERead More:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E T\u003Cem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4603123\u002Fleila-de-lima-philippines-opposition-duterte-drug-war\u002F\"\u003Ehe Fighter: How Leila de Lima Ended Up Leading the Opposition to Rodrigo Duterte&#8217;s Drug War\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFearing the worst, de Lima traveled from the Senate to her home on Thursday evening to spend time with her family, expecting to have the night at home to prepare for her detention. But shortly after arriving at her house, members of her staff called her to inform her that the arresting officers were en route to take her in. She hastily returned to the Senate, where security officials negotiated with officers to wait until the morning to arrest her.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EShe spent Thursday night in her office, meeting with her staff and well-wishers. She says she slept less than three hours and woke up at dawn, and at around 8 a.m., before a sea of television cameras and reporters, she went outside the Senate offices and surrendered herself to authorities. It was so surreal &mdash; being fingerprinted, having my mugshot taken,&rdquo; she says.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe news of her arrest went viral quickly; by midday Friday, overseas Filipinos in places like Hong Kong were already talking about it. De Lima&#8217;s photograph was splashed across the front pages of newspapers across the Philippines on Saturday morning.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDe Lima is unsure what will come next. Her legal team is challenging the legality of her arrest, claiming it was wrongfully ordered by a regional trial court and not filed before an ombudsman &mdash; a necessary measure, they say, in the detention of a public official. (&ldquo;Hope springs eternal,&#8221; her spokesperson, Ferdie Maglalang, said when asked about the likelihood of success.)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ERead more: \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4462352\u002Frodrigo-duterte-drug-war-drugs-philippines-killing\u002F\"\u003EThe Killing Time: Inside Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte&rsquo;s War on Drugs\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn the meantime, she sits in her enclosed facility, receiving a limited number of guests, several of whom have brought baked goods and cans of soft drinks. Philippines Vice-President Leni Robredo visited on Friday night (Robredo, who under the Philippine election system was elected independently of Duterte, is a stanch opponent of the drug war); former and current public officials, including chairs of the Philippines Commission on Human Rights, stopped by on Saturday morning.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;They&rsquo;re trying to say she&rsquo;s not a political prisoner, but what else is this but political harassment?&#8221; Etta Rosales, who chaired the Commission from 2010 until 2015, said to TIME outside of the detention facility on Saturday. &ldquo;There is a global regression of rights, and Duterte is part of that, and Senator de Lima is hopeful that her arrest will bring attention to it.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe timing of her arrest, de Lima says, is no coincidence. Earlier this week, a retired Davao police officer named Arthur Lasca&ntilde;as \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.rappler.com\u002Fnation\u002F162057-arthur-lascanas-profile-davao-duterte\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Etestified\u003C\u002Fa\u003E that during his mayorship, Duterte personally paid members of the so-called Davao Death Squad, as the cabal of vigilante killers there was known, between $400 and $2,000 for each alleged drug user they killed. This testimony, de Lima says, is an unprecedented inculpation of Duterte as an offender of human rights; she believes she was arrested to distract from the news, and to discourage others from pursuing the matter.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFor all his braggadocio, Duterte in September \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.philstar.com\u002Fheadlines\u002F2016\u002F09\u002F23\u002F1626561\u002Fduterte-denies-involvement-davao-death-squad\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Edenied\u003C\u002Fa\u003E direct involvement in the killings.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-custom-size aligncenter \"\u003E\u003Cimg slogans as they hold a rally outside the court building in Muntinlupa City, suburban Manila on February 24, 2017, where De Lima was brought by the police to report to the court of her arrest. \\nThe highest-profile critic of Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte's brutal drug war was arrested February 24 on charges supporters said were meant to silence her, but she vowed to keep campaigning against killings and \\\"repression\\\". \\\u002F AFP \\\u002F TED ALJIBE        (Photo credit should read TED ALJIBE\\\u002FAFP\\\u002FGetty data-image-title=\"PHILIPPINES-RIGHTS-CRIME-DUTERTE-DELIMA\" data-image-description=\"\u003Cp\u003EA supporter of Senator Leila De Lima shouts slogans as they hold a rally outside the court building data-medium-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fgettyimages-644711202.jpg?quality=85&w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fgettyimages-644711202.jpg?quality=85&w=600\" class=\" wp-image-4682910\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fgettyimages-644711202.jpg?w=300&quality=85&w=459\" alt=\"PHILIPPINES-RIGHTS-CRIME-DUTERTE-DELIMA\" width=\"459\" height=\"306\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\" style=\"max-width:459px\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\" \u003ETED ALJIBE&mdash;AFP\u002FGetty Images \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"caption\" \u003EA supporter of Senator Leila De Lima shouts slogans as they hold a rally outside the court building in Muntinlupa City, suburban Manila on Feb. 24, 2017.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;By arresting Senator Leila de Lima on politically motivated drug charges, President Duterte has effectively expanded his &lsquo;drug war&#8217; from the urban poor to the legislative branch of the government,&#8221; Phelim Kine, Deputy Asia Director of Human Rights Watch, said to TIME in a statement. &ldquo;Not only Congress, but other pillars of Philippine democracy, from the press to the judiciary, should be worried about the future. The arrest suggests that Duterte is willing to debase Philippine governance to the level of personal vendetta.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EUltimately, though, one wonders the extent to which the average Filipino cares, if they care at all. Duterte has been intensely popular since he was elected, clocking an approval rating of 83% when it was tallied in January. If the comparison between Donald Trump in the U.S. and Duterte in the Philippines is tired, it is because it has mileage: to many voters outside the educated urban elite, both men offer a muscular candor that stands in refreshing contrast to years of a stultified establishment.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ERead More:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Cem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4436655\u002Frodrigo-duterte-philippines-drug-newspaper\u002F\"\u003EThis Photo Has Given the War on Drugs in the Philippines a Human Face\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&ldquo;I believe in him &mdash; we believe he&rsquo;s really concerned with the Filipino people,&rdquo; says 50-year-old Isabelle Santiago, one of the hundreds of red-shirted Filipinos who assembled under stormy skies at the historical Rizal Park along Manila Bay for a festive pro-Duterte rally on Saturday afternoon. &ldquo;You all [in the foreign press] don&rsquo;t like him because of the way he talks &mdash; the words that come from his mouth. But for us as Filipinos, it is very natural. It is very true.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESaturday, as it happened, was the 31st anniversary of the culmination of the People Power Revolution, the uprising that brought to a close more than two decades of autocratic martial law under President Ferdinand Marcos. A smaller gathering was held to commemorate it at the People Power Monument along Epifanio de los Santos Avenue, half a mile down the road from the facility where de Lima is being held.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&ldquo;It&rsquo;s all precarious,&rdquo; says Maria Aleta Tolentino, an attorney who helped organize the event. &ldquo;We saw this in the years under Marcos. We&rsquo;re being made to believe that the entire Philippines is in trouble. In the guise of cleaning of society, these totalitarian presidents would like to instill fear and violate human rights. Back then, the enemy was the Communists; this time it&rsquo;s the drug addicts. It&rsquo;s the same thing.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The headquarters of the Philippine National Police, known as Camp Crame, sits like a fortress in the middle of Quezon City, the busiest and most populous of the 16 municipalities comprising Metro Manila. (“Hope springs eternal,\" her spokesperson, Ferdie Maglalang, said when asked about the likelihood of success.)"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["Read more: "]},{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4462352\u002Frodrigo-duterte-drug-war-drugs-philippines-killing\u002F"},"content":["The Killing Time: Inside Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte’s War on Drugs"]}]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In the meantime, she sits in her enclosed facility, receiving a limited number of guests, several of whom have brought baked goods and cans of soft drinks. Philippines Vice-President Leni Robredo visited on Friday night (Robredo, who under the Philippine election system was elected independently of Duterte, is a stanch opponent of the drug war); former and current public officials, including chairs of the Philippines Commission on Human Rights, stopped by on Saturday morning."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"They’re trying to say she’s not a political prisoner, but what else is this but political harassment?\" Etta Rosales, who chaired the Commission from 2010 until 2015, said to TIME outside of the detention facility on Saturday. “There is a global regression of rights, and Duterte is part of that, and Senator de Lima is hopeful that her arrest will bring attention to it.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The timing of her arrest, de Lima says, is no coincidence. Earlier this week, a retired Davao police officer named Arthur Lascañas ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.rappler.com\u002Fnation\u002F162057-arthur-lascanas-profile-davao-duterte","target":"_blank"},"content":["testified"]}," that during his mayorship, Duterte personally paid members of the so-called Davao Death Squad, as the cabal of vigilante killers there was known, between $400 and $2,000 for each alleged drug user they killed. This testimony, de Lima says, is an unprecedented inculpation of Duterte as an offender of human rights; she believes she was arrested to distract from the news, and to discourage others from pursuing the matter."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["For all his braggadocio, Duterte in September ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.philstar.com\u002Fheadlines\u002F2016\u002F09\u002F23\u002F1626561\u002Fduterte-denies-involvement-davao-death-squad","target":"_blank"},"content":["denied"]}," direct involvement in the killings."]},{"tag":"caption","attributes":{"id":"attachment_4682910","align":"aligncenter","width":"459"},"content":[{"tag":"img","attributes":{"src":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fgettyimages-644711202.jpg?w=300","alt":"PHILIPPINES-RIGHTS-CRIME-DUTERTE-DELIMA","width":"459","height":"306"},"content":[]},{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"figcaption","attributes":[],"content":["A supporter of Senator Leila De Lima shouts slogans as they hold a rally outside the court building in Muntinlupa City, suburban Manila on Feb. 24, 2017."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"figcredit","attributes":[],"content":["TED ALJIBE—AFP\u002FGetty Images "]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"By arresting Senator Leila de Lima on politically motivated drug charges, President Duterte has effectively expanded his ‘drug war' from the urban poor to the legislative branch of the government,\" Phelim Kine, Deputy Asia Director of Human Rights Watch, said to TIME in a statement. “Not only Congress, but other pillars of Philippine democracy, from the press to the judiciary, should be worried about the future. The arrest suggests that Duterte is willing to debase Philippine governance to the level of personal vendetta.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Ultimately, though, one wonders the extent to which the average Filipino cares, if they care at all. Duterte has been intensely popular since he was elected, clocking an approval rating of 83% when it was tallied in January. If the comparison between Donald Trump in the U.S. and Duterte in the Philippines is tired, it is because it has mileage: to many voters outside the educated urban elite, both men offer a muscular candor that stands in refreshing contrast to years of a stultified establishment."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["Read More:"]}," ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4436655\u002Frodrigo-duterte-philippines-drug-newspaper\u002F"},"content":["This Photo Has Given the War on Drugs in the Philippines a Human Face"]}]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["“I believe in him — we believe he’s really concerned with the Filipino people,” says 50-year-old Isabelle Santiago, one of the hundreds of red-shirted Filipinos who assembled under stormy skies at the historical Rizal Park along Manila Bay for a festive pro-Duterte rally on Saturday afternoon. “You all [in the foreign press] don’t like him because of the way he talks — the words that come from his mouth. But for us as Filipinos, it is very natural. It is very true.”"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Saturday, as it happened, was the 31st anniversary of the culmination of the People Power Revolution, the uprising that brought to a close more than two decades of autocratic martial law under President Ferdinand Marcos. A smaller gathering was held to commemorate it at the People Power Monument along Epifanio de los Santos Avenue, half a mile down the road from the facility where de Lima is being held."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["“It’s all precarious,” says Maria Aleta Tolentino, an attorney who helped organize the event. “We saw this in the years under Marcos. We’re being made to believe that the entire Philippines is in trouble. In the guise of cleaning of society, these totalitarian presidents would like to instill fear and violate human rights. Back then, the enemy was the Communists; this time it’s the drug addicts. It’s the same thing.”"]}],"plain":"The headquarters of the Philippine National Police, known as Camp Crame, sits like a fortress in the middle of Quezon City, the busiest and most populous of the 16 municipalities comprising Metro Manila. Tall walls along its two-mile perimeter separate it from the clamor and chaos of the cell phone shops and passing trucks outside; so quiet is it inside the detention center deep within the complex that its prisoners can, if nothing else, get a good night&#8217;s sleep. Senator Leila de Lima is indeed well-rested. &#8220;I prepared myself for this psychologically,&rdquo; she says on Saturday morning, sitting in the small concrete courtyard outside her cell. Just over 24 hours have passed since she was arrested outside the Philippine Senate on three charges of drug trafficking &mdash; charges that she dismisses as attempt to silence her vocal crusade against President Rodrigo Duterte&#8217;s war on drugs. Since taking office last June, 57-year-old de Lima, who previously served as the Philippines Secretary of Justice, has been the brash President&#8217;s most prominent opponent, attempting to use her position of power to fight the campaign of extrajudicial killings that has claimed the lives of thousands of alleged drug users and pushers. Now, she says, she is his first political prisoner. &#8220;It&#8217;s an attempt to intimidate his critics &mdash; to bring about a chilling effect,&#8221; she says. She wears a yellow T-shirt, jeans, and sandals; her expression is uncharacteristically stony. She is one of 26 individuals being held at Camp Crame&#8217;s custodial center &mdash; some of whom she investigated during her tenure as Secretary of Justice, an irony she appreciates &mdash; and the only woman. She is ineligible for bail. Read More: 12 Photographers in the Philippines Reveal the Drug War Images That Moved Them Most De Lima was anticipating this. She launched her campaign against Duterte within two weeks of taking office, when she introduced a Senate resolution calling for an investigation into the emerging spate of extrajudicial killings that had been Duterte&rsquo;s foremost campaign promise. (The death toll today stands at more than 7,000, according to a running tab by Rappler, a Philippine news website.) The 71-year-old President had made his political name as the foul-mouthed mayor of the southern city of Davao, where he had spearheaded an unorthodox anti-crime campaign that left an untold number dead. (A 2010 U.N. special report, which landed on de Lima&rsquo;s desk when she was Secretary of Justice, described Duterte as an &ldquo;authoritarian populist&rdquo; who &#8220;insisted that he controls the army and the police.&rdquo;) Duterte swiftly fought back. In August, he publicly claimed that while she was Secretary of Justice, de Lima had willfully turned a blind eye to the rampant drug trade at Metro Manila&rsquo;s New Bilibid Prison in exchange for kickbacks, which went toward her senatorial campaign. Duterte also alleged that her accomplice in this scheme was her longtime bodyguard and driver, Ronnie Dayan, who was also her lover; the President said that he had seen a sex tape of the two of them that made him &ldquo;lose his appetite.&rdquo; &ldquo;De Lima is not only screwing her driver; she is also screwing the nation,&rdquo; Duterte said in public remarks in September. In a conversation with TIME in December, de Lima admitted to a romantic relationship with Dayan, but firmly denied allegations of legal wrongdoing. She was formally charged in October; plans to arrest her began to galvanize last week. A local court formally issued a warrant for her arrest on Thursday afternoon. &ldquo;She knew that if she kept criticizing the Duterte administration, she would eventually go to jail,&rdquo; Donnah Camitan, de Lima&#8217;s lawyer, told TIME on Saturday. &#8220;She was prepared for this, and she did not want to stop speaking out, because the killings were not stopping.&rdquo; Read More: The Fighter: How Leila de Lima Ended Up Leading the Opposition to Rodrigo Duterte&#8217;s Drug War Fearing the worst, de Lima traveled from the Senate to her home on Thursday evening to spend time with her family, expecting to have the night at home to prepare for her detention. But shortly after arriving at her house, members of her staff called her to inform her that the arresting officers were en route to take her in. She hastily returned to the Senate, where security officials negotiated with officers to wait until the morning to arrest her. She spent Thursday night in her office, meeting with her staff and well-wishers. She says she slept less than three hours and woke up at dawn, and at around 8 a.m., before a sea of television cameras and reporters, she went outside the Senate offices and surrendered herself to authorities. It was so surreal &mdash; being fingerprinted, having my mugshot taken,&rdquo; she says. The news of her arrest went viral quickly; by midday Friday, overseas Filipinos in places like Hong Kong were already talking about it. De Lima&#8217;s photograph was splashed across the front pages of newspapers across the Philippines on Saturday morning. De Lima is unsure what will come next. Her legal team is challenging the legality of her arrest, claiming it was wrongfully ordered by a regional trial court and not filed before an ombudsman &mdash; a necessary measure, they say, in the detention of a public official. (&ldquo;Hope springs eternal,&#8221; her spokesperson, Ferdie Maglalang, said when asked about the likelihood of success.) Read more: The Killing Time: Inside Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte&rsquo;s War on Drugs In the meantime, she sits in her enclosed facility, receiving a limited number of guests, several of whom have brought baked goods and cans of soft drinks. Philippines Vice-President Leni Robredo visited on Friday night (Robredo, who under the Philippine election system was elected independently of Duterte, is a stanch opponent of the drug war); former and current public officials, including chairs of the Philippines Commission on Human Rights, stopped by on Saturday morning. &#8220;They&rsquo;re trying to say she&rsquo;s not a political prisoner, but what else is this but political harassment?&#8221; Etta Rosales, who chaired the Commission from 2010 until 2015, said to TIME outside of the detention facility on Saturday. &ldquo;There is a global regression of rights, and Duterte is part of that, and Senator de Lima is hopeful that her arrest will bring attention to it.&#8221; The timing of her arrest, de Lima says, is no coincidence. Earlier this week, a retired Davao police officer named Arthur Lasca&ntilde;as testified that during his mayorship, Duterte personally paid members of the so-called Davao Death Squad, as the cabal of vigilante killers there was known, between $400 and $2,000 for each alleged drug user they killed. This testimony, de Lima says, is an unprecedented inculpation of Duterte as an offender of human rights; she believes she was arrested to distract from the news, and to discourage others from pursuing the matter. For all his braggadocio, Duterte in September denied direct involvement in the killings."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EThe Philippine senator has led the fight against Rodrigo Duterte&#8217;s war on drugs. She was arrested on Friday on charges of drug trafficking. TIME gained access to the Manila detention center where she is being held\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":91731554,"featured_media":4682912,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[430952442,430953145,430953144,430940287,430935681,430940692,4255,430940288,429942529],"time_section":[204777757],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937774],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682886"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682886\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682886\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=4682886"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=4682886"},{"taxonomy":"topic","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftopics?post=4682886"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682886\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682886\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682886\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682886\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\ more","parent":0,"count":13738,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["world"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4682791,"date":"2017-02-24T19:20:46","date_gmt":"2017-02-25T00:20:46","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4682791"},"modified":"2017-02-25T14:11:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-25T19:11:00","slug":"fbi-russia-reince-priebus-andrew-mccabe-justice-rules","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4682791\u002Ffbi-russia-reince-priebus-andrew-mccabe-justice-rules\u002F","title":{"rendered":"The FBI Talked to the White House About Its Russia Probe. That Was Probably Against the Rules"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EFBI Director James Comey and Deputy Director Andrew McCabe may have violated multiple existing Justice Department rules controlling contacts between the bureau and White House officials \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4681516\u002Freince-priebus-fbi-trump-media-russia\u002F\"\u003Ewhen they spoke earlier\u003C\u002Fa\u003E this month with White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus about their \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4672853\u002Ftrump-russia-investigation-puting-congress-flynn\u002F\"\u003Eongoing investigation\u003C\u002Fa\u003E into Russia&rsquo;s influence operation against the 2016 U.S. presidential election, according to several former senior Justice Department officials.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe first questionable contact came when McCabe spoke with Priebus for five minutes after a 7:30 a.m. meeting at the White House on Feb. 15 on an unrelated intelligence issue. The day before, the New York \u003Cem\u003ETimes\u003C\u002Fem\u003E had \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002F14\u002Fus\u002Fpolitics\u002Frussia-intelligence-communications-trump.html?_r=0\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Ereported\u003C\u002Fa\u003E that Trump&rsquo;s campaign and other Trump associates had multiple contacts with known agents of Russian intelligence in the year before the election.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAt the White House meeting, McCabe told Priebus, &lsquo;I want you to know story in \u003Cem\u003ENYT\u003C\u002Fem\u003E is BS,&#8221; according to senior Administration officials who briefed reporters on Feb. 24.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EPriebus asked McCabe what could be done to push back, saying the White House was &ldquo;getting crushed&rdquo; on the story. McCabe demurred, and then later called back to say, &ldquo;We&#8217;d love to help but we can&#8217;t get into the position of making statements on every story.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFBI Director James Comey later called Priebus himself and repeated McCabe&rsquo;s statements about the New York \u003Cem\u003ETimes\u003C\u002Fem\u003E story. Comey also said he was unwilling to speak publicly about the piece but agreed to let Priebus cite senior intelligence officials in his pushback, the officials said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe back-and-forth may have broken internal rules in place for decades, according to former officials.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAfter President Nixon&#8217;s scandals in the early 1970s, the Carter Administration imposed rules designed to prevent the FBI from meddling in politics, and to keep politicians from meddling in criminal investigations. In Bill Clinton&rsquo;s first term, Attorney General Janet Reno limited contacts between the White House and law enforcement regarding criminal investigations to the top three officials at the Justice Department on the one hand and the President, Vice President and the top two White House lawyers on the other. George W. Bush loosened those limits after 9\u002F11, but after a series of scandals, his last Attorney General, Michael Mukasey reimposed them. Those limits were again adopted by the Obama Administration in a 2009 memo by then-Attorney General Eric Holder.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EMatt Miller, a Holder aide, says &#8220;that memo directs that contacts between the White House and the Justice Department be funneled through the White House counsel&#8217;s office to the AG or Deputy Attorney General&#8217;s office precisely so there can be no inappropriate tampering with investigations. If McCabe and Comey told Priebus about what was happening in an ongoing investigation into the president&#8217;s associates, they clearly violated that guidance and crossed a major line.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThose limits aren&#8217;t the only rules Comey and McCabe may have violated. There are also longstanding written controls, based on authority given to the Attorney General under an \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.archives.gov\u002Ffederal-register\u002Fcodification\u002Fexecutive-order\u002F12333.html\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eexecutive order\u003C\u002Fa\u003E issued by Ronald Reagan in 1981 and on several \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.law.cornell.edu\u002Fuscode\u002Ftext\u002F28\u002F509\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Estatutes\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, that require the Attorney General&rsquo;s approval for most contacts between the FBI and the White House regarding foreign intelligence matters that involve domestic political activities.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThose \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fvault.fbi.gov\u002FFBI%20Domestic%20Investigations%20and%20Operations%20Guide%20%28DIOG%29\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Erules\u003C\u002Fa\u003E say that, &ldquo;Compromising information concerning domestic officials or political organizations, or information concerning activities of United States persons intended to affect the political process in the United States, may be disseminated to the White House only with the approval of the Attorney General, based on a determination that such dissemination is needed for foreign intelligence purposes, for the purpose of protecting against international terrorism or other threats to the national security, or for the conduct of foreign affairs.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENeither the Justice Department nor the FBI would comment on whether the Attorney General approved the contacts between the FBI&rsquo;s leaders and the White House. White House spokesman Sean Spicer told reporters on Feb. 24 that there was a &ldquo;carve-out&rdquo; for public affairs communications. The Holder memo does exempt &ldquo;officials in the communications, public affairs, or press offices of the White House and the Department of Justice from communicating with each other to coordinate efforts.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBut the Holder rules also explicitly say that &ldquo;pending adversary cases in litigation that may have national security implications&rdquo; are not exempt from the rules.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESeveral former Justice Department officials from both political parties, speaking anonymously, said they believed the contacts violated those rules, but none would speak on the record. Democratic House Leader Nancy Pelosi \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.democraticleader.gov\u002Fnewsroom\u002F22417\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Ecalled\u003C\u002Fa\u003E Friday for an investigation by the Justice Department&rsquo;s Office of the Inspector General into the contacts between the FBI and the White House.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe DOJ&#8217;s Inspector General, Michael Horowitz, has already launched a broad investigation of the FBI and the Justice Department&rsquo;s actions during the 2016 election. That investigation includes Comey&rsquo;s handling the FBI probe of Hillary Clinton&rsquo;s emails, and the meeting held between then-Attorney General Loretta Lynch and Bill Clinton during that investigation in July, Horowitz told Congress on Feb. 1.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["FBI Director James Comey and Deputy Director Andrew McCabe may have violated multiple existing Justice Department rules controlling contacts between the bureau and White House officials ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4681516\u002Freince-priebus-fbi-trump-media-russia\u002F"},"content":["when they spoke earlier"]}," this month with White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus about their ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4672853\u002Ftrump-russia-investigation-puting-congress-flynn\u002F"},"content":["ongoing investigation"]}," into Russia’s influence operation against the 2016 U.S. presidential election, according to several former senior Justice Department officials."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The first questionable contact came when McCabe spoke with Priebus for five minutes after a 7:30 a.m. meeting at the White House on Feb. 15 on an unrelated intelligence issue. The day before, the New York ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Times"]}," had ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002F14\u002Fus\u002Fpolitics\u002Frussia-intelligence-communications-trump.html?_r=0"},"content":["reported"]}," that Trump’s campaign and other Trump associates had multiple contacts with known agents of Russian intelligence in the year before the election."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["At the White House meeting, McCabe told Priebus, ‘I want you to know story in ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["NYT"]}," is BS,\" according to senior Administration officials who briefed reporters on Feb. 24."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Priebus asked McCabe what could be done to push back, saying the White House was “getting crushed” on the story.
