George W. Bush loosened those limits after 9\u002F11, but after a series of scandals, his last Attorney General, Michael Mukasey reimposed them. Those limits were again adopted by the Obama Administration in a 2009 memo by then-Attorney General Eric Holder."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Matt Miller, a Holder aide, says \"that memo directs that contacts between the White House and the Justice Department be funneled through the White House counsel's office to the AG or Deputy Attorney General's office precisely so there can be no inappropriate tampering with investigations. The Holder memo does exempt “officials in the communications, public affairs, or press offices of the White House and the Department of Justice from communicating with each other to coordinate efforts.”"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["But the Holder rules also explicitly say that “pending adversary cases in litigation that may have national security implications” are not exempt from the rules."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Several former Justice Department officials from both political parties, speaking anonymously, said they believed the contacts violated those rules, but none would speak on the record. Democratic House Leader Nancy Pelosi ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.democraticleader.gov\u002Fnewsroom\u002F22417\u002F"},"content":["called"]}," Friday for an investigation by the Justice Department’s Office of the Inspector General into the contacts between the FBI and the White House."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The DOJ's Inspector General, Michael Horowitz, has already launched a broad investigation of the FBI and the Justice Department’s actions during the 2016 election. That investigation includes Comey’s handling the FBI probe of Hillary Clinton’s emails, and the meeting held between then-Attorney General Loretta Lynch and Bill Clinton during that investigation in July, Horowitz told Congress on Feb. 1."]}],"plain":"FBI Director James Comey and Deputy Director Andrew McCabe may have violated multiple existing Justice Department rules controlling contacts between the bureau and White House officials when they spoke earlier this month with White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus about their ongoing investigation into Russia&rsquo;s influence operation against the 2016 U.S. presidential election, according to several former senior Justice Department officials. The first questionable contact came when McCabe spoke with Priebus for five minutes after a 7:30 a.m. meeting at the White House on Feb. 15 on an unrelated intelligence issue. The day before, the New York Times had reported that Trump&rsquo;s campaign and other Trump associates had multiple contacts with known agents of Russian intelligence in the year before the election. At the White House meeting, McCabe told Priebus, &lsquo;I want you to know story in NYT is BS,&#8221; according to senior Administration officials who briefed reporters on Feb. 24. Priebus asked McCabe what could be done to push back, saying the White House was &ldquo;getting crushed&rdquo; on the story. McCabe demurred, and then later called back to say, &ldquo;We&#8217;d love to help but we can&#8217;t get into the position of making statements on every story.&rdquo; FBI Director James Comey later called Priebus himself and repeated McCabe&rsquo;s statements about the New York Times story. Comey also said he was unwilling to speak publicly about the piece but agreed to let Priebus cite senior intelligence officials in his pushback, the officials said. The back-and-forth may have broken internal rules in place for decades, according to former officials. After President Nixon&#8217;s scandals in the early 1970s, the Carter Administration imposed rules designed to prevent the FBI from meddling in politics, and to keep politicians from meddling in criminal investigations. In Bill Clinton&rsquo;s first term, Attorney General Janet Reno limited contacts between the White House and law enforcement regarding criminal investigations to the top three officials at the Justice Department on the one hand and the President, Vice President and the top two White House lawyers on the other. George W. Bush loosened those limits after 9\u002F11, but after a series of scandals, his last Attorney General, Michael Mukasey reimposed them. Those limits were again adopted by the Obama Administration in a 2009 memo by then-Attorney General Eric Holder. Matt Miller, a Holder aide, says &#8220;that memo directs that contacts between the White House and the Justice Department be funneled through the White House counsel&#8217;s office to the AG or Deputy Attorney General&#8217;s office precisely so there can be no inappropriate tampering with investigations. If McCabe and Comey told Priebus about what was happening in an ongoing investigation into the president&#8217;s associates, they clearly violated that guidance and crossed a major line.&#8221; Those limits aren&#8217;t the only rules Comey and McCabe may have violated. There are also longstanding written controls, based on authority given to the Attorney General under an executive order issued by Ronald Reagan in 1981 and on several statutes, that require the Attorney General&rsquo;s approval for most contacts between the FBI and the White House regarding foreign intelligence matters that involve domestic political activities. Those rules say that, &ldquo;Compromising information concerning domestic officials or political organizations, or information concerning activities of United States persons intended to affect the political process in the United States, may be disseminated to the White House only with the approval of the Attorney General, based on a determination that such dissemination is needed for foreign intelligence purposes, for the purpose of protecting against international terrorism or other threats to the national security, or for the conduct of foreign affairs.&rdquo; Neither the Justice Department nor the FBI would comment on whether the Attorney General approved the contacts between the FBI&rsquo;s leaders and the White House. White House spokesman Sean Spicer told reporters on Feb. 24 that there was a &ldquo;carve-out&rdquo; for public affairs communications. The Holder memo does exempt &ldquo;officials in the communications, public affairs, or press offices of the White House and the Department of Justice from communicating with each other to coordinate efforts.&rdquo; But the Holder rules also explicitly say that &ldquo;pending adversary cases in litigation that may have national security implications&rdquo; are not exempt from the rules. Several former Justice Department officials from both political parties, speaking anonymously, said they believed the contacts violated those rules, but none would speak on the record. Democratic House Leader Nancy Pelosi called Friday for an investigation by the Justice Department&rsquo;s Office of the Inspector General into the contacts between the FBI and the White House. The DOJ&#8217;s Inspector General, Michael Horowitz, has already launched a broad investigation of the FBI and the Justice Department&rsquo;s actions during the 2016 election. That investigation includes Comey&rsquo;s handling the FBI probe of Hillary Clinton&rsquo;s emails, and the meeting held between then-Attorney General Loretta Lynch and Bill Clinton during that investigation in July, Horowitz told Congress on Feb. 1."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003ECalls for investigation from Congress\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":16435805,"featured_media":4682855,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[430953138,189091,68079,630134,426939439,2606,62303,16962395,10759,7053],"time_section":[204777755],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937769],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682791"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682791\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682791\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=4682791"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=4682791"},{"taxonomy":"topic","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftopics?post=4682791"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682791\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682791\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682791\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682791\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u0 The daily briefing is normally open to all credentialed reporters when the President is not traveling, whether the event happens on-camera in the White House Briefing Room or off-camera elsewhere.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe White House Correspondents&#8217; Association, a group that represents credentialed reporters, promptly denounced the move. &#8220;The WHCA board is protesting strongly against how today&#8217;s gaggle is being handled by the White House,&#8221; said board president Jeff Mason of Reuters. &#8220;We encourage the organizations that were allowed in to share the material with others in the press corps who were not. The board will be discussing this further with White House staff.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETwo other members of the board, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fauthor\u002Fzeke-j-miller\u002F\"\u003ETIME correspondent Zeke Miller\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and Julie Pace of the Associated Press, emailed these concerns to Spicer prior to the briefing. They both declined to attend Friday&#8217;s briefing when the concerns of the board were not addressed.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EShortly after the briefing was concluded, reporters in attendance transcribed and circulated Spicer&#8217;s comments to the entire White House press corps.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn 2009, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fcontent.time.com\u002Ftime\u002Fsubscriber\u002Farticle\u002F0,33009,1929220,00.html\"\u003Etop Obama Administration officials declared that Fox News\u003C\u002Fa\u003E was not a news organization because of opinions often aired by the network that were sharply critical of Obama&#8217;s policies. At one point that same year, the Treasury Department declined to invite Fox News, but not other networks, to a briefing, prompting complaints from other news organizations. The Obama White House later said the omission of Fox had been made for logistical reasons, and included a Fox reporter in a briefing with the same Treasury official. &#8220;This White House has demonstrated our willingness to exclude Fox News from newsmaking interviews, but yesterday we did not,&#8221; said White House spokesman Josh Earnest \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftalkingpointsmemo.com\u002Fdc\u002Fwh-we-re-happy-to-exclude-fox-but-didn-t-yesterday-with-feinberg-interview\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eat the time\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. The Obama White House did not restrict news organization access to daily briefings by the Press Secretary.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn recent weeks, Trump has made more pointed attacks on news organizations he says have been unfair to him. &#8220;A few days ago I called the fake news the enemy of the people. And they are. They are the enemy of the people,&#8221; he said Friday, in an address to the \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4681640\u002Fcpac-donald-trump-analysis\u002F\"\u003EConservative Political Action Conference\u003C\u002Fa\u003E in Maryland. &#8220;Because they have no sources, they just make &#8217;em up when there are none. I saw one story recently where they said, &#8216;Nine people have confirmed.'&#8221; They&#8217;re no nine people.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe President did not identify the story he was describing. A \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.washingtonpost.com\u002Fworld\u002Fnational-security\u002Fnational-security-adviser-flynn-discussed-sanctions-with-russian-ambassador-despite-denials-officials-say\u002F2017\u002F02\u002F09\u002Ff85b29d6-ee11-11e6-b4ff-ac2cf509efe5_story.html?tid=a_inl&amp;utm_term=.3f7becaf104b\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EWashington Post story\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, dated Feb. 9, reported that nine current and former officials had spoken to the newspaper for a report disclosing that then-National Security Adviser Michael Flynn had been misleading about the content of his conversations with Russian officials after the November election.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDays later, President Trump accepted Flynn&#8217;s resignation. Spicer said the resignation had resulted from &#8220;an eroding level of trust&#8221; between Flynn and Trump.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Hours after ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4682023\u002Fcpac-donald-trump-speech-transcript\u002F"},"content":["President Trump"]}," told conservative activists Friday that he planned to \"do something\" about unfair press coverage, the White House broke with tradition by limiting access to the daily briefing by ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4643390\u002Fsean-spicer-donald-trump-press-briefing-watch-live\u002F"},"content":["Press Secretary Sean Spicer"]},"."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Reporters for CNN, Politico, the New York Times and other outlets were barred from entry to an off-camera but usually on-the-record briefing, called a gaggle, in Spicer's office. The board will be discussing this further with White House staff.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Two other members of the board, ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fauthor\u002Fzeke-j-miller\u002F"},"content":["TIME correspondent Zeke Miller"]}," and Julie Pace of the Associated Press, emailed these concerns to Spicer prior to the briefing. They both declined to attend Friday's briefing when the concerns of the board were not addressed."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Shortly after the briefing was concluded, reporters in attendance transcribed and circulated Spicer's comments to the entire White House press corps."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In 2009, ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fcontent.time.com\u002Ftime\u002Fsubscriber\u002Farticle\u002F0,33009,1929220,00.html"},"content":["top Obama Administration officials declared that Fox News"]}," was not a news organization because of opinions often aired by the network that were sharply critical of Obama's policies. The Obama White House later said the omission of Fox had been made for logistical reasons, and included a Fox reporter in a briefing with the same Treasury official. \"This White House has demonstrated our willingness to exclude Fox News from newsmaking interviews, but yesterday we did not,\" said White House spokesman Josh Earnest ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftalkingpointsmemo.com\u002Fdc\u002Fwh-we-re-happy-to-exclude-fox-but-didn-t-yesterday-with-feinberg-interview"},"content":["at the time"]},". And they are. They are the enemy of the people,\" he said Friday, in an address to the ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4681640\u002Fcpac-donald-trump-analysis\u002F"},"content":["Conservative Political Action Conference"]}," in Maryland. \"Because they have no sources, they just make 'em up when there are none. I saw one story recently where they said, 'Nine people have confirmed.'\" They're no nine people.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The President did not identify the story he was describing. A ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.washingtonpost.com\u002Fworld\u002Fnational-security\u002Fnational-security-adviser-flynn-discussed-sanctions-with-russian-ambassador-despite-denials-officials-say\u002F2017\u002F02\u002F09\u002Ff85b29d6-ee11-11e6-b4ff-ac2cf509efe5_story.html?tid=a_inl&amp;utm_term=.3f7becaf104b"},"content":["Washington Post story"]},", dated Feb. 9, reported that nine current and former officials had spoken to the newspaper for a report disclosing that then-National Security Adviser Michael Flynn had been misleading about the content of his conversations with Russian officials after the November election."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Days later, President Trump accepted Flynn's resignation. Spicer said the resignation had resulted from \"an eroding level of trust\" between Flynn and Trump."]}],"plain":"Hours after President Trump told conservative activists Friday that he planned to &#8220;do something&#8221; about unfair press coverage, the White House broke with tradition by limiting access to the daily briefing by Press Secretary Sean Spicer. Reporters for CNN, Politico, the New York Times and other outlets were barred from entry to an off-camera but usually on-the-record briefing, called a gaggle, in Spicer&#8217;s office. The daily briefing is normally open to all credentialed reporters when the President is not traveling, whether the event happens on-camera in the White House Briefing Room or off-camera elsewhere. The White House Correspondents&#8217; Association, a group that represents credentialed reporters, promptly denounced the move. &#8220;The WHCA board is protesting strongly against how today&#8217;s gaggle is being handled by the White House,&#8221; said board president Jeff Mason of Reuters. &#8220;We encourage the organizations that were allowed in to share the material with others in the press corps who were not. The board will be discussing this further with White House staff.&#8221; Two other members of the board, TIME correspondent Zeke Miller and Julie Pace of the Associated Press, emailed these concerns to Spicer prior to the briefing. They both declined to attend Friday&#8217;s briefing when the concerns of the board were not addressed. Shortly after the briefing was concluded, reporters in attendance transcribed and circulated Spicer&#8217;s comments to the entire White House press corps. In 2009, top Obama Administration officials declared that Fox News was not a news organization because of opinions often aired by the network that were sharply critical of Obama&#8217;s policies. At one point that same year, the Treasury Department declined to invite Fox News, but not other networks, to a briefing, prompting complaints from other news organizations. The Obama White House later said the omission of Fox had been made for logistical reasons, and included a Fox reporter in a briefing with the same Treasury official. &#8220;This White House has demonstrated our willingness to exclude Fox News from newsmaking interviews, but yesterday we did not,&#8221; said White House spokesman Josh Earnest at the time. The Obama White House did not restrict news organization access to daily briefings by the Press Secretary. In recent weeks, Trump has made more pointed attacks on news organizations he says have been unfair to him. &#8220;A few days ago I called the fake news the enemy of the people. And they are. They are the enemy of the people,&#8221; he said Friday, in an address to the Conservative Political Action Conference in Maryland. &#8220;Because they have no sources, they just make &#8217;em up when there are none. I saw one story recently where they said, &#8216;Nine people have confirmed.'&#8221; They&#8217;re no nine people.&#8221; The President did not identify the story he was describing. A Washington Post story, dated Feb. 9, reported that nine current and former officials had spoken to the newspaper for a report disclosing that then-National Security Adviser Michael Flynn had been misleading about the content of his conversations with Russian officials after the November election. Days later, President Trump accepted Flynn&#8217;s resignation. Spicer said the resignation had resulted from &#8220;an eroding level of trust&#8221; between Flynn and Trump."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EWhite House Correspondents&#8217; Association files protest\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":5535601,"featured_media":4661062,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[189091,3996,2764,430946732,7053],"time_section":[204777755],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937769],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682690"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682690\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682690\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=4682690"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=4682690"},{"taxonomy":"topic","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftopics?post=4682690"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682690\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682690\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682690\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682690\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4682690\u002Fauthors"}],"fo Daily Briefing","mt_seo_google_news_meta":"white house, sean spicer, news media, press","negative_coverage":false,"short_title":"White House Bars News Outlets from Daily Briefing","home_deck":"Hours Not only did he bless his followers with \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4460579\u002Ffrank-ocean-new-album-blonde\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Etwo new albums\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4461555\u002Ffrank-ocean-new-album-blonde-2\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Ehotly sought-after zine\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, he also presented a broadcast on Apple&#8217;s Beats 1 radio called &#8220;blonded RADIO&#8221; on Friday afternoon.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHis first show was a treasure trove of insanely good music&mdash;\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4668265\u002Fprince-music-spotify-streaming-tidal\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EPrince\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, Sade and Celine Dion were just a few of the selections&mdash;as well as an engrossing conversation with\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4656929\u002Fbeyonce-pregnant-twins\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E Jay Z\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, an interesting choice given that the latter owns Tidal, a rival streaming service to Apple.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDuring the exchange, the two discussed the shortcomings of modern radio, which the Roc Nation mogul called &#8220;pretty much an advertisement model&#8221; that caters to a very specific demographic: young white women.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;You take these pop stations, they&rsquo;re reaching 18-34 young white females,&#8221; Jay Z said. &#8220;So they&rsquo;re playing music based on those tastes. And then they&rsquo;re taking those numbers and they&rsquo;re going to advertising agencies and people are paying numbers based on the audience that they have. So these places are not even based on music. Their playlist isn&#8217;t based on music. If you think a person like Bob Marley right now probably wouldn&rsquo;t play on a pop station. Which is crazy. It&rsquo;s not even about the DJ discovering what music is best. You know, music is music. The line&rsquo;s just been separated so much that we&rsquo;re lost at this point in time.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhile it&#8217;s yet to be seen if Ocean&#8217;s &#8220;blonded RADIO&#8221; Not only did he bless his followers with two new albums and hotly sought-after zine, he also presented a broadcast on Apple&#8217;s Beats 1 radio called &#8220;blonded RADIO&#8221; on Friday afternoon. His first show was a treasure trove of insanely good music&mdash;Prince, Sade and Celine Dion were just a few of the selections&mdash;as well as an engrossing conversation with Jay Z, an interesting choice given that the latter owns Tidal, a rival streaming service to Apple. During the exchange, the two discussed the shortcomings of modern radio, which the Roc Nation mogul called &#8220;pretty much an advertisement model&#8221; that caters to a very specific demographic: young white women. &#8220;You take these pop stations, they&rsquo;re reaching 18-34 young white females,&#8221; Jay Z said. &#8220;So they&rsquo;re playing music based on those tastes. And then they&rsquo;re taking those numbers and they&rsquo;re going to advertising agencies and people are paying numbers based on the audience that they have. So these places are not even based on music. Their playlist isn&#8217;t based on music. If you think a person like Bob Marley right now probably wouldn&rsquo;t play on a pop station. Which is crazy. It&rsquo;s not even about the DJ discovering what music is best. You know, music is music. The line&rsquo;s just been separated so much that we&rsquo;re lost at this point in time.&#8221; While it&#8217;s yet to be seen if Ocean&#8217;s &#8220;blonded RADIO&#8221; was a one-time deal or a series, you can listen to his full broadcast on Apple Music below. Frank Ocean presents #blondedRADIO!TAP IN NOW for selections with @vegynvegyn, Roof Access and Federico Aliprandi. https:\u002F\u002Ft.co\u002FrAPwDbsSan pic.twitter.com\u002FfAoD54OSV0 &mdash; Beats She not only became the first African-American woman with three Oscar nominations, surpassing Whoopi Goldberg, but she is also poised to become the first black actor&mdash;male or female&mdash;to win the Triple Crown of Acting (one each of a competitive Oscar, Emmy and Tony). A win for Davis would mean, above all, recognition of her fierce talent as a performer, but it would also give audiences another chance to enjoy one of her unfailingly powerful acceptance speeches. style","parent":0,"count":19452,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["entertainment"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4682723,"date":"2017-02-24T17:12:35","date_gmt":"2017-02-24T22:12:35","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4682723"},"modified":"2017-02-24T17:12:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-24T22:12:00","slug":"homeland-security-intelligence-report-travel-ban","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4682723\u002Fhomeland-security-intelligence-report-travel-ban\u002F","title":{"rendered":"Homeland Security Intelligence Report Disputes Terror Threat for Countries Included in Travel Ban"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E(WASHINGTON) &mdash; Analysts at the Homeland Security Department&#8217;s intelligence arm found insufficient evidence that citizens of seven Muslim-majority countries included in President Donald Trump&#8217;s \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4673870\u002Fdonald-trump-travel-ban\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Etravel ban\u003C\u002Fa\u003E pose a terror threat to the United States.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA draft document obtained by The Associated Press concludes that citizenship is an &#8220;unlikely indicator&#8221; of terrorism threats to the United States and that few people from the countries Trump listed in his travel ban have carried out attacks or been involved in terrorism-related activities in the U.S. since Syria&#8217;s civil war started in 2011.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETrump cited terrorism concerns as the primary reason he signed the sweeping temporary travel ban in late January, which also halted the U.S. \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4666342\u002Fprivate-citizens-help-refugees\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Erefugee program\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. A federal judge in Washington state \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4666465\u002Fappeals-court-president-trump-travel-ban\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eblocked\u003C\u002Fa\u003E the government from carrying out the order earlier this month. Trump said Friday a new edict would be announced soon. The administration has been working on a new version that could withstand legal challenges.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"video-container\"\u003E\u003Cvideo id=\"brightcove-player-5325921826001\" data-video-id=\"5325921826001\" data-account=\"293884104\" data-player=\"SJa0Thl7\" data-embed=\"default\" autoplay controls preload=\"auto\" class=\"video-js responsive-video\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fvideo\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHomeland Security spokeswoman Gillian Christensen on Friday did not dispute the report&#8217;s authenticity, but said it was not a final comprehensive review of the government&#8217;s intelligence.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;While DHS was asked to draft a comprehensive report on this issue, the document you&#8217;re referencing was commentary from a single intelligence source versus an official, robust document with thorough interagency sourcing,&#8221; Christensen said. &#8220;The &#8230; report does not include data from other intelligence community sources. It is incomplete.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe Homeland Security report is based on unclassified information from Justice Department press releases on terrorism-related convictions and attackers killed in the act, State Department visa statistics, the 2016 Worldwide Threat Assessment from the U.S. intelligence community and the State Department Country Reports on Terrorism 2015.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe three-page report challenges Trump&#8217;s core claims. It said that of 82 people the government determined were inspired by a foreign terrorist group to carry out or try to carry out an attack in the United States, just over half were U.S. citizens born in the United States. The others were from 26 countries, led by Pakistan, Somalia, Bangladesh, Cuba, Ethiopia, Iraq and Uzbekistan. Of these, only Somalia and Iraq were among the seven nations included in the ban.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOf the other five nations, one person each from Iran, Sudan and Yemen was also involved in those terrorism cases, but none from Syria. It did not say if any were Libyan.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe report also found that terrorist organizations in Iran, Libya, Somalia and Sudan are regionally focused, while groups in Iraq, Syria and Yemen do pose a threat to the U.S.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe seven countries were included in a law President Barack Obama signed in 2015 that updated visa requirements for foreigners who had traveled to those countries.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe report was prepared as part of an internal review Trump requested after his executive order was blocked by the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. It was drafted by staff of the Homeland Security Department&#8217;s Intelligence and Analysis branch at the direction of its acting leader, David Glawe.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhite House spokesman Michael Short said this was not the full report that Trump had requested. He said he believes &#8220;the intel community is combining resources to put together a comprehensive report using all available sources, not just open sources, and which is driven by data, not politics.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe intelligence document was circulated beyond Homeland Security.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe draft document reflects the tensions between the president&#8217;s political appointees and the civil servants tasked with carrying out Trump&#8217;s ambitious and aggressive agenda. Trump has repeatedly complained about leaks meant to undercut his policies and suggested he does not trust holdovers from the Obama administration.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETrump originally said the ban was necessary to overhaul the vetting system for both refugees and would-be foreign visitors, saying that terrorists may try to exploit weaknesses to gain access to the United States. The order sparked chaos, outrage and widespread protests, with travelers detained at airports and panicked families searching for relatives.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBut several courts quickly intervened and the 9th Circuit ultimately upheld a ruling blocking the ban and challenged the administration&#8217;s claim that it was motivated by terrorism fears.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETrump&#8217;s ban temporarily barred citizens from the seven countries from coming to the United States for three months. The order also temporarily shut down the U.S. refugee program for four months and indefinitely banned anyone from Syria.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA senior administration official told the AP on Sunday that a draft of the revised order will target those same seven countries. The official would not be named discussing the document before it is made public.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn a speech to the Conservative Political Action Committee Friday, Trump reiterated his claims on terrorism.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;We are going to keep radical Islamic terrorists the hell out of our country,&#8221; Trump said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHe said he singled out the seven countries because they had already been deemed a security concern by the Obama administration.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["(WASHINGTON) — Analysts at the Homeland Security Department's intelligence arm found insufficient evidence that citizens of seven Muslim-majority countries included in President Donald Trump's ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4673870\u002Fdonald-trump-travel-ban\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["travel ban"]}," pose a terror threat to the United States."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["A draft document obtained by The Associated Press concludes that citizenship is an \"unlikely indicator\" of terrorism threats to the United States and that few people from the countries Trump listed in his travel ban have carried out attacks or been involved in terrorism-related activities in the U.S. since Syria's civil war started in 2011."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Trump cited terrorism concerns as the primary reason he signed the sweeping temporary travel ban in late January, which also halted the U.S. ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4666342\u002Fprivate-citizens-help-refugees\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["refugee program"]},". A federal judge in Washington state ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4666465\u002Fappeals-court-president-trump-travel-ban\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["blocked"]}," the government from carrying out the order earlier this month. Trump said Friday a new edict would be announced soon. The administration has been working on a new version that could withstand legal challenges."]},{"tag":"video","attributes":{"autoplay":"1","controls":"1","videoid":"5325921826001"},"content":[]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Homeland Security spokeswoman Gillian Christensen on Friday did not dispute the report's authenticity, but said it was not a final comprehensive review of the government's intelligence."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"While DHS was asked to draft a comprehensive report on this issue, the document you're referencing was commentary from a single intelligence source versus an official, robust document with thorough interagency sourcing,\" Christensen said. \"The ... report does not include data from other intelligence community sources. It is incomplete.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The Homeland Security report is based on unclassified information from Justice Department press releases on terrorism-related convictions and attackers killed in the act, State Department visa statistics, the 2016 Worldwide Threat Assessment from the U.S. intelligence community and the State Department Country Reports on Terrorism 2015."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The three-page report challenges Trump's core claims. It said that of 82 people the government determined were inspired by a foreign terrorist group to carry out or try to carry out an attack in the United States, just over half were U.S. citizens born in the United States. The others were from 26 countries, led by Pakistan, Somalia, Bangladesh, Cuba, Ethiopia, Iraq and Uzbekistan. Of these, only Somalia and Iraq were among the seven nations included in the ban."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Of the other five nations, one person each from Iran, Sudan and Yemen was also involved in those terrorism cases, but none from Syria. It did not say if any were Libyan."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The report also found that terrorist organizations in Iran, Libya, Somalia and Sudan are regionally focused, while groups in Iraq, Syria and Yemen do pose a threat to the U.S."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The seven countries were included in a law President Barack Obama signed in 2015 that updated visa requirements for foreigners who had traveled to those countries."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The report was prepared as part of an internal review Trump requested after his executive order was blocked by the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. It was drafted by staff of the Homeland Security Department's Intelligence and Analysis branch at the direction of its acting leader, David Glawe."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["White House spokesman Michael Short said this was not the full report that Trump had requested. He said he believes \"the intel community is combining resources to put together a comprehensive report using all available sources, not just open sources, and which is driven by data, not politics.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The intelligence document was circulated beyond Homeland Security."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The draft document reflects the tensions between the president's political appointees and the civil servants tasked with carrying out Trump's ambitious and aggressive agenda. Trump has repeatedly complained about leaks meant to undercut his policies and suggested he does not trust holdovers from the Obama administration."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Trump originally said the ban was necessary to overhaul the vetting system for both refugees and would-be foreign visitors, saying that terrorists may try to exploit weaknesses to gain access to the United States. The order sparked chaos, outrage and widespread protests, with travelers detained at airports and panicked families searching for relatives."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["But several courts quickly intervened and the 9th Circuit ultimately upheld a ruling blocking the ban and challenged the administration's claim that it was motivated by terrorism fears."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Trump's ban temporarily barred citizens from the seven countries from coming to the United States for three months. The order also temporarily shut down the U.S. refugee program for four months and indefinitely banned anyone from Syria."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["A senior administration official told the AP on Sunday that a draft of the revised order will target those same seven countries. The official would not be named discussing the document before it is made public."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In a speech to the Conservative Political Action Committee Friday, Trump reiterated his claims on terrorism."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"We are going to keep radical Islamic terrorists the hell out of our country,\" Trump said."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["He said he singled out the seven countries because they had already been deemed a security concern by the Obama administration."]}],"plain":"(WASHINGTON) &mdash; Analysts at the Homeland Security Department&#8217;s intelligence arm found insufficient evidence that citizens of seven Muslim-majority countries included in President Donald Trump&#8217;s travel ban pose a terror threat to the United States. A draft document obtained by The Associated Press concludes that citizenship is an &#8220;unlikely indicator&#8221; of terrorism threats to the United States and that few people from the countries Trump listed in his travel ban have carried out attacks or been involved in terrorism-related activities in the U.S. since Syria&#8217;s civil war started in 2011. Trump cited terrorism concerns as the primary reason he signed the sweeping temporary travel ban in late January, which also halted the U.S. refugee program. A federal judge in Washington state blocked the government from carrying out the order earlier this month. Trump said Friday a new edict would be announced soon. The administration has been working on a new version that could withstand legal challenges. Homeland Security spokeswoman Gillian Christensen on Friday did not dispute the report&#8217;s authenticity, but said it was not a final comprehensive review of the government&#8217;s intelligence. &#8220;While DHS was asked to draft a comprehensive report on this issue, the document you&#8217;re referencing was commentary from a single intelligence source versus an official, robust document with thorough interagency sourcing,&#8221; Christensen said. &#8220;The &#8230; report does not include data from other intelligence community sources. It is incomplete.&#8221; The Homeland Security report is based on unclassified information from Justice Department press releases on terrorism-related convictions and attackers killed in the act, State Department visa statistics, the 2016 Worldwide Threat Assessment from the U.S. intelligence community and the State Department Country Reports on Terrorism 2015. The three-page report challenges Trump&#8217;s core claims. It said that of 82 people the government determined were inspired by a foreign terrorist group to carry out or try to carry out an attack in the United States, just over half were U.S. citizens born in the United States. The others were from 26 countries, led by Pakistan, Somalia, Bangladesh, Cuba, Ethiopia, Iraq and Uzbekistan. Of these, only Somalia and Iraq were among the seven nations included in the ban. Of the other five nations, one person each from Iran, Sudan and Yemen was also involved in those terrorism cases, but none from Syria. It did not say if any were Libyan. The report also found that terrorist organizations in Iran, Libya, Somalia and Sudan are regionally focused, while groups in Iraq, Syria and Yemen do pose a threat to the U.S. The seven countries were included in a law President Barack Obama signed in 2015 that updated visa requirements for foreigners who had traveled to those countries. The report was prepared as part of an internal review Trump requested after his executive order was blocked by the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. It was drafted by staff of the Homeland Security Department&#8217;s Intelligence and Analysis branch at the direction of its acting leader, David Glawe. White House spokesman Michael Short said this was not the full report that Trump had requested. He said he believes &#8220;the intel community is combining resources to put together a comprehensive report using all available sources, not just open sources, and which is driven by data, not politics.&#8221; The intelligence document was circulated beyond Homeland Security. The draft document reflects the tensions between the president&#8217;s political appointees and the civil servants tasked with carrying out Trump&#8217;s ambitious and aggressive agenda. Trump has repeatedly complained about leaks meant to undercut his policies and suggested he does not trust holdovers from the Obama administration. Trump originally said the ban was necessary to overhaul the vetting system for both refugees and would-be foreign visitors, saying that terrorists may try to exploit weaknesses to gain access to the United States. The order sparked chaos, outrage and widespread protests, with travelers detained at airports and panicked families searching for relatives. But several courts quickly intervened and the 9th Circuit ultimately upheld a ruling blocking the ban and challenged the administration&#8217;s claim that it was motivated by terrorism fears. Trump&#8217;s ban temporarily barred citizens from the seven countries from coming to the United States for three months. The order also temporarily shut down the U.S. refugee program for four months and indefinitely banned anyone from Syria. A senior administration official told the AP on Sunday that a draft of the revised order will target those same seven countries. The official would not be named discussing the document before it is made public. In a speech to the Conservative Political Action Committee Friday, Trump reiterated his claims on terrorism. &#8220;We are going to keep radical Islamic terrorists the hell out of our country,&#8221; Trump said. He said he singled out the seven countries because they had already been deemed a security concern by the Obama administration."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EThe document concludes that citizenship is an &#8220;unlikely indicator&#8221; of terrorism threats States","permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4682723\u002Fhomeland-security-intelligence-report-travel-ban\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ftime\u002F4682723\u002Fhomeland-security-intelligence-report-travel-ban\u002F?source=dam"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"landscape","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":4652795,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002Ftrump-muslim-ban.jpg?quality=85","alt":"U.S. President Donald Trump signs an executive order to impose tighter vetting of travelers entering the United States, at the Pentagon in Washington, U.S., January 27, 2017. She has none of the characteristics of someone with Stockholm Syndrome because she keeps her independence, she keeps that freedom of thought.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["MORE"]}," ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4573300\u002Fold-new-beauty-and-the-beast-trailers\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Here's Proof That the New ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Beauty and the Beast"]}," Trailer Is Pretty Much the Same as the Original"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["Your favorite talking appliances are back and more alive than ever."]}," Lumiére (",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F3830208\u002Fewan-mcgregor-lumiere-beauty-beast\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Ewan McGregor"]},"), Mrs. Potts (",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F3746591\u002Femma-thompson-mrs-potts\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Emma Thompson"]},"), Cogsworth (",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F3818523\u002Fian-mckellen-cogsworth-beauty-beast-disney\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Ian McKellen"]},"), Plumette (",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F3819780\u002Fbeauty-and-the-beast-gugu-mbatha-raw\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Gugu Mbatha-Raw"]},"), Madame de Garderobe (Audra McDonald) and Chip (Nathan Mack) chatter away throughout the movie. Here&#8217;s everything you need to know ahead of the premiere. The film has a star-studded cast. Emma Watson plays Belle and Dan Stevens inhabits the Beast. Luke Evans will fight like Gaston while Josh Gad portrays sidekick Le Fou. Kevin Kline will also appear as Belle&#8217;s father, Maurice. Emma Watson is aware of the common critiques of the plot. In a recent interview with Entertainment Weekly, Watson defended Belle&#8217;s relationship with the Beast, which some say encourages women to stay in abusive relationships. &#8220;It&rsquo;s something I really grappled with at the beginning; the kind of Stockholm Syndrome question about this story,&#8221; she said. &#8220;That&rsquo;s where a prisoner will take on the characteristics of and fall in love with the captor. Belle actively argues and disagrees with [Beast] constantly. She has none of the characteristics of someone with Stockholm Syndrome because she keeps her independence, she keeps that freedom of thought.&#8221; MORE Here&#8217;s Proof That the New Beauty and the Beast Trailer Is Pretty Much the Same as the Original Your favorite talking appliances are back and more alive than ever. Lumi&eacute;re (Ewan McGregor), Mrs. Potts (Emma Thompson), Cogsworth (Ian McKellen), Plumette (Gugu Mbatha-Raw), Madame de Garderobe (Audra McDonald) and Chip (Nathan Mack) chatter away throughout the movie. And Stanley Tucci plays a new character, Cadenza, a harpsichord. (See character posters for each at EW.) Director Bill Condon decided to remake the film to &#8220;distinguish Belle again, 25 years later, as a 21st century heroine.&#8221; In an interview with EW, Condon said: &#8220;She is a character in an animated movie, so it is a question of taking these characters and putting them into this extra dimension, putting them into a live-action context, which means adding levels of psychology and nuance, and updating it.&#8221; MORE How Beauty and the Beast&#8217;s Screenwriter Shaped Disney&#8217;s First Feminist Princess Ariana Grande and John Legend sing an updated version of the theme song. The full movie soundtrack also features a song by Celine Dion and contributions from Josh Groban. The film is one of more than a dozen classics being remade by Disney. Live-action versions of Mulan, Aladdin and The Lion King are among the ones expected to premiere in the next few years."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EDisney&#8217;s live-action adaptation of href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4671501\u002Fnorth-korea-brother-kim-jong-nam-un\u002F\"\u003Edeath of Kim Jong Nam\u003C\u002Fa\u003E in Malaysia on Feb. 13 eliminates another member of the Kim family, which has ruled North Korea with an iron fist for more than 70 years. Current Supreme Leader Kim Jong Un is suspected to have ordered the murder of his estranged older half-brother, who died en route to the hospital after two women held what police believe to be a poison-soaked rag over his face at Kuala Lumpur International Airport.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIt is unclear if there was a direct motive for the 45-year-old&#8217;s assassination, as he never expressed any desire to overthrow his younger sibling. However, Kim Jong Nam&#8217;s close ties to Beijing &mdash; Pyongyang&rsquo;s increasingly reluctant sponsor &mdash; may have vexed the young despot. Current Supreme Leader Kim Jong Un is suspected to have ordered the murder of his estranged older half-brother, who died en route to the hospital after two women held what police believe to be a poison-soaked rag over his face at Kuala Lumpur International Airport. It is unclear if there was a direct motive for the 45-year-old&#8217;s assassination, as he never expressed any desire to overthrow his younger sibling. However, Kim Jong Nam&#8217;s close ties to Beijing &mdash; Pyongyang&rsquo;s increasingly reluctant sponsor &mdash; may have vexed the young despot. In any case, his death sheds light on the dysfunctional and murderous dynasty whose tireless pursuit of nuclear weapons could threaten the whole world. &nbsp;"},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EA Dictionary Proves It's Totally With It By Adding 'Squad Goals,' 'Yas' and 'Drunk Text'"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4010748\u002Foxford-dictionary-update-2015\u002F\"\u003EOxford Dictionaries\u003C\u002Fa\u003E has added 300 \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4662821\u002Fmerriam-webster-dictionary-throw-shade-meaning\u002F\"\u003Enew words\u003C\u002Fa\u003E to its officially recognized collection, including \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4525422\u002Fquarter-life-crisis-find-passion\u002F\"\u003Emillennial\u003C\u002Fa\u003E favorites such as &#8220;yas,&#8221; &#8220;cat lady&#8221; and &#8220;squad goals.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe online reference guide often updates its language to reflect the vocabulary of the times, and this expansion was no exception. In a \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fblog.oxforddictionaries.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fdictionary-new-words\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eblog post\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, Oxford noted that many of the new words are popular terms in food, fitness and party culture, such as the Thai dish &#8220;\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fen.oxforddictionaries.com\u002Fdefinition\u002Fpad_kee_mao\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Epad kee mao\u003C\u002Fa\u003E,&#8221; &#8220;\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fen.oxforddictionaries.com\u002Fdefinition\u002Ffitspo\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Efitspo\u003C\u002Fa\u003E&#8221; and &#8220;\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fen.oxforddictionaries.com\u002Fdefinition\u002Fdrunk_text\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Edrunk text\u003C\u002Fa\u003E,&#8221; respectively.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHere&#8217;s a selection from the latest update, according to the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fblog.oxforddictionaries.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fdictionary-new-words\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EOxford blog post\u003C\u002Fa\u003E:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cblockquote\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003Ecat lady\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E noun: An older woman who lives alone with a large number of cats, to which she is thought to be obsessively devoted.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003Ecraptacular\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E adjective: Remarkably poor or disappointing.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003Edrink the haterade\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E phrase: Indulge in excessively negative, critical, or resentful behavior.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003Edrop bear\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E noun: A mythical marsupial resembling a koala, said to live in trees and attack people by dropping on to their heads from above.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003Edrunk text\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E noun: A text message sent while drunk, typically one that is embarrassing or foolish.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003Efemslash\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E noun: A genre of fiction, chiefly published online, in which female characters who appear together in film, television, or other popular media are portrayed as having a sexual relationship.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003Efitspo\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E noun: Short for fitspiration, a person or thing that serves as motivation for someone to sustain or improve health and fitness.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003Efreecycle\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E verb: Give away (something used or unwanted), as opposed to selling it or throwing it away, especially in an arrangement made via the Internet.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003Efrita\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E noun: (in Cuban cuisine) a sandwich consisting of a fried cake of seasoned pork and beef that is topped with very thinly cut chips and served in a roll.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003Eherd mentality\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E noun: The tendency for people&#8217;s behavior or beliefs to genders."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["yas"]}," exclamation: Expressing great pleasure or excitement."]}]}],"plain":"Oxford Dictionaries has added 300 new words to its officially recognized collection, including millennial favorites such as &#8220;yas,&#8221; &#8220;cat lady&#8221; and &#8220;squad goals.&#8221; The online reference guide often updates its language to reflect the vocabulary of the times, and this expansion was no exception. In a blog post, Oxford noted that many of the new words are popular terms in food, fitness and party culture, such as the Thai dish &#8220;pad kee mao,&#8221; &#8220;fitspo&#8221; and &#8220;drunk text,&#8221; respectively. Here&#8217;s a selection from the latest update, according to the Oxford blog post: cat lady noun: An older woman who lives alone with a large number of cats, to which she is thought to be obsessively devoted. craptacular adjective: Remarkably poor or disappointing. drink the haterade phrase: Indulge in excessively negative, critical, or resentful behavior. drop bear noun: A mythical marsupial resembling a koala, said to live in trees and attack people by dropping on to their heads from above. drunk text noun: A text message sent while drunk, typically one that is embarrassing or foolish. femslash noun: A genre of fiction, chiefly published online, in which female characters who appear together in film, television, or other popular media are portrayed as having a sexual relationship. fitspo noun: Short for fitspiration, a person or thing that serves as motivation for someone to sustain or improve health and fitness. freecycle verb: Give away (something used or unwanted), as opposed to selling it or throwing it away, especially in an arrangement made via the Internet. frita noun: (in Cuban cuisine) a sandwich consisting of a fried cake of seasoned pork and beef that is topped with very thinly cut chips and served in a roll. herd mentality noun: The tendency for people&#8217;s behavior or beliefs to conform to those of the group to which they belong. jelly adjective: Jealous meet-cute noun: (in a film or television program) an amusing or charming first encounter between two characters that leads to the development of a romantic relationship between them. otherize verb: View or treat (a person or group of people) as intrinsically different from and alien to oneself. otherkin adjective: Denoting or relating to people who identify as non-human. sausage party noun: An event or group in which the majority of participants are male. screencast noun: A video recording or transmission of the data displayed on the screen of a computer or mobile device, typically with accompanying audio. shoestring fries noun: French fries sliced extremely thinly. smishing noun: The fraudulent practice of sending text messages purporting to be from reputable companies in order to induce individuals to reveal personal information, such as passwords or credit card numbers. squad goals noun: Used in reference to a person or thing seen as a model to aspire to or emulate, especially with one&#8217;s friends (often as a hashtag in social media). third gender noun: A category of people who do not identify as male or female, but rather as neither, both, or a combination of male and female genders. yas exclamation: Expressing great pleasure or excitement."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EDon&#8217;t forget &#8220;cat lady&#8221; and
